Although thick and chewy, the light carbonation makes for a great session brew.

Black with a nice creamy tan head that leaves a nice stickiness on the glass. the smell and taste are of smoke, coffee, chocolate and malt. the smell has some other sweet qualities to it and the taste falls in the order listed above, with a finish that goes back to the coffee flavour for a nice dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 re-rate june 2012: Bottle sample at beerandbeyond farewell tasting at Dagans place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Dark brown, almost opaque, minimal off-white head. Smoke, wood and a little peat aroma, soft smokey bitterness. Bitter, alcoholic finish, medium body, soft carbonation. 
9/4/9/3/15=4
Bottle at a porter/stout blind tasting. Pours black (not opaque), airy tan head. Chocolate, coffee and grape aroma, bitter, roasty taste. Full body, delicate carbonation and a long finish. OK. 
7/4/7/3/11=3.2

Keg at The Dean Swift, Tower Bridge, London. Dark chestnut with white head. Quite sharp initially and surprisingly, this developed quite a bitter, malty flavour. There is a hint of smoke, just a tad, there is also liquorice and nuts. A good rounded beer, liked it.

Pours a very dark brown with a dense off white head.  The aroma is malty with faint notes of roast and smoke.  The flavor is malty, dark chocolate, coffee, bitter dark malts, and just a hint of smoke on the back end.  Medium body, soft mouthfeel.  Not bad but not great
Nice dark porter.  Great 2 inch head and the flavor is pretty awesome.  Coffee, chocolate, and almost a little raisin flavor.  I dont pick up much smoke, however, its still an enjoyable beer
pours dark with frothy brown head that laces the glass.  Good aroma of coffee, chocolate and smoke.  Taste of the smoke comes through well.

Bottle at home. Pours black with a dark red tint and a creamy beige head. A hoppy roasted malt aroma which is majors on the roast pineapple with some vanilla notes. This has a well-rounded mouthfeel filling the whole palate with fruity vanillary roasty malty goodness. There is a light smoked malt which comes into play at the end of these flavours with a supporting role, very much as designed from what I read. A lovely light toastiness with a hint of friutiness lingers on the palate without any dryness. This is a wonderfully well balanced beer, with every element in perfect harmony to produce a burst of flavour which caresses the tongue and lingers delightfully on the palate. Outstanding.

Pours black with a nice tan head. Sticky lacing. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and malt. Taste is coffee, caramel, chocolate, and a hint of smokiness. Nice bitterness balance. Smoke is nice in this one not like a campfire. Would definitely go well with barbeque.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/13/2008.  On tap in a stange at Stone Brewery.

Stone Smoked Porter has a dark coffee color and a very small head (wonder what the head looks like out of a bottle) with some delicate lacing. The head leaves a collar that remains over the course of the beer.
Chocolate, coffee, and cigars control the aroma. 3 distinct and abrupt smells, working well together.

Taste: A very strong porter; they definitely dont mess around at Stone Brewery. A smokey oak flavor up front, and it is easy to taste the alcohol. The middle and end are a bomb of malt and hops, with some vanilla and caramel flavorings. The end leaves with a slight smokey chocolate aftertaste residue.

Definitely a full body, but still fairly smooth. There is a definite bite to this porter, like it wants to fight your tongue.

The richness of the porter will definitely impede the speed of consumption, although the fact that it is a thick, chewy, tasty brew more than makes up for that fact.  I would definitely recommend this to anyone wanting a kick-ass and kick-your-ass porter.
Disappointed.  Somewhat flat (maybe it was just my bottle).  I prefer a more bitter beer.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2012 Pitch black color. Couldnt see light through it, just how I like it. Smoked flavor was present but not overwhelming. Accenting the smooth palate. Caramel chocolate smoothness with a masked alcohol content.

Pitch black with a tan head. Excellent retention and lacing in the glass. Tons of oaky notes on the nose with spicy undertones. The smoke is present, but some coffee and caramel persist as well. Mouth coating and one that I couldnt put down.

Pours rich, unctuous black, with thick, fluffy mocha head. Aroma is smoke, sour wood, toffee. Taste is sweet, malty, yet somewhat savoury with hints of treacle. Some is subtle and restrained, mostly evident in the finish. Body is thick and oozing, a real treat.

Pours  a rich dark brown, with a medium beige head.  Aroma of chocolate, dark malts, and a minimal amount of smoke.  Nice malt flavor up front, with a dry chocolate settling in the background.  Finishes dry with the smoke finally arriving.  Very nice, and very well done.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2012 Bottle sample at beerandbeyond farewell tasting at Dagans place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Pours clear black to brown with a nice beige head, aroma of smoked wood, chocolate, acidity, wood spiciness, flavor is smoked with charcoal notes, chocolate, malt sourness, medium bodied, good  8/4/7/3/13[3.5] 

At the Stout & Porter Blind Tasting Part A, pours black with a medium head, aroma of roasted malt, some coffee and lightr smoked notes, flavor is quite hoppy and bitter with some grapefruit, roasted malt, more of a BIPA, medium bodied  7/4/7/3/14[3.5]

Spectaculer coffee aroma accompanied by a nutty, bready presence. Very dark shade of red and brown with a thin foam top. Taste is bitter hop and coffee upfront with a pleasant bready/doughy taste on the finish. Other subtle flavors of chocolate, caramel, spices and an earthy/leafy taste. Overall, a fantastically brewed porter with lots of smooth coffee flavor but still giving off that signature hoppy bite that Stone Brewing is known for. Id give this an A rating.

650ml bottle. Deep dark clear brown with medium to small off-white fading but lacing head. Smokey, roasty, dark malt not towering aroma with a beacon note. Suprisingly "cold" and watery beginning, immediately displaced by a rather grainy, bread-like, sweet prosecution, a somewhat sweet Zwickel-Keller-like middle part, not as dark in taste as the colour suggests. Touches coffee at 3/4, leading to a grainy, sweet, only rudimentary dry finish. Well-understood, really not bad, but not a typical Porter: Somewhere between a pushed to the limits Franconain Zwickel, a Rauchbier like Aecht Schlenkerla Märzen combined with the sweet and earthy carrot-like remnant of an Black IPA. 
-------- may be another example of "changing/developing character" via "increasing temperature". I can smell coffee now not detected before. Somewhat complex without being complicated. An indecisive brew.
pours dark brown with a tan head. Flavor is smoky and taosted chocolate. has a touch of malt and finishes cery smokey.

660ml bottle from Whole Foods SoMa, San Francisco, CA

Pours dark brown with a reddish haze and a foamy light brown head. Aroma has notes of burnt leather, smoke, ash and roasted malts. Taste is quite roasty with a lot of chocolate and coffee notes and hints of smoke and ash. Finish is smooth and slightly bitter with roasty notes. Well balanced porter with a nice smoked touch.

A decent porter. Very smoked. Pours black with a light tan head. Taste is very deep, with herbs and coffee. Had in the bottle.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown with medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt and smoke notes. Light sweet taste with a peat finish.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma of freshly mowed hay, I was surprised by this, light roasted malts and black licorice.  Taste is a nice balance of smoke and roasted malts.  Medium to lighter body and medium carbonation, more than that of the  Firestone Reserve Porter I had a couple of days ago.

Deep ruby with a small off white head. Aroma: chocolate. Nutty, smoke but nothing overpowering, earthy, coffee,  deep caramel , malty. Roasted , dried fruits notes,  taste: la bit watery, roasted, some smoke, chocolate ,coffee, earthy, herbal, caramel, dry and some bitterness

Bottle. Pours a blackish color with an off whit head. Aroma is of roasted malt, smoke in the way of campfire burnt wood, subtle smoked meat notes, dark fruits, cocoa nibs, coffee and dark caramel. The flavor follows the nose, the smoke is again campfire notes, burnt wood, ash and burnt notes, and a faint trace of meaty flavors, along with cocoa nibs, coffee, dark caramel and some coffee notes. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall a pretty good smoked Porter!

Dark brown, opaque pour with a thick head that thins but lasts with some lacing. Sweet nose with some smokiness.  Smooth entry with a mild maltiness, and a thick, almost syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet ending with significant roasted malt smokiness and cocoa.

Chocolate, roasty notes in the nose and mouth.

great beer. what I want in my porters.
Pitch black, small head. Nice coffee and chocolate aroma. Taste chocolate, smoked malts, and sweet aftertaste.
Poured at Euston Tap, London. Dark beer with a beige head. Dried fruits and lic.orice aroma. Dark chocolate, smokey, licorice flavour

Bomber.  This one was a few months out of date which I think impacted the pour (Huge foam head), but didnt seem to due too much to the taste.  Brown, clear.  Roasted coffee aroma with peat.  Taste releases more smoke. Finish is somewhat long.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with medium disappearing head with nice lacing. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate and some peat smoke. Flavor of sweet malt, dark chocolate, caramel, coffee with moderate carbonation and a slight bitterness that leaves a dryness on the mouth. Really, really nice porter. Does Stone even know how to make a bad beer?

Bomber from Binnys on Clybourn. For my 250th rating, I go back to my favorite brewery with a nod to one of my favorite styles - plus I cannot believe I have not rated this particular brew before ...  Pours dark brown with reddish highlights. Off white foamy head that sticks around as the glass goes down. Nice lacing. Aroma has smoky meat with some hints of chocolate and of maltiness.  Licorice later. Taste brings dark chocolate, some caramel, some coffee. Not much smoke in the flavor. Mouthfeel a touch thin.  Really nice flavor mix. Finishes with some length, mostly sweet but with some bitterness and perhaps residual smoke. Always enjoyable to have a Stone creation!
Dark brown beer, a good big head. Roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. More dryness, biterness and roastiness then expected. Dry mouthfeel, not bad.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Bottled from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Very dark brown colored, thick lasting brown head. Very smoky nose, tar, liquorice, coffee, malts, nice. Initially somewhat sweet flavor, malty, then the liquorice and especially hops take over, resulting in a lasting bitter finish. Relatively thin mouthfeel. Technically a good brew, lots of complexity and still easy to drink. Still, imho the strong bitterness (especially in finish)  from the hops disrupts the balance. I prefer bitterness to be an ELEMENT of the flavor, instead of THE character ;-).

22oz bottle for Christmas 2011.  The porter poured a deep dark brown with a frothy brown head.  The head laced down the glass and the aroma of coffee was subtle.  This version does not over power you with smoke.  The porter is thinner than expected.  There are flavors of roasted malt throughout and at the finish.  The carbonation was active at the pouring but average at the finish.

650ml bottle. Pours opaque black with a very generous cream head. The nose has sultanas and just a hint of smoke. The taste is initially of chocolate and smoke, then liquorice. The palate is medium bodied with a creamy but tight texture and a long dry finish. Overall, I reckon this is a dry stout and its a good one.

22oz bottle from Binnys Lincoln Park. Pours a deep brown color with a creamy, light tan head with some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, smokey, chocolate. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Flavor is sweet, smokey, a little caramel, With a smooth, smokey finish. Not on the same level as Alaskan Smoked Porter, but pretty tasty on its own.
Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a large, beige head.  Aroma and flavor of roasted malts, coffee and some very light smoke.  Slightly chalky finish.  The smokiness is very light, but not a bad porter.

Poured from a 22-oz. bottle into a pint glass. Color was very dark, but more brown than black. Reddish looks in there, too. A bit more than an inch of head, that lasted for awhile. Nice coat of bubbly lacing on the top. Frosty tan film on the sides of the glass. 

First smell was an almost even whiff of chocolate and coffee. On the second whiff, coffee seemed to be the overwhelming note. Caramel and toffee contributed to the nose.

Initial taste was dark chocolate, which seemed to be the middle marker of coffee and chocolate. Also some smoky, roasty malts. Nice and smooth. 

Medium-to-full body. Slick texture. Soft-to-average carbonation. Long, smooth finish. Smokiness ruled the day here.

A decent beer overall, but I have to say the taste and feel let me down a bit.

Pours dark brown with a fluffy beige head. Aroma is slightly smokey, grassy, doesnt smell like a porter. Smells more like a saison. Flavor is trademark stone bitterness, peety malts, bitter chocolate. Its got a really busy hop character. Thin-body in the pour; full bodied mouthfeel. May need to give this one another go at some point.

Draft.  Pours black with thick off white head.  Aroma of peat and chocolate.  Taste has light smokiness and chocolate.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is great with BBQ.  Good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark brown color in the glass, it has a smokey aroma. Taste is very smooth with a cocoa taste up front and a smokiness that hits you on the finish. Good beer.

Poured like root beer.  Had an slightly smoky  aroma,  slight but present  .  Had a very weak light taste, a taste almost as thin as the beer.  I would have expected more flavor  from the label but  it just was not there.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 The aroma is hops, malts and hint of smoke.  The flavor is smoke up front with an edge of hops that is balanced by the malts, chocolate being the dominate element of the malts along with a mild nuttiness.  A complex porter, hoppier than most but makes it stands out.
Aroma of campfire, pine, and coffee.  Pours black with an enormous foamy head.  It sticks around too.  Tastes nice and roasty.  Chocolate, coffee, and more roasty malts.  Delicious porter.

Bomber 3 months past its best by date- to glass a burnt brown with red hues somewhat transparent,but dark.Creamy  good tan frothy head.good lacing.
 Aroma is hoppy, nutty ,sweet chocolate,toffee,somewhat kinda toasty bready,maybe a robust german? like malt.Nice hop aroma though grassy/herbal floral.As it warms the smoked malt and hops seem to come out a bit more.
 Up front chocolate toasted malt carmel semisweet backed by a nice bittering.Mild tartness maybe  slightlycitrus but the hopping showcases niclely, theres a good  chocolate creamyness but toasted dryness as well.Subtle sweet smokiness.Vanilla tones-maybe the carmelly butterness.Slight yeastyness but comes off as bready like. Nice aftertaste- very nice finish. One of my favorate porters right here.Not a big porter fan either.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2013 Note: new rating, by accident... but its a good thing, I liked it better now.
9/IV/13 - 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle from a Boston supermarkt @ home - BB: XI/24/2011 (just noticed the tiny etching, a bit too late) (2013-xxx) 
Note: this is the last of 18 beer bottles that we brought home from our honeymoon! Thanks a million to my lovely wife for putting up with all my crazy beer shit! :-) Clear dark brown beer, huge beige irregular head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: caramel, floral hops, roses, some ocha and chocolate, sugary sweetness. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: pretty bitter and hoppy start, caramel, mocha, bit sweet, dark chocolate, bit smoky. Aftertaste: caramel, smoky, little sweet, bitter hops, mocha and coffee, more smokiness.

Original rating:
13/12/2011 1Pt. 6Fl. Oz. bottle @ Klaas place - BB: n/a (2011-711) Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle!
Very dark brown beer, beige irregular head, unstable, little adhesive. Aroma: very yeasty, dairy, cheese (when cold). On warming up: caramel, mocha, bit dusty, pepper. MF: soft carbon, medium body. Taste: bit sour start, mocha, slightly smoky, red fruits. Aftertaste: some dairy, coffee, dry hop bitterness.
Ar: 6, Ap: 4, T: 7, P: 4, O: 15

22oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a red tint. Thin beige head with minimal lacing. Aroma is smoke and roasted malts with hints of coffee and dark fruit. Taste is heavy smoke and ash. Flavor smoothly transitions to a coffee and woody hops slightly bitter aftertaste. Medium body and carbonation helps make this a very balanced beer. One of my favorite porters.

The most obvious element of this beer is its smoky flavor and aroma, which is right up front and in your face. If your palate can handle the extreme smokiness, then youre in for a treat. This is the beer exemplifies its style. Delicious.

Bottle:
Beige light brown head on top of an almost black beer, some brown tints.
Smell roasted malts, sweat, coffee, coal, smoke.
Taste oatmeal, coffee, karnemelk, medium bitter, roasted malts, some smoke, roasted herbs, coal, even some sweets. Nicely balanced.
Nice coffee roast medium bitter aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, medium to fuller body and a more watery than creamy texture.
Pretty soft and smooth.
Nice!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Smells and tastes of caramel, coffee, roasty, herbs, smoke, vanilla, woody, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, average carbonation. Not over powered by smoke taste a nice taste worth checking out but not many times a year.

Pours a nice, dark brownish-black with little head. Aroma of smoke and malt. Flavor is a nice blend of coffee and chocolate/licorice flavors with the smoke complementing the mixture. Unlike some smoked beers Ive tried, the smoke here is really understated and doesnt overpower the whole, which is, I think, a good thing.

25 cl. draft @Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas: A: black with a slightly tanned 2 finger head S: grapefruit hops (almost every Stone beer appears to have these hops) & roasted malts, ashes & some spices T: wow, this is scorched & not roasted, talk about overkill, lots of ashes, coal, burned malts & scorched coffee, very bitter pure pine resin, touch of bitter grapefruit B: cork dry and the burned malts, coffee & ashes simply coat your mouth, the taste of a scorched land, not bad honestly but almost off-putting by the end of the glass considering how much they went overboard & I expected this to be moderate, the vanilla version if definitely the superior one  - Greg Koch remark that unlike a rauchbierthe "smoke" in Stone Smoked Porter is an ELEMENT of the character rather than being THE character is questionable since yes the smoke is the character of a rauchbier but those are perfectly balanced, moderate & delicious, this is harsh and punnishing & scorched & not smoked

Bottle: pours a wonderful black-brown color with a tan head.  Aromas of coffee and chocolate swirl with the smoke.  It tastes like a beautiful blend of bitter chocolate and coffee mixed with just enough smoke to keep your mind working.  Wonderful, wonderful beer!

6oz bottle. Pours a beautiful almost point black with a medium tanned head. Nose : American hops ! Bitter citrus zest with a strong dutch skunk aroma. Coffee. Sip : Creamy body with a small carbonation. Sweet coffee wonderfully surrounded by bitter citrus and floral notes followed by coffee bitterness on the aftertaste. Wow. I really enjoy american hops.

Great proter character. The aroma is deep full of slight hops with a tinge of smoky malt and dark fruit.  The beer is dark almost stout colored with minimal head. The flavor is slighlty sweet with a middle and end bitterness. The finish is dry and snappy. A great porter.

Pours deep red. Can actually see some light through this one. Nose is actually pretty big in the citrus and fruity hops along with complex chocolate, roast and malts and light smoke. The flavor really lets the smoke shine. Its more intense than I remember in the past. Interesting beer for being smoked. Medium full body. smooth and carbonation is fairly prominent.
Rich porter flavor with chocolate and coffee flavors. Slight smoke flavor. Excellent dark color.

This is a very nice and well rounded brew and the subtle smokiness is a welcome addition.  For the price ($4.50 for a 22oz.) this is certainly something that will go in the rotation when wanting to fulfill a cost effective smooth sipping porter.  Pours a dark barely translucent brown with tan head.  Minimal lacing.  The  nose is  some roasted caramel malts with known chocolate and coffee. Taste is smooth roasted malts, caramel, light cocoa, some mild coffee and a very faint but noticeable smokey character.  This comes out more as it warms.

Draft at The Lackman on September 23, 2011 (Midpoint Music Festival weekend).  Nice sweet malty nose, opaque brown hue, tan head, robust malty flavor with ample smokiness.  Stone puts out a lot of quality brews, and this very fine beer is no exception.

Keg at CP&K. It pours jet black, with a thin beige head. The nose is roasted malt, smoke, liquorice and salted caramel. The taste is roasted malt, smoke, dark chocolate, dark cherry, salted liquorice and caramel, meat and treacle, with a dry-roasty finish and some lingering smoke. Medium body and fine carbonation. Tasty and very easy to drink.
just another fantastic product from stone. roasty chocolate and coffees that youd expect from a porter with the smoke as a nice complement.

Pours dark black with some cola brown rays coming through at the edges, head was nice and khaki brown, laced well and settled to a nice fine carbonation, out of 22 oz bottle.  Aroma brought notes of chocolate, toffee, coffee, roasted espresso and biscuit with a nice smoky component.  Taste is some bitter coffee and chocolate up front, hints of sweet caramel, biscuit, toffee notes in there with a smoky middle, finishing fairly roasty, nice smoke component that lingers well. Carbed well to push through the palate, low to medium bodied but full flavored for only 6%.  Nicely done.

Bottle. Pours dark brown / nearly black. A head pops up and then quickly vaporizes. Has a smoky flavor but not overpowering. In fact, the smokey flavor trails after each sip leaving a taste in your mouth. Absolutely fantastic. I would drink this all day.

An interestingly complex porter with heavy roasted malt flavors and aromas, good hop presence, smoke up front and a bit of dark fruit (plums and possibly dates) lurking in the background. Deep, dark ruby to mahogony color with an off-white and moderate head. Quite unique and quite enjoyable.

22 oz from Chucks. Certainly not as intense as the Alaskan, but if the copy is to be believed its supposed to be that way. Smells like cookies. Tastes smooth and delicious. Pretty hoppy for a porter.

Dark brown colour, small beige head.
Surprisingly light aroma, smoke, malts, toasted malts and coffee. Slight sour malts. Rather sweet flavour, cocoa, liquorice, coffee. Some burned malts bitterness. Body medium thin. Finish like liquorice, somewhat sweet.
(From 0,65L bottle -22oz- @ DRBM, courtesy of joes)

Bottle @ DRBM. A black colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of coffee, dark fruits some port with a little smoke. The taste of coffe, dark fruits dry, bitter. The aftertaste of bitter coffee and dry.

22 oz bottle. Dark brown pour with a thick, light tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted coffee and very faint smoke. Flavor is rich, roasty malt, some bitter coffee and a bit of acidic smoke. Medium to full body with average carbonation and a long, dry finish. This is a nice porter, the smoked character is very light but its there.

Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is roasted malt with hints of chocolate, coffee, caramel, toffee, and smokey notes. Medium body with medium carbonation. Very good brew.

650mL bomber bottle poured deep black in color with a modest brown head and some fine lacing.  Aromas of dark roasted malts and smoke with a hint of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is roasted malty sweetness with a hint of smoke and coffee bitterness.  This is a solid beer from start to finish.  HIghly recommended.
Port, madera tones and raisin sweetness. Some spices, too. Very little smoke. Black body and small green head. Thin. Too thin, maybe. (DRbM 2011)

Bottle @ drbm. Aroma is smoky baltic roast, chocolate and earth.
Flavour is roasty, earthy, slight smoke. Nice.
Bottle at UDRBM. Black pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is coffee, ash, tobacco, burnt malts. Flavor is dry, black, and quite bitter burnt malts. No smoke?

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2012 Aroma includes roasted coffee, and dark chocolate. Black in color, with nice frothy head. On the palate, you can pick up a dominant coffee, and chocolate flavor, yet it had a nice creamy finish. One of my favorites.
Solid from start to finish.  solid porter with a lite smoked effect.  Small disippating head

At the stone brewery on tap. Pours blank with long lasting tan head. Aroma of smoke with burnt coffee and chocolate. A subtle bitterness throughout   No smoke flavor with hints of coffee. High carbonation.
Reddish brown of color with a beige head. An aroma of smoke, liqurice, roasted and weak prunes. A flavor of smoke, roasted, bitter, coal and weak sweets.

Dezent rauchiger Antrunk, der, wie das Röstaroma, zum Mittelteil noch einmal deutlich steigt. Die Rauchigkeit geht dann in den Röstnoten im Verbund mit der Süße unter. Hier auch etwas hopfig, deutlicher als die Rauchigkeit. Nett aber bitte mehr Rauchigkeit. 13/10/10/10//10
Gedronken bij Moeder Lambic in Brussel, pik zwarte kleur, een wit/bruine kraag, koffiegeur, chocolade. Smaakte wel zoet, lichte koffie en chocolade smaak.
Draught @ Moeder Lambic during the Stone vs Moeder Lambic event. Pitch black, opague with an off-white head. Smells smokey, coffee and chocolate. Tastes sweet, coffee. Full body, great carbo.

A mighty fine smoked porter! This brew poured up a dark ruby-brown colored body with a nice, foamy mocha-colored head with good retention and amazing lacing effects on the glass.  Aromas of heavy cream, coffee, sugars, chocolate and sweet malt.  Flavors of the same but light hints of smoke and roasted malts mix in at the finish. Medium- to Full-bodied, thick and creamy; definitely not a brew for those that dont like big thick brews; somewhat chewy and thats the way I like them!
light smoked aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, nice smoked dry finish.
65cl, American brew, from The Bottle Shop Canterbury, complex smoked Porter, malty/roasted and slightly fruity/bitter, easy to drink, very balanced, clear, good head, good brew, yet expensive

Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Dark brown coloured. Has a light brown head, mostly diminishing. Aroma is roasted, faint burnt, dark chocolate, mild coffee. Faint smoke and soy sauce. Flavor starts moderate sweet and finish moderate bitter, long duration. Creamy and soft.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Nice, smoky aroma of roasted malts with some sweet chocolate and subtle hops. This beer pours a thin black that lets some light through. The palate is sufficiently carbonated, if a bit thin, and the flavor is mostly bitter from all the smoke/roast and, less noticeably, from the hops. I was really expecting more character out of this, but the taste notes die out rather quickly, with only the smokiness lingering for a while. Very nice, but not game-changing.
Keg at brewdog. A fantastic porter. Black, thick and roasty tasting. The smoked element is there but not a contolling stake. It folds in to the thick richness wonderfully. Tremendous.

Draught at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas during the three day Stone Event, 16-18 september 2011. Pitch black, opaque color with a nice off-white head. Smell malts, smoke, coffee and chocolate. Taste some bitter, chocolate, coffee and caramel. Nice carbonation, medium body.
Pours black with tan head. Decent wack of smoke on the aroma. Good bit of smoke on the taste but not huge, goes well with the roast malt profile. Nice

Bottle, beer tasting at Beer Temple. Deep dark brown to black colour, light beige head. Aroma of salty smoke, beechwood, light peat, roasted malts, coffee. Flavour is thin, light smoke, meat, roasted malts, cofee, roasted bitter finish. Light bodied, thin.

Beer tasting at beer temple Amsterdam
Thin off white head.  Deep dark clear pour. Smoked taste is subtle. Very nice
Tasting at Beer Temple.  Black pour with small tan head.  Aroma is light with a slight milkiness.  Flavour has milk, roasted malts and grapefruit.  Smoke comes through in the finish.
Poured into a pint glass from a bomber.  Rich brown with tan head.  Coffee/caramel aroma.  Very smooth...has a brown ale feel to it.
Tap @ Stronghill. Very dark with thin tan head. Smoky aroma. Not too heavy. Nice dry finish.

22 oz from malt & vine in redmond, wa. pours a dark, rich black color with a creamy beige head that formed. immediate smell of coffee aroma and smoked flavors were preminent. very smooth first sip, taste of coffee, light caramel flavors. smokey sensation in the taste isnt as strong as the smell. overall delicious and would replace this with a coffee any day of the week

22oz bottle.  Pours a pitch black with beige head.  Roasted malt and coffee come through in the aroma.  Slight smoky overtones accent the coffee-like flavor.  Medium-to-full bodied with a creamy, smooth finish.  One of my favorite examples of one of my favorite styles.  Excellent.

Draught at BoHo.
Dark brown with a light brown head, nice lacings. Aroma moderate malty, roasted, heavy smoky. Flavor moderate sweet, moderate+ smoky. Medium body.

From a Stone bomber into a pint glass.  No bottled on date that I can see.  Pours a medium brown thats translucent just a bit.  Exactly as a porter should be.  About an inch or two of head that dissipates into a thin foam leaving just a touch of lacing.  Mild aroma of smoke and coffee.  Mouthfeel is moderate, again, just perfect for a porter.  But its got a bit too much carbonation even after sitting.  Taste is very in your face smoke and dark malt.  Kind of chalky and bitter.  Other flavors are licorice, coffee (burnt) and mild cherries/plumbs.  Overall a very good porter.  Odd thing is, the more I drank, the less I liked it.  Usually, its the opposite for a beer.  Worth a try for sure, but I may not buy it again.
UPDATED: APR 7, 2017 At Red Lion.  Smooth nice porter.  All the flavor blend well with none being too overwhelming.  Smoky but does not smell like a campfire. Serving: Bottle

Bottle poured into English pint.  Deep mahogany brown w/ some nice ruby red peeks when held to light.  Big, 3-finger head thats fluffy and slightly tan in color.  Nice aroma with notes of coffee, leather, sugar cookies, earthy hops, and a touch of smoke. Soft and somewhat thin going down.  Taste starts out with a bitter blandness before a wave of smoky roastiness closes it out on the lingering finish.  Most porters dont do much for me.  Like the smoke, thats great, but little else going on.  Great look and aroma though.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 Poured with an average, frothy, lasting tan head, which provided nice lacing throughout. Subtle smoke aroma, slightly sweet, but mostly smelled of roast malts. Medium bodied with a thick texture, average carbonation and bitter finish. Lightly smokey character, but not ?bacon in a bottle? as are some other smoked beers. Well balanced beer, could have used a little more smoke and a little less roast character.
From the bottle multiple times. Near black with tan head. Flavor of dark malts and smoke. Medium thickness. Perfect for steaks.
UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 Almost as close to perfection as it gets for me.  Love smoke, love porters.  This is wonderful
Pours not quite black with a brown head. Aroma is peat, meat, roasted malts and liquorice. Taste is light hops, smoke, liquorice and roasted malts. thin mouthfeel. Expected a bit more.

On keg at The BrewDog Bar. Pours a black colour with a lacy tan head. Nice chocolately aroma, light smoked quality with dark malt notes. Flavours of chocolate, dark malts and yeast. A foamy mouth-feel with moderate carbonation and CO2 prickle. OK. Quite subtle for a smoked porter.

Aroma had distinct coffee and roasty character. Appearance brown with touch of red.  Taste was slightly bitter.  Medium body and had average carbonation.  To me the beer was average at best but then again I have high expectations for Stone being from San Diego.

De toutes les stone que jai engouffré, cest de loins la moins spectaculaire. Cest tout de même une bière bien bâti qui se bois ridiculement bien. Pas tant darôme sinon le malt rôti, le café. En bouche cest mince avec une légère finale fumée et presquaucune amertume. Rien dextraordinaire pour Stone...sinon une très bonne Porter au bas du spectre de la robustesse.

Draught pours deep brown with light tan head.  The aroma is smoke and roast coffee.  Taste is vanilla, coffee, and some smokiness that reminds me of pit barbeque.  Body is medium, with a thin but creamy mouthfeel.  Overall, this is a solid performer.

Pours a nice dark ruby, with a thick, light tan head that stays.  Aroma of malt, floral hops, very gentle smoke.  Taste is bitter over sweet, drawing out the malt.  Getting dark chocolate, bit of coffee.  Gentle bitter finish.  Nice porter, for sure.

Keg at BrewDog Edinburgh. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, smoke and a hint of bacon in a black beer with a smallish white head. Tastes very nice, very balanced with coffee, smoke with enough coffee and hoppy bitterness to balance it out. Average mouthfeel. I respect it hugely, but cant love it, for some reason. Doesnt stop it being incredibly good, though.

pours a very deep red/brown with a good foamy chocolate tindged head. initial smells are of coffee and malt with a little chocolate.  taste is pretty complex with lots of coffee, liqurice an unexpected hop burst as well.  Plenty of bitterness in the mouth and all the smoke hits in the finish.
a very good porter.  what else would you expect from Stone?

A black beer with a medium tan head that leaves decent lacing.  The aroma is roasted malts and coffee, nice.  The flavor has an edge of smokiness, a lot of roasted quality, and a touch of bitterness.  Medium body, good flavor, nice aroma, all around pretty good.
Pours black from tap with an inch of brown head. Slight smoked notes on the nose. I get a bit of coffee on the tongue but its a bit faint. Finishes dry which i like. Not my favorite Stone.

Black with a tan head. Aroma is very slight smoke with the robust coffee/chocolate smell one would expect from a standard porter. Flavor is some roasted coffee with a strong hop presence (especially compared to a standard porter). Smoke is present in the aftertaste, especially as it warms a bit. Pleasant but not the overwhelming characteristic that it is in some smoked beers (which can be a positive or negative depending on what youre looking for). Overall, excellent porter with a light touch of smoke, great with grilled or smoked meat.

22oz bottle. nearly pitch black red color, tan head, good lacing. Very complex, malty aroma. Roasty, definitely smoky. Mildly bitter, but not in a painful way. Crisp carbonation, great long aftertaste. Does not dissappoint.

Appearance is dark brown with reddish edges and a 1 finger tannish head with o.k. retention.  Aroma is very mild with notes of smoke, toasted nuts, bittersweet chocolate, and coffee. Taste is rich bitter coffee with a lasting smoky and bitter finish, also, a hint of salt as a result of the smoked malt.  Body is medium with high carbonation and a long bitter finish.  Overall, this is rather ho-hum for Stone
They do a good job with this Porter, but it really needs to be heavier and stronger.
650ml bottle.  Pours black with a large head.  Aroma is old leather, smoked Bacon and salty liquorice.  Taste has leather to start.  Smokey bacon finish.  A bit watery.

Date: July 7, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Apple Valley Liquor, Apple Valley, MN Appearance: Dark brown with large amount of head Aroma: Coffee/Chocolate/slight smoke Flavor: Heavy on the coffee, light chocolate and a slight bitter and smoky finish Other: A solid offering from Stone, but I prefer the Bells Porter to this one.

Pours opaque black. Nose is beef jerky and smoke. Flavor is some roasted malt, coffee, and tons of smoked meat, bacon, and jerky. The mouthfeel was rather thin and the flavor lacked much complexity. Smoked meat and jerky really dominate everything. Not bad, but also not exciting, and hard to finish a whole bomber.
It poured a black color with a small tan head. The aroma was a slight hint of smokiness. The taste was consistent with coffee followed by a slight smokiness. This was a good beer.

Pours an opaque black with a large creamy light beige head. Aroma is definitely smokey and full of roasted grains, with a little chocolate and coffee. Taste has the smoke present in it as well but not overpowering, along with a mild sweetness and a nice dry bitterness. Full body, smooth on the palate, and soft carbonation.
dark brown color with tanish head. Chocolatey coffee aroma, taste was smokey coffee and sweet chocolate. Very smooth.

Pours black/brown highlights with a large light tan head.
Nose shows piney, grapefruit hops, sweet cocoa and roasted malt.
Flavours are similar but with the addition of some delightful smoky flavours.
Nice creamy carbonation.
Great stuff, very moreish.

Bomber pours dark brown/black with ruby highlights and a large khaki head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, peat, molasses, with a very balanced smokiness. Taste similar to aroma, smoke is proportioned nicely with the other flavors and is not overbearing, finishes bitter. Nice!

A dark brown pour with a tan head.  The aroma is mildly sweet, but with a pleasant smokiness.  The medium body has a creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste begins semi-sweet, then finishes bitter and dry with an earthy smoke taste.

Pours a nice dark brown with a light white head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, light smokiness. Taste is very much roasted malts, coffee and smoke in the finish. Very nice carbonation. Very smooth and flavorful.

I love Islay scotches, so I had to try this one.  Smokey on the nose, but I didnt taste it.  I wanted this to be a bit smokier than it was.  I liked this, but it wasnt as memorable as I thought it was going to be.

650ml bottle. Pours a deep, dark mahogany with light tan head (and lots of it) that recedes slowly, coating the glass walls. The nose is full of smoke thats balanced nicely against a big roasted coffee note. I also get a nice citrusy hop note bouncing around the edges. Fairly robust on the palate with heavy smoke that doesnt dominate the deep coffee notes completely. Finishes with a little burst of hoppy bitterness.

22oz bottle 5/29/11 (Binnys Downers Grove)-Pours black with a big tan head. Aroma of smoke and malt. Taste of smoke, malt, bitter, coffee, chocolate, and slight caramel. This light to medium bodied brew is a little light for a porter but still well balanced and quite tasty.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2012 650 ml bottle @ Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Rated @ 23.5.2011.
Pours a pitch black colour with a small, white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, grassy hops, syrup and some smoke. Flavour of roasted malts, smoke, mild tar, and some grassy hops. Medium bodied with a pleasant smooth mouthfeel. Fruity, nutty finish. Very good. 8-3-8-4-15 3.8
650 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a creamyish white head. Aroma of roasted malts, baking yeast and white bread. Flavour of roasted malts, subtle smoke, baking yeast, grass and some tar. Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel and a roasty, smoked wood and bread. Not as good as before, maybe this isnt as fresh as it should.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Has a bit of a campfire smell to it and some yeast. Has a smoky taste with some tobacco in the finish. Not bad

Pour is a black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is a nice chocolate with a rich coffee.  Flavor is again a nice chocolate malt with some coffee and a nice hop follow up.  I get no real bacon bomb smoke out of this but Im sure the malts were roasted over a peat fire. I just did not pick up much.  Still thisis a nice porter on its own.  Plenty of roasted malts with a nice hoppy backbone

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2011 Bottle. Poured a dark muddy black with dark ruby red highlights beaming around the edges of the glass. It had an average sized (1-2 finger) light brown creamy head that lasted a nice while, leaving a layer of foam floating on top of the brew which resulted some excellent lacing.

The aroma was was bold to say the least. It had a strong scent of roasted caramel malts, a leathery yeast with a subtle smokey odor and had notes of  dark roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and a touch of raisons.

It tasted wonderfully lightly bitter-sweet with nice notes of dark chocolate, caramel and dried fruit in the beginning then became a tad more on the bitter coffee side and had a mild smokey finish that was left lingering on the palate for a really nice long time.

Mouthfeel was medium to full in body (I am leaning more towards full) and smooth and creamy in texture with a nice light soft carbonation.

Overall this was an awesome brew. I am always a little leary about smoked beers but the flavors in this one melded so well together that it left me wanting more.

Bottle. Poured a pitch black color with a smaller tan head. Aroma was faint burnt malts, coffee, and roasted malts. Flavor was some milk chocolate, roasted malts, toffee, and caramel. Aftertaste was a little woody, with some roasted flavors. Kind of a dry finish. Longer on the palate. A decent beer.

Tasted in March [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Edinburgh.
A dark brown beer with smokey scent so strong it puts one in mind of a German Rauchbier rather than a Porter, Also hints of vanilla and coffee. The taste is more akin to a porter, though the smoke is pervasive through to the long finish of burnt malt and chocolate. The smoke certainly doesnt overpower in the taste and adds an enjoyable element to what is already an excellent beer style.

You gotta be careful with smoked malts-- its very easy to overload them into a brew and end up with beer that tastes like its being served in an ashtray.  Stone Smoked Porter eases back the throttle on the burnt roastiness, presenting a good porter that just so happens to also give off a bongwater finish.  Look, Im trying to be objective, but smoked beers have yet to rub my rhubarb the right way.  Stones Smoked Porter serves as the best example of the style Ive come across, but I still dont like it very much.  The smokiness only grows as the beer warms, and eventually the beer turns my burps into charcoal briquettes.  (2008)
Well balanced, slightly sweet porter with very subtle smoke flavor.  Great beer.

Bottle. Pours brown/black, thick pale tan head, fantastic lacing. Nose is smoke, bacon, roasted barley, a little watery-smelling. Flavours of smoke, cocoa, coffee, tar, lots of roast, very chewy, extremely smooth. LIke this a ton!

On tap at Sallys Restaurant.  Pours nearly black with a fair amount of tan head.  Aroma is smoked malts and some chocolate.  Taste is some chocolate, smokiness some roasted nuttiness.  This is a pretty dry beer for the style.

5oz draught.  Pours a dark brown/black.  Aroma of smoke, chocolate, coffee, peat.  Flavor is coffee, peat, chocolate, smoke.  Good, easy drinking porter.  Not overly powerful on any level.  Just balanced.
Smoky, hoppy aroma. Inch-thick brownish white head. Solid black in appearance (as it should). Very rich taste, overwhelms the taste buds. Smoked is correct. Smooth finish.

dark brown pour with a thick tan head.
aroma is strong roast malt, chocolate and wood smoke.
flavour is peaty smokey that blends well with a nice roast malt body. Some coffee and hint of bitter chocolate.
Bit thin in the palate. Still enjoyable though.
Medium brown with very foamy, tal head. Smells smokey, dryly of alcohol, and of spices, maybe allspice. Starts sweet and fades to a more bitter, spice flavor. Medium bodied.

On draught. Pours an extremely dark (almost black) brown with a thin tan head. Aromas of smoke, chocolate and vanilla. I was afraid the smoke flavor would overpower the beer (that is the case with many of the smoked bears I have had), but it didnt. The smoke blended in very well with the rest of the flavor profile. Not sure if Ill have this one again, but it was better than I thought it would be.
Overall, I liked the beer. I have not had a smoked beer before and I could smell it, like hickory.  Nice taste that was not too sweet and had a nice lingering bitter flavor.

22 oz bottle. Pours  is darkest of browns with a light tan head. Nose is smoky, chocolate, vanilla, earthy coffee grounds. Full, smoky body, that finishes with a fairly bitter hop bite. Full taste that matches the nose. Delicious! Two thumbs up! Not bad with some brie cheese.

Bottle. Brown black pour with a kahki tight soapy head that fades to a sudsey film. Aroma is mellow peat smoke and roasted malt. Taste is smooth smokey with some coco and day old coffee and little bitter in the end. Palate is medium and light carbonation with a creamy chaulky dry finish. Not the best smoked porter I have had, but for the price you really cant go wrong. I used half a cup in my roast and that turned out pretty nice!
Bottle. Dark brown ruby pour with a thin white head. Smoke and coffee on the nose. Very smooth. Smoke, chocolate, and coffee flavor. Very good.
Pours a quite black color with a frothy head. It is unbelievably smooth for a porter. It had a very pleasant hint of smokiness along with the other roast characters.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 Pours a sandy head - though dissolving, persists in roiling up for a minute - resulting in a fine layer over a very dark, cloudy, red-oil colored body with a spectacular forest of columns of a continuing event of effervescence under a lacing that leaves a line at the level of the body of the beer before the last quaff.
Smokey-fish-stew-in-metal-pot aroma with definite coffee notes.  Very mild.
Smoked-salt, bitter taste like black coffee.
Palate first feels a little creamy but is quick, fizzy, clean: thin, light, and with an abrupt finish except for a lingering bitterness.  
Needs to breathe or age but is a good-tasting beer.

Bomber.  Dark brown pour, good head/lasting lacing and a slighty smoky and creamy chocolate aroma.  Flavor is thin chocolate, light smoke, vanilla and a little watery on the finish.  Not bad, but not outstanding.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2011 22 oz bottle.  Pours a lovely black cherry color with a nice creamy tan-to-brown head.  Chocolate aroma is almost there; Im not personally picking up any smokiness.  Watery/thin in the mouth with a slight amount of carbonation.  Subtle chocolate flavor.  Lingering smokey finish.  Not bad.

Smoky, roasted malt and a hint of coffee.  Taste like a porter poured into a charred bbq sauce tray and mixed around until the smoke permiated. It was ok, not awesome, but pretty good overall, just didnt love it.

A great porter from Stone Brewery Co.

A: roasted malts, caramel smell, coffee taffy vibe.

A: 3 finger caramel head, dark brown color with a light dark ruby red hue at the bottom of glass, nice creamy lacing, and had minimal carbonation.

T: Taste smoked coffee beans like a mocha with bitter hops.

P: roasted malts from the front to middle of the palate then a nice bitter hop taste at the back of the palate.

O: I would drink this during the winter time not at a bbq.

I had such high hopes for this beer. I love porter and I love smokey beers so how could this go wrong? Sadly, I was wrong.

The beer pours black with light tan head that is big, 3 fingers high with good retention and lacing.

The aroma is really light and doesnt bring forth nice smokiest that you would expect. The smoke is there just really light with a tad of chocolate.

The taste is really super light as well, you can barely get any smoke at all and just a light coffee taste.

Guest keg at BrewDog Edinburgh. Very dark brown with an off-white head. Light coffee, charcoal, sweet liquorice nose. Rich and sweet. Smoky flavour is subtle but lovely. Light bitter finish. Very nice indeed.

22 oz. bottle from Oades Big Ten

Ar:  Toasty roasty aroma with a background of smoke.  
Ap:  Deepest black pour with a rich, fluffy cinnamon head.  Excellent lace along with great retention.
T:  Relatively dry stout (well, relative to the Bells Double Cream I had a couple hours ago), with a deep roasty flavor.  Smoke is complementary; it comes through but does not dominate.
P:  Creamy body with relatively mild carbonation.

O:  Delicious!

Aroma: Chocolate, Caramel, Coffee, and Toasted Malts
Appearance: Black with tan head that dissipates too quickly.
Taste: Medium sweet with light bitterness, but no real depth here.
Palate: Full body, dry texture, light carbonation, long finish
Overall: Its good, and obviously well thought out and crafted. The smoke is not overpowering, which is a good thing. Still, it seemed very one dimensional taste wise.

650ml bottle.

It pours a nice dark brown with some reddish hues, the head is thick and foamy. The head is slightly tan. It holds for a bit then recedes to some pretty nice lacing.

It smells like an IPA with some brown sugar thrown in, Stone loves their hops huh. There is a hint of roastiness but much less than expected.

The flavor isnt hoppy bitter, but it has a considerable amount of hop flavor. There is also a hint of smokiness and some caramel sweetness.

It is a bit mixed up but overall it is a decent brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-23-2010 04:22:19
Mild smokey aroma.  Blackish-brown in color with a tan head.  Smokey but just right, not overpowering like most smoked ales.  Chocolatey tones, a great porter.

Bottle. My second smoked beer. Thought this one was good. Poured deep, dark black with a tan head. Smelled like a day old camp fire mixed with heaps of chocolaty malt. Taste was similar but well balanced overall. I like it.

22oz bottle.
Dark black color with a very nice tan head.  Roasted malt, chocolate, and smoke aromas - I really like how the smokiness works with the malty flavors and that is in no way overpowering.  Another delicious brew from Stone!

Another beer that shows the brewers ability to give flavor along with balance. The smoke plays a part but only A part. Otherwise, the malts shine and the complexity shows its face and isnt smoked out. The mouthfeel is right on, coating your mouth with silk. Also, the pour was beautiful with a tannish head. The aroma is sweet like sweet smoked pork. The malts show through in the nose. Great beer.

Appearance:
Pours jet black. Dark Ruby Red color when held to the light with a 1 1/2 to 2 finger tan bubbly head 

Smell:
First nose dip brang heavy chocolate maltiness with a touch of espresso and brown sugar. smelled a littl grapefruit rine from the hops. After giving it a little swirl the heavier smoke smells and a bourbon like booziness become apparent.

Taste:
Hard Smoke like im enjoying a cuban.... cigar. It hits on the outside of the tongue with a nice silky layer of decedent chocolate sifting over the middle of my tongue. Just an ever so slight hint of caramel pops out here and there. it sits and waits in the background till you ahve wore out the smoke and chocolate.

Mouthfeel:
creamy on the top of the tongue, hard on the sides with the smoke edginess. leaves a very slight stickiness on the upper lip.

Drinkability:
I want some blackened chicken and roasted corn, perhaps texas style BBQ. Char some meat a little bit and drink this with it. mmmm. I remember having some cheesess with Ash rind. I think those would be deligtful with this. I could drink this with that food or on its own. I think late fall would be great for this when you can smell the russian ash trees. right when it gets cold and you light the fire. very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2012 Really dark brown to almost black with a thick beige head. Slight lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and a subtle smoke character. The taste is richly roasty with the smoke as more of an accent than the dominant element. It has a creamy, smooth, and somewhat oily medium body, and a nice slightly dry and bitter finish. Really good stuff.

Appearance:  lovely pour--very dark brown, with deep ruby highlights lightening to amber at the edges; creamy, one-finger beige head; thick, creamy lacing.  Aroma:  meaty (bacon), smoke and a little ash; chocolate, caramel, a bit of wet golden retriever.  Taste:  as the aroma indicates, minus the wet dog; lots of smoke, meat, ash and wood, a little leather, bittersweet dark chocolate and caramel.  Finish:  long, smooth, moving from smoky and richly sweet to a little bitter.  Notes:  Very nice smoked porter.  Palate is a delight--rich and creamy-smooth, which compliments the sweetness.  The bitterness comes through at the end to ready the palate for the next satisfying sip.  Comparable to the Great Divide Smoked Baltic Porter; just a notch or two below.

22oz bottle.  Pours almost black with a medium, slightly tan head.  Taste upfront is dry with just hints of dark cocoa and espresso.  Then the smoke hits.  Definitely the most pronounced taste but not overpowering.  Good beer but not exceptional.
UPDATED: MAR 10, 2011 I wouldve liked this more smoked, its very subtle, first time ive seen stone be subtle, the porter backgraound is very good, rich roasted malts, recommended
(bottle)   A descent porter cloaked in smoke.  Elements of roasted coffee and charred malts.  A nice choice for the right occasion or food paring.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2014 Bottle fr om Bullit. Strong smokey aroma. Rich dark brown colour. Flavour & aroma complex, rich, smooth, smokey malt. Lingering aftertaste.  Not as good as the first time I had it
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Black colour, tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, smoke, coffee. Flavour is roasted malts, smoked malts, a bit salty. Slightly bitter finish.
Bottle. Full-on "campfire in the mouth" throughout the entire expirience. Not my favorite style, but well done here.

22 oz bottle. Another Stone to try. Pours a dark brown that catches the light in the edges, with a small light tan head that dies quickly. Smells of coffee, chocolate, and a strong smoked and roasted smell. Tastes of coffee and chocolate, with the smokiness being not too overpowering, but a nice addition to the other flavors. Not a terribly strong character/body to the taste however. Overall a very decent porter.

Aroma: wood pile, toast, charcoal; Appearance: deep brown with a hint of purple, pours a think, dark tan head that lingers; Taste: just awesome, I can see why this one is rated 100 amongst its class, burnt malt, but not bitter in the slightest, very foody, meaning that it reminds me a lot of grilled things, although I cant be more specific than that, totally wonderful, and this is coming from someone who doesnt usually do porters; Palate: very, very smooth while remaining crisp enough in carbonation, a totally feel-good beer, Id even recommend it for a late night snack; toastiness lingers; Overall: very, very good, maybe its just because I didnt go into this beer expecting much, but, whatever the case, Im tempted to say its one of my top 10 favorite beers
Pours black with some tan head. A good malt base with chocolate and coffee overtones. Not so much smokiness but I cant help feeling that it would taste a lot better without it. Sorry, Stone.
This is an outstanding porter. Very smooth taste with just a hint of smokiness, not chocolate or coffee, just a true porter. Delicious.

22 fl oz bottle. pours a typical almost black color, very little light passing through. Nice mocha colored head with good lacing on the glass. Aroma is pretty underwhelming, just some roastiness and chocolate overtones and some maltiness that disappears as the drink wears on. Taste is really satisfying with the smoky, roasty sweetness as advertised. Leaves kind of a dry and bitter aftertaste but sits very well on the palate. Drink at or near room temp for best aroma/taste possible.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2014 Like dessert in a glass- chocolate and coffee flavors come through and then it finishes with smokiness on the back of the palate.  Smoke element is well done, not overpowering.   Really smooth, really interesting.   Not too heavy on the palate.  Easy to drink but hard to drink too much.   More hoppy than your average porter.  Softly carbonated. If Porter were my favorite style of beer, this would be my favorite beer. 
"shared" (ok. I had most of it) a bomber 04/01/14.  Even better than I remember.  Had a really nice reddish hue to the pour and the weight of it is just right.  Nice to not miss out on any of the dark beer flavor but have a lighter mouthfeel.   Really phenomenal.   Probably one of my top 5 beers ever.

Pours a dark ruby color with a light tan head. Smells of chocolate, coffee and a faint hint of wood smoke. Taste is heavy on the roasted malt but light on the tongue. Certainly bitter but not particularly hoppy. Smoke comes in on the aftertaste.

22 oz bottle. Its hard to specifically pinpoint why, but I was kind of disappointed here. It just lacks a bit of the complexity and boldness that I was expecting. Oh well, its still pretty solid. I will give it some major credit though for a beautiful pour. Bountiful head of the deep cream, soft cloud-like variety, a sticky smattering of lacing, a medium, mostly opaque appearing body, and a chocolate color with hints of ruby. A overarching hazy sweetness in the nose. Some sweet apples, mixed fruit with toffee and cereal malts. Smoked woody grain in there, but very much in the background along with light mocha, earth and light pine. These notes sort of blend together though a bit and dont stand individually as maybe they could have. The flavor notes act in a similar way. The balance is fine, but again the flavors dont pop as much as they could for a heavier feeling 6% abv. Soft carbonation here as well, with a lack of smooth creaminess. Flavor notes are rather sweet up front with mixed fruit, coffee, chocolate, and toffee. Then some smoked, roasted grain, and a decently bitter earthy and minor herbal bitter/balanced finish. Lingers with some roasted malt and a subtle bitter. Overall, this is really a pretty decent beer, just slightly overhyped.

Pours a dark dark brown with about a finger of tan head.  A little smoke to the odor, and chocolate.  Roasted malt taste, with a burnt toast aftertaste and a little bit of chocolate sweetness to it.  Ends with a solid hop bitterness.  Its good, but not as much flavor as I would have expected.

Bottle - pours dark, dark amber with a lively head.  Aroma is nice and smokey but not overpowering; taste is smokey with toasted malt and a coffee semisweet aftertaste.  Nice for a smokey beer, not something I would drink all night, but a great once-in-a-while brew!

Taste was mainly bitter with some coffee notes and very light smoke. I think the "smoke" did more to just make the other flavors more mild than to really add much in the way of smoky flavor. Not that thats a bad thing, but it wasnt really what I expected or was looking for.
A very fine porter. Roasted malt, cocoa, some hints of coffee, and a nice smokiness that strangely smooths out this beer. Well done!
Good porter. Really good porter. Not a really good "smoked" porter. The smoke flavor was lost. you could smell the smokiness but had to really search for it in the taste.

Bomber from Winooski.

Appearance : Black with a light brown head. Some lacing.

Aroma : Great piny hops with light smoke and roasted malt. Some chocolate and coffee.
Taste : Great piny and resinous hops with roasted malt and light smoke. Finish is rather dry. Notes of chocolate and coffee on the finish.

Overall : Very nice stuff. Quite hoppier than the other beer from this style. Not very smokey. Very well balanced. Very drinkable and tasty. Surprisingly tasty and rich for such a low abv. Could drink the whole bomber by myself. Kick-ass brew !

The beer pours a very dark brown color with a large tan head. The aroma is a very nice mix of smoke. roasted malt and chocolate. The smoke compliments the other flavors and doesnt overshadow them. The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of chocolate and roasted malt, with the smoke mixing very well. The beer tastes smokier than the aroma, but it is still not overwhelming. Very easy to drink. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. One of my favorite smoked beers and a beer that goes very well with barbecue brisket.

On tap at Stone brewery Dark brown pour with a fast disappearing head. Hints of chocolate toffee and coffee. Tastes closely follows nose but includes a touch of smoke. Not too noticeable to me but overall a nice mellow porter.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2011 After comparing the grey import with it at Justins Private Tasting at The Monk, I realised my last rating was very skewed. Grey import was just not up to scratch. So much more smokiness with an oily wood-like aroma come out on the nose. Lingers for much longer than the grey import as well. Great balance between roasted notes and smoke. Much less bacon notes than a lot of other smoked beers. Very easy going but enjoyable
Bomber, pours opaque black w/ resilient slightly off-white head, slight smoked malt aroma,  slightly oasted malt flavor w/ moderate bitter and soky finish, tasty but not exceptional

Man I love this stuff, so flavorful yet so drinkable, and light enough abv that i can actually drink a bunch.  Sessionable porter!

Pours like lava, dark brown and opaque.  All the roasty flavor of a porter, with just a bit of smoke.  Also accents of chocolate.  Finshes quick and clean so you can drink some more.

Aroma is chocolate, caramel, and smoke. Appearance is dark brown with hint of red, small tan head. Taste is chocolate and toffee with smoke, creamy. As the description says, smoke is mild  just right. Palate is medium +. Coats tongue well and pleasant flavors linger. Overall this is a really nice Porter. Easily the best beer I have had from this brewer.

22 oz bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a tulip. Pours clear mahogany with a tall tan head. The head mostly remains and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has aromas of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts with a hint of smoke. The flavour is predominantly roasted malts, with notes of coffee, smoke and herbal hops. The smokey notes become more prominent as it develops. It also develops hints of caramel and fruit as it lingers on the palate. The finish is fairly clean but has a touch of roasted malt. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent rich porter with chocolate, coffee and smokey notes. The smoke is not overwhelming; it serves as a nice complement to the chocolate and coffee. This brew is more complex than I was expecting; a definite hit. 2010-12-31
On tap at Fermentation Lounge, pours black with little head, a little smoke, Bacon, burnt malts, chocolate, very nice but ho hum.

Poured from an 22 ounce bomber into a New Belgium globe. Enjoy by 8/21/10 etched on bottle.

Appearance: Pours a dark cola brown with a 1 finger foamy tan head. Excellent lacing.

Smell: Roasted malt, sweet cocoa and mild floral hops with a very faint hint of smoke in the background.

Taste: Toasted bread up front followed by semi-sweet chocolate in the middle and ending with a combination of bitter hops and a nice dose of smoke. Aftertaste is smoky and mildly bitter and lingers for quite a while.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Goes down very smooth.

Drinkability: High drinkability. You could knock back more than one bomber over the course of an evening. This is a great choice for a cold day.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. This is one of the best porters Ive ever had. I would definitely recommend trying this. Once again, Stone does not disappoint.

Really black with a hint of red when held to the light. Dark smoky head. All flavours subtle and come mainly at the end. There are so many flavours in such a small abv porter. Coffee, chocolate, liquorice all lifted out by a beautiful smoky shadow. Very nice indeed.

Pours deep brown-to-black with a small tan head that quickly disappeared.  Aroma was chocolatey, with a slight smoky note underneath.  Deep and slightly thick palate, but not cloyingly so.  Flavor was chocolatey, maybe mixed with coffee.  Some smoke flavor blooms in the finish and lingers on the tongue.  If you can talk yourself out of drinking it, this also makes a great base for braising ribs.

A: poured into a snifter. The Smoked Porter pours an obsidian color with a nice thick frothy tan head on top. Good head retention and a fair amount of lacing.

S: dark roasted malts. Some coffee and dark cocoa aromas, with some smoked peat as well. The smoked quality is a little light.

T: roasted malts are the overall flavor, some toffee, coffee, and chocolate tones. Mild hop character, but it is present. Smoky characteristics are all over this, yet not overly done.

M: smooth and creamy mouthfeel. low carbonation level. A little think.

D: one of the best smoked porters out there. I have yet to be disappointed by Stone, and this is another reason why. Very drinkable.

At this risk of being completely imflamatory this is a classic case of another (very?) over-rated beer from a cult US brewer relative to the genre globally.  No doubt quite a full bodied example and theres nice roast, cola and touches of bitterness. Some mineral tang as well. Good balance. Hard to pick up the smoke impact although theres a faint woody sweetness that comes close.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a minimal head. Chocolate and smokey aroma. There is a strong smokey flavor, that can be almost overwhelming. I was expecting the smokey flavor to have a resolution, but it did not come. Still a very nice porter, but I had higher expectations
great porter pours pitch black. first i find huge smoky and coffee notes and afterwards a bit of licorice and fruitiness maybe fig or raisin. one that i will find myself drinking often
Dark black with a small tan head. Aroma of smoke peat and coffee. Sweet aroma of mild roasted malt, smoke and peat. Soft carbonation and nice full body. Tastey and well made.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2012 On tap at Track 84 - Warwick, RI. I cant believe Im finally getting around to this. Smoke comes lightly in the aroma, along with some moderate toasted characters. Theres some smoke, some porter. Thats fine. Dark brown pour, sienna head. Flavors bring some of this peat up and then wash it away pretty quick. I understand that this isnt a smoked beer, and that the smoke presence is less than what I would like. My problem is that its a watery, washed out porter that lacks good malt nuance in the first place. Sub-par.

Bottle purchased from sicilianos in grand rapids, mich.  Tastes of burnt malt, chocolate, dark fruit and maybe even a little sour apple.  The smokiness didnt really shine too much for me though.  Another nice brew from stone.

Pours black with a frothy brown head. Nose is basically smoke and dark roasted malts. Flavor is rich chocolate, oak and roasted malts with lots of smoke and a slightly bitter, drying finish. Medium bodied, delicious porter.
"Smoked" is a good name for this beer. That certainly one of the main things that jumps out at ya.

Bomber. Pours a deep, almost black mahogany with a fluffy and quickly dissipating tan head. The smoky aroma releases as it pours and pervades through the coffee and chocolate maltiness. Hints of burnt toffee and finishes smoothly and just a bit bitter. Well balanced and light enough to be easily drinkable. Widely available and relatively inexpensive, this is one of my go-to beers on a chilly night.

Pours nearly black with a small tan head which never really dissipates; strong lacing. Not much in the nose, slight notes of smokiness. Taste is consistent with coffee followed by a slight smokiness. Very drinkable and for a style I am not particularly fond of, it is a good beer.

Very deep ruby color.  Brownish/orange/ruby highlights around the edges.  Almost black when held away form the light.  Nice tan, creamy head with very nice retention and excellent lacing.  The head settled to a wonderful film on top.  The description on the bottle is spot on.  A nice smokey aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Licorice is both delicate and birlliant.  The dark fruit is subdued, but makes a worthy impression.  The smell is very well balanced in my opinion.  A nice robust black coffee flavor jumps out at first.  Followed by some rich chocolate flavors.  Both flavors are equally roasty, burnt and smokey.  The dark fruit, like in the taste, is pushed to the backgorund to give a little complexity.  Medium to mostly full mouthfeel.  Chewy and smooth.  Tons left on the palate waiting for the next sip.  Very dry and exquisite.  This is a Porter that has a strong character and flavor.  Its perfect for the bitter cold evenings.  The smokey aroma and flavor are really prominent and, to some extent, started to distract me.  Not a great deal, but some.  Its still a great, well rounded Porter.  One that I will pick up again and again.  I could drink this in moderation with extreme pleasure.

Im still learning to enjoy porters, so I need some time to truly appreciate them, but I really enjoyed this one.  Aroma?  Not much there for me.  Pours medium-dark brown with a big tan head.  Taste is roasted grains, nice bitterness behind it.  Pretty tasty.  Would try again for sure - especially since Stone generally doesnt gouge you on bomber prices like some other brewers.
Bomber. Pours black. Aroma of blackberry, smoke, and bitter chocolate. Taste of espresso, resin, caramel and chocolate. Not too bitter on the finish.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver, Co. Pours allmost black, some red tone, small light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, oak, cold coffee, light smoke. Taste is dark chocolate, roasted malt, hint of coffee, dark fruit, little smoke. Thin to medium body, smoked and bitter finish. 
041210

650ml bottle. Pours thick and hearty, a meal in a glass, with a beaming thick head the colour of freshly brewed coffee. Tar black in colour with a pleasing coffee aroma and hints of wood smoke hidden underneath. Rich and velvety in the mouth with a roasted malt and toffee flavour that penetrates deep into your throat.
This is a dam good beer! I will be brewing it myself soon! aroma is sweet and smokey and it looks scary. The taste starts and ends with a slight smokiness. Nice job Stone!

650mL bottle.  Pours dark brown with a thin tan head that quickly diminishes to a ring.  Aroma of caramel, malt, roast, dark and dried fruit with some faint resinous hops and alcohol.  Mild roasty flavour, mild sweetness, a bit of burnt bitterness, some dark fortified wine flavours.  Light-medium bodied, soft carbonation, mildly creamy and slightly astringent with a finish of burnt acidity and bitterness.

Pours a very dark brown with a nice, creamy head. The aroma is definitely dominated by the smoke, although its not too overpowering. A bit of chocolate, wood, and miscellaneous roast. The smoke continues to come through in the taste atop the chocolate flavors from the nose, with a wee bit of coffee thrown in as well. Smooth and slightly dry.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 01-20-2010

Finally - a smoked beer I can enjoy.  Black, with a good tan head.  Chocolate aroma with just a hint of smokiness.  The taste doesnt let down - coffee and roasted malt in the front with some tastes of chocolate and a slight bit of smoke in the taste.  If I didnt know beforehand, I would probably not be able to place the smoke taste - only to note that its "different".  A very good porter.

Bottle: Pours a rich dark brown/black with a modest beige head - decent retention but light around the edges. Aromas are rich roast coffee, chocolate, and a light smokiness. This brew has a touch of hop bitterness, but it is accented by the sweetness in the chocolate. Flavors are coffee beans, chocolate nibs, smoky malts, and a hint of cream near the end - this brew is terrific. Medium bodied - I only hoped that the abv was a bit higher honestly.
Moderate robust aroma. Dark amber color with a medium tan head. Mild sweet beginning with a light bitter finish.
Smells like a smoked porter, I believe it says that on the bottle. Tastes like a smoked porter. I think is a smoked porter....smoked porter
Had this at Kickbacks on King Street in Jacksonville, FL. Very small smoked flavor. with a side of vomet like my dad said below.

22 oz. bottle.  Opaque black pour with heavy frothy head.  Mild carbonation.  Excellent taste up front with no aftertaste.  Mildly bitter with a great finish.  Not at all smoky like I imagined.  This is my second beer from Stone.  Will definitely drink a lot more.

Very nice porter. Im not really getting much smoke and the body is far too carbonated (almost a gusher), but the flavor (chocolate and caramel malt) is very good. Not quite what I hoped from stone, but quite enjoyable.

SÖF 25 year feast at Haket 2010-11-13 Göteborg - big bottle
AP: pitch black, wee beige head
AR: vinos, chocolate
F: smokey, a bit fruity, a bit pochu porter, but fruity and interesting

22 US fl.oz. bomber poured into a tulip pint glass...

A nice dark brown (or very deep mahogany) colour to it. The head is very foamy at first, then it settles down to about a finger in thickness. Very nice lacing and good head retention. Looks beautfiyl.

The smell is not that intense (probably because the beer isnt that fresh). Roasted malts, bitter chocolate, a tint of coffee. Some earthy hops and a fair amount of smoke.

The taste had a wonderful roasted and smoked profile. Pretty sweet for a porter, but the sweetness is not pushing the limits. Some earthy hops. The smoke adds an extra layer of meatiness to the beer. The after-taste is full of roasted malt and chocolate notes; the bitterness is not too strong. Very balanced and flavourful. I like how the bitterness, which is pretty intense, is suppressed by the sweetness and the smokiness.

Medium-to-full-bodied. Quite thick, but very smooth, even creamy. Not much carbonation. A slight slight warming sensation from the alcohol. Moderately dry and bitter.

This is a very drinkable porter. Goes down smoothly. Each sip is enjoyable.

Overall, this is a fantastic porter, and another very solid beer from Stone.

Having previously sampled other Stone offerings (and raving about them), I was a little biased when I ordered this draft at a local restaurant.  Stone is known for in your face beers with powerful aromas and distinctive tastes.  I must admit, this smoked porter was too subdued for my liking.  While I enjoyed aspects of this beer, I hold Stone to a higher standard, because I know theyre capable.

Pours a deep amber brown color with a white foam head.  Has a roasty, almost smoky aroma with hints of caramel and chocolate.  Has a sweet roasty taste with some smooth chocolate notes on the finish.  Light to medium mouthfeel.

Tasted on tap at Old Chicagos in Denver, Colorado.  Pours a deep black appearance with a fairly decent foamy brown head.  Good roasty, charred BBQ flavor.  Nice and smooth  and a bit creamy like a porter, just awhile lot more flavor.  Very easy drinking so it could appeal to people that tend to avoid smoked beers.

Beautiful dark brown body with reddish hues.  Theres a nice tan head that sticks around for a while.  Very inviting aroma of chocolate, coffee and cream, and a touch of smoke.  Smooth and creamy medium mouthfeel.  The brew starts sweet, chocolate and sweet coffee, and finishes with a nice bite of smoke.  Like drinking a fantastic beer and smoking a good cigar.  Nice!

22 oz. bomber, $5 @ Lemon Tree. Robust. Yep, thats about the way to describe it. Pours a big, robust deep brown with a big slightly tan head. Nice peat smokiness up front in the nose, and it segues right into the taste. Malts show in a little later; a nice coffee roast thats still wedged in behind the smoke. Some malt stickiness starts to build on my lip. Taste is nice and rich, but it makes clear the alcohol is no stronger than any mass beer. Nice to sit with at the end of the day, with some sausage or an ice cream dessert. I tried it with a PB&J as suggested on the bottle. That works too, but I wouldnt serve that at a beer pairing.

Great porter. I am not a huge fan of the style but this is a top notch example. The smoke is quite light (compared to a scherlenka for example) and the chocolate and bitter coffee, particularly in the finish. Reasonably hoppy too (though its a stone so its expected).  Another fantastically made stone beer, this one showing they can do more than hideously hoppy beers.

bomber.  Pours black with nice big frothy, creamy tan head.  Aroma of bbq ham pizza, roasted malt, brunswick stew.  Although the smoke is very much present in the aroma, as advertised it is no where near to the extent of a rauchbier.  Full bodied, creamy, smooth palate.  Flavor is big on roast chocolate tones, which are overlain by smoke, and the finish reveals a darker, more bitter aspect off coffee and dark chocolate.  I do like rauchbiers, but can also appreciate smoked malt being used more sparingly like in this offering.  Always been a big fan of stone and this one does not disappoint, although I wont call it their best.  It is rich, modestly complex, and easy drinking.  Good.
another great offering from Stone. On tap att he Bonaventure brewing co.  Loved it.  Piscator woud have been in 7th heaven

This a porter only Stone could make. Just like everything else they make, this beer is downright ballsy. Pours thick and black with a nice foamy head. The scent is heady and smokey and absolutely intoxicating (no pun intended). It tastes much like it smells, the flavor rich and biting. The smokiness is very present, and adds a unique experience to the familiar style. As usual, Stone pulls no punches, thought I wish this beer wasnt so hard on the palette. They really make sure that if youre going to drink one of their beers, youre going to stick with it by god. Personally, Im fine with that.
