Bottle. Pours a clear but very dark brownish mahogany with a creamy tan head that lasts a while. Aroma is quite smoky and chocolatey with notes of coffee and licorice as well. Flavour is very similar to the aroma with a pronounced mocha character and nicely interwoven smokiness as well as additional hints of vanilla and caramel. Mouthfeel is both dry and creamy with light tingly carbonation and a long bitter finish. Well made and nicely balanced - this is a great combination of styles and very easy to drink.

Poured into a snifter. Appearance is a dark black with a thick tan head. Ridiculous amount of carbonation. At one point the head was larger than the body of the beer by a good bit. Aroma is smoky chocolate, coffee, and light hops. Taste is comparable to the nose but with the hops playing a smaller role. This beer is probably becoming one of my favorites of all time. Simply fantastic.

22oz Bottle poured into english pint glass.  Beautiful dark brown with ruby highlights that you can actually see light through towards the bottom of the glass.  Large head with good lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, alcohol and a little smoke.  Taste is a little more smoke, hops, coffee, roasted malts.  Very good porter.

Just enough smoke to give it a richness for those cold winter nights. the aroma is smoky malt with some chocolate and maybe a touch of caramel. The pour is dark brown with a light tan head. The flavor is smoky sweet with a rich creamy smooth feel.

Bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger.Pours black as Coke with a nice looking 2 inch creamy tanned head. Aroma is moderate smoked malts, peat, chocolate and some dark caramel, quite interesting. Taste is mildly smoked, not too much in any way, more subdued smoke, with some nice chocolate and liquorice as well. Modertae bitterness, finishes off on the sweet side. Very good and inviting beer.
Bottle. Pours black with off white head. Nose of heavily roasted malts and smoke. Taste of burnt coffee grinds, smoke and heavily roasted malts.

Just like the bottle says, theres a subtle smoke in the aroma as well as chocolate and hints of fruit. The overall aroma is not overwhelming, and does not give away the intensity of the flavor. The head is rich, taking some time to fade before you can really take a proper inhalation, but it is well worth it. The brew is nearly as dark as a stout, but it is not as heavy as it looks. Brilliant, silky in palate, as bright in taste as it is dark. Maybe this is just a great day to have a beer, but I am detecting no aftertaste. It goes as it arrives, like smoke.

Bomber btl. Pours a medium bodied dark almost deep deep copper with a light tan head. Nice aroma of smokey malt and some subtle fruit beneath. Nice balance of sweet malt start with pleasant bitterness and smoke finish. Good pick for a cool evening.

Pours a very dark brown / black color, nose was coffee with a hint of raisins and cocoa, taste was quite complex, nice level of smokiness, subtle, but easy to pick up. There was almost an out of place, but still quite nice hop flavor, reminded me of rogues use of cascades in their darker beers, tons of contrast in this one.

Poured from the bottle, this is a very dark, intense brown with not a lot of foam. In this sample, the nose is not distinctive other than a slight muskiness  I wonder is this ones been on the store shelf too long. Although the finish does deliver a somewhat smoky taste, its characterized by a thin finish and bitter aftertaste, rather uncomplicated. I agree with lj6880 that this presents like a black lager.
Silky Smooth and very drinkable.  The aroma is not to good on this one, I have to say that is the only downfall.  Black body, with white head with a smooth mouth feel.

From tap.
Very dark brown. Strong smoky aroma with dark malts and hints of coffee and nuts. Full bodied with some bitterness and a long, smoky finish. Exactly what I look for in a smoked porter.

Pours a very dark brown. Smells roasty but not strongly of coffee. Tastes dark and rich with hints of chocolate and prune with a slight aftertaste leading into licorice. Very thin body, but one of my favorite smoked porters.

22 oz bottle served in an English pint.  Pour is dark cola with 3 fingers of tiny bubbled soda like foam on top.  Nose is very simple as I pick up only green wood and smoke.  Taste is hops, smoke, and light roasted malt that are delivered in a very creamy fashion.  The finish drys off a bit and solos a lingering smokiness.  This was worth a try and definitely not a bad brew, but it does not leaving me desiring more.  However, if the hops were toned down and the malt character increased, I would have really enjoyed this.  This comes off more as a black lager, rather than a porter.

Bottle at Monks Porterhouse, Gamla Stan Stockholm.
Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head.

Aroma of green apples, red onion and a hint of smoke.
Lots of coffe, some chcolate, tart apple, dark fruits and a hint of smoke.

This is a good smoked porter but it just doesnt blow my socks off like the rest of the Stone line of beers. It has a nice smokey aroma, but the taste seems to be lacking. Its worth a try, but doesnt leave me wanting more

Very black in color with a touch of red when held up to the light.  Light in flavor at first but then asserts itself with a deep dark chocolate and smoky flavor.  Slight smoky aroma.  Overall, this is damn good!

UPDATED: APR 17, 2011 Great, dark brown porter color. Getting mostly  sweet chocolate on the nose, but there might be a slight coffee malt there. When it warms more the sweet chocolate smell disappears and its mainly an acid smoke. Taste relatively light, get a smoky coffee acidity, roasted malt. A little thin, but quite drinkable.  Im not the biggest fan of smoke flavors.

Bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with a gray brown head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a nice smoke and roast note with backing chocolate and a hint coffee. Flavor has same chocolate backbone with a bit more coffee and the roast and smoke adding a nice bit of complexity.
One of my favorite beers. Dark brown with a slight red hint. Malty and chocolaty aroma. Smokey taste. Clean, bitter. Drinks well, smooth.

Tony Romas sampler platter at Mission, San Diego. Colour: Dark. Taste: Quiet, aside from some smoked wing sauce?!? Taste: Smokey oysters, stale coffee...long, finally a sooty finish. Not a fan at all. Dusty mouth feel. Seeing the popularity of this beer, Im hoping I just got a bad tap....

1pt Bomber: Pours near pitch black, awesome thick, velvety tan head that leaves some impressive lacing behind. Tremendous peaty, smoky aroma with an almost apple-like fruity note, chocolate, coffee. This is promising. Smooth as silk to drink and just teeming with flavour. Theres definitely a rauchbier like character to it but the smoke, while prevalent, doesnt overpower. You can definitely catch the chocolate, roasted coffee beans, black cherries, oak and a hint of hops. Great.
Huge fan of Porters.  This one did not disappoint.  Got the big 22 oz bottle and was quite impressed.

dark brown with ruby highlights and thick tan head. aroma is roasted and smoky there is also a sweetness like that of dry fruit. the taste is rich and smoky with a clean bitter finish.  thick mouthfeel but a dry finish. chocolatey aftertaste. overall very tasty and well balanced.

Aroma of licorice, chocolate, light caramel with a hint of smoked malt. Appearance is black with tan head; oily pour. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is creamy and bubbly. Nice, but I wasnt blown away. Personally, I would have liked a more smokey aroma and flavor.

Really nice porter.  The smoke is not huge anywhere.  The nose is espresso and chocolate.  Color is black is  a light head. Taste is coffee, chocolate and hints of smoke.  Palate is very smooth and full bodied.

I couldnt really see what the beer looked like in the bar, so Ill give it the benefit of doubt. Smells nice, coffee, chocolate, some smokiness. A little lighter on the hops than Id like, but I guess Ive been having a lot of imperial everythings lately; pretty nicely balanced with a nice body. The bubbliness and lightly caramel aspect honestly reminds me slightly of coke, minus corn syrup and plus a lot of other far richer flavors...

I think this tastes increasingly good the more of it you drink. This seems to be true (at least for me) of a lot of darks.

Very dark, near-black pour with a fat, fluffy tan head. Powerful smokey aroma, complete with all the chocolate, coffee, and toffee accents youd expect from a porter. One of the best smelling beers Ive ever come across. Taste doesnt quite match up to the intense aroma. Espresso flavors meld with roasted malts, possibly some licorice, with a lingering bitter finish. Full, slick body with lively mouthfeel. Very good overall, just a bit less smokey than I was expecting given the smell.

0,65 l bottle from CrackedKettle, courtesy of Balazs, thanks!
Poured black with a small but nice beige head that diminshes to a small lacing one. Dry, smoked aroma with coffe and dark chocolate, some tobacco and leather. Wooden cask flavor with dry tastes of burnt wood, ash and deep roasted grains, mild caramell with a fruity character because of hop and yeast. Tart and peat-like character, wooden aftertaste.

Poured dark brown, with a beige, quick to disappear head. Some minor lacing on the edges. Roasted, smoked aroma with molasses, hops, licorice, some hints of honey. Medium dense body with medium carbonation, overall thinner and bitter than I expected. Pretty good though.

West USA trip 2010. Bottle. The aroma has roast, coffee, bacon and smoke. Black coloured beer with a beige head (as observed in a dark tent). The taste is light sweet and bitter and has roast, coffee and smoke. Well bodied, especially if you compare it with the relative low alcohol percentage.

22fl.oz bottle. Pours opaque, deep brown with faint ruby tinge. Lightly balanced smoky aromas with some hop zest and malt sweetness. Medium carbonation gives way to a medium-full bodied brew with a caramel sweetness lingering on through the chewy finish. Smoke flavours are apparent, yet not overpowering and are balanced quite well with the hop flavours and bitterness. Definitely a nice porter you just want more of.
22 oz bomber. Pours dark brown with a thin brown head. Slightly bubbly on the palate. Chocolate and caramel malts lead the way to a bitter lingering finish.
a porter is a porter. what can i really  tell you about this porter? a bit of smoke. roasty/burnt as it should be. nothing particularly intriguing about this beer, but it gets the job done. well.

Very dark brown pour with a loose beige head.  Chocolaty nose with very mild smoke, roasty coffee, a touch of toffee.  Rich chocolate up front moving to bitter roast and coffee, fairly subdued smoke on the finish.  Nice creamy moderate mouthfeel.  This is a nice rich tasting porter, with the smoke being pretty much in the background.  Im a smoke fiend and could go for more smoke, but this is a very tasty beer for a good price.

Dark brownish pour with some ruby red highlights.  Small head, left some web like lace on top of the brew.  Aroma was of chocolate, roasted malts, not much smoke to speak of.  Flavors followed suit although there was a bit of smoke in the finish.  Lots of dark chocolate with a lingering bitterness in the finish.  Carbonation was light.  Mouthfeel was decent, this was a fine porter.  Well crafted.

Deep brown with tan head.  Aroma of deep roasted malts, toffee, mild sweetness, and a barely perceivable smokiness - a bit surprised by this.  Taste mimics aroma with light bitter, dry finish.  Very little smokiness in the flavor.  For a brewery that prides itself in being different and pushing boundaries....This would have been more accurately called Stone Porter.  When viewed as such, an excellent, excellent example.  As far as being a smoked porter - lacking.  Could have been great.

Bomber. Dark pour with medium brown head. Aroma is very subtle, roasted grain, some wood, dark malts, coffee, chocolate. Taste is rather sweet, roasted grains again some hop bitterness as well in the finale. Decent palate, average carbonation. Quite standard, good.
nice smoke aroma.thin a bit thin on the palate but comes through with nice smoke burnt to chocolate and dark malt flavors. smoke is nice but not overpowering. one of my favorite smoke beers
An ok porter but over priced.  Nothing special about this beer. I was hoping for a smokier flavor.

(22oz bottle).  Pours almost black with chunky tan head.  Aroma of smoke, coffee and caramel.  Taste is fairly sweet with light hops-surprising for Stone!  Medium bodied with thin texture.  Finish is bitter, but not overdone.  Smoke is definitely present but its quite mild compared to other beers where the smoke dominates.  The writeup on the bottle says it all: the smoke is an element of the beer.  Overall, the beer itself seems somewhat weak, but they coaxed the right amount of smokiness to make it work in total.  I find it pretty pleasing and will make sure to have this on hand when Im smoking some brisket.
wow. like all of stones offerings, this one packs quite a wallop. its not quite a pungent as some smoked beers, the flavor profile is more balanced. basically a porter with a smoky background.

Aroma: Smoke, Chocolate, Coffee

Appearance: Dark brown with tan head and slight lacing. 

Taste: Chocolate, Coffee Malt with dark Chocolate malt finish.

Palate: Full Bodied with soft tannins, dry finish. 

Overall: Sip & Savor. As a porter lover Id highly recommend this as a porter for that porter drinker looking for something to enjoy thats different. Stone takes this one and runs with it.

Nearly opaque dark brown color with lasting head retention and lacing. Has a smoked malt with chocolate aroma. Taste has a chocolate, coffee, smoked malt characater. Also has notes of vanilla, wood and butterscotch. Soft carbonation and slightly bitter finish.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ tiger NYC. Dark brown almost black body with a small offwhite head. Aroma and flavor is smoke, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt. Hoppy aftertaste.

(Bottled, 0.65l) Very dark brown with a medium, beige, lasting and lacy head. Aroma is roasted-malty (Fullers London Porter style) with a touch of licorice and milky sourness, plus moderate smokiness. Flavor is smoothly roasted-malty (almost burned), salty and mildly smoky with tarry notes. Medium body with soft, slightly foamy carbonation. A well-made, pleasant and balanced porter, with smoked malt adding oomph to the flavor nicely, but not overpowering. Could be slightly less burned to reach the top. 4335

Pours a rich mahogany with a foamy tan head and great lacing.  A smoky chocolate aroma, lots of smoke in the flavor, a bit acrid at first, but layers develop as you drink it, coffee and chocolate dominant.  Great creamy mouth.  Excellent and complex brew.
Dark/carmel pour with a small sweet head.  Good beer with hints of espresso and chocolate laced with a smoked finish.  Great porter- would recommend it to everyone.

I have had this beer sitting in my fridge for about 4 months and I just had a chance to crack it. I shouldnt have waited. This beer is great, the smoke isnt too overwhelming and I sense chocolate and in the mix

Pours a dark cola slowly cascading to a large tan head that retains well as it lightens and laces. The aroma is very smokey, with a tobacco, roasted malt, and some coffee. The flavor is sweet, with smoke, coffee, coca powder, and some sharp bitterness to finish it out. Medium boded at best, with some soft carbonation.

Served from tap into a standard pint.  Pours a dark dark brown with a one finger off white head.  Maintains nice lacing throughout.  The aroma was smoky with subtle malt notes.  The flavor was of malt, nutty, and woody notes.  It had a medium feel on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall all of the flavors in this brew were very subtle and tame.  I actually liked this so you could taste the woody flavor imparted on it.  The aroma was a little disappointing, but okay.  Have very nice drinkability, but was not my favorite from Stone for sure.  Still quite good though.

Brad - did you bring this? Ive forgotten. Pretty dark brown, ok sized light brown cap, excellent slow moving silty lacing, messy messy wicked lacing - Damn fine looking brew. Smokey aroma, well placed smoke - its obvious but fits in very well. Chocolate, big roast, raisin! ashes, underlying hops - nothing over the top, nothing amazing but its just a great smelling beer. Some smoke taste, very prominent bitterness that seems to be half chocolate and half hops, some sweetness, a bit of leafy hops and lightly piney. A lot of sips have a watery emptiness. Some bitterness, bad roasty breath, long smoky mouth, pretty boring feel. Nice beer.

Purchased at Trader Joes in Nashville. Pours a dark brown colour with red highlights. Big foamy head that is beige, has great retention and full lacing. Roasted malt scent that is not too strong and a little yeast. Notes of raisins and coffee. No smoke in the aromas, but in the taste, it comes out a bit. Not much, but it lingers in the aftertaste. The roasted malt is there, and so is the mild coffee and light bitterness. Kind of a short finish, and dry. Overall, pretty good, but was expecting a kick in the teeth. Oh well (a first for Stone Brewing... being from Canada - and heard so much from this brewery).

Overall a great porter, nice dark brown color with a creamy coffee colored head.  The smokey flavor of the malt is evident right away but not too over powering that it takes away from the rest of the taste.

[bottle]
Sweet smoked barley aroma with some raisins and other dark, dried fruit. Almost opaque dark red-brown under a lasting beige foam that laces the glass. Sweet and toasty brown malt flavour that delicately balances with smoke and roasted barley vanilla. Medium body, moderate carbonation, slightly bitter and sour bread crust finish.

Alley Kat hang your head in shame this is what a smoked porter should be like!!!!!! Awesome brew. Brown body with a minimal cap a very standard looking beer.  Aroma is a pleasant smoke with burnt malts and some chocolate, the smoke is perfect its strong enough to let you know this a smoked porter but it doesnt over power the rest of the elements. Taste is much of the same nice burnt to a chocolate malt profile with great smoke presence. You can tell this is a high quality porter that they added smoke to not just a crap porter they tried to dress up. There are even hints of hops the give a light pine flavor in the finish. Good beer easy to drink.

SD trip, sampler: Another solid Stone offering, deep black with red notes and great burnt coffee, chocolate malt nose. Light smoked, alcohol and cask like flavors (this was not a cask-conditioned or wood chip version) in the mix.

A good porter with chocolate and coffee notes but less flavor than hoped for. Its a big, flavorful porter that pours a rich, dark brown color and supports a nice-sized, coffee-cream head. Rich chocolate sweetness predominates in the nose, but it lacks the complexity of a bigger beer. Im not being very forgiving here, but I was hoping for more smoke and more interest from this entry in Stones lineup. Smoke is disappointingly weak in the flavor profile. Its there, but I was expecting and hoping for it to punch me in the face. Chocolate and coffee were both stronger for me than smoke.

650ml bottle, 12C. Brown verging on black. Light tan head fades from an inch to a good coat, then laces nicely. Aroma: rich roasted malt, blackberries, coffee. An accent rather than a hint of smoke. Taste has quite a lot of roasted malt coffee and cocoa bitterness. To my mind, very savoury. Hints of dried fruit and berries. Smooth mouthfeel. Some drying carbonation, coffee, salt and hop/ roast bitterness at the finish. Lovely weight for a porter.

Pours a dark ruby brown. Thick beige head. Decent retention and lacing. Aroma is toffee and smoke. Flavor is coffee and tannins. Smoke flavor is muted and really only show up in finish. Slightly thin, fizzy mouthfeel and offputting metallic feel in the back of the throat. I like this style, and I like most of Stones stuff, but I just couldnt get into this one for some reason.
One of the best smoked porters I have ever had. Balance between the smoke, roast, toast, cocoa, hops and sweetness has got to be tough, but Stone has done it!

Exactly what it says on the bottle. Caramel darts around in between pillars of bitter high cocoa chocolate, and roasty coffe  flavour. The smoke is a lingering idea, and reminds me a little of the morning after a night in a smokey bar. Not in a bad way though, just a lingering feeling that youve accidentally smoked a cigar! A tasty and truly individual beer, Im just not sure its my thing.

Bomber poured into a pint glass had a solid tan head that dissipated slowly leaving some nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasted and chocolate malt, as is the flavor. There is a little bit of smokiness in both, but I can definitely understand the complaint that for a "smoked" porter, the smokiness is not very pronounced. Its plenty for me, though. The color is basically coke; its pretty much black, but if you hold it up to a light you can kinda-sorta see that its brown. Sort of.

The more I sit here and drink, the more the sweetnees and the smokiness are coming out. Theres also a nice, lingering bitterness on the backend (the beers, not mine). I tend to like my pale ales on the dry side and my porters and stouts a little sweeter. This is definitely on the dry side for me. But, with that said, its definitely a beer worth repeating.

22 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  2009 vintage- Ive had this for a while in the fridge and Im just now getting around to it.  Aroma of smoked wood, earthy hops, roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, toasted sugar, and cola.  Flavor of earthy hops, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, brown sugar, flat cola, rainwater, and campfire.  Medium-bodied, with average carbonation and a dry, roasty finish.  Not as smoky as expected, and a little too watery.  Not on the level of Yazoo SUE or Alaskan Smoked Porter if you are expecting a smoked, but a good porter nonetheless.

22oz bomber

Appearance: Classic smoked porter...dark brown with fairly light mocha 2 finger head. Loads of lacing and good retention.

Smell: Roast malt, average smokiness, and bitter hops.

Taste: Same as the nose. Very nice.

Mouthfeel: A bit thin for my liking.

Drinkability: With the low abv, thin body, and controlled smokiness Id say its quite drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-04-2009

On tap at Flying Saucer in Nashville, TN. Wow I gotta say that Stone missed the boat on this one. I hold smoked porters to very high standards. Those standards being Yazoo Sue (a local brew) and Left Hand Smoke Jumpers. These are slightly unfair standards as they are both high alc beers. Nonetheless, the Stone Smoked Porter seems watered down and boring in comparison. Mouthfeel and flavor profile were just weak. The smoke portion seemed dumbed down as well. Not thrilled with this especially given the high average score.
A lot more mellow than I thought it was going to be.  The smokiness was well balanced and understated.  Smooth and easy to drink with a rich coffee / chocolate presence.

Very dark brown with red tones. Aroma is milk chocolate with some roasty malts and coffee. The taste is of bitter coffee, and smokiness. Its quite smoky on the palate as well. A little thin, but sharp.
Has an aroma of chocolate and coffee. Smooth and sweet from the start but ends a a little bitter on the back end. Enjoyable, but Ive had better.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2010 Bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a medium-toned brown/black body with a thin, white head. Smell is soft smoke-peaty tones with some dark malt sweetness in the background. Taste is mild dark malts, some roasted undertones and hints of earth and caramel. The smoke gets around your palate first when the aftertaste hits you, a nice surprising touch as you keep feeling for that smoked aroma all the way through the sip. A bit watery; this wouldve been truly great as an imperial stout version. Regardless, this is a well-crafted beer from Stone Brewing.

Big brown-beige lasting head. Barely translucent dark red body. Resiny chocolatey aroma with vinegary notes. Dry-acidic chocolate and charcoal smoke taste with milky resiny notes. Mild mouthfeel. Fullish body. Dry resiny roasty aftertaste with long lingering chocolate notes. Chocolatey charcoal smoke taste lingers. Much milder than expected, but certainly nice and drinkable. Feels like it has a light infection; need to rerate. (0.65l bottle at Olympen, Oslo.)

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2011 Bomber from BevMo Long Beach.

Aroma is full of smoky dark malt with a touch of roasted chocolate at the end.  Pours a dark black with a solid off white foam head which lingers and leaves a bubbly lacing. Taste is smoke, coffee, and chocolate with a nice bitter finish courtesy of the hops. Solid carbonation and body to this porter. Overall an amazing porter with a great smoky character.

From big bottle.  Pours brown opaque molasses with a thin caramel-colored head. Full of roast and coffee but also gives a decent hop nose and finish.  Oily mouth feel.  Surprisingly smooth though.  This is definitely not a "light" brew.   Its not my favorite style, but I would buy again.  Typical Stone high quality!

Bottle.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a thin film of light tan head that leaves just a sporadic dot of lacing.  Aroma is chocolaty with a slight smoky richness and notes of roast and hops.  Flavor is fairly bitter with some obvious piny hop notes and a dry roast backbone.  Smoke is subdued.  Medium bodied with a slightly oily character.

Bomber. Pours a dark brown-black with a beige head. Laces the entire way down. Aroma is hickory and coffee. For all the praise, this was surprisingly thin. The flavors overcome that. Really nice coffee, chocolate flavors with hints of black licorice. Finishes leaving a nice smokey flavor in your mouth. A very good porter.
(22 oz bottle) very dark amber colour with tall tan head; aroma - light lychee on the beginning, then roasty malts; taste - light and consistent bitter, bit of coffee

Bomber. Very smooth and creamy. A sweet porter, but drier than is usually for the style. Decent hops, but they are not outstanding. Very little smoked flavor to my palate. Amazingly smooth texture, very full and creamy in the mouth, heavy body. Very nice, although not outstanding in taste or aroma.
chocolate, coffee, toast, black, medium bitterness, light sweetness, full body, creamy, thick feel, average carbonation, long finish, bitter,

Deep, rich porter. Sweetness, sourness, malt. Raisins. Not extreme, just full bodied. Dry chocolate.
Discreet smokiness, Id have expected more.

Bomber via trade with phaleslu, thanks Peter! Pours dark ebony brown with a 3 finger chunky beige head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is roast, nice peat smoke, bittersweet chocolate, mild coffee, light wood notes, hints of fig and wine soaked dark fruits. Flavor is roast, peat smoke, mellow dark chocolate, pine woodfire smoke, licorice, a bit of char, caramel covered granola some saltiness and a nice, smokey, roasty, lightly bitter and dark caramel fade. Palate is light  bodied, fairly cream on entry, interrupted by a blanket of pretty prickly carbonation then finishing fairly dry. Damn fine porter, the smoke is an awesome touch, it couild definitely use a little more body and/or lower carbonation though.
Bottle. Black with a big head and lively upon pouring.Gentle smoked flavour with a medium body. Some lacing a tracesof bitterness. Slightly creamy and easy to drink.

The color was dark almost black with a tan/chocolate milk colored head. Roasty aroma filled with the spicy notes of hops. First taste starts with a roasty malt blend and finnished with a nice hops bitter and spice. In true stone style this was a bold beer with a smooth nice balance.

22 oz bottle and this was an outstanding brew. Lots of complex flavors Chocolate and coffee really stand out. Perhaps a bit too much on the coffe side.  Smooth and thick on the plate with a flavorful taste. Not as thick as some other porters but robust enough. This has just been introduced in this area and is getting good ratings.

22oz bottle.  Poured black with a touch of amber/brown around the edges with little or no head.  Not much aroma that I could detect.  Hints of coffee and chocolate but minimal.  Taste is great.  A very dry smoky taste.  This is a good porter.  Love it.

Stone beer dinner at BJs Brew house. This is a very unique beer...its like you took a really good stout and stuck it in your smoker for 24 hours. Caramel, vanilla and toffee flavors but its the really great smoke flavor that comes through that made it stand out to me.

Split a 22 oz. bottle of this with my dad-we both liked it.

A- Deep brown body with thick, smooth and creamy dark tan head. Head has good retention and leaves behind plenty of lacing in the glass. Vibrant-bright red tone can be seen throughout the body when held up to the light.

S- Lots of chocolate malt, toffee, and some vanilla. Nothing overpowering and a nice balance between them.

T- Robust chocolate malt upfront with lots of toffee and hop flavor in the background. Lots of vanilla comes out for the finish along with plenty of chocolate malt and some bitter coffee taste. Both chocolate malt and a subtle vanilla sweetness linger.

P- Medium to low carbonation and medium weight body. Smooth and creamy. Near perfect for a porter.

O- This stuff is good. Probably my favorite porter. Has the big robust taste of a stout but the smooth drinkability of a porter. One I will definitely have again. Nice job by Stone.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-26-2007 23:54:04

UPDATED: APR 27, 2010 Smokey malt aroma, pours a bit on the light side.  Nice bitterness backed by full body, full of smoky roasted, even burnt malt which contributes a bitterness itself.  The smokeness in the finish is a bit overpowering and subtracts from what otherwise is a great beer.

Pours extremely dark brown to black in color with a fairly large tan colored head. Carbonation bubbles are very close knit and small and the lacing is above average. Smell is of dark roasted malts, chocolate, and a little tad of smoke. The taste is very smooth and textured filled consisting of dark chocolate, smoke, and a tad of bitter hops. with only slight hints of alcohol. A very drinkable smoked porter.

Tap.  Pour is dark brown with a light brown head.  Aroma is roasted malt, light coffee ,and only a hint of smoke.  Not really too much smoke.  Flavor is also loaded with roasted malt and hints of coffee, smoke, and dark chocolate.  Pretty thin body.

On tap at Brixies in Brookfield, IL. and dispensed a dark, black/brown, with average, light tan foam to the head, and clingy, curtainy lacing. The aroma was roasty malt, some grain, and pleasant hints of vanilla, cocoa, smoke, and wood. The flavor added to these, moderate bitterness, medium+ body, along with a creamy mouthfeel. Very nice!

Bottle at home.  Pours a rich dark brown with a thick gorgeous tan head.  Smells of smoke, malt, wheat, and chocolate with subtle hints of vanilla and coffee.  The flavor is rich and mellow with only slight hints of alcohol.  A good drinkable porter with a thick body and rich mouthfeel.  I love it.

Poured from the 22oz bottle a clean deep brown color with a dense, tan, creamy head. Aroma has a good amount of chocolate, nice roasted barley note follows, a very light smoked peat presence and finishes with lots of roasted notes. Flavor has a very early roasted barley kick followed by a solid amount of sweet chocolate malt and then a light smokey, lightly burned and deep roasted malt flavor hits at the very end. Burping brings up some mild leafy hops bitterness. Body has a very nice heaviness, low carbonation and some modest amount of lacing on the glass. Overall a very tasty brew and one that I think I will be stocking quite often. Smoke flavor is there but not overpowering and the overall heavy roasted character really works well for the style.

Bomber from Whole Foods. My first Illinois Stone purchase. Coffee, chocolate aroma, deep brown, nice toffee head. Roasted coffee flavour, with some chocolate and liquorice too. Almost a full bodied, bitter and bold. Terrific just wanted it thicker body, and I didnt get any smoke? But thats o.k.

Bomber. Pours a deep brown nearly black with some red highlights and a creamy tan head. Aroma is very prominent chocolate, some roasted, slightly burnt malts. Coffee is also in front, and the earthy peat character really stands out. Some hops are noticeable. Flavor starts with a big time smoke character, really woody and rich along with the chocolate that is more on the bitter cocoa side. Some metallic notes toward the finish which is bittersweet but still refreshing. Medium to medium-full body and a subdued but still fizzy carbonation. Very nice porter, excellent flavor complexity.

Bomber.  Pours dark brown/black with a two finger khaki head into a pint glass.  Aroma of dark malt, roast coffee, dark chocolate, and a subtle, almost peaty smokiness.  The smokiness comes out quite a bit more in the flavor.  Rich and velvety with roast coffee and dark chocolate coming through in the rear.  Almost a roasted hazelnut quality as well.  Medium bodied with a frothy mouthfeel and a medium level of carbonation.  I used to hate smoky beers.  Thankfully, my palate has developed and this one is almost always in my fridge.  Very nice stuff.
16oz glass at Stone brewery,Color is an almost black dark brown with a tan head.The aroma is a rosted coffee and chocolate.Flavor is dark chocolate, rosted coffee, a little smokyness with a hop bite.

Bomber shared with my brother in law. I picked this up on the day that Stone started releasing their brews in Chicago. This beer poured a dark brown color with mahogany tints around the edges. It also had a one finger width brown frothy head. The aroma was pretty bland for a smoked porter. I only caught a little bit of smoke, some roasted malt, and possibly some light coffee and cocoa. The taste was also not as robust as I thought it would be. It had a hint of smoke, a lot of roasted malt, and a bit of coffee... fairly standard for a porter. It had a medium bodied mouth feel and was very easy to drink. Overall a very good beer by Stone. I wish it had more smoke character in it though...

Dark brown color with red hues, a healthy light brown head, and strong lacing.  Aroma of heavily smoked malt.  Go peat!  Palate is smooth, very clean and balanced for the smoke presence - which, by the way, is out of this world.  Closely comparable to a real rauchbier.  Smoke aside, this is a great porter with your standard coffee and chocolate qualities.  Great body and hefty smoke without being uncomfortably or annoyingly smoky like some smoked beers can get.  Exceptional.

Bottle. Aroma is not as strong and diverse as I thought it would be. I got some coffee and a light amount of smoke. The body is a very dark deep red thats almost black with a 1 finger thick cream head. On first sip I got a lot of smoke and roasted malt. As I drank more and the beer warmed I got a lot more bitter coffee, roasted malt, and of course the smoke flavor. The mouthfeel is a medium creamy thickness with soft carbonation and it finishes a bit bitter. Overall I enjoy this beer and believe its another win for Stone!

Pours dark brown with a fluffy tan head.  Subtle malt aroma, but not much smoke yet.  Sweet chocolate, malty flavor followed by a nice smoky finish.  The smoke is a nice addition, but not overpowering.

Smoked porter, consumed at home from bottle bought from Utobeer. Hops have gone a little but the taste is there and this is classic. The smoke is very affective, much like a Bamberg beer but not as smokey on the cap release as I had anticipated. I get roasted malts; smoke, wood, leather and vanilla. A great beer. Cheers Stone, keep on brewing these fine ales.

Bottle. Black with red highlights, like coke, but with a big tan head leaving loads and loads of lacing. Looks amazing. Sadly, it was served way warm, but liquorice, bonfire and bbq came through. As it warmed, some fruity sweetness, a burnt sourness and coffee joined in. Quite sweet initially, before a solid burnt bitterness leaves the mouth dry. Thick, creamy and lush textured. Quite light in flavour, could have been richer, but all in all a very drinkable and likeable porter with more than the usual flavours of coffee and chocolate.

Bottle.  Pours as a porter should with nice thick tannish head.  Didnt really get the smoke aroma of flavor for that matter.  Smell was of malty goodness and the taste is that what a porter should be.  Overall, high quality beer here.

1 pt. 6 oz. bottle shared with Rune@Håndverkerstuene, Oslo. Black body with ruby highlights. A tan ring of foam is clinging to the glass. Soft, lucious malt aroma. Rounded dark malts, rounded roastedness, and subtle notes of wood and ash.  Taste has a supersoft, gently sweet and creamy malt body. Again, very well rounded, with suggestions of ash/smoke. Vague tones of chocolate and cocoa. Very mouthfilling for a 5.9 % beer. Silky texture. Rounded and lasting malty, faintly roasted ending. Extremely well balanced, both complex and subtle. A state of the art Porter.
On tap at The Taphouse, pours black with a small head. Aroma of smoke and roasted malt. Well-balanced body of roasted malt, nuts and smoke. Very fine porter.

Fairly potent smoked aroma coming forth, with just a hint of sweetness behind it.  Pours dark ruby, with a huge tan head.  The smoke is present in the flavor, and is a fairly strong characteristic, but there is the roasted notes there, as well as some dark fruit.  Not my favorite style.  But good example of the style, as well as something I wish to cook with.

Big bottle shared with OleR at Håndverkerstuene. Devil black body tinged with a brownish shade. Silky surface with a few dimples. Smell of earthy malts and candy sweetness. Smoked accented flavour, well integrated with the sweetness and dryness of chocolate malts. Bitter undertones towards the finish. Nice mouthfeeling and quite well bodied (Oslo, 19.03.2010).

22 oz bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown, almost black with a bit of red and a medium beige head.  Malty, smoky aroma but not too heavy.  Flavor is chocolate and a bit of licorice with a smoky finish.  A flavorful beer without having any overpowering elements.

1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5.9%. Black colour, moderate beige head. Interesting aroma of roasted and smoked malts, blending seamlessly together with notes of chocolate, hints of dark fruits. The flavour is first fruity, then chocolatey and smoky, but the smoke is not overdone. Some hoppy and roasty bitterness in the finish. This is an excellent and well balanced beer!

Has a deep mahogany brown color with a nice but quickly-dissolving cardboard brown head.

A deep coffee smell. Heavy malt scent, smells almost like a stout. Smoky.

Coffee taste, but with a slight sweetness at the end to counteract the bitterness. Deep dark hint of fruit, very rich. Slight chocolatey bitterness, and a slight hit of yeast.

Thick and full-bodied. Lingers like a black coffee. Smooths out as it warms up. Surprisingly smooth considering how thick it is. Nice coffee thickness/taste. Nice brew.

22 oz. bottle from Bottleworks tasted blind.  Pours black with great tan head and good lacing.  Aroma of bacon, smoke and pine.  Flavor is nice sweet vanilla with balanced bitter.  Overall a bit too bitter, and too carbonated.  Incredibly drinkable beer that Ive been drinking for years.

Bottle kindly sent by Durhambeer. Pours a deep reddish black with a great head and good lace. The aroma is smoky coffee dark chocolate and some nice roastiness all complimented by a some dark berry flavors. The flavor is deep roasty coffee and a nice bitterness, the beer is just lightly smoky but very well balanced.

650 ml bottle. Black, but lets some brownish light through. Seems clear. Medium-sized light beige head that clings to the glass. Nice and rich smokey malty aroma with some roasted notes. Chocolate and hints of licorice. The smoke works really well with the otherwise rich darker malts. Relatively high carbonation level. Very nice beer.

Black pour off white head ... smell of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate .... taste of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and smokiness is evident .... finishes with a light bitterness .... oily mouthfeel .... a good porter with peat smoked malt added had it fresh on tap was a good one

[2635-20091205] Cask. Mild toasted fish cakes aroma with smoked dried meat notes. Dark dark brown body with a quick creamy light tan head. Sweet band-aid roast malt flavour has a long sweet syrup finish. Medium-full body. Fairly enjoyable, nice smoke characteristics.
(@ Coles, Buffalo, NY)

22 oz. bottle. Moderately strong and complex aroma thats primarily dark chocolate and licorice with a dark fruit element, maybe dark cherries or blackberries. Color is a deep ruby, almost black, with a inch thick, creamy, espresso-colored head that quickly subsides to a fine layer which laces thinly down the glass. I dont know what Koch is talking about because the peat malt is unquestionably the defining character of this beer. Still, its not overwhelming so you can still enjoy the bittersweet chocolate malt behind it. The texture could be a bit thicker but the beer still manages to be rather creamy and soft. All in all this is a damn fine beer.

(22oz bomber - pint glass)  Nearly opaque dark brown color with lasting head retention and lacing.  Has a smoked malt and slighty hoppy aroma.  Taste has a chocolate, coffee, smoked malt characater and an undefinable hop quality.  Also has notes of vanilla, wood and butterscotch.  Soft carbonation and long bitter finish.
22 ounce bottle A black pour tan head A dark rich creamy robust smoked caramel, chocolate, coffee, . a real good porter

Bottle Sample at work.  Not bad...
  Didnt think Id be much for it, smoked isnt really my style.  But it was light and balanced wityh just a mild smoked flavor that made for an enjoyable experience overall.
  Still no where near my favorite style, but worth trying again.

This one is very interesting. Got it on tap at the Yardhouse. Pours jet black(maybe the lighting?), smells of slight fruit and smoke. There was a bit of head forming in mine, lasting until the end. The taste is a bitter one, pre-dominated by fuity/earthy touches. I love Stone brews, and this one is pretty good.
Cask at Churchkey.  Very dark maroon, small beige head.  Aroma of toffee, oak, smoke.  Flavor has butterscotch and caramel that changes to roasted coffee, bitter smoke finish.  Interesting.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2014 Very dark brown, almost black with a finger and a half of off-white head. Smells smokey, of course, with aromas of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, and a bit of sweetness. The first sip is sweet, primarily caramel. As it warms up a bit, the slight smokiness comes out, as do the traditional porter flavors such as coffee and chocolate. A nice roasted malt taste is prevalent. Im generally not that big of a fan of smoked beers, but this one is light enough on the smoke, and it seems to add a bit of sweetness.

Poured from a 22oz. bottle into a stemmed glass.

The color is dark black with a three fingers of head some lacing on the glass.

The smell is a smokey hop flavor with some nice salty bitterness giving the aroma a bit of a pepper feel.

The taste was quite something as well. A bit more mellow then some Stone beers but still quite flavor full. The pepper flavor comes on nicely without being too harsh. In the mix is a good malty flavor as that gives the beer some toasty flavor as well.

The feel is feel of this beer is quite mellow with a nice medium body. Is pretty easy drinking an is one of the easier Stone beers to try for first timers new to Stone brews.

Nice black body with a bubbly off-white head.  Smells like chocolate and roasted goodness, though it is lacking in comparison to the flavor, which is quite nice.  Full of rye bread and burnt malts.  Quite enjoyable.  Finishes nice and a little sweet.  Good beer.

Brown bottle, 1 pint 6 ounces, savoured on February 13 2010; eye: deep ruby, clear, no effervescence, beige head, light lacing; nose: roasted malt, roasting, coffee, slight smoke, dark chocolate; mouth: roasted malt, roasting, coffee, smoke, dark chocolate, hint of hops, finale in roasting, medium-full body, below-average carbonation, slightly oily texture, lightly acrid and bitter; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 6 onces, savourée le 13 février 2010; il : rubis foncé, claire, pas deffervescence, mousse beige, légère dentelle; nez : malt rôti, torréfaction, café, très léger fumée, chocolat noir; bouche : malt rôti, torréfaction, café, fumée, chocolat noir, pointe de houblon, finale en torréfaction, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation sous la moyenne, texture légèrement huileuse, légèrement âcre et amère; en résumé : bien

22 oz. bottle from Market Street in Allen, TX.  Dark pour.  Simply excellent.  Chocolate, coffee and smoke on the nose.  Just enough alcohol to warm, reminds me of Sam Adams Black Lager.  Without a doubt, will buy this one again.

Cant believe I hadnt rated this before. Pours a deep, dark brown, ending in a black glass with a pillowy beige head. Very pretty. Roasty toasty malts and a good amount of hops in here - super dry - and its true, the smoke just barely comes through. Mostly in the finish. Its definitely light for how it looks. Tasty, for sure, though I probably wouldnt put it quite up with where its rated.

"Tastes like black" is usually what I tell my friends who ask about it. Pour is viscous with little head, scent and taste are very dark. The coffee, chocolate,  and smoke blend together well without any part dominating. Delicious even in a bottle.

Growler fill at CBX.
Pours a dark black with lots of tan head. Nothing overwhelming about the aroma, but a bit of sweet and coffee. Great lacing down the glass as it is being devoured. The boilerplate description of this beer serves it well so I dont have much to add. Some sweet (chocolate) and coffee taste with a subtle hint of smokiness. Nothing overwhelms the other and they are very well balanced into a delicious drink.

22oz bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Very dark amber brown ale with a long lasting medium high tan head that laces your glass sides as it recedes. Light smokey-caramel aroma. Medium body with a bitter chocolate and coffee flavor. Porter is generally not my favorite style however, its evident that this is better than average for its style. Once again, Stone appear to do very little wrong.

Pours a deep pitch black with a 1 finger high country eggshell colored head. The smell is that of dark malts, chocolate, brown sugar, and a hint of hickory smoke.  The taste is heavy on the malts, light on the smoke...pretty much light on everything that isnt chocolatey or malty...theres really no smokey quality that I can taste.  Finish isnt overwhelming...maybe a bit underwhelming...but it does pair well with the barbequed chicken in front of me.

this is one damn good porter, probably the best one ive had in a long time, although it has been a while since ive had a porter... smoked malt, chocholate and coffee taste, dark and very rich. really good.....

Pint glass. Pours very dark brown, almost jet black looking. With a light brown, frothy, 1 finger head. I smell coffee, and thats about it. Mouthfull is medium. Very smooth, comfortable and drinkable. Low carbonation. Tastes of coffee, expresso, and dark chocolate. Not as bitter and hoppy as i usually like. Or expect from stone, but is over all a very good, casual desert beer. Would follow nicely with red meats. Stone has yet to dissapoint.

22 oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a foamy, tan, long lasting head.  Aroma of roasted malt with hints of coffee and chocolate. Medium, slightly tangy body. Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and molasses. Finish is long, espresso coffee. Tasty, easy drinking porter.

Dark brown liquid with a thick, tan head. Good lacing. Chocolate, malts, and hops.  Full with slight creaminess and good carbonation. Dark chocolate, coffee, mild smoked flavor, nice balancing bitterness at the finish.  Very enjoyable and drinkable porter. Well balanced.

Soft chocolate, some coffee, just a whiff of clean incense-like smoke, some subtle hop notes.  Dark brown with deep orange hues, thick frothy tan head.     Rich warm chocolate slight roasted malt sweetness, mild but fitting bitterness.  Medium carbonation, fullish body, rich chocolate finish with some bitterness, and the incense like subtle smoke.  A very delicate, but deeply flavored rich beer.

22oz bomber.  Dark brown body with nice mahogany highlights.  Tan head recedes quickly.  Aromas of milk chocolate, mild sweetness, slightly roasted coffee and light smoked malts.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, slight hint of smoke, light coffee, smoke again and slight coffee/hop bitter.  Dry finish thats part roasty, part cocoa, part coffee.  Balanced and sessionable IMHO.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2010 This stuff is delicious. Lightly bitter, chocolaty coffee. The smoked flavor complimented it very well. I took their advice from the bottle and had it with some chocolate. They were right . It was like a match made in heaven (Well maybe not that ridiculous but hey it was good)

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Bomber. Pours black with a half-inch of thick, creamy head. Aroma is dark roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  First sip begins with strong roasted malt sweetness followed by smokiness along with hints of bittersweet chocolate and dark coffee along the way. It finishes dry and smoky with a little bit of roast malt sweetness at the end. Not nearly as overpoweringly smoky as the Alaskan Smoked Porter. Rich and complex.

I was not quite expecting something as strong as a rauchbier, but I was expecting something with a bit more smoked kick like a good scotch ale.  This could use a bit more peat malt.  There was a slight hint of smoke flavors and aromas, but I would not label this as a smoked porter.  The overall porter base was not robust.  It was thin and plain and not very well hopped.  Probably would be better if I had the oaked aged version.  I would not drink again.

I lived in San Diego 15 years ago- BEFORE the county became renown as a hot spot in the craft brew community.  Man, was I suprised by this offering from Stone Brewing.  I bought a 22oz from BevMo and was blown away by the quality of this porter.  The smoke comes through loud and clear, but doesnt overwhelm the chocolate and coffee notes.  I will make it a priority to visit this brewery on my next trip to SD.

Bomber from the local. Pours a bright mahogany with amber highlights and a huge light tan head. Some globby lacing sticks to the glass as the head recedes. Nice smoked aroma with dark fruits...I could taste the smell in the back of my throat actually. Flavors are mostly light coffee, chocolate, smoky dark fruits with a nice caramel backdrop. Not too shabby.

Im not a big smoked brew fan so Id avoided this one - but, its Stone, so I have to try.  Bomber.  Deep brown pour with a medium tan head and some soapy stick.  Nice restrained smoky aroma with chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor is dry toasted chocolate malt and background smoke.  Yeah, not my thing - but drinkable enough.

Draft. Pours a very dark brown/black color with lots of head, settling in a few minutes.  Smoke mixed with dark fruits dominates the taste.  Chocolate and coffee are secondary flavors that sneak through.  Enjoyed at first, but seemed to get old quick.

Pours dark brown, beige head
aroma, chocolate and smoked malts, although the smoke profile was light.
flavor, silky smooth palate, chocolate malts and the smoked malts being a little subdued. Some dark fruits also to be noted, overall the smokey profile is right where it should be, not overpowering and enough for the rest to blend it perfectly.
the smoke is bold and unpleasnt.  a decent porter is behind it but the smokey masks good flavors.  i could have skipped this one.

Pours nearly black with hints at brown-red at edges. Off-white head and smoked white lacing. Medium aromas of smoked hickory logs. Smoke flavor is mild on palate but pronounced in the long finish. Semi-sweet with flavors of smoked meat. Malty with light hops. This is a really  nice beer, expecially for winter, but I wish the smoke flavor was more pronounced on the palate

Pours medium brown darkening to deep black. Tan head, good retention. Fruity, smoky malty aroma. Smoky, roasted flavor with light fruity hints. Slight bitterness that lingers on the tip of the tongue. Smooth, medium thickness body with a medium carbonation that dissipates quickly.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 (Br-btl painted-Bu/Wt-lbl, 22oz)

bk-opq, thin but lasting creamy tan head, full body, med-light-co2.

aroma:  sweet hoppy §smokey alchl molasses-malt.

flavor:  sweet §malty dark-fruit T1, ashy bittersweet-chclt-malt §smokey leafy-hops T2, sweet wood-ash §malty §smokey §chrcl short T3, balanced, good throughout, complex but not overly intense.

Bottle.  Pours close to black, opaque, with a medium-sized foamy tan head.  Aroma is full of sweet roasted malts, mild smokiness, coffee, and cocoa.  Taste is sweet, very roasty, with notes of smoke creeping through periodically to enhance the rich cocoa flavor.  Creamy, smooth mouthfeel makes this very easy to drink.  Awesome porter.  Thanks to Dane for sharing!

Not a great deal of "smokiness" in this Rauchbier, however, it was pleasant to drink with roasted coffee and semi-sweet chocolate dominate in the flavor and aroma.  Dark brown body with tan head.  Not bad.
Poured a deep dark brown, almost black, with a long-lasting head that left a lot of lacing.  Taste is roasted coffee and chocolate. Not too bitter, not too sweet. A good way to finish off a night.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2010 This beer gets better every time! Pours a sexy black with a thin, tan body.   Aroma is chocolate with some burning wood and maltyness.  The body is very full, almost pushy.  Lots of smokeyness in the flavor with dark chocolate and a hint of anise.  Finish reveals the hops for the first time and leaves the drinker very pleased.  This is an excellent beer and my personal standard for porters.  Im so glad Stone has made this so widely available.

Rich dark black color with a tan fluffy dense head. Aroma is sweet, smokey, peat, some nice roasted malts and burnt caramel. Flavor is nice and smooth. Great level of smoke but not meaty. Roasted malts, bitter coffee and dark bittersweet cocoa. Always consistent and flavorful.

Dark, nearly black pour with a small tan head. Aroma is malt, sweet dark fruit, and a little smoke. Flavor is a little sweet, malty, dark chocolate, and a slightly bitter finish. Not my favorite style, thus the only above average rating.
It would be great with a cigar.

Aroma: Smoke, oak, malt. 
Appearance: Dark opaque color, medium head fades to thin layer w/ decent lacing.
Taste: smokey, coffee malt, chocolate, touch of hoppyness
Palate: medium carbonation, creamy mouthfeel, lightly dry.
Overall: This is a really good beer, my favorite porter thus far. I love the smokeyness and balance of this beer. At $3.99 its an awesome value!

Growler. The quintessential smoked porter. Pours a dark, black hue with a full, beige head. Deep, rich aroma with strong roasted malt character. The taste follows in a similar vein: burnt malts and strong flavors of coffee and dark chocolate. Some mild hop bitterness. Silky mouthfeel and medium- to big-bodied. Aftertaste lingers for a while with that burnt malt flavor. Really good stuff.

Color is an almost black dark brown with a tan head.The aroma is a rosted coffee and chocolate.Flavor is dark chocolate, rosted coffee, a little smokyness with a hop bite.The finish is a little bitter.My favorite stone brew.

22oz bomber. Pours slightly-opaque black, long-lasting off-white head. Slight lacing (though my inappropriate glassware may have an impact on that...). Aroma is nicely smoked. Not over done though. Flavor: smoky, toasted malts, chocolate on the back end. Goes nicely with some dark chocolate. Overall: not a beer that separates itself from the pack, but simply exists as a good beer that can be enjoyed nicely from time to time.

A dark almost black pour with a coffee colored head.  Aroma is nice and malty with notes of chocolate.  Body is lighter and smooth.  The smoked character comes through with the malt with a slight bitter taste.  Smooth and flavorful with a light finish.

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Pours black with a beige head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, dark fruits. Nice. Good robust flavours of chocolate, smoke, licorice, caramel, coffee. Finishes smoky with a good hoppy bite. Tasty.

Draft at the Big Hunt in Dupont area, Washington DC

Light chocolate and coffee aroma.  Dark appearance with a light head.  Matly, semi-smoky taste.

I liked this porter, but it might not be my prefered type of porter - perhaps the Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter is better for me, or I need a desert to go with this Stone Smoke one.
Overall one of the best porters.  Smooth, wonderful flavor and aroma.  Rich and dark.

RnH:  share with Pwn3d... pretty much echo his words: "Dark brown/ black pour, leaving this beige head. Taste of tobacco, smoked malts, nutmeg, dark chocolate... thin, easily chug-able body, as per the style."

Hmmm, perhaps the first Stone beer that hasnt blown me away instantly. I mean yes its a good beer, but unfortunately nothing ground breaking. Although I will say I think its probably a little on the cool side, so I will wait for it to warm up a little, and then may re-rate. But for now: Looks pretty good in the glass, I think my 3 seems harsh, but I know how appetizing Stone beers can look, and this is about average for them Id say, so it rest on a 3 for that reason. Deep brown/red around the edges with very dark brown/black center, small creamy looking tan head. It has a lovely aroma but its a tad subdued. Theres vanilla, cream, wood chips, milk chocolate, mocha on the nose and a sort of earthy dustiness. Flavour is complex but quite subtle, which in a way is quite nice as it proves that Stone arent just about big expressions, though thats what I love them for. Lots of earthy smokiness, like ash or oak smoke, very tasty. This is definitely a beer that grows as it warms. There more vanilla and cream with more bitter notes like coffee and dark chocolate and then some quite fruity background flavours alo the lines of dark sultanas or prunes. Finish is very well balanced with a touch of sweetness but a definite bitter edge. Doesnt dry the palate out too much although the initial flavour is quite dry, but somehow through the mids into the finish a sweeter syrupy texture takes hold to balance everything out. All in all a very good beer that has everything I want but for some odd reason, just misses truly exciting me. I think on closer inspection the downfall maybe the texture/conditioning/carbonation. The beer could perhaps be creamier, theres a almost too present "fizzy" quality as it washes over my tongue... Look dont get me wrong its a great beer, but Im marking on a very high level here and for Stone this is what I would call a flag ship bench mark style of beer.

Nice smoked porter.  Pours dark black with amber hue and a nice frothy head.  Aroma has some coffee, toasted malt and a nice smokiness.  Plenty of coffee, chocolate and smokiness in the flavor as well.  I dont like this one as well as the Alaskan Smoked Porter, but still very good.
8th August 2008. On tap at GBBF. Lovely rich fruity porter. Chocolately, mellow mellow smoke. All very well joined up in to quite a sumptuous porter.

pours out clear black with a thin partially bubbly grayish beige head that settled rather fast.  the body is pretty black with no light penetration and no bubbles rising up that i can see.  the aromas are bitter chocolate with hints of smoke and dark roasted coffee beans.  i also smell peat, grass, malts, and some sugar with no real hoppy smell, but is still bitter to the nose.  it is medium bodied and finishes pretty dry.  i taste some smokey wood, coffee, chocolate and milk.  the carbonation is pretty smooth but still a little to much for the tongue for this style of beer.  the aftertaste is nicely sweet and sticks around very nicely for a little while and leaves a watery feeling on the tip of the tongue.  very enjoyable and this beer could be paired with a whole range of culinary dishes very well.

Bottle. Pours a beautiful deep, nearly opaque mahogany that light barely escapes. Atop it sits long-lasting tan head around a finger thick. Aroma is predominantly coffee and a little smoky. Flavor is a complex intermingling of bitter chocolate, coffee and smoked malts that linger on the palate for a while afterward. Quite good.

Dark, dark ruby color. Appears black at first. Nice easy pour produces a frickin huge head of dense tan foam, which has hellish retention. Will it ever go away? Wow. Impressive for sure, but almost too much. Lacing is nice and sticky.

Big chocolatey malts. A touch of smoke. Light hint of some hop spiciness. Hints of caramel and dark fruits. Big earthiness quality.
A fairly complex nose.

Big flavor of roasted malt. Underlying hint of smokiness, not nearly as much as I expected. Sweetness of vanilla and caramel. Nice earthy quality here, also. Very slight hops bite. Light chocolate and coffee notes. Hints of dark fruits.

Good solid medium boby. Good level of creaminess. 

This is an excellent porter, overall. I would drink many of these, and often, if given the opportunity.
Not as smoky as may have been expected, but a very good offering from Stone, nonetheless.

Bomber poured into a snifter; borderline viscous for a porter, nearly ink-black, quickly-developing thick white head that stays put forever. Nose is heavy with a mixture of dark fruits (blackberry?) and bitter coffee; touch of smoke. Tastes of strong dark chocolate, nearly burnt peat, with a touch of espresso on the palate. Finishes clean, but lingers in the sinuses. My new favorite porter.

Definitely "smokey" characteristics.  Nice looking dark ruby appearance with lacing.  Cant rate as one of my favorite porters.  Looking for some sweetness to balance the bitter smoked malts, but I can see how this might be appreciated by many tasters.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2010 A nice deep rich brown color with a creamy beige head. An earthy peat scent.  Has a fairly strong smoky peat flavor with tobacco undertones. Finishes with a medium bitter bite. I expected a stronger, bigger beer from the look of it. Kind of make me think of a beer made from garden soil and mulch. Not totally unpleasant beer but not one that I would recommend to friends.

Bottle.  Smoke and coffee dominate the scent.  Opaque black pour with a HUGE frothy head.  Taste is similar, black coffee with smoky undertones.  The smokiness isnt the main flavor, but it adds a nice background - you can taste it all the way through.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 Draft at the Brew House Grille in Camp Hill. Poured black in color with a thin tan head. Aroma of light smoke, chocolate. Tastes of smoked malts, chocolate, roasted coffee. Nice body.

On tap with rattle n hum with CUJO.   Pours very dark, near black.  Beige head atop.  Taste of tobacco, smoked malts, nutmeg, chocolate.  Call me crazy but, I find the palate on most porters a bit too thin.. this one is not an exception.
black pour with tanish head that seems to last, nose is smokey with some wood and some chocolate malt, taste is smokey but not overpowering, some chocolate and coffee, really like this smoked porter.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 this is one tasty brew but I dont detect a lot of smoke. loads of mellow chocolate, liqourice and roastiness.good body, good carbonation, good bitterness. Excellent but not smokey.btw,  a bit more head retention and apperance would have been a 5. 
Edit: I take the lack of smoke back. As it warms up it actually becomes quite smokey and more comlex,even better than at first sight!
(draught) pours dark ruby with lasting tan head. Nose is subtle of nuts, dried fruits and roasted malts. Taste Is smoky malt, very creamy, toasted raisins, and lingers with light bitter cocoa.

Enjoyed on tap in a pub glass.  The beer pours a very deep dark brown with a large and long-lasting tan head.  The subtle notes of the smoke in the aroma is initially very surprising, especially given the fact that I was expecting something closer to German rauchbiers.  Instead, there is a hint of smoke, while the quintessential roasted notes of roasted barley and chocolate malts come through.  The palate is full in flavor, very slightly smokey, and roasty without tasting like ash or charcoal.  High crystal malts, more roasted barley, and some milk to slightly dark chocolate.  The finish is nicely sweet, which helps to restrained the roasted flavors.  Overall, nicely crafted.

22 oz Bottle --  Pour black with a thick tan head.  Aromas of nutmeg, coffee, chocolate, caramel, and some smoke.  The smoke is much more pronounced in the flavor of the beer.  Large amounts of bitter chocolate and hops form a bitter back end that lasts and lasts.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle.
Appearance: Black with slight ruby highlights and a huge, creamy, light tan head.  Great head retention and great lacing.
Aroma: Pine hops, light caramel, soap, and a bit of smoke.  A much lighter nose than I was expecting.
Flavor: Bitter pine hops, licorice, and light fruit notes. A bit of chocolate emerges as the beer warms.  Kind of anticlimactic.  Good, but not great.
Palate: Medium-high carbonation with a medium-rich mouthfeel and a long bitter finish. 
Overall: Worth a try but I would call this one a bit overrated.  Take it or leave it.
Pours black with a thin head and a little lacing.  Faint smoked malt aroma.  Thin mouthfeel. Moderate amount of hop and dark malt bitterness.  Slightly dry finish.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

An exceedingly dark brownish-red that remains slightly transparent. Massive foamy head with major lacing.

Aroma of smoke, caramel and roasted malts, cherry.

Definitely can taste the smoke, almost a charbroiled taste. Slightly sweet chocolate malts and fruit are balanced by roasted malts and hop bitterness. Different facets of the taste shine more than others dependent on the temperature.

Low to moderate carbonation, medium body, quite smooth and dry on the finish.

Very flavorful porter that insists you keep drinking, although the flavor overload may eventually wear thin. One of the best porters I have had.

Pours dark black with a huge tan head.  The aroma is sweet chocolate and coffee with just an edge of smoke.  Bitter, earthy, light smoke and coffee.  Nice hint of sweet mid palate.  Finishes clean and not cloying.  Great by itself or with any smoked meats.
bomber.  Pours black with a large tan head.  Nose is of smoked meat.  Taste is of smoke and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin.

On tap at the porter tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 10/22/09. Dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Malty aroma with some bread, smoke and hops. Flavor is chocolate malt with a bit of apple and a smoky finish. Not overdone on the smoke, which is nice.

(Draught) Deep dark brown and clear. Medium sized white head. Smoke and roastedness in aroma. Full bodied palate with medium carbonation. Smoke, malts, roastedness, grilled sausage, bitterness and lightly coffee in taste. Bitterness and smoke in aftertaste. Nice one.
Yummy smoked porter that goes great with smoked meats. It does what it says right on the bottle.
22oz bottle.  Black with nice lacing.  Chocolate and licorice aroma.  Slight hint of smoke in the flavor, but finishes very smooth

22 oz. bomber.  Pours pitch black with two fingers of tan creamy head that laced the sides of the glass.  Roasted malt and a slight chocolate aroma.  Coffee, bitter chocolate, and smoked malt flavor with a sweet lingering aftertaste.  Full bodied with high level of carbonation.  This is a smooth easy to drink porter.
Tap @ Monster Bs. Best thing about this beer is its 2/3rds length tan lacing. Really pleasant to look at. Coffee flavor with marshmallow sweetness. Soft fluffy texture. Solid.
Great looking beer - dark brown with ruby highlights, creamy head. Taste is smoke, chocolate, and coffee. Solid beer drinkable and enjoyable.

For a guy that usually does not like the flavor of a porter, this was an eye opener. i was trying to find the right taste this one has and found it when i read the description, peat. its so unusual but really adds something new to the flavor to make it almost a smoked stout flavor. great porter that will have me trying new ones, thanks.
Appearance: pitch black. Small White head. Aroma: malt, chocolate, sour, oak. Flavour: lots of smoke, peat, chocolate, dark, like licking a brick of coal. Incredible.

22-oz bottle (NapaCabs.com) - Aroma: sweet, licorice / dried fruit, chocolate (malt); Flavor: sweet, salty, chocolate (malt), almond (smoke); Appearance: dark brown to black with tan head; Mouthfeel: full bodied, creamy-high carbonation; Overall: well balance of smoked and malt, full-bodied beer.

Bottle. 22 oz. Pours deep brown with a thick, tan head. Aroma of peper, smoked almonds, chocolate, roasted malt, and cinnamon. Full body with an outrageously heavy, smooth, spicy finish. Absolutely fantastic porter. Highly recommended.

1 pint 6 oz. bottle. Pours black, light-brown head that diminished quickly. Aroma is somewhat fruitty with a malty background. Roasted and Toasty flavors mix well with the fruitty aroma. Flavor is dominated by a heavely bitter catch thats lingering...Somewhat fizzy, and creamy...burnt, a burnt tang is present. Very Good.
Pint @ Taco Mac. Black with dark tan head. Robust, roasted profile with a nice smoky malt character. Deep and full-bodied with coffee and chocolate notes.

Bottle at Oliver Twist shared with Andreasen11 and plovmand.
Pours brown with a tiny light brown head. 
Aroma is roasted malt, hops, coffee and a hint of smoke. 
Flavour is roasted malt and coffee with a hint of tar.

08/10/2009. Clean, smoky, sweet, roasty. Really good beer, made well, and in great condition but it doesnt scream drink more of me.  Maybe its a shade too sweet... like the young girl you flirted with in your early twenties but never bothered to properly chase down.
dark brown pour with a big light brown head. coffee aroma, no real smoked aroma or taste. this is a good example of the porter style.

Large bottle.  What can I say, Stone knows how to craft a fine beer. This is a very drinkable porter. Big taste without the big alcohol. Chewy sweet malt with just a hint of smoke that becomes more noticeable as it warms.

A dark brown to black beer with a fast disappearing head. The aroma is roasted like close to charred malt, with a dash of smoke. The taste is very smooth with a somewhat roasted taste with some tar & a very slight smokey aftertaste that is akin to an ashy taste. The first time I had this I did not detect any smoke taste but on the second try as it warmed up it was noticeable. Would be good to drink outside in the cold next to a fire.

The Stone Smoked Porter poured a translucent brown with an amber hue. The off-white head was massive due to a very heavy pour. A very evident lace was left as the head receded.

The aroma was dominated by smoky malt. The taste was malty with a hint of spice and a smoky finish. For those of you who do not like smoked beers, be aware that as a smoked porter, there truly is not a lot of smokiness to this beer...for those of you love smoked beers you might be disappointed.

The mouthfeel is mediocre, not as creamy as I would have liked but with a nice carbonation that makes the beer quite drinkable. All in all an enjoyable brew.

Had this at the Great Lakes Brew Fest.  This porter was incredible, maybe one of the best porters Ive ever had.  The smokiness spreads out to the back of your throat in a coating manner.  Very very good beer, wish I could drink more often.
Tap at the Saucer.  Smoky, thick mouth feel. Nice coffee notes. Has the usual Stone punch.

Bottle at Oliver Twist. Dark brown body with a small off white head, Sweet malty aroma with notes of tobacco, caramel, light smoke and dark fruit. Flavour is light roasty with some peat, dakr fruit and bitter chocolate. Medium bodied.

bomber from total wine in norfolk. pours a dark, chestnut brown with a thick, tan head and great lacing. aroma is very nice big notes of smoke, wood, salt cured bacon, and roast with a touch of red fruit, coffee, and ash. flavor is excellent with huge roasted malts, smoked almonds, charred wood, and coffee up front with slight hints of tart, red fruit, chocolate, and toffee rounding out the sip leaving a dry, roasted finish. palate is medium bodied and very smooth with solid carbonation. overall, a damn good porter.
It poured a dark liquid with a small foam that left no lacing. It smelled sweet with chocolate, smoke and coffey. It tasted similar. Felt ok but not spectacular.
22 oz bottle at Isaac Newtons in Newtown Pa. Poured black as night.  Very smooth down the throat.  No lingering aftertaste.  Excellent porter.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2009 22 oz bottle.  Smoky aroma and flavor. Tastes a little like burnt coffee--thats good. Blacker than black, excellent flavor, excellent excellent excellent beer.  Fantastic example of the style.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2009 On tap at The Yard House (West Palm, FL): I think this is the best porter Ive had- and no surprise its from Stone. Chocolate, roasted malts, raisins, burnt marshmellow, rich toffee, smoky char lingers in the palatte... Perfectly balanced. Drinkability: Hells ya. Rebuy: :) #115 on 11092009, DG.

Dans Bachelor Party Extended Weekend Rating #13 of 90. Draft at Old Town in Fishers. Appears moderately dark brown/black with ruby edges and cookie sized tan head. Nose is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, minimal smoke. Flavors follow and blend very well. Excellent finish, very tasty.

Deep brown pour, almost reddish, with a thick tan head.  Sweet chocolate and roasted malt aroma.  Flavor is very chocolatey and roasted nut, well-balanced with hints of raisin and slight smokiness.  Finishes easy and slightly dry.

750 ml bottle.Pours black with a hint of red ,tan head.Mild smoke aroma with a good dose of roast and chocolate.Flavor, expectedly, continues in the same vain.Good roast and chocolate with mild smoke  .Medium body.Nice and easy going porter.

Let me start by saying I am not a big fan of Porters, but I am a fan of Stone Brewing Co. So I picked up the a bomber of Smoked Porter just to try it out.

And as usual Stone did not disappoint.

The beer poured a murky dark brown, with a smokey coffee aroma with just a hint of sweet malt.

Taste started with a sweet malt and a hint of heavy fruit, and was quickly taken over by the smoke and roasted malts. The finish was very clean and dry with the strong taste of roasted malts and hop bitterness.

Mouthfeel was good, and for a porter very drinkable.

For me one of the few porters I have truly enjoyed

22 oz bomber from Casanova.  Medium thick pour, black in color.  Smokey chocolate aroma.  Thick mouthfeel, hints of chocolate with a smokey coffee flavor and a smooth finish.  Very flavorful but surprisingly smooth.

On tap at the brewery after the tour. I have had this before but this one had more flavor. Dark black with a cocoa head. Smells smoky. This just tastes way too smoky for me, I wonder how they get the smoke flavor?? My cousins exact words were :"You cant hide behind your IPA forever!". Needless to say the Stone employees did not take a liking to us. I bet this would be better with the chipotle peppers or vanilla beans to temper that smokiness.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-04-2007 18:30:28

Dont know if it was the bottle or what, but I wasnt too impressed. It has a nice smooth flavor and is very drinkable, but is far from anything special or complex. I enjoyed it a lot more as it warmed and could more easily taste the alcohol and subtle smokiness.

Aged 18 months. Pours with a surisingly explosive head Ɠ/4 of the glass even when poured carefully? Jeez.). The beer part is a very dark brown/black that is slightly opaque on the edges. Aroma is sweet roasty malts, dark fruits, and some oxidation. Taste is most akin to a very fruity aged porter. The smoke has almost completely dropped out after a year and a half of aging. The faintest hint is still present. If this ages along the same curve as Alaskan Smoked Porter, then the smoke should come back around in about a year. It would be better balanced then. As it stands, this is way better fresh than Alaskan Smoked Porter, but the Alaskan has better ageability.
Strong coffee and roasty aromas. Pours dark black with a thin, but creamy head. Strong bitter coffee flavors. Very porterish mouthfeel that belies how thick it looks sitting in the glass.

This could very well be my favorite porter thus far.  It has a very subtle smokiness that adds a little to the complexity.  It is has a a mild chocolatey flavour that acts as its backbone but there are other elements (coffee, peatiness) that add to its complexity.  It has a great mouthfeel, (goes down very smooth)  I really enjoyed this one.
Bottle.  Pours a very dark black color with a good size tan head.  Smelled roasted and smokey.  Tastes of caramel, smoke and a little hopiness to it.

22oz bomber obtained at The Lighthouse in Manchester, Maine. Pours a virtually opaque black body with ruby-red highlights around the edges with a good half inch or so of light tan head. Smells roasty and slightly smoky. Tastes very roasty with some caramel malt sweetness, hints of citrus hops in the aftertaste, and undertones of smokiness. Rich full body with very moderate carbonation. This one is definitely a sipper, which is fine since the flavor lingers longer. One of the better porters Ive had for sure. Ill be sure to try and pair it with a pulled pork sandwich sometime...
Aroma is mostly malt; flavor is roasted malt with some coffee, and a slight buttery finish that I suppose is attributed to the smoke.

My first and only smoked porter as yet, and it was very nice.  Colour was rich and dark and a creamy, thick head.  Aroma not so strong, but what an interesting taste!  Malt, chocolate, and at the end of it all, the smoke.
Keg at the White Horses American Beer Festival 2009. A smoked toffee aroma but the flavours are completely overpowered by the chocolate. It was really like drinking a Yoo Hoo.
