Pump @ The white horse. This beer is awesome to me. Aroma is very complex, plenty of vanilla, cocoa beans, tobacco, some fruitiness, leathery, just an hint of smoke. Stunning. Flavour is complex as well, sweet balanced and warming. A beautiful beer.

[Tap] Pours a very dark brown color with a small tan head. Sweet and roasty aroma with some light smoke. Heavily roasted and burnt tasting caramel and molasses. Some smoke, but more of a burnt character. Slight astringency and below average mouthfeel. This is a pretty good beer, but it didnt seem to hold up to some of the better smoked beers.

Pours a dark brown with a red hue, and an off-white/ tan head. The aroma is sweet and roasted with hints of dark fruit and smoke. Taste is great, a full flavored porter with a good malt bill and balance of hops. There is a slight tobacco finish with the smoke. A great porter.

Bottle . A dark brown to black pour with a huge bubbly brown head , loads of sticky lacing left on the glass , light carbonation . Aroma of roasted malt , coco powder  and hints of smoke and coffee . Flavor is very good , a nice roast to the malt , some coffee and light hop bitterness, light chocolate sweetness , and just a hint of smoke at the end . Full body with a creamy mouthfeel . a nice malty smoky finish . very drinkable and quite sessionable . NIce job Stone .

Pours a deep amber-brown, not quite opaque but almost. Aroma is vague, but I can detect a little nuttiness and smokiness...the roasted malt comes through only after it has warmed up a little. Flavor: The smoke is the first thing out the gate, followed again by toasted malt, and then just a little coffee bean acidity. Creamy palate, but a little watery though. Overall, good minus.
Black/ Brown. Bottled Bomber. Beautiful thick tan.caramal head. rich flavor of coffee and smoked malts. well balanced finish. Almost oily palate.
UPDATED: OCT 14, 2009 Dark brown almost black pour with a light tan head. Very deep complex flavors. Good stuff! Will get more tomorrow!

Nice attractive pour.  Mostly clear brown body with a sufficient khaki head.  Scents of caramel, cola, fruit, and peat.  Flavor starts out a bit thin and watery.  However, as this warms up, the flavors seem to come out a little more.  I was expecting more, but this ended up being decent for the style.  In my mind, this still doesnt hold a candle to Alaskan Smoked Porter or Left Hand Smokejumper.
Drank it with my wife and brother last nite, combined with Oaxaca dark chocolate.  Up my alley, nice notes of chocolate and smoke, perfectly balances with some smokiness.

A friend of mne said it was liking drinking bacon from a bottle.  I dont know about that, but it is robust, smoky, and quite meaty somehow.  Roasty, and slightly hoppy, but not too intense for a porter.  Smoky flavor dominates, but its not one-dimensional.  Really interesting selection.
Pours a dark brown with tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, smokyness.  Similar taste, with pleasant hop finish.  A well balanced porter.

Pours dark brown with ruby edges and a thick tan head that is creamy and lasts. Aroma is chocolate, light smoke and dark fruit. Initially smoked flavor is strong but then dulls once all the malt sweetness kicks in, also ripe fruit and coffee notes. Silky smooth and delicious.

Overall Impression: 
A really tasty and enjoyable porter, dark, almost black color.  Smokey and roasted.  Yummy.  You cant help but enjoy this one...
Excellent beer from one of my favorite breweries. Very drinkable and smooth.
UPDATED: OCT 30, 2010 A very nice porter. Pours almost black, with a thin tan head. Smoky with a hint of burnt semi-sweet chocolate. Not particularly sweet. All in all a thumbs up.

Pours an opaque dark brown with a medium brown head.  Very attractive looking.  Smells of a woody smoke, a bit of dark chocolate.  A perfect bit of hops.  Flavor is of a bit of smoke n BBQ.  Malt and Hops are well balanced and fused together into one beer taste.  Very Good.  Thanks again Stone!
poured black with little white head that faded quickly.  smelled of coffee, chocolate, and smokiness.  taste is very smokey at the beginning and fades quickly.

Blind tasted - Real surprised when I pulled the brown paper bag off this baby, because I figured the smoke would be more noticeable. Instead, I got just a whiff of smoke on the nose, with some roast and malt. Taste was bitter chocolatey roast and a little burnt wood. Just a touch of that smoke, too. Its medium and creamy--real nice in the mouth, but there wasnt anything that stood out about this beer.

bomber from a trade with scrizzz. pours dark brown with red highlights. thick tan head laces nicely. huge roasted malt aroma with a hint of smoke. huge and in your face. the flavour starts with roasted malt leading to a hint of smoke and a hoppy finish. hoppier then i thought it would be and not really that much smoke. really big for a 5.9% beer. wonderful porter all around. thx clint!

ALMOST BLACK BEER WITH THIN CREAMY HEAD AND MILD SMOKEY AROMA ALMOST TASTES LIKE A  GUINESS WITH A SUBTLY BURNT MALT FLAVOR , HINT OF RICH COFFEE AND LITTLE MORE LICORICE ESSENCE EXCELLENT BEER GREAT STRAIGHT UP OR WITH DINNER OR EVEN DESERT.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2010 Bottle at home ... From Beer of Europe ... deep brown red .. thin tan head ... milky roast malt ... very soft ... creamy light smokey malts ... little chocolate .. little toffee ... just a touch too much sweet milk sugers that take the edge off this one .?. bottle muu ... little over fizzy ... dark brown... thin light tan head ... light roast liitle chocolate malt nose ... nice soft roast 3.6

Ahh, boy do I love a good porter, and this one doesnt disappoint. Right from the get go the smoked presence lifts to the nostrils followed by a pleasant chocolately coffee bean facade. This brew pours an opaque black that one friend said "looks like molasses," with a delicate, stout-like dark brown head. While Stone prides the Element part of the smoked malt, I would prefer a bit heavier smoked presence, after all it is a smoked porter. The body is the only region where this beer struggles, as it seems to carry a bit too much water, undoubtedly unusual for a Stone. Regardless, this brew is worthy of your attention, and your tastebuds. CP NOTE: Not nearly as smoky as a Rauchbier, and a PB and J really does go great with this one!

bottle, pours dark brown, tall tan head.  Aroma of vanilla and cinnamon, with some roasted malt.  Suprisingly lighter bodied, some roasted malt and sweet malt ends with a light smoke flavor that lingers with some hop bitterness.  Nice and easy to drink, I wish there was more smoke.

Pours a dark brown, nearly black, with off-brown head. Aromas of roasted burnt malts, and chocolate. Flavors included roasted malt(little nutty), strong chocolate with some coffee, finishes with a sweet peaty oak that lingers.

22 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market Charlottesville, VA. Pours a clear dark red color with a medium head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma is chocolate and very light smoke and roast. Taste is caramel, roasted malts, coffee, tea and very faint tobacco-ish smoky notes. Medium bodied.

Bottle.  Pours a great thick black, tan head.  The head is not huge, but definitely gets the job done.  The flavors are great, the smokiness balances the sweet chocolate and the coffee is a nice back note.  There are also of course some great malty flavors.  Finish is very dry, overall balance is fantastic.

On tap @ McGraths.  Pours a pitch black with a nicely lacing tan head.  Smoky, roasted malt aroma, some hints of cola; a little boozy.  Coffee, roasted malt, and marshmallow flavors; dry finish.  Great.

Bottle.  Black pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma is roasted with some chocolate, rather nice.  Flavor is more of the same, a nice chocolate base with that smoked presence coming through.  Very good overall.

Mildly smoky aroma with hints of chocolate... Dark brown in color... Flavor is malty with hints of caramel, smoked malts, dark chocolate and hints of coffee on the palate... Not bad depiction, but Ive brewed better.

On tap at Stone.  Dark brown with brown highlights.  Creamy tan head.  Sweet chocolaty and bitter coffe nose.  Taste is actually refreshing with even mixtures of malt, cocoa, coffee, and even hops.  Palate is not overpowering.  Like this beer.

Pours dark brown with a significant tan head.  The head of the aroma is sweet, but deeper down there are hints of bitter chocolate and smoke (as one would expect).  The flavor is creamy bitter chocolate and hops with a slight hint of smoke.  The taste is not at all overpowering, and the beer feels very smooth in the mouth.  My only real complaint about the flavor of this beer is that it may be a little sweet for my taste.

The first thing that hits you as you open is that trademark Stone hoppiness, wow! Im not a big hophead so was a little apprehensive. Pours a very nice, deep brown with creamy head. Quite appealing.

The smokiness was not apparent at first, but as I sipped the hoppiness gave way to a subtle smoke. Im not a porter aficionado so I have nothing for comparison. This seems spot on for my tastes though. Not overpowering, very balanced.

Tasty roasted malt ending with an almost inconspicuous smokiness. Hops still present but as an "also-ran" that doesnt intrude. Slightly sweet and simple. Flows a bit thinner over the tongue than I thought. I expected a bit more density, but again Im not porter savvy.

5.9% makes this a winner for drinkability and would go extremely well at a backyard barbecue. Would make an excellent gateway for those that think craft beer is only about extremes. A pleasure.

22 oz bottle from Rays.  Pours nearly black with a two-finger tan head that slowly fades to a thin rim.  Aroma is an interesting mix of roasted malt, chocolate, spices (oregano?), and of course smoked malt.  Flavor is much the same with quite a bit of spiciness and a tiny bit of noticeable hops in the finish.  The smokiness is a nice touch and not overpowering at all.  The beer tastes like a delicious smoked piece of beef.  Nice.

bottle: pours really dark with medium-thin tan head.  medium-thin body, but full of well balanced flavor: smoky coffee and chocolate over tones.  My first porter and Im liking it, but aroma is a little disappointingly absent.

Was not sure what I was going to be getting from thsi beer. Is it a porter or a rauchbier? A darkbrown pour that collects into a blacker color in the glass with respectable head. Some seet ness on the nose is overridden by a taste of chocolate and coffee so bitter it is almost burnt. I used this as a replacement for espresso after I had dinner. The palate is thin enough for this to be one of the wide spread releses from stone and is easily enjoyed by most. The bitterness might have been a bit much for some though.

22 oz. bottle from Total Wine (Enjoy by 7/23/2009).  Cola-like pour with a creamy beige head.  Slightly smoky flavor with more dominating semi-sweet chocolate, a hint of coffee, and a faint note of grassy hops.  Smoky malt flavor with a slight hop bitterness.  Surprisingly thin even for a porter (certainly not rich like the description says).  This is a very good porter but the body leaves me wanting a bit more.

so good, like every stone beer i have had
the beers aroma was mostly coffee and hinted very subtly at chocolate
the taste imo was very complex and amazing, strong coffee flavors with hints of chocolate and caramel which is very nicely ballanced by hoppy bitterness
will definitely drink again 
very thick but not syrupy on the palate

Raisins and brown sugar on the nose, not strong. Clear dark cola colored, thin beige head, very minimal lacing. Smoky, charred oak and blackberry flavor with grass and coffee at midpalate. Charcoal and lemon grass finish. Interesting complexity, good transitions, and decent balance. Thinish mouthfeel that works for me. It tastes phenolic at times when warm. It sure beats the smoky overkill in rauchbiers.
Bottle.  Not much head or aroma.  tasty with smoky toffee flavor.  Not my favorite Porter in the world but certainly not bad.  Especially since its stocked at my grocery store.

Great malty profile with hints of fruit toffee cocoa and java - comforting detailed aromas. Am drinking this warm so the sweetness will crisp up with cooling. The roast, smoke and hops are just a nice edge to balance the sweetness. Excellent! Loving Stone beers.

Pours a deep mocha brown with a red tinge and thick, fizzy off-white head. Aroma of mocha and a bit of malt. I dont really get a smoke taste anywhere, but there are some good hints of dark chocolate and roasted pistachio. Moderate body for a porter. A bit more alcohol finish as it warms. This is very good.

Compared to others in its class (Smoke Jumper, Alaskan Smoked Porter, etc.), this one just doesnt quite stand up.  Still tasty...but more mild and easy on the palate.  Dark mahogany pour with a fluffy latte head that left some lacing.  A bit thin leaving the bottle and in the mouth.  Chocolate, caramel, and a hint of smoke/pulled pork.  Good, unfortunately not great.

Pours a rich, dark brown.  Aroma is strong of smoke and dark malts.  Notes of chocolate and caramel stand out as well.  On the palate it is smooth and creamy.  The taste is really stong in smoke.  The finish is a bit dry leaving an after taste of sweet burnt malts and smoke.  A little too much smoke for me, but still alright.  I could not drink more than one in an evening.
I really enjoyed this beer.  Very dark color, thick head that lingers as it should.  Aroma of coffee, a hint of chocolate, lots of malts.  A smoky flavor that was not too overpowering.  Very good.
UPDATED: OCT 17, 2009 Much more of a subtle taste this time around, now that I am more used to smoked beers.  More appealing, definitely.

Maybe I am spoiled by other brews, but this was pretty disheartening. No smoked flavor to be had, very thin body and thinner flavor. Malt/toast flavor, hint of alcohol warmth, and then, gone..... Bah! Perhaps it didnt get a chance to fully warm, but I tried to give it a proper chance.
Sampled at Rozis Wine & Liquor, Stone Tasting Event, Lakewood, OH.

Sample at Rozis Wine House at Stone Brewing Co. event.  Red brown appearance, thinner pour than their Russian Imperial Stout (2006) with lighter tan head.  First sip was almost nothing/water then a small hint of the smokey taste and at the finish a kick at the back of the throat.  Not greatly impressive, I felt this was a pretty average porter.
My least favorite of the Stone lineup.  I will give it another chance though, this was number 40 on my beerfest trek.

Aroma of smoked gouda (subtle) and chocolate malt.  Taste is chocolatey/coffee with a subtle smokiness - not too overpowering.  A high carbonated finish and grainy aftertaste with hints of coffee and smoke in the palate.

Deep brown-black color, a thin consistent head with a little lacing. Smoky malty sweetness in the aroma. Chocolate and coffee show up along with the smoky malt in the flavor, just as Stone describes it. Finishes very smooth and comfortably dry. Pretty tasty.

In addition to the flavors listed in the description I also caught some subtle tobacco flavor.  

I love this beer.  Another solid contribution from Stone!

Thanks Daknole. Dark cola-brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and some sweetness. Smokey taste hits you first as you sip the beer. Then you get the roasted malt and a little sweetness. Dry aftertaste. Very nice balanced beer. Nice lacing.

HEAVY smoke flavor.  Not enjoyable... forced it down and poured some down the drain.  Ive had other smoked beers, and I have to admit im not a fan... lighter on the smoke than some, but still very overpowering... smokey bacon bitter hops... not for me.
Little smoked taste. Good taste of coffee notes and chocolate.  Very smooth.  Wonderful pour. Dark with a lite brown/white head.  Wonderful overall porter for a non drinking porter guy!

Bottle poured into an English pint.  SSP pours very dark brown with a nicely sized head that settle pretty quickly.  The aroma is mild with malt and faint wood smoke showing through.  The body on this bad boy is more reminiscent of a stout than a porter, being thick and chewy.  The carbonation is slightly elevated in this beer but not to its detriment.  The hops dont peak out, they JUMP out at you and take you by surprise for the style.  The smokiness adds a great level of complexity without overshadowing the burnt malts, and sweet chocolate.  I give this one two thumbs up.

smells like a campfire or burning cedar mixed with a mild sweet odor. is a very dark, somewhat translucent brown with beige head. tastes fairly sweet and has a very intense smoky flavor, imagine the comment i made about a campfire, then imagine eating that campfire. feels very thin in my mouth though, which is a bit of a disappointment i like my porters and stouts to have a little thicker viscosity. pretty good nonetheless.

A great looking beer, pours almost like a Guinness...my goodness!  Needs to be  accompanied with a T-bone steak.  Pretty overwhelming smokiness mid-palate, but it has a smooth finish.  Dont know why such a good brewery is in San Diego, I lived there for 3 years, and almost everybody drinks heineken or corona, heathens.  However, I have always got good head in SD ;)  Buy it at World Market, and save $2.

(bottle from Powers Liquor Mart in Colorado Springs). Pours a black color. Medium size tan head. Light smoky aroma. Malty and smoky flavor. Avg duration. Slightly astringent finish. Watery texture. Fair lacing. Moderate carbonation.

22oz bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black body with some red tints around the edges. Thick and foamy, two-finger width, light brown colored head that dissipates slowly and leaves a lot of nice layered lacing. Solid aroma with lots of sweet brown malts and a nice fruity, soft roasty smell. Smokey, but more like a honey ham smoke than straight up smoked ham. It definitely accompanies the rest of the beer. Some sweet chocolates and licorice with just a splash of coffee. Flavor is very similar. Sweet malts and dry backing of roast and smoke. Initially a lot of sweet caramels and fruity malts with a slow developing hop bitterness. Some chocolates come in as well as more dark fruits before the smoke and roast come in to completely dry this sucka out. Not a big aftertaste, but a solid echo of chocolate, caramel, and smoke. Palate is soft, very balanced, and medium bodied. Overall, a damn good beer. Solid all around. Not a very intense hoppy/roasty porter, but I love when smoked beers have balance like this and the smoke accompanies the flavors rather than dominating them. Excellent.

Very dark, with a bittersweet chocolate color. The light beige head is thin but long lasting.

Dark sweet malts are the primary aroma to this beer. Theres a chaulkiness to the smell. Any hop takes a back seat to the chocolate malt. Surprisingly, there is little smokiness to the aroma. 

First impression is the fullness of the body--more than would normally be expected. Chocolate malt is the predominant flavoring. That said, there is a soft hop balance that lingers in the aftertaste. The "smoke" appears in the swallow, briefly. 

This is another complex and interesting beer from Stone. I dont rank it as high as some of their other beers, but it is certainly superior to many of the available porters.
Bottle from local shop. Poured very deep brown with foamy yellow head. Very earthy smoke flavor. Slightly sweet malty finish, almost like a cola.
From a bottle poured dark brown with a good amount of head.  Nice smokey malty flavor with a lasting finish.

Tried this in the past and seem to recall enjoying it more, not sure quite why. As advertised, its chocolaty and slightly smoky. Seems to have a thick, sticky mouthfeel and is a bit weak. (Of course, my palate has already been violated by a Ruination, so that might be affecting my rating.)

Bottle @ BA Järntorget. Pours reddish brown with thin white head. Looks pretty light and pale. The aroma is small and soft. Vanilla, caramelly and fudgelike. 

Weak body. Low hops, and leaning on a grainy, caramelly malt base. Almost no smoke flavor. Dry finish.

The tamest brew Ive had from Stone thus far.  Pours dark with a thin head,  has a wonderfully sweet smokey aroma.  Taste is initially sweet with a slightly bitter end.  Very good brew for after dinner or smoking a cigar.

Pours a little darker than cola.  Off white head thins down slightly but stays on the glass until the beer is gone.  Citrus hops, roast, and a hint of smoke in the nose.  Flavor is complex.  Its got a mild sweetness with roasted malt, a bit of bitterness, a little smoke and alcohol.  I would have liked a little more mouthfeel, but this is fine as-is.  Theres just enough body to let the flavors linger.

Very dark pour. Wonderfully sweet aroma with smoky hints. Fantastic taste, malty and full of life with an ashy finish. Had the aftertaste retained a bit more of its sweetness, this would have been a solid 10. Nevertheless, solid through and through.

Very nice, with the smoke very much in the background.  Really just enough to keep things interesting.  Borderline stout, as it is pitch black and pretty smooth.  

Not really a SMOKED porter, but a smoked PORTER.  It does tie the room together though.

I bought this hoping for a rauchbier not an element of the character....ah well it was still a good beer but i cant help being disappointed a little bit....overall impression..smooth with a capital smoo!

nose of sweet malt, nearly oats.  smoke is currently only a background element. flavor of lightly salted smoke but not the pronounced bacon found in some smoked beers.  sweet roast and even some hops. some essence of cola as well. smoke somehow seems to affect yeast character with slightly off aromas and an odd aftertaste.  this needs to be a bigger beer to be more successful with this kind of roast, smoke nonwithstanding.
Amazing  balance in this fantastic beer. Rich and sweet with a smoky, earthy, almost moleasses feel.

Pitch black with a creamy tan head.  Sweet chocolate malt aromas abound. Smooth and not too smoky with a balanced bitterness. Strong chocolate and dark fruit flavors which accentuate the smokiness and complexity.
Pours very dark black with a decent head.  Smells of roasted malts, some chocolate, and smoke.  The taste is virtually identical, with some coffee hints (from the roasted malts).  Very nice beer.
pours black, nice creamy head, smell is smokey, piney,  it has a nice smokey chocolate, coffee tast, overall a nice beer

Bottle. Extremely dark red/brown body with a one finger brown head, which lasted the duration of the beer. Smoky and sweet aroma, like a good brisket, as well as nicotine, hickory, oak smoke, and earthy dirt notes. Creamy yet fizzy mouth feel.
I love to cook with this. Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate. Some meat flavor with a hint of chocolate. Good for chili.
Solid porter with good amounts of smooth roasted malt flavor. not enough smoky flavor in my opinion, but great porter regardless.
Nice layed back brew by Stone, subtile smokeyness and nicely light roasted flavours and caramell. Not very inventive or original but really drinkable and well balanced.
Bottle. The Rover. Gothenburg. Dark brown colour with a light brown head. Lightly smoky, malty, coffee, chocolate, dark bread, smoked ham. Very subtle for a Stone beer.

pours black with small tan head. aroma is really rich smokey malts and coffee pushing through. thinner then i expected, but drinks nice and full. subtle hops, smoked coffee, and a little chocolate round out this great smoked porter. finishes clean with short lasting after taste.

Pours a non-opaque black with two-finger tan head that dissipates fairly quickly.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of smokey coffee, some hops.  Light body, with medium low carbonation.  Taste is slightly smokey, maybe a little chocolate?  Lacking complexity.  Not as full bodied as I expected, a little disappointed.  Good thing I only paid $4.50 for a bomber.

If you thief any of TCs fuckin beats, right
We will send round the most murkiest murkmen from Murkton
On a Monday, which is a murky day

Its the rough-rugged, ever-ready raw-core classic
Deep black with large tan head. Aroma was smoke,spice,roast and malt. Flavor as all of that and dark chocolate. Rich, smooth and complex.

From a 22 oz bottle purchased locally poured into a 0.5 L glass. Aroma is roasty chocolate with some peat coming through. Deep dark brown with ruby barely peeking through, almost black with a big rocky tan head. Dry, roasty dark chocolate flavor with the smoke in the background, not overpowering. Evenly balanced with hop bitterness making it smooth and easy drinking.
22 oz bottle.  One of my favorite porters.  smoked, chocolate.  nice head!

Poured a deep black with a thick lasting tan head. Good lacing. Aroma is rough and seems to be confused by itself though it is no indication of the rest of the beers qualities. Once the beer enters the mouth a harmonious blend of chocolate, coffee, sweet toffee, figs, and smoke. I was expecting a smokier beer such as alaskan but was very impressed by the balance achieved in this beer. Mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy with a subtle bitterness that cuts through the sweetness.

Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, smoked peated malts,and some coffee.The taste of the peated malts hits you first, then the lovely roasted malts follows along with some coffee flavor peeking through as well. This brew has a wonderful smokey aftertaste as well. What a great Porter!

Bottle. Poured black with a creamy tan head that settled to a ring and left light lace. Hoppy aroma with a light smoked malt background. The flavor found chocolate, coffee, and a s decent smoke backing. Medium body and a coffee bitterness throughout.

As I pour most of the contents of my 220oz bomber into my awaiting glass, a deep earthen black-brown body greets my eyes while a soft tan head crowns and then fades into a thin film. Sticky lace mark her trail while a bouquet of smoke and wood waits for no one, rushing out to invite me in for a much closer encounter. Faint licorice, dates, chocolate and light notes of bitter espresso mingle amidst the smoke and wood. Mouth watering, I savor our first of many quaffs together which are surprisingly clean with a medium-bodied airiness. Wood and smoke pervades every beery pore, while subtle notes of soft milk chocolate, licorice, cream, and raisins keep her true to her porter roots. Faint bitter hops nips at her pleasantly dry finish. Each quaff is a rich bouquet of delicate smoked wood with nibs of chocolate, cream, and dark fruits passing through. Thankfully the smoke is not overwhelming, which would only serve to smother the beer and my palate. Instead, my Stone Smoked Porter has achieved a perfect balance of smoke and beer, in this case a porter. As she warms, more soft chocolate and coffee notes mingle amicably with the smoke and wood when suddenly, without warning, I find my glass empty.


A 22oz bottle of Smoked Porter sounds like a lot, but instead she is just the right amount. I could and did easily enjoy every single quaff of her smoky porter depths. Im not sure how long she would age before the freshness of the smoke would start to subside, but maybe someday Ill experiment and find out. In the meantime, I am going to enjoy as much fresh Stone Smoked Porter as I can possible fit in my fridge.

Pours to a high foamy head, dissolves well to leave a webby film.  Slightly smoky aroma, but not too strong.  Nice and dark.  Dont fast too much of the chocolate, almost more like a dark hazelnut,  good malty mouthfeel.  Not too much movement on the palate, but a decent finish.  Good stuff.

Bottle.. Poured into a snifter. Light black in color that lets some light come through. Nice smoke, fire place aroma on the nose. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate and just a touch of smoke. None of the flavors dominate the others. Very well balanced. Nice creamy smooth texture. A little on the thin side. The commercial description describes this beer to the "T". Oveall a good example of a smoked porter.

Eye-wateringly expensive bottle at The Penguins Arms. Handsome jet pour collared with beige, collapsing to a marbled slick in swigs. Nose notably soft and lactic; mellow in the hop department with soap and blackcurrant but mostly milk chocolate, walnut, vegetal locust bean notes, alcohol, prune at a push. Caramel and soft casky tones in there. Sweet and lactic like a Belgian dubbel, but not especially porter-like and certainly not smoked or even roasty. A typical English mild of half the strength is charred to a cinder compared to this. Thick black milk with barely a tickle of fizz, luxurious creaminess; soapy alkaline licks. Slippery, heavy and a bit tiring after half a bottle, Considerably less hop and malt excitement than I was expecting. Chocolate, milky coffee, caramel and oak creaminess; wood, slate and boredom. Overall impression: dull and silky like Chimay, drank over a pint and hardly noticed.

Pours a nice head.  Nice mouthfeel.  Good flavor balance, except the smokiness is more than Id like and while it doesnt overwhelm, it sort of upstages the rest of the flavors.

Its good, but not exceptional.

You know how Porters and Stouts get better as they warm? Well, I finished mine about 3 hours ago and I am still waiting for it to get better. I didnt taste anything that set this apart from any other porter I have had, even the smokiness requires a little imagination to pin down. If this was a Brown Ale, it may kick ass, but for the style Id rather go Baltik. $9 per 22oz bottle at Abraxas, Miami Beach

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown color with a small beige head.  The aroma is  caramel, mocha, smoke, and some char.  The flavor is roasted malt, caramel, light coffee, and smoke.  Medium mouthfeel, smmoth drinking.  A very good offering from Stone.  I think by itself this one does very well.  When it is tasted side by side with the Alaskan, it seems to be weaker in almost every category.

Beautiful dark golden brown with a small creamy head that holds at .5 inches pretty well. Aroma is a touch of smoke, wood, raisins, and ashtray. Taste is tar, ashy, smokey, woody and a little coffee. Strong bitterness in the finish. Kind of light bodied. This could use a touch more sweetness to balance it out in my opinion.

Bottle from Total Wine. Pours a raven black color and no head. The nose is rich with roasty toffee and smokey wood chips. Flavors produce notes of coffee, more toffee, subtle fired wood, dark fruits, grains, subtle bitter hops, and more smoke in the finish. Medium carbonation and medium/full body. Great porter; smooth and easy-drinking.

Bottle  Pours a deep almost black with a big tan creamy head.  The head lasts pretty well.  Has a very subtle aroma of caramel, and a smokey burntness.  Has a slightly mustiness about it.  Has a very mild taste.  Definetly can feel the smoked part.  Nice mouthfeel , low carbination and a touch watery.  Blending is fairly good.  Lacks some depth but is a pretty good beer.

22oz. bottle from Willow Bend Liquors in Lutz, FL. Pours a dark brown with a decent tan head. Aroma is nice woody, caramel, nuttiness. Great smoky, burnt wood, and black coffee flavor. Nice smoky/wood aftertaste. Really smooth. Medium mouthfeel. This is a really good porter...I love the smoky/woody features. Actually reminds me alot of Lost Coast 8 Ball Stout.

2009 Bottle - Pours a thin dk brown with a lasting creme head...aroma is dark malty fruit and a bit of wood...flavour is the same with a hit of smoke...it comes across a bit thin however, but is still pretty nice overall...
A rather good porter with a bit of smokey flavor.  Hints of chocolate, licorice, some dark fruit.  Very enjoyable.
Overall a nice smokey flavor not too overpowering.  A little weak on the palate kind of watery.  If you like bbq you will love this beer.  Enjoy with food cause it needs some bread or crackers.

Quite good. I enjoyed this fresh brew,after keeping it at my cupboard , more or less warm weather here in my town which is in the middle of the desert however, i think this one has to be cooled before opening coz the taste its quite heavy when warm,some toffee,coffee,chocolate,average look for porter,quite nice and drinkable body,and very liquid not oilly for the style,beige abundant quick-fading bubbles for head.Good

A truly nice and dark  smoked beer.  Has hints of coffee, chocolate, nuts, and something sweet.  This tastes really good for a smoked porter.  Not too carbonated, and has a smooth nutty, coffee flavor.  This is kind of similar to a light Old Rasputin.   An unbelievable smoked flavor in the end.  Makes me wish that it was warmer outside so that I can do some barbecuing.

Nose of caramel, chocolate and smoke, light roast and coffee. Deep chocolate, close to black but not quite there, off white and dissappating head. Medium body, little light on the palate. Smokiness in the flavor very subdued, caramel and light chocolate are in the forefront, with light molasses, coffee, toast, and hints of dried fruit esters.  Finishes on the sweet rather than dry end.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2010 22oz bomber.   $4.99 at Total Wine.    Dark brown Beer with a small tan head.  Smoky malt aroma.  Flavor is rich and full with roasty coffee, chocolate, and smoky dark malt.   A bit of hops in the background.   Low carbonation, just right.  Smooth and creamy, full mouthfeel.  A solid, if not spectacular porter. ..  . 12/12/2010 .  .  Pint on tap at Intuition Ale Works.   Really smooth and drinkable.   Very nice, tasty, but not amazing.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2016 re-rate 9/16....7 years after first rate; increased from 2.7.   I think I was an idiot in 2007.  very good porter; not sure I got much smoke but plenty of taste; ash, chocolate, malt, balanced. niiiiiiice........................................ smell nor tast much if any smoke.

Not bad, but not flavorful or special

On tap at The Beechtree.  Pours an almost jet black with a touch of crimson at the edges of the pint.  Tanned head that vanishes rather quickly.   Coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, but nothing more prominent than the smoke, which while strong, doesnt overpower.  Body is a little thinner than Id like, but the luscious smoke more than makes up for it.  Finishes with a light bitter.
Easily the meh-est smoked anything Ive tasted.  Very boring aroma, and only slightly smoky.  Flavor was barely smoky at all.  Hopefully got a poor one, and spent way too much on it : (

I heart smoked porters and this one is run of the mill, which is to say excellent.  Not quite Smokestack Heritage, but that may be the difference in freshness.  If you like smoked porters, youll like this one of course.
Tap in the Rake. Alround rating: Chocolate and coffee are the base, smokey burntess speeds up and burns you, some spicey bitterness tickles you later.
Taste 2/9 Bottle.  Looks: Deep black body with a 1/2 inch thick tan foam. Aroma: Smoke, toasted and roasted malt. Taste: Smoke, bacon. Nice medium body, creamy with a good spice.

Very dark, almost black pour with a thin lasting tan head.  I have a cold, so I will just assume the aroma matches the flavor.  The flavor is very chocolaty with coffee and malt bringing up the rear.  The smokiness is very noticeable, but not dominant.  All in all this porter is very balanced.  There is no wateriness to the flavor or the feel, which is a welcome change from some other porters I have had recently.  I am very happy with this one.

Good, but not as good as other Stone beers in my opinion. Appearance is excellent dark brown with an off-white head and aroma is smoky. Flavor is coffee, chocolate malt, and smoke. The smoke is not as well done as in other porters (Alaskan for example) and lingers a little too long. Dont get me wrong, I wouldnt refuse this stuff, but I wouldnt blow a homeless guy for it (actually I wouldnt do that for any beer).

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 Bottle at Ashleys in Ann Arbor.  Excellent Porter.  Pours a thin, black, with little head which dissipates.  Nice touch of sweet malt taste and oatmeal nutty.  A heavy porter, brings lots of taste, not watered down, but cleans clean and quickly.

A- Pours an opaque black with tinges of dark brown highlights, head is big, thick, foamy and tan, big thick lacing throughout... superb
S- Aroma is dominated by a mix of chocolate and coffee malts, wonderfully balanced with a hint of good old Stone hops in the background, smoked hues abound along with some woody/cedar/roasty tones
T- Initial taste is rich and creamy coffee-forward malts backed by some cocoa tones all dominated by that wonderful smoky presence, some dark fruits (fig, plum) come in soon followed by a slight bitter hoppiness which characterizes the short, sweet finish
M- Fairly medium-bodied porter, very creamy mouthfeel and a perfect amount of carbonation
D- Easy drinking porter at 6% with very well-masked alcohol presence, easily a session beer that is wonderfully delicious and complex. I am not a huge porter fan, but Stone Smoked Porter is simply the best of this category and one of the top beers I have ever reviewed, do not hesitate to have several bottles readily available for BBQ or meat-intensive dinners, and be sure to grab the special Porter with chipotle peppers whenever it is available at Ston

Pours very dark brown with a couple of fingers of light tan head. Roasted malt heavy aroma, with some chocolate and smokiness. Nice mocha flavor, with some dried fruit and dry smokey finish.  Chose this beer to celebrate the adoption of my new dog, aptly renamed "Porter".
Dark pour with medium tan head.  Had a very sweet aroma of malt, chocolate, and light smoke.  Flavor was again real sweet with a bit more smoke that blended well with a light fruity note.  Good brew.

Bottle from a box ordered from Beers of Europe, consumed and shared with Loz 31-01-09   Pours dark brown with a tan head. There is a nice smokiness (as you would expect) that is immediately present on the nose and then in the mouth. There are some burnt malts, its a little fruity but surprisingly I find this just a touch thin, its nice but just a little bit lacking somewhere.  A6 A4 F6 P3 OV13  3.2

Dark reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is spicy cachou sweetness with a seaweed background. Taste is leathery, mocha soaked cardboard, with full cream or perhaps evaporated milk just on the turn. Gentle woodsmoke finish with a slight dryness. Complex and interesting, if not entirely to my taste.

22oz bottle, dark brown color, with a creamy tan-colored, leaving laces, toasty, caramel, mild roasted malt, fruity, light smoky nose, with some hints of black coffee, dark chocolate, with a sweet molasses accent, and a peaty aroma folows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet toasted, roasted malt, fruity character, with a mild smoky flavor, with a hint of ashy beechwood, with some molasses, chocolatey, liquorice accents, leading towards a mlaty, fruity, roasty bitterness finish. I thought it was much smokier than that.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Little transparent.  Definitely not dark enough.  Creamy, full mouthfeel.  Strange that its smoked, because the smokiness is subdued.  Most smoked I look for bacon flavor.  Not here, but its also pretty damn good, so I cant hold that against it too much.

22 oz bottle Pours dark brown with great dark tan head retention. Aroma is not overbearingly smokey, but certainly present. Base porter is roasted and silky with nice smoke qualities. Personally, Id like more smoke, but this is a well balanced beer.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2009 The aroma is of chocolate, dried apples, beech wood, faint sulphur, coffee, seaweed, sugar and spciy/herbal hops. Smooth taste with a lot raisins and beech wood showing up. Sweet. Very faintly smoky. Decent bitterness. Poor lacework. Some seaweed sneaking in. Pleasant. A bit sour. Medium bodied. Residual sugars, beech wood and caramel in the finish. A bit dissapointing. Thanks a lot nearbeer!

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2011 First rating1 pt 6 fl oz bottle, at The Rover, Göteborg. On January 22, 2009.Dark red to black color (dim lighting), smallish tan head. Mellow smoked and sweet scent. Sweet, alochol, raissin, smoke taste. Medium, though dry, mouthfeel. Medium bitterness. Expected a "bigger" beer than this, but not so challenging, more subtle and drinkable.6/3/6/3/12=3.0RerateShared bottle at Haket on November 13, 2010, during SÖ 25 year anniversaryClear brown color, off-white head. Fruity, sweet scent. Smoke,s weet taste. Moussy mouthfeel, medium bitterness. Smoked malt aftertaste.I think it needs more smoked malt.7/4/7/3/13=3.4RerateDraught at Moeder Lambic, Brussels, for Zwanze Day 2011 as well as the Moeder vs Stone beer festival. Sampled on September 17, 2011Very dark red to black color, big fluffy lasting tan ehad. Sweet, malty, roasted taste. Lingering dry, roasted aftertaste. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, dry medium high bitterness. Sweet, roasted scent.7/5/8/4/15=3.9

Malty, somewhat salty, campfire aroma. Pours opaque black, dense tan head. Coffee, chococlate, roastiness, smokiness. Creamy malt palate. Dry, smoky finish. The boys at Stone never seem to disappoint.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2014 Re-rate 6/4/12: Bottle sample at beerandbeyond farewell tasting at Dagans place. Thanks beerandbeyond. Dark brown with a beige head. Roasted malt, smoke, meat. Very smoky finish. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

Re-rate 2/12: Bottle sample at a Stouts & Porters blind tasting at Sar HaMashkaot Ramat Gan. 2 months after BBD. Very dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of roasted grains, a bit of coffee and light smoked wood notes. Sweetish roasty flavor with light acidity, continues drier, finishes bitter. Medium-bodied. 6/3/6/3/12=3

(11/3/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Escondido. Transparent dark brown color. Aroma of roasted malt, some smoked meat and a bit of coffee. Malty flavor with some smoke, roastiness and some chocolate hints. Medium-bodied. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4
Dark red brown pour with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts but not overwhelmingly strong.  Flavor of roasted malts and coffee with hops and just slight smoke at the finish.
Very nice porter with only a hint of smoke. That is good for me because I cannot stand smoked beers!
22oz bottle. Dark redish brown poue with an off-white head. Smokey, peaty aroma. Smooth flavor, light smokiness, not overwhelming. Decent.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle.  Pours a burnt brown with a nice 1 finger creamy, tan head.  The aroma reminded me of the smell of your clothes after a night next to the campfire.  The flavor, much to my surprise, was not dominated by the smokey notes but rather by the roasted malt character.  There are hints of smooth chocolate and dark fruits as well.

Tap.  Pours a deep almost black color with a medium-sized tan head.  Aroma is dark malt, coffee, and a bit of a smoky characteristic.  Taste is chocolate and coffee up front dissolving into a smooth aftertaste of hops, yeast, and smoke.  Palate is rather dry and heavy.  Very solid.

22oz - Aroma of chewy dark malts, chocolate, fresh hops and a touch of smoke.  Pours deep mahogany with a huge fluffy light brown head and great lacing.  Looks like a root beer float.  Flavor matches aroma with the smoke coming out stronger in the finish.  Palate is chewy and dry.  Tasty but nothing special.

On tap at Brass Tap (Wesley Chapel, FL).  Pours a dark brown almost black color with a creamy tan head.  The smoke flavor is immediately noticeable from the aroma alone.  Balanced flavor includes roasted malts to go along with smoke.  Nice bitter finish too.

Bottle, Beer Ritz, Leeds. Poured a ruby tinged nearly black colour with a creamy and largely lingering tan head. Aroma was sweet chocolate, malt with coffee and molasses hints. Pretty enticing, but  didn’t really pick up on the smoked aspect. Creamy mouthfeel. Lots of chocolate in the flavour, and a really good fruity edge as well, which leads to a balanced licorice tinged finish; but the smoked side of things was very muted. That isn’t to the overall detriment of this though, as I thoroughly enjoyed it.
22 ounce bottle purchased at Big C Liquors Orlando, FL for approx. $5.00 Excellent!
Pours out dark brown with some head. Taste is roasty, malty and smokey.Semi-sweet porter with dry finish.Very good for the style,balanced taste not too much smoke.

Bottle, from Ojai Liquors.  Pours brown with a small cream head.  Aroma of caramel malt, chocolate, vanilla and roasts.  Flavor showcases roasted notes, though firmly complemented by a nutty, woody, caramel flavor.  Finishes dry and roasty.  Solid overall, but there are more exciting smoked porters out there.

22oz bottle. Pours a dark-brown/black color with a thin tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, and smoke. Complex roasted malt flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee and with a nice smokey finish at the end. Balanced mouthfeel makes this a very drinkable, fantastic porter.
Bottle.  Very dark brown color with nice tan head.  Roasty and mild smokiness on the nose.  Great porter flavor with subtle smoke and meat.  Good body and finish.
Bottle.  Black beer with a strongish head.  The aroma is lightly roasted and smoked, and the flavour is deeply roasted, strongly bitter and rich and malty.  Overall a very nice porter.
Pours a dark brown almost black color with a tan head. Scents are smokey and coffee and chocolate. Not really my style, but a pretty good porter.

Pours clear dark brown, with a medium beige head, good lacing.  Smells of apple, toffee and chocolate.  Medium, velvety crisp body.  Sweet and malty, with toffee, coco and apple.  Well balanced with a mild bitter woody pine and slightly smoky aftertaste.

Another great one from Stone. Not as much smoke as I expected but the coffee and chocolate played well with the more subtle smoke. While I never thought I would say this about a Stone beer it almost strikes me as delicate. Absolutely delicious.

Apologetically dissapointed.  I was expecting bliss here.  The aroma was faint and the smokiness was fainter.  I hope over-refrigeration was not the culprit.  The flavors were present but so mild it was difficult to finish.

bottle.  small khaki fizzy head (quickly and fully dissapating) into clear dark brown body with minimal lacing.  aromas of smoke (mild but prevelant throughout), light chocolate, some hops, and coffee.  flavors is initially lighltly bitter and finishes bittersweet.  long finish duration.  slightly dry mouthfeel.  lively carbonation.  pretty damn good porter.
Bottle.  Pours a black body with a a tan head.  Sweet chocolate with minerals and a light hop nose, and mild peat.  Big grassy floral hop start with mild etoh, creamy bitter choc and light smoke.

This is one of the best Porters Ive had, which isnt too surprising considering who brews it. Pours a very nice dark color with amber highlights, moderate tan head, and a little bit of lacing. This is slick and smooth to drink with chocolate, creamy coffee, a little bit of smoke, with some bitter hops showing in the finish. A nice drink we have here. Porters are far from my favorite style but Ill be getting this one again.
POURS A DARK RICH COLOR WITH A CREAMY HEAD. YOU CAN TASTE THE COFFEE MALTS WITH A SLIGHTLY SMOKED TASTE. I NORMALLY DO NOT LIKE SMOKED BEERS BUT THIS IS DEFINITELY AN EXCEPTION.
Bottle from Utobeer. Dark brown with an off white head. Very well balanced porter with less smoke and acsertivness than I expected.. Flavours developed as I drunk more and beer warmed up. Very good.

Draft @ ravenous pig. Pours a deep brown/black that shows red when held up to the light. Fuzzy tan head topping, leaves some nice lacing. Chocolate, roast, a little caramel and hints of smoke. I wish the smoke was stronger. Dark chocolate, caramel, not dominating sweetness, a light hop presence. Not too astringent, well-carbed and drinkable. Paired well with two cheeses and assorted charcuterie, it was good, want more smoke,

Bottle.  Dark brown with hints of red and a small head.  Aromas are chocolate and coffee malts with earthy notes.  Has an almost meaty  smokiness.  Flavours are chocolate and coffee malts.  Sweet and  smooth with peppery notes towards the finish.  Smoky, meaty and moreish.

22 oz. bottle - Poured a black color with hint of ruby on edges. Small, almost no head.
Aroma - very light coffee and chocolate scent. Smoke scent is evident but very light.
Flavor - sweet, salty, coffee and chocolate.
Palate - Earthy almost dunkel like. Smooth slightly oily mouthfeel. Finish is lightly smokey and chocolatey.
Overall - A really nice porter. That smokey chocolate taste gives it a earthy dunkel flavor. I am not a huge Porter fan but this beer I could drink!!

Draft at the brewery. Pours a rich black with a nice tan head. Great chocolate and smoke nose. Loads of malt too. Taste is wonderful. Sweet roasted malt with a pleasant subtle smoke flavor. Nice coffee and chocolate  hints as well. Very tasty treat.

Bottle courtesy of Tony at Oldsmar Tap House (Tampa, FL). Pours a brown to black color with a thin tan head. Some retention and lacing. Aroma is toasty, roasty malt with smoked fish and almond notes. Flavor is also malty and roasted with a dry, smoke note toward finish. As the beer warms there were some subtle fruit flavors that emerged. Some notes of chocolate and coffee as well. Medium to full body with a roasted malt finish.
Bottle: Full bodied, large range of smokey flavors, chocolate and coffee, earthy and herbal from first to last sip.

Pours dark brown with light tan head. Roasted malt aroma with just a hint of smoke. Roasted malt flavor with some chocolate and coffee. The mild smokiness really complements those flavors. Medium body with mild carbonation. A really nice porter.

Bottle. Black with ruby at the thinnest points, a patchy off-white head on top leaving nice lacing. Chocolate is the dominant aroma with some roastiness and a hint of smoke. Flavor gives waves of smoke interlaced with chocolate and caramel. Low carbonation, smooth and thick. Very drinkable with a nice subtle smoke character.

This is a pretty mellow beer.  The flavors balance well to give a very drinkable, highly enjoyable experience.
Appearance:  A very Dark Brown, with a little clarity.  There is a dark tan head with big bubbles.
Aroma: Chocolate and roasty smells dominate.
Taste:  This is a very low hopped beer, which is appropriate for style, but surprising from Stone.  It tastes of caramel and chocolate, with a hint of smoke.  It could be smokier for my taste.
Palate- Very silky smooth, and drinkable.  Lots of residual sweetness.
Sampled at the Great Decatur Beer Tasting Festival in Georgia on 10/18/08. Deep amber in color. Cocoa aroma. Light smoke, malt and cocoa taste. Decent.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Hoppy aromas, bitter chocolate, smokey coffee come off the nose.  Pours very dark brown almost black with a very thin tan head.  Rich hoppy and roasted malt flavors, bitter chocolate, dark toasted coffee, with hints of smoke.  Very smooth and easy to drink.

Pours a pitch black colour with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is strong of dark chocolate, campfire, burnt toast and heavily roasted malts. Taste is rich, intense dark fruits, steak, and chocolate milk. Mouthfeel is very creamy, round and almost chewy. Lots of great flavors.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2008 This porter has a plain look to it. It does not look bad. I love the black opaque color, but the head is an off-white. I am not ragging on it, but a porter with such high praise should have a better looking head. Anyways, there is a nice rich smoke, and coffee aroma. This porter is pungent. I dont have to stick my nose in the beer just to catch a whiff. There might also be some leather in there to accompany the smoke taste. Pretty good aroma. Wow, what a great complex taste. There is  a lovely roast aftertaste that hits the back of my throat. This is strange I have never had this type of roast flavor last this long. Generally, the bitter takes over, but with this the smoke just lasts. Nice taste of wood and coffee, as well. A little watery, if you ask me. I think it could be a bit smoother and thicker. Overall, a nice porter, but it is surely not the best I have tried. I think what saves this is the lasting roast flavor. I think this is like a nice looking car that is actually not as good as its hype. I would recommend trying it, but only to try.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a big foamy tan head that has very nice retention and good lacing.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted malt with a touch of smoke.  Flavor is a very nice melding of the normal roasted chocolate flavors of a porter and just a hint of smoke thrown in to play off the other flavors.  This is a very nice balance.  The smoke is not too overpowering like you find in some smoked porters.  Very nice mouthfeel and very drinkable.  Yet another reason to love Stone.

Draft at Redlight.  This was possibly my favorite of the beers at the Stone Orlando Kickoff.  Pours black with a standard chocolate and coffee smell and taste.  Tastes like a great porter, but then the smoke kicks in.  Just a light amount of smokiness at the tail end finishes this off nicely.  Very good smoked porter.

Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is coffee, smoke, chocolate. Flavor is mostly coffee and bitter chocolate, with smoke flavor present in moderation. Finishes clean, but leaves a bit of smokey aftertaste.

The aroma is about what I expected. It’s smokey, toasty, malty, nutty, and mildly alcoholic. The appearance is red/brown with a nice foamy head. The taste is like the aroma with a bitter finish. The palate is OK but not as thick as I was hoping for. Overall it’s pretty good for a smoke but I don’t really like it.

Pours jet black with a blood red hue.  Head is crisp, thin, and tan.  Smells of charred oak, some roasted coffee.  Tastes smokey, burnt coffee, and rich.  As it warms, a little more coffee comes out.  Aftertaste is semi sweet and smooth.  Lots of lacing.
great beer, not overly done on the smoke nor on the porter side of cocoa and coffee. it has a fair amount of both the balance works very well

More like a smoked schwarzbier or black lager, in that it’s sweet but not roasty, except in the finish, which is good. Aroma has some ham, as does flavor. Flavor has good peaty flavor. Enough clean bitterness in the finish with some good pine roughness. Flavor starts out poor and watery, but improves as it goes.

This brew pours a dark, almost black color with a band of light tan head. Lacing retains somewhat but is not significant.

The smell is of smoke and semi-sweet chocolate.

The first taste to hit the tongue is the smokiness followed immediately by the nicely roasted malt. A hint of dark chocolate can be tasted as well. The finish is a very roasted flavor with a hint of charcoal. An excellent blend in the finish.

The carbonation is done very well and complements the brew’s viscocity.

A fine tasting brew that all could drink all night. Extremely drinkable and proves to be yet another astounding offering from Stone.

Reviewed on: 12-20-2007
Poured black with a tan head.  Smokey/sweet aroma.  Taste was a little creamy and very smooth.  The chocolate malts blended well with the smokey flavor.  Overall a little watery.  Very good!

Brewed in the USA !!! Pours a very dark mahogany / black color with a med creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malts, smoked almonds. Taste is of nuts, coffee, bitter chocolate, and malts. There was some nice lacing in the glass. Mouthfeel is smooth and the finish is warm. Very nice porter .....  :)

Bomber. Black with thick tan head. Nose of maltiness but light smoke. Taste comes off with light smoke flavor, burnt malts, sweet. Smooth profile, easy to drink, alcohol very evident-tastes like an 8% ABV beer. Warms up nicely. Good beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Pours a dark black with a smoky aroma that hints at charcoal and dirt.  Flavor is the same with smoke, chocolate malt, peat, and finishes dry with some rubber flavor.  Interesting beer with lots of dryness throughout.

How I haven’t rated this I don’t know, bomber shared with my girlfriend and used in the beer battered Seitan she made tonight. Pours black with a tan ring. Nose is smokey and rich. Taste is mild and somewhat smoked. This better than I remembered, I never really had much a taste for this beer before.
Bomber, 22 oz.  Dark brown with thin tan head. Smoke flavor is too subtle for my tastes given other smoked porters I’ve had.  Relatively solid proter otherwise.
Full-bodied bear with a malted coffee flavor. The smokiness is not overbearing, but instead brings character to the porter. Very drinkable.
Pours out a dark brown color with a nice tan head.  aroma is smokey and malty with nice choco under tone.  flavor was sweet with a smokey choco finish.  a very good beer

The smoke is almost too subtle... I almost feel like the word smoked should be taken out of the name... Allow it to be a surprise rather than an expectation... As an expectation i find a bit disappointing, as a surprise i think i would have enjoyed this more... This is rich and creamy with very little carbonation....Everything about this beer is subtle, which in a way is refreshing in a word of oneupsmanship and super aggesiveness in terms of flavor... I thought my sample was a bit off, but given the other reviews im led to believe nothing was wrong with it... Overall, i genuinely liked it, but i would have liked a bit more aggresiveness flavorwise, especially from a brewer like Stone....

22 oz bomber - Poured almost a pitch black with a thin head. 

Roasted malt and a light hint of coffee at first smell.

Initial flavor had a smoked coffee overtone. Has a very subtle richness to it.

Very creamy and low carbonation. 

Another great beer by Stone

Bottled. Pours very dark brown, thin mocha-cream head with nice lacing. Aroma is smokey roast coffee and some citric hops. Flavor is subtly smokey with overtones of bittersweet chocolate and roasted coffee malt, and nutty. Palate is nice and not too carbonated. Another good Stone.

This porter comes out of the bottle a deep, opaque sable, nearly black, with a thick, fine-bubbled tan head. Aroma is thick and smoky and has hints of coffee, unsweetened chocolate, and what seems like wheat. Flavor is like well-roasted coffee with a subtle sweet undertone and hints of chocolate and molasses and even a touch of nutty taste. Texture is sublimely smooth but has just a bit of an edge.

Dark brown pour, with a huge brown head that never seems to go away! Some lacing on glass. Smell is chocolate, coffee and  strong burnt malt. Tatse is same with a burnt sweetness and a bit of alcohol nothing overwhelming. Good character on the tongue. Well balanced beer. Just what a expect from SBC.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2011 Black with big, foamy, tan head / Mild, roast, smokey nose / Medium body, creamy, a hint of sweetness and somewhat chewy, with good balance and dry finish / Flavors of roast barley, roast coffee, (subtle) smoke, and bittersweet chocolate / An elegant, balanced smoked beer that I would drink again.

Pours dark brown nearly black with a small to middling tan head. Intense smoky aroma hits the nostrils like a freight train and clears those sinuses straight out. Taste is primarily coffee with the smoky flavors coming through on the back end. This beer is not messing around.

1 Pint bottle. Pours a pitch black with a small, creamy tan head. Initial taste is almost like pure cream or half&half. Pretty awesome lacing. Aroma is milk chocolate, water. Palate is moderate and smooth. Tastes are dark fruits, milk chocolate, cream, buttery toast, a hint of roasted malt, but I am missing the smoky parts. Aftertaste is quick and then disappears. Well balanced. Much better warm. A drinkable, smooth porter but not a knock-out.

22oz. bomber, pours a dark brown with a towering light tan head, great retention, moderate lacing.  Aroma is light meaty smoke and light peat.  Flavor is more of the same; a more understated smoked for sure, and a bit thin and one dimensional, but drinkable and tasty on a cool evening.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 pours deep dark brown with a slight head that looks almost creamy.  stays lacy throughout. I Dont get an overwhelming smokiness like the name would suggest...  at least not like youd find in a Paradox (Brew Dog).  Great, solid brew.  This beer improves greatly with warming, finding a nice balance.

Dark dark brown with a large slowly settling light tan head with some sticky loops of lacing and great retention.  Mostly roasted porter malts, the smoke is there but not enough to warrant the smoked name.  Some grassy hops on the nose.  Taste is more smokiness over top of roasted malts, heavy hop bite combines with the bitter roasted malt.

Bottle as shown. Pours a very dark brown with a medium light tan head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is strong roasted malt and dark chocolate. The taste is a rich roated coffee with the smoke coming out in the finish. Easy to drink, a great porter from Stone.

Pours a dark black color with some mahogany around the edges with a small beige colored head that settles to a thin film. A little bit of lacing is left behind. The aroma is of chocolate malts, roasted coffee, some caramel, and some light smoke. The smoke was pretty subdued, but added a nice touch. The roasted coffee comes through themost in the flavor with some chocolate malt, a touch of smoke, and some hops to add balance. Medium bodied with good carbonation and goes down fairly smooth. I was hoping for a little more smoke, but this is still a solid porter. I enjoyed this one.

Bottled. Clear brown color, medium brown head. Aroma of some coffee, some smoked sausage, salami, ashes. Smoked taste, bit bitter, bit sweet, malty. Finishes with some coffee and chocolat. Quite good.

It pours a thick black color with a medium to thin tan head that wofts chocolate and woodsy hops together, then after that fades to smoky chocolate. Very smoky in the flavor - kinda made me jump back. This is my first smoked beer. Some coffee notes. A lasting bitterness goes good. Real nice lacing.  Very bubbly and soft on the palate. At first the smokiness wasn’t subtle but as it warms a little it mellows out.  Very nice beer indeed.

Dark brown with an off-white head, gone quickly. Nose is a little flat, but heavy coffee and a little smoky licorice give it a backbone. Very sweet beer despite the strong coffee elements, mainly thanks to the licorice and milk chocolate, slight tobacco adding to bitterness. Medium-sized, good beer, but just "good."
bottle. dark brown has a smokey/ nutty tastse to it, could be a bit stronger but its a solid buy

Dark black brown pour with some reddish highlights. Decent sized tan head that is frothy. Nose is roasted malt. chocolate, smoke, coffee. Taste is about the same. Goes does smooth with a moderate mouthfeel. A well crafted beer that does everything well and nothing outstanding.

Looks like a classic porter with an almost black body and a nice tan head that lasts a good while and offers some sticky lacing.  A nice classic porter aroma as well with roasted notes, coffee, and chocolate.  Smoke and peat are also noticeable.  Flavor is delightful with, again, those classic porter flavors.  Chocolate, coffee, smoke, and just a smidge of hop.  The smoke is not dominant and is just enough to add character.  Feel is silky smooth and substantial.  I like the moderate ABV.  The good news is that it was a 22 oz. bottle.  The bad news is that it was only 22 ounces.  Absolutely delicious.
bottle, pours a almost black beer with a light tan head.  Aroma is malty and smokey.  Flavor is sweet, bitter and dry of light choco, smoked malt, molasses.  Decent, but a little bit waterd down.
Bottled: a really really good porter. Pours a dark color with a tan froathy head. Smells of malts and chocolate. Tastes of light roasted malts with hints of chocolate and a dry finish. Good beer!

Poured from tap at the brewery a dark brown/black with medium sized tan head.  Aroma is light with roast grain, coffee and a touch of peat.  Flavor is a nicely blended combination of roasted grains, coffee, dark chocolate, soft smokiness, and some toasted hop notes.  The palate has just a splash of sweet mixed into a mostly dry taste and very subtle hoppy and smoky notes.  Overall, I found this beer enjoyable and incredibly easy to drink.  Nice  balance and interesting flavor.
poured dark with a brown head. i didn’t catch the smoked flavor so much at first but its definitely in the aftertaste
UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 I have to agree with the tagline on this one, in that the smoke is not the sole character of this beer, which is why I probably enjoyed this one.

Pours an espresso colored dark brown. Black and thick with a creamy head. 
Chocolate, cream, coffee, some hops, and a slight acidity. 
Creamy smooth chocolate and velvet caramel flavor rolls across my tongue and as it makes it’s way back it mellows into an elegant hopped coffee flavor. 
The palate is everything I’ve ever wanted from a porter. Smooth, full not to thick or sweet, but not to watery. The aftertaste is wonderful leaving me wanting more more more!

Bomber. Pours a very dark amber with a tick light tan head that laces to the bottom. Light aroma of chocolate, malt and smoke with some earth tones preasent. Flavor is were this beer is at with chocolate, coffee, wood, smoke, and roasted malts balancing from begining to finish. Med body,  lively carb, creamy texture, and smooth dry feel. A very fine and interesting porter.

Bomber. Dark reddish brown pour with thick light tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and light coffee. Flavor of roasted malts and chocolate with hints of coffee and smoke. Well balanced and smooth. Could have had several more glasses of this. Very nice porter.

(Draught at Stockholm Beer Festival, 20 Sep 2008) Black colour with ruby hints, frothy pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with delicate notes of coffee and chocolate. Malty, roasted, slightly smokey taste with chocolate. Well balanced and smooth with a rather delicate smoke character. Very nice beer.

Draught at Cole’s. Mainly opaque deep brown with red tint and thick white head. Mellow, barely smoked aroma. Nice malt but just a light touch of smoke. Great palate. Smooth, sweet entry and lingering sweetness with loads of peat. More scotch and peat than in your face smokiness. It’s no Alaskan but is really subtle and nice.

Bottle pours opaque black with thin quick disipating white head. Aroma is malt and light smoke. First taste is sweet coffee and a little bit of smoke. The balance is nice and finish is slightly bitter coffee and light smoke linger. Really like that the smoke is not overpowering.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a one finger brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt and some smoke.  Flavor had roasted malt, smoke and a bitter mocha finish.  Slightly thin body for the style, but a good beer overall.

Dark brown pour, fairly clear.  Small cream head.  Aroma roast malt and smoke.  Roast malt, smoke, peaty up front.  Slight mocha and coffee and slight hop bitter through the finish.  Pretty clean, I’d say quite drinkable.  Characteristics mellow and improve as it warms a little.  Straight forward as described, can’t complain too much about this one.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Had this a bunch of times but never bothered to rate it. Pours out a dark brown with a slight ruby hue. Moderate off white head. Aroma is of roasted malts, chocolate and an earthy smoky aroma. Taste is well balanced, roasted malts, smoky, chocolate and a slight bitterness, smoke/wood/earth comes through with slight bitterness on the finish. Solid

Attractive head with only a bit of tenacity. Very deep brown color. Aroma is a complex range of roasted malts and hops with a smoked presence and a high note of alcohol at the end. Medium body and surprisingly balanced. Flavor is complex with a slight sweetness of caramel as well as the bitterness of a moderate chocolate. Hop flavors blossom closer to the finish and provide a woody dryness that would make it an excellent pair for stronger entres.

dark brown, almost black with a large creamy brown head.  smoky, meaty, chocolate, milked coffee aroma.  smoked peat, earth, meat flavors dominate.  i get some chocolate malt but mostly just smoke.  touches of hops.  body is a little light for a porter.  kind of creamy but also watery.  moderately dry finish.

At a tasting at Priscillas in Morehead City, NC.  All I needed was a good cigar and my rocking chair!  A dark pour with a great head that leads to an off white lacing.  Aroma was smoky, could have been stronger.  Taste offered smoke, chocolate and some coffee.  Mouthfeel was wonderful.  Can’t wait to drink the whole bottle by myself!

Pours dark black with a nice, foamy brown head. Beautiful, steady, permanent lacing that lingers down the glass. Great looking beer in the glass. Smells of weak malts -- no smokiness, no chocolate, nothing else. Very disappointing aroma. Flavor is lots of chocolate, ironically not very smokey at all. Digging deeper there is some dark fruit there. Theres a bit of a watery character to the beer as well. Unusually weak brew from Stone. Other reviews on this site rave, but I didnt come away with a great experience from this beer.

Poured dark brown, close to black from bomber.  Formed nice size off white foamy head, aroma of roasted malts, smokey chocolate cocoa beans and some coffee tones.  Flavour much of the same, even a bit of hop type character under smoke taste.  Not my fave style, but had to try it at Priscillas beer tasting in MHC.  Thanks Matt and Ed.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
Bomber:
Pours brownish black with a tan head that lasts long enough to... blow your mind. Aroma of fall, light malt, leaves, sugar, mist, burning wood. Flavor is full and light. How do they do that. It tastes like smoke, malt, honey, sugar, cocoa, and goodness. Context is pure, clean, and smooth, lightly thick, and just the right amount of bite. This beer is better than the last 30 you’ve had.


On Draught:
Pours dark brown, almost black, with a 1/2" off-white head. Aroma is of wood, malt, and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is malty, with a little bit of bland cocoa. There is definitely the smoked wood taste present. Texture starts out lightly cremay then goes watery, like most porters. Lacing is intricate and frequent. Mouth feel has a distinctive bite that is on the borderline of good and too much bite. The pint has a gummy, slightly dry finish and a quick taste of coffee follwed by diluted sugar cream water milk flavor. No I am not there yet, that’s just exactly what it tastes like. The bottles version is slightly better than the draught version because out of the bottle, the beer is creamier and less harsh. The bottled version is markedly better than the draught version because out of the bottle, it is creamier and less harsh. Rating reflects draught version.
bottle thanks to tizzlejizzle.  black pour with a thin cream head. slight smokey scent with hints of roasted malts.  nice roasted flavor with a smooth smokey backbone.
Dark brown with medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, coffe and smoke notes. Flavour likewise with a peat  finish.

Stone Smoked Porter pours a very dark blk/brn with a tan colored head. Nose is of smokey roasted cuffee beans. Think a french roast. Taste is nice smokey malt like that of a non-acidic coffee! full bodied and the smoked flavor is definetly present. This beer would be great in chilli,or a stew. or on a nice cold night!

This beer pours deep ruby almost black with a medium tan head.  The aromas are dark roast, chocolate and faint smoke.  flavor is chocolate, light smoke, hoppy and good!  I really like dthis one!  Cheers!

bottle from midway mart in denton tx.  poured black with ruby hues and a tan head.  aroma of hops and chocolate.  flavor of dark roasts with a dry bitter.  seemed like the hops were to strong for this to be a porter.
on tap pour a dark choclate color.  Flavor is dry, sweet, with just a bit of coffee.  Can not detect any smoke and a bit thin.  Very drinkable for a porter.

pitch black with great tan head.  flavor is of black patent and chocolate malt with a noticeable hop bitterness and even flavor.  a lot of depth to this beer with huge flavors everywhere, but it maintains a nice balance.  top of the line

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.
Pours a nice deep dark brown with ruby hue’s and tan head. Aroma of dark roast, chocolate, hints of smoke. Flavor has nice dark roast, some chocolate, slight smoke, and hoppy. Palate is medium with med-high carbonation....good porter!

Bomber - Pours a very dark black/brown in color with a small light tan head that faded to thin covering over the beer and around the rim of the glass.  Lacing is significant and very nice. Aroma is faintly smokey with plenty of roasted malts, some chocolate and a small amount of coffee.  Flavor is a bit more smokey with plenty of chocolate... I agree with the other BBQ comments... and with plenty of hop bitterness along with more than a fair amount of malty sweetness in the finish.  Finish is lingering.  I really liked this one...
bottle, dark brown pour, tan head, nose of some malt and slight smoke, flavor is a roasted malt with some cocoa, finish is medium, smoke is very mild

Pours a deep brown into the glass with nice red highlights.  There is a good tan head which gives some pretty nice lacing throughout.  I smell a lot of chocolate with a spicy hop characteristic.  I pick up on a very faint smoke, kind of the second hand smoke you’d get at a bbq.  I pick up on the smoke much more in the flavor which provides a nice counter to the chocolaty sweetness of the malt.  The light smokiness and chocolate/coffee flavors stay on the tongue well after the finish.  Really nice brew.

not a huge fan of porters personally. this one does have a unique smoked flavor that is quite enjoyable. the bistro makes an outstanding smoked porter bbq sauce that i’m sure would be good on just about anything! yum

Black color......opaque.  Thick, creamy head.  Heavy malt aroma, with subtle hints of smoke.  Somewhat of a smoky malt flavor up front......very smooth mouthfeel.  Smoke flavor continues into the back, though mingled in with a slightly bitter taste......finish is long and bitter.  Though quite tasty, this smoked porter is a tad thin, and a little too bitter.
Draught. Low and quickly disappearing off-white fluffy head. Pitch black body. Coffee cocoa vineous aroma. Coffee cocoa liquorice hops kovely smoked flavor. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.

22oz bottle:  Pours very dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma of smoky,roasted malt, cocoa and slight hint of coffee.  Nice smoked taste with some dark chocolate flavor gives it a subtle bitter finish.  Surprisingly lighter body than I expected.  I’ll probably try this one again.
About what I expected. Moderate roasted malt backbone with light smokiness.  Moderate dark chocolate with some light coffee bean notes. Woody and somewhat earthy, a tad thin.

pours dark brown and clean with tan head and lots of lacing aromas of smoke and coffee and roasted malts taste is of smoke.chocolate,coffee  and malts has a smooth mouthfeel not a big fan of smoke beer but not over powering it is a flavor in the beer not the flavor of th beer

Started with a wonderful smokey dark fruit aroma.  Dark brown pour with tones of amber and a thick light tan head.  Flavor was disappointing compared to the aroma.  Reminded me of Dogfish Head d’Etre but watered down and with smokey overtone to it.  Finished with a slight bitterness.  Overall not a bad beer, but very mellowed flavor of malts and hops that do not let reach its potential.
Dark brown color with tan head.  Smoky aroma.   Roasted malt flavor with chocolate and coffee flavors.  This beer was just ok for me.

Got this beer some time ago in a trade. Pours a black body with red hints at the edges, and a huge beige head. The aroma was light; earthy notes, some smoke, toasted malts and light chocolates. The flavor was a full and nice porter, some toasted malts and a creamy body, but also a nice smoked aspect, especially in the finish. Very nice.

Bottle.  Deep dark mahogany pour with tan head.  From the nose to the taste, what struck me about this beer was its hoppiness.  Wow... never had a porter this hoppy.  For my taste buds, it obscured the more porter-like elements (which were all there--lactose, smoke, peat, chocolate, malt), and I didn’t think this was smoked enough to merit the "Smoked Porter" label, even if they don’t claim it to be a rauchbier.  All that said, it was a very enjoyable brew; just needed some expectation management.  Not to mention that I had a very meaty/smoky Alaskan smoked porter directly before... so quite different.

22oz bottle, purchased somewhere in Boston for $5.  Consumed during the month of its best before date.  Pours very dark with minimal head.  Nice lacing though.  All malt aroma of medium strength.  The first sip gives an initial peppery sensation.   The peppery sensation remains throughout.  Nice malty flavours, with some coffee tastes thrown in the mix.

Bottle from some liquor store in Rehoboth Beach DE. Pours deep brown with a nice light beige head that dissipates to a retentive ring. The aroma is very nice, smoky peat, dark roasted malts, nutshells, and cocoa powder. Medium bodied with average carbonation. This beer has nicely balanced flavors of smoke, dark chocolate, tobacco, and coffee. Just enough bitterness to keep this in balanced, with average attenuation. Finish has a slight milky flavor. I need to kick my own ass for waiting so long to try this. Great beer, and I don’t like smoke beers. I bet this would kick ass on cask.
Deep brown red pour with a large tannish thick head.  Smoke and metalic nose.  Taste of smoke and coffee, quite light in palate.

first you can smell the aroma of smoke,and more  smoke, the frothy, head sits atop a black,as night lake of beer but i was suprised this was very light in  body,soft and  creamy,with little to soft carbonation, and left a long finish, of a smoky fireplace behind i had this beer with smoked mozzarella and salami.

Almost pitch black pour with a foamy light brown head.  Aromas are light chocolate and toasted malts. Flavor is very smooth and a bit creamy.  Roasted malts, chocolate and a hint of coffee.  This actually reminds me of a a beer in the realm of a dry stout.  Nice beer.

Cask at GBBF 08. Very dark brown with a ruby tint. Lots of peat on the otherwise chocolately malt nose. In the mouth, the beer is oily and smooth with vinous flavours and evident alcohol but not too much smokiness. A robust beer that I was surprised is ’just’ 5.9%.

The malts and hops are both delicate and light. Taste of light body coffee with a touch of a smoked chocolate. This is much milder in taste than in aroma. Would work in harmony with grilled fish. Enjoyed from a snifter.

22 ounce bottle from kegbear. Thanks.
Pours almost black with a small frothy head. Aroma isn’t too strong, a bit of dark chocolate and smoke. The taste is much lighter than I have come to expect from smoked beers.
