Thinner than I had thought but still very tasty. Would buy again and would love to have with a meal. It seems like it would go with a heavy feast. Lovely
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Pours near black with a huge fine creamy tan froth that has popping bubbles on the very top.   Light aroma of dark malt, peat, creamy chocolate, and smoked wood.  First taste is of dark chocolates, followed by peat smoked malt and coffee bitterness.  The flavors arent extremely assertive, but they meld together extraordinarily well.  The smoke is pretty faint, more of a scotch ale peat flavor.   This is a dead-ringer for my buddys home-brew smoked porter... hes a very good brewer =) .   Lingering licorice aftertaste, some residual sugars.  Softly carbonated medium/full body.  Very easy drinking, the carbonation is so soft.  Full agreement that the smoke is an "element" rather than the full character of the beer.  8.5.8.4.17 . . . . .(rerate 2.19.12 7.4.8.4.15)

Bottle.  Very dark brown pour with a small tan head.  Seems a little thin and the head only leaves some small spotted lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and a bit of smokey malt.  Flavor is better than what I was expecting.  Mild sweetness and the smokiness is more apparent while sipping.  Palate is a little thin but silky and with a decent short aftertaste.  Pretty solid.  Plenty of flavor but not overpowering making this some what of a session porter.
dark brown in color, medium-large head, smells of coffee and molasses.  tastes slightly sweet at first but finishes bitter.

Pours with a light brown moderately sized head. The body hue is dark brown with a hint of amber if you look at it from afar. The aroma is very smokey (hence the name) with a hint of coffee and molasses. 
It feels medium to the palate with light carbonation. The beer has a moderately sweet beginning to a bitter finish.
Although I desperately want to try the vanilla and aged brews, this porter, my oh my. Not quite the bitterness of other stone ales, but for once the smoky quality adds to porter.

22oz bottle served in an English pint glass. Medium brown pour topped by beige foam. Smells mainly of bitter chocolate, very little smoke detected. It is present in the flavor however, seamlessly blending with a nice dark chocolate,earthy flavor. Very nice.

Amazing beyond belief. Smoky chocolaty and just a well done coffee like appearance. 

I actually use this in a chicken marinade. 

Cheers to this one

(Bottle).  I had low expectations for this, but was very pleasantly surprised.  It’s a terrific beer.  Aroma is chocolatey.  Black color, thick brown head.  Flavor extremely well balanced between chocolate, coffee, and malt.  Nice finish.  Wonderful.
22 oz bottle.  It tastes just like I’m eating a BBQ.  Smoke, oak, coffee, chocolate.  Very easy to drink, I just with it had a higher ABV. Great for drinking outdoors on a hot day.
Good balance for a Stone Brewery product. Malt,smokiness, coffee, caramel chocolate and hops. A very easy drinker. On my regular list.
Smoked Beer tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee. Nice rich porter Chocolate and coffee. Not the best Porter I have had but very good.

Brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, sweet malt and notes of hops.  Taste in line with aroma plus a little chocolate.  Smoke not overpowering, nice complement to the beer.  Finishes Mildly bitter with a dry semi-hoppy finish.

Dudebra says this is disappointing and I’m not saying his wrong, aight? Full bodied, big smoke flavor, a good example of the style. However, I don’t look to stone for "a good example of the style", I look to stone for beers that blow my mind. This didn’t.
Great beer.  First porter I’ve had in 10 years!  I am going to make a promise to grab a porter or 2 next time i go to the beer store.  Deep mohagny and very rich flavor.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 10, 2008 Bottle that was a few months past its enjoy by date. It poured black with a tan head that was gone within 2 minutes. It smelled like someone lit a campfire in the distance. I could really taste the smokiness.

From bottle in snifter. Pillowing and colored head quickly recedes towards the black liquid leaving intermediate lacing.  Yeast aroma pervades with little else. Smokey flavor with a little metallic note. Smooth chocolate flavors throughout, sweet. Subtle complexity, good porter.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark amber-brown with a small creamy head. Big malty aroma, a bit sweet, with some smoke. Taste is more bitter, with smoke and meat, malt, and a hint of an alcohol bite. Great lingering malty bitterness. Very tasty porter.

22 oz bottle.  Clear dark brown with some frothy tan haze.  Nose is earthy grape and brown sugar with a faint sweet smokiness.  Medium light with crisp carb; gets fuller with the finish.  Taste is cocoa, coffee, greens and smoke.  Solid but not very smoky.

22 oz. bomber served in an english pint. awesome beer. nose of ruby port and licorice. taste is heavy chocolate malt. not as smoky as i thought it would be. long, bitter finish. tasty and smooth, went down easy. highly recommended.

Pours a ruby brown color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is hoppy, fruity, caramel malts, chocolate, and smoked oak. Taste is not as rich as I would have expected.  Chocolate, caramel, and roasted malts, with a hoppy and bitter finish.  Good, but a bit thin and hoppy for such a style.

Long lasting brown head tops an dark brown (almost black) opaque beer.

 The first smells are of hops and malt. The hops are a little more than I would expect for this style, but exactly what I have come to expect from Stone. 

 The overwhelming taste here is of malt and a hint of chocolate. The smoke joins in about half way through and is just right not over powering in the least.

 Very smooth on the tongue, oily and full bodied.

 I tried this one with a danish blue cheese which is an excellent contrast. The porter wipes the pallet clean after each taste and makes the sharpness of the cheese even more pronounced.

 Great representation of the style.

Pours out a dark brown color with a light tan head, leaving pretty good retention and some lacing. Aroma is roasted with a little bit of chocolate, some caramel too. Some caramel in the taste, I definately get roastiness but the smokiness is very subdued. Medium bodied with fairly high carbonation. Pretty easy to drink beer, I’d probably have it again, but wouldn’t seek it out.

I have to say that I think this beer is one of the easiest-to-drink beers I’ve ever had. Mild but noticable tones of smoke, chocolate, and vanilla with a fine creamy texture. A lovely smooth texture. The more I have this beer the more I love it!

I was worried about this one...  with stone’s flair for the overdramatic in their hops, I was afraid that they would go overboard with the smoke in this one.  Not true at all.  I really don’t get much smoke in this one at all.  It is a great porter though.  Pours opaque brown with a thin head.  Aroma is a bit smoky, with lots of chocolate malts in it.  Flavor is of a rich porter.  There is a bit more hops in this one (as expected from stone) which is a welcome addition.  Stone really doesn’t seem to do bad beer.  As you drink this one, you get more of a woody smoke towards the middle to end of your drink.

Pours dark, opaque brown with a tan head. This beer has a rich, roasted Malt aroma and taste. The flavor also has a nice smokey quality and a light hop finish. I enjoyed this on draught and it was creamy and smooth. A Very Nice Beer!
Pours dark brown with a good light brown head that lasts.  Aroma of sweet malt, flavor of chockolate and caramel, nice finish.  All in all an excellent porter.

22 oz. bomber poured deep ruby red/black with a one-finger brown head that left a lattice down the side of the glass. Smoky malt aromas as expected, also a hint of coffee, caramel and hops. Very nice coffee and chocolate flavors were most evident on the tongue, and the smokiness lingered in the aftertaste. Full bodied, richer than most porters. I had high expectations for this, and it delivered.

Bottle. Aroma of roasted (maybe lightly smoked) malt, coffee, bitter chocolate. Flavor has a little more chocolate, a little more smokiness/charredness, as an interesting subtle contrast to the standard porter flavors. Good stuff.
Bomber.  Dark brown pour with nice thick creamy head.  Aroma of campfire and faint chocolate.  Taste of malt, burned almonds with a nice smoky finish and faint hops.

Bottle.  Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma of smoke, roast, coffee.  Flavor of sweet roasted malt, slight bitter chocolate, and light bitter hops.  Not too smokey (a plus for me).  Palate is not as robust as the great porters, but its pretty decent.  A nice porter.

22 oz bottle.  Pours opaque black with a sizable dark tan head.  Aroma sweet, dark fruits, some roasty and bitter chocolate aromas.  Taste is roasty and smokey, bitter chocolate, dark fruits, something a little tart in the flavor as well.  Smokiness lingers on the palate.  Pretty good.

Loved this beer.  One of the lightest Porters I have tasted.  Light malty nose with a hint of smoke.  On the palate are flavors of toasted malt, dark chocolate with just a touch of smoke.  I like that the smoke is light and really enhances the beer instead of becoming the only taste component.  Dry and slightly bitter finish.

The beer pours a deep black with a thin off white head that leaves a good lacing down the sides of the glass. The nose is very light with a hint of smoke. The taste is very light but I can pick up some hints of smoke and sourness with light notes of chocolate. The finish is short and dry

A dark mahogany beer witha  tan head.  Definitely can smell the smokiness.  Can taste burned malt with hints of bitter chocolate.  Tastes less smokey than I anticipated.  A solid porter but I felt liike it could have been better if it had more of a smokey flavor.

~Pours light black with red tints. Creamy off white head, nice lacing.
~Nice roasted smoked coffee aroma.
~Roasted smoke coffee flavor. Yum.
~Roasty bitter finish.
~Mmmm. This is a great porter.

Pours deep red, big tan head on top.  Aroma is yeasty, some hop fruitiness and a mild, far away smoke.  Flavor is subtle, the hops and smoke in the nose dont dominate the sweet chocolate notes, tobacco, rye bread, and toast flavors that mingle on the tongue.  Very well balanced, though hops are more prominent than many porters (West Coast brewers, I suppose).  Very nice.  Thanks, beastiefan!
A porter with a tuch of smoke. Lots of coffey and chocolate but with a litle thin body for the class.
Pours dark black and brown with small white/tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts, nuts and coffee. Slightly smokey. Smooth flavor of Chocolate malts with a medium body.

Bottle. Pours pitch black, big creamy tan head, and a lot of lacing. A perfect pour from yours truly. Lots of roasted notes in the nose, some slight spices, coffee. Roasted malts hit the tongue first. Caramel and some fresh fruits follow. Has a basic malt finish. Med-bodied, velvety feel on the tongue, and easy to pound down. Enjoyed it.

Have had this quite a few times now.  Not my favorite style, but they do it well.  dark black color on the pour with a nice tan head.  Overall, its pretty straightforward.  Nice chocolate and smokiness, but enough bitterness to keep it balanced.  Very drinkable and well done.  Worth a shot.
dark black coffee color smoky coffee roasted malts a little thin but good for a smoked beer

As Stone is as of yet unavailable in my state (NC), I must continue to seek it out when visiting friends abroad (VA). As this particular offering I found to be averagish-good, Im not sorely lamenting its absence at my LBS...yet it was still worth trying to be sure.

Appearance: Coca-cola, pure and simple

Aroma: Weak smoke permeates all else.

Taste: Smoky porter! An American take on an English style mixed with Rauchbier.

Overall, its a one-trick pony, not especially smoky (but then again I love Rauchbier). I kinda dig it -- one caveat, though, if youre not into the smoky beer thing, dont bother with this one!

Serving type: bottle
whate4ver, i dont really like porters, or at least ive never had one that i really liked. this was ok i guess. w/evz

Bottle, 22 oz. Pours black with a tan head. Smoky and roasty malt aroma with sweet dark fruit notes. The palate is met with sweet malt, then hops for a slightly bitter finish. I would have enjoyed some more smokiness, but its still good.

I am a huge fan of Stone beers, but I was expecting a bit more by the Smoked Porter. It was generally very mild in aroma and flavor. It poured a dark brown almost black color with a tall creamy tan head. The aroma had hints of smoke obviously and some chocolate and licorice. The taste was on the slightly dry side like a porter with a very pleasant flavor. I had a grilled T-Bone with the beer and I think a bit stronger flavor would have gone better with the steak. It was a very nice beer.
deep deep brown. Smoke is mild and not overly meat orented. smooth mild malt and bitter coco. Great carbonation and strong lacing.

Dark dark brown/black. Lacing through the roof.  light brown thick head. Wow chocolate bitter back end. Medium body Roasted malt, chocolate, nice heavy carbonation. Not extremely full flavored. Really good beer.
UPDATED: JAN 2, 2009 Dark brown,  roasted malts, coffee with a sweet smokee finish, and a slight dry hoppy bite.

22 oz. bottle, pours an opaque, dark brown body with light brown head.  Aroma of toasted and chocolate malts and brown sugar with hints of coffee and smoke.  Flavor is the same as the aroma, with the smoke flavor coming through in the mid and back of the palate.  Well-balanced and medium bodied; smooth mouthfeel.  Dry, toasted malt and smoke finish.

Thanks to zeke626 for sharing this bottle. The beer was near opaque dark brown with thin tan foam. In the flavor there was semi-sweet candy malt and more subtle coffee. No smoke. In the flavor there was sweet candy malt, burnt malt, coffee. There was a faint smokiness on the mid-palate and on the finish which was rather bitter.

Picked this up in for Vermont of all places in the bomber. Poured into a pint glass dark as night with a really nice head. The lacing from the head was amazing as it stuck to the sides. It smelled of smokey chocolate malts but the aroma really didnt blew down any doors. The taste however did. It was balanced and complete. Nearly all porters in my book lack somewhere: When the flavor is on the body is too light, when the body is nice and creamy the flavor is watery. To this point I can say this is probably the best porter I have had and it reinstalled my faith in porters.

A bit overated in my opinion. I must say, I agree with Greg Kochs quote, the smoke level is perfect. Pours with a leage, foamy, ligh brown head covering an ultra dark brown body. Aroma is smoke and tons of molasses. Taste is smokeyness, and coffee. Tons of intense flavor for a sub-6% ABV. Sort of a nutty aftertaste. Great lacing from the head. Light carbonation and a decent mouthfeel.

Pours a dark brown with a small dense beige head. Aroma is lightly sweet and smoked, some licorice, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is light roasted malt, some chocolate malt, coffee and a decent bitterness. Medium bodied, creamy texture.  Medium smoky bitter finish.

Wow. I finally tried this stuff. Picked up a bomber from Jaspers in Nashua. Pours like oil, black and completely opaque. Cream colored one finger head that recedes quickly. Vanilla, caramel, coffee, and maybe licorice (?) in the aroma. Full bodied mouthfeel, roasty malt character, chocolate, medium sweetness, smokiness, and just a bit of hop on the backend. This was a fantastic brew, and replaces Anchor as my favorite porter.

Poured from bottle 5/2008.  Chocolate, vanilla, caramel, a hop or two in the aroma.   Solid black, tan lacing head.  Flavors explode in your mouth - cocoa, coffee, chicory, dash of vanilla.   Nice bitterness to it up front, but mellow in the aftertaste.  Flavors blend beautifully at finish.  Excellent!
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: clear and dark, you can only see through the glass when held to a light.  thick pale tan head.  roasted aroma with a backseat hint of smoke.  yummy.  the smoke adds a welcome highlight to the tasty full foundation.  ive had this before and forgot how good this is.

Pitch black with a medium tan head. If you hold it up to the light, you can see red highlights. Smells of chocolate and caramel. I got the first hint of smoke somewhere deep in the nose. Flavor is pleasant. Not strong, not complex, just pleasant. I can taste some toffee, and a little smokiness. Perhaps some chocolate, but Im not too sure about that. Palate is liquid silk. Absolutely perfect! I like this one a lot.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2008 On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear brownish black with a small, dreamy off-white head and a bit of lacings. Moderate sweet- and bitterness. Aromas of toasted malts. Also a hint pof smoke aromas. Medium piny hoppiness. Medium to full bodied with a nice creamy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Dry smoky finish..

Extremely dark ruby red color, almost black, with medium sized light tan head. Aroma has chewy malts, slightly nuty, fair amount of vanilla, touch of caramel and cherry, and an almost imperceptible touch of smokeyness. Flavor has a bit more smoke, bit of caramel, vanilla, oak, molasses, faint ash and bitter malts. Finish is a bit thin but is well balanced.

pours black with a foamy off-white head that starts at two fingers and slowly falls to one and coats the glass. Aroma is of subdued chocolates and malt, though theres not much at first. Flavor shows some carbonation and alcohol and leaves behind a coffee aftertaste.

this beer poured a browinish black with a little head that turned into a straw colored ring. i couldnt detect much in the nose at first because i think the beer was a bit too cool. as it warmed up, i noticed the smoked maltiness. this beer isnt complex in the nose, but smells delicious. the taste is of roasted malt with some hop bittering. superbly balanced. the mouthfeel is full and great for this style. overall, this is a freaking awesome beer that i could drink on the daily. a big thanks to barefootbrewer for sharing this one with me.

Vintage 2004

Pours dark brown, almost black and opaque.
Mahogany edging with a crimson hue.
A humble half-inch head of beige retreated quickly to a partial coverage skim coat and a few dots of lacework.

Aromatics are surprisingly vineous. Bitter chocolate, red wine, scorched caramel bits, some dark fruit, and a smidge of smoldering embers. A hint of vanilla rounds out the bunch.

Thin mouthfeel. Slightly creamy with low carbonation.

Dark chocolate, deep roasted malts, espresso grounds and mild smoke on the pallet.
All are quite balanced and the overall character is subdued and sessionesque.
Finishes with some lingering caramel drizzeled dark malts.

While the four years in the cellar has brought a complexity to the nose, the body and pallet has faded.

Somehow I managed to overlook this one, rating from memory. The smoke, to me, is closer to what you get from roasted malts than from actually smoking the beer. But this seems to be pretty common from peat smoking. At any rate, chocolatey and chalky, finishes dry. Pretty nice.

Opaque black pour with a thick light-tan head.  Beautiful lacing on the glass.  Malty aroma with hints of wood and smokiness.  Bitter malt and roast flavor.  Hints of smoke.  Lots of coffee on the tongue.  Typical porter.  Not bad, but nothing special.

Pours a dark black letting almost no light escape through the glass. Nice looking cream colored head which does not dissipate quickly. Smells hopped up and inviting however it doesnt nearly smell like i would expect for how dark it looks. Although the smell was mild, the taste is smoky and reminescant of burnt hops. Very tasty. It has a fairly thick mouthfeel and seems to be carbonated just the right amount, enough to give it a good consictency but not be distracting. It is a pleasure to drink but since it is dark the drinkability suffers a bit, easy to drink one glass but after that it gets harder.
Very soild porter. nice smokey flavor that is not overpowering. nice rich flavors of chocolate, roasted malts, and hops.  another great brew from Stone.

Bottle courtesy of Beervirgin72.........thanks Dawn!  :)

Poured a deep, deep brown, almost black, letting almost no light in. Head was creamy and left a nice smooth thick lace. The nose hits home with a start of minty hops and roasted coffee beans. It then leads into cocoa and milk chocolate with a dark fruit component, and the smoke just barley makes an appearance. This is a very roast-forward porter upfront in the mouth. The roast is accompanied by a dark chocolate and sweet plums. Following towards the finish are bitter espresso notes with a very fresh hop profile. Quite bitter with a nice minty, sweet aftertaste. Interesting there is very little smoke here. This is a very creamy, drinkable porter, and at 5.9%, I could drink a lot of this. Thanks Dawn, for giving me the opportunity to try this. Ive wanted this for a while, and it makes a perfect #1300. Much appreciated!
I love porters, and this one was no exception.  It was black with tan head, and of course had a smoky taste.
Utterly delicious porter here especially when it warmed up.  Lots of chocolate, roasted malts, dark fruit, and the merest hint of wood smoke evident in this one.  Another great offering from Stone...

Aroma: vague smokyness, malt, obscene, beautiful, chocolate, hops. Quite subtle. 
Flavour: nice, hoppy, smoky, delicate sweetness. Nutty & oily. 
Palate: lovely, velvet, coffeelike mouthfeel. Crisp. 
Appearance: deep blackish red with beige head.

Nice porter.  Poured very dark with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Some smoke is barely present.  Not overwhelming, which is nice.  Taste is very crisp, of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate.  I cant really taste any smoke.  Finish is very crisp, with some hops coming through.  Mouth is smooth and body is medium, maybe a little light for a porter.  Overall, a great porter.

subtle smoke, but still great--quaffable and tasty; cocoa and stinky cheese nose, the aroma remains as chocolate and coffee; good balance from the hops that makes this not overwhelming, but i could use more smoke; i would love to have more because this beer is simple, but hides more quality.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2008  Pours dark brown with great dark tan head retention.  Aroma is not overbearingly smokey, but certainly present.  Base porter is roasted and silky with nice smoke qualities.  Personally, Id like more smoke, but this is a well balanced beer.
a interesting porter...smoke is not overpowering at all.....very nice!  good malt backbone..and great balancing of hops

Dark brown pour, with a medium foamy tan head that leaves a little lacing.  Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted nuts and smoke.  Very tasty.  Dark fruits, chocolate, and a hint of smokiness.  Not bad at all!

I am learning that I dont much like porter as a style. That is unfortunate because this is a very nicely balanced brew with good color, reasonable mouth feel and a nonlingering finish. But, I like hops.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2009 I remember first buying this beer at a local liquor store in Las Vegas and having high expectations. The aroma had a nice nutty and smokiness to it. It poured an awsome black and had a brown head. The taste was exceptional, with notes of chocolate, coffee, and smokiness from start to finish. A nicely balenced porter and one of my favorites out there.

I general havent like Stone in the past (specifically the bastards) but this one is pretty good.  It is not boozy and has a nice consistent taste.  Nice dark beer with coffee and roasted nut taste with hints of smoke.  If you dont like smoked beers you will probably still like this as the smoke is not overpower like Left Hands smoke jumper for example.  This has more of just a hint of smoke rather than it overpowering the whole beer.

brown pour, healthy tan head head, good lacing.  Mellow chocolate, coffee.  hints of dark fruits.  Mouth is smooth and smoky.  Bittersweet chocolate taste, slightly dry finish.  Had in bomber on this occasion and have on tap at Strangebrew in Manchester.  Delicious, wonderfully ballanced porter with a strong but mellow smokiness

22oz bottle from Total Wine, River Edge, NJ...pours black with beige head...malty aroma with subtle coffee and chocolate...smokey dry flavor, coal, roasted dark coffee bean, dark chocolate powder...abundance of flavor...creamy but dry mouthfeel.

22 ounce bottle, first pour, in tumbler (no pint glasses at my mothers in AZ).  Black with lasting tan head and lotsa lace.  Smoky chocolate and chocolate chip cookie dough aroma.  Fruity chocolate fig flavor, with smoke and roasted chocolate, and mild-to-medium finishing bitterness and some lingering smoky dark chocolate.  Medium-full body and medium-low carbo.  Friggin excellent all-around.

22 oz bomber in a snifter.  Aroma of roasted  malt, dark fruit, hint of coffee and smoke.  Dark brown with nice tan head.  Heavy smoke in the flavor with  chocolate, coffee, and hop bitterness in the finish.  Not a big fan of porters, hard to get through the smoke of this one.  Ill stick with Edmund Fitzgerald over this one.

I love the aroma, a deep smokiness with all kinds of robust chocolate and dates.  Nice light brown head that is quite plentiful.  Flavor is... porter.  Im just not crazy about porters for some reason.  I love the smoky character to it.  This is probably one of my favorite porters. I would drink a sample of this and love it, but a whole bottle is too much for me.

Bomber poured into a pint glass. Mahogany color with a medium tan head. Some lacing and decent retention.

Aroma is not particularly smokey, instead reverting to the notes of a standard porter: roasted malt and chocolate.

Flavor is very roasty with coffee flavors sweetened by chocolate. The smoke takes a larger role here than in the smell, complementing the charred roastiness.

Pretty thick in mouthfeel with low carbonation. Smooth but a little flat to me. Overall one of the better smoked porters.
Has a slighty smokey coffee aroma. Nice dark appearance. Good smokey chocolate taste, a little bittersweet.

Poured a little too vigorously, so it had a huge foamy, frothy head. Beautiful head. Nose is roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is smooth and roasted malt with some coffee, just like the nose. Slight bitter finish. Good brew.

Oct. 2007 - Dark pour, one finger head, little lacing. Little aroma. The flavor was a mix of fruit and roast with faint chocolate. The smokiness also comes out, but not overpowering. Thick smooth mouthfeel coats the tongue. Good beer, but not fantastic.

I just could not get as excited over this one as most people are. While the thiock body and rich tastes found in most Stone beers was present, the smoke overwhelmed all other scents and flavors. I did detect some chocolate and coffe in the nose and palate, but again, I had to fight through too much smoke to get there.

I would enjoy this beer much more as just a Porter, that hasnt been smoked,
Nice and rich, this is what a porter should taste like.  Smooth and dry, dark in color, malty and smoky.

From bottle. Smoked coffee, chocolate aroma. Very dark ruby red, almost black colour with a stained head. Smoked, roasted hop flavour. found it lacked something which I cant put my finger on. A good porter mind.
This beer has a lot of character for a porter. Cofee, chocholate, malt, and hops are all present in a nice combination. Cant wait to try their RIS.

Mighty tasty selection from Stone, one of my favorite brewers. Aroma and flavor redolent of smoky malt, coffee and chocolate. From the first taste you know you are in for a treat. Excellent silky mouthfeel. Aftertaste lingers pleasantly, whispering that hops were involved, too. This goes on my top shelf, and Im an IPA man!

Pours a deep red black with well formed light tan head and nicely formed lacing. Aromas of roasty chocolate blend perfectly with mild smoky notes. There is a slight spice to the nose, perhaps a combination of the smoke and hops, and a subtle touch of fruit. 
Great balance of flavors between the sweetness, medium bitter dark chocolate, and light pleasant smoke. Ends on a roasty note with mild smoke and piney hops/. Body is slightly creamy and finishes mediumm dry. Very nice drinkable porter. The light smoke adds a really wonderful twist to this brew. Carbonation is nice and prickkly up front turning smooth on the the back end.
Really enjoyed this (more-so after it got a bit warmer). Pour damn near black.
Very prominent smoke flavor and aroma. Poured black with a medium thick head of tan color. Goes good with BBQ and steaks.
Very dark brown with a nice tan head. Aromas of coffee, malts, dark chocolate and smoke. Flavors of smoked meat, coffee and roasted malts.

deep brown, almost black color, medium tan head, nice lacing.  aroma of mild smoke, malt, coffee.  flavor of unsweetened coffee, chocolate.  full-bodied, with a lingering bitterenss, and finally leaving a sweet note in the finish.
Pours black with a nice white head.  Good flavor with a hints of dark roasted coffee and chocolate.  Let this one warm up and more flavors start to pop up.  Another fine beer from Stone

750ml bottle.  Pours black with medium lasting tan head.  Contains a slight smokey aroma.  Good carb.  Coffee, roasted malt, creamy with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Very drinkable, and great with food.

Bottle. Black pour, thin light tan head with a few bubbles popping around that dissipates quickly. Not much of an aroma. Nice sweet taste with perhaps a hint of smoke. Not nearly as smoky as the Alaskan smoked porter (which just preceded the stone in my tasting) very close to a standard porter.
Pours a dark chocolate color with a nice tan head. With a strong coffee aroma. Chocolatey/coffee flavor with a hint of smoke. Really surprised I could taste a bit of smoke. Really good beer.
smells sweet with a very faint smokeyness.  very small head, that picture to the left is misleading :)  I taste chocolate and dark fruit, with the smoke appearing during the finish

incredible aroma- blasts your nostrils into oblivion. appearance is gorgeous, dark brown, almost black. complex flavor- raisins, toffee, dark chocolate, and the obvious smoked overtones. mouthfeel is great- sticks to the tongue. awesome beer.

Bottle:  Very dark brown almost black pour with a nice thick off white head that went thin after sitting for a minute.    First scent is of liquid smoke and a dark chocolate.  Similar in taste as well.

Bomber. Extremely fizzy, literally 90% head. Something wrong with this bottle maybe? I found the nose to be relatively tight, maybe a little caramel. After a few minutes the head settled to reveal a nice black color. The first thing that came to my mind when i tasted it was smoked bacon. There is a hint of sweet malt and coffee but the smoke dominates. I think there was something off with this bottle though.

Pours very dark with a massive and thick tan head... bomber may have been dropped at some point... Roasted caramel coffee aroma, smells more sweet then smoky. Strong but smooth coffee taste with a roasted malt finish. Smoke is kind of an overlay to the entire taste.

tap had at the Stone Bistro on 3/2.... a dark brown almost black pour allowing some light to penetrate.  topped off with a tan had that settled after some time.... nose of chocolate malt with lighter hints of smoke and ash....flavores of smoke, burnt roast, chocolate.  really light on the palate overall, smooth and highly drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2008 Pours a solid light brown head, pitch black color.  Slight aroma of chocolate.  Rich, toasted malt and chocalte flavors with slight smokey flavor at the end.   Not much hops bitterness.  Goes down surprisingly smooth for all those strong flavors.  Im amazed how well theyve balanced all the rich flavors, especially the smoke.  Its easy to ruin something with too strong a smokey taste.
Bomber.  Notes are from memory.  This was sweeter than the Alaskan Porter drank side by side and did not show much smokiness at all.  A soft but weighty palate with a sweet midpalate.

Bomber. Nearly black, not much head. I agree that the smoke isnt quite the lead actor here, though it is present along with the usual coffee and chocolate. Mostly dry. Im not sure I like the smoke...its a bit ashy. Body is medium, a tad over-fizzed. I didnt like this as much as others did.

22oz brown bomber, served in a shaker pint. Poured a dark brown almost black with a couple of fingers of fine bubbled tan head. Not a lot of smoke in the aroma, some chocolate malt and a little hops. Roasty, chocolate malt flavor that quickly gives way to the smoke. Dry finish with the smoke and chocolate malt really lingering. A fair amount of hop bitterness in the middle. Smoke seems to come out more as the beer warms.

A solid smoke flavor without being overwhelming on top of a good base beer. Flavors of the base beer come through.

Bomber purchased at Crown Liquors #15, in Fishers, IN. Pours a deep reddish brown with a sizable creamy/frothy head that leaves behind a trail of sticky lace. The nose is truly interesting. On the pour, I am hit by an aroma that reminds me of a peanut butter and banana sandwich (emphasis on the fruit). As the head diminishes, the peanut butter transitions into more of a cocoa note with a touch of fruity hops in the background. Medium-bodied and slick, with a smoky, roasted and lightly bitter finish. Thr flavor features a lot more roasted character than the nose would indicate. The flavor runs from dark roast, caramel and chocolate malt to a hard wood smokiness and fruity hops at the conclusion. This is a tasty and very drinkable porter with a subtle smokiness that supports, rather than dominates, the flavor. I would bet this pairs well with all kinds of foods. I suppose that i will have to acquire some more and find out if Im right.

Great looking: rick dark brown (almost black) with a great tan beige head that held only so long.  Smelled of a rich porter: chocolate, dark fruits, molasses, and smoke.  Flavor is the same, pretty complex flavors that surface at different times as you drink further.  Palate feels good, thick and rich.  Overall: great porter... only way it would have been better is if it were a "strong ale" (thus leading to more alcohol and a bit more flavor).
looks beautiful, just like a porter should, tastes smoky, hence the name, yummy coffee and chocolate flavors, would recommend to all porter drinkers
Pours dark brown with an off white head. Aroma mostly of smoke and fruit. Flavor is similar with the addition of some deeply roasted flavors.

From bottle : Pours very dark brown with bubbles clinging to the side of the glass.  Forms a finger of light brown head, with tons of bubbles, that slowly fades, but leaves still more bubbles and pretty sticky lacing.  Nose has alot going on.  Fruit notes, smokyness, roasted malts, and small hints of chocolate.  Flavor is very good too, this is a really nice porter.  Roasty malts come out first, followed with some subtle smokyness.  Towards the end we have some chocolate and coffee flavors, and a little hop presents on the very end.  Feels wonderful in the mouth, very smooth.  Medium body that just flows right through your palate.  This is really a good porter.

Bottle - Pours appears dark brown with some chestnut highlights but when held to the light you find that its a dark ruby with brown edges.  Lovely generous tan foam.  Aroma is musty with light woody scents w/ faint peat smoke.  Flavor is subtle roasted malt, faint chocolate and peat smoked malt (but not noticeably smokey).  Mouthfeel is medium with light carbonation and a dry bitter finish.  As the beer warmed, the peat smoked malt became a bit stronger toward the finish.
Pours a dark brown with a nice beown head. Aroma of chocolate, malt, coffee. Flavors of roasted malts, with subtle hints of chocolate, smoke and coffee. This is a very smooth well balanced porter.

Poured from a 22oz bomber and served in an English pint glass.  This porter poured a dark brown with a two-finger thick head of slowly fading tan foam that settled into a thin, creamy, lasting layer.  Heavy lacing covered the sides of the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of very mild chocolate, vanilla, and a bit of smoke.  The flavor consisted of a subltle blend of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and roasted malts.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and creamy smooth with mild carbonation.  Very tasty and smooth without the harsh, dry coffee bitterness displayed in other porters.  Not enough smoke, though!

The best parts the appearance - its rather beautiful. The consistency and mouth-feel are also nice, but I find the flavor pretty dull. Dark, smoky, dry: Its all that, yes... but not strikingly tasty.

Extra credit for being from my hometown of San Diego, though. :)

Bottle. Pours ebony with a good amount of transparency around the edges where the brew thins. A nice abundant tan head forms and lasts for some time. The aroma isnt strong at all. I notice some cocoa, vanilla, smoke, and a little bit of wood. But it took me a few times of pressing my nose into the mouth of the glass. The initial flavour is mildly chocolaty with hints of wood, and a bit of vanilla and brown sugar. The brew passing causes me to think, "watery," as it has that similar feeling in your mouth when you drink unfiltered tap water. Hm, thats not exactly a quality that I like. The smoked and wood notes start to creep in. The smoked notes seem to mix nicely with the chocolate flavour. Though, the feeling of the unfiltered tap water just doesnt seem to go away. All in all, this is okay. Its drinkable. But far from impressive.
Nice pour and attractive.  Smells rich, chocolate, burnt.  Tastes clean porter, mild smokiness.  Okay not Stones best effort.

Pretty black color with a loose tan head. Slightly smoky aroma. Heavy on the roasted malts at the front with a bitter finish and occasionally smoky element in there. A little metallic. Apart from that standard porter flavors. You dont get the smokiness on every sip. You kinda have to look for it, some of my friends could not find it at all.
This is the beer that made me look for more by Stone.  Smokey, but not overwhelming.  One of my favorites, a dark, full-bodied beer -- glad my "beer guy" can get the bombers by the case for me.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 650 ml. Opaque black with a three finger head that settles to a lasting ring. Earthy coffee, smoke, cocoa, wood and molasses aroma. Marshmallow and molasses flavor is well-tamed by the peat, cocoa and coffee. Some wood and prickly-herby hops peek through at the finish. Medium body is smooth with light carbonation, slightly watery and dry-chalky at the same time, like a good porter should be.

on tap -pours a rich tan head and black color with red tint.  Aroma is dark malt-chocolate, peat, some dark fruit.  Taste is sweet dark malt-chocolate, peat/smoky, some dark fruit, earthy hops.  Nicely done, not my style.  Occasional.

Bomber pours a dark chestnut body with a healthy tan head. Aroma of burnt charcoal, Pacific hops, and caramel. Taste features smoke, fruity hops, a hint of chocolate, and some roasty bitterness. Topnotch!

Bottled.  Pours a thick motor oil black with no head.  An incredible beer with smoke, chocolate, fruit, and caramel.  Very smooth, very calm.  Seems like it should be stronger, and it probably should be.  Will definitely have to buy again.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is smoked, coffee, cocoa. Flavour is smoked, coffee, hop, sweet, roasted. Very nice beer, but i wish there should be more.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2009 22 oz bottle. Dark brown body with a small dense beige head. Aroma is smoked, some liquorices, chocolate and coffee as well. Flavor is light roasted malt, some chocolate malt, coffee and a decent bitterness. Not bad at all, but I find it a bit weak and disappointing anyway comparing with many other fine smoked porters. Maybe has something to do with a relative low ABV

Re-ratet 650ml bottle. Dark brown with a medium beige head. Quite mild roasted malt aroma with coffee and chocolate. Flavor has a mild and pleasant roastines, malt, chocolate, coffee with a gentle balanced bitter finish. Very pleasant and easy drinkable.

bomber.  quite a porter... this one has more flavor than any other porter Ive had before... pours a deep dark brown - approaching black with a 1" tan head.  aromas of malts, chocolate, coffee and slight fruits.  as the beer flows over the palate more distinct flavors come through - such as liquorice, slight smoke and dark fruits.  I really like how the smoke flavor does not dominate the beer like some other smoked porters.  This beer is incredibly well balanced and dynamic.  Wonderful palate from front to back, medium full body with smooth sides and a lively front.  Excellent finish leaves you wanting more.

This beer is nowhere near  the smokiness that I was expecting.  There is really very little smiokiness in it at all, but has more of an earthiness to it than full smoked flavor.  It comes across as a choclate lovers dream with a hint of bitterness but a large amount of sweetness to balance out.  It has very little bitterness with the full sweetness up front and center.

poured in a wide bodied red wine glass.  very dark with a small but full bodied head - the color of which is reminiscent of what you might see on top of a root beer float.  Absence of hops smell (duh) and faint aroma of bittersweet chocolate.  Solid mouth feel - a bit chewy.  Im impressed with the blending (as advertised) of the smoked malt, I was expecting it to perhaps overpower - but not the case.  Good beer...
Stones Smoked Porter is really good. It tastes like coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate.
A really good porter, but light on the smoke flavor when compared to Alaskan Smoked Porter.  Lots of chocolate and coffee/toffee flavors.  Nice and thick. Well done Porter

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Bottle, 22oz. Pours a very dark brown, with a rather small beige to tan head. Chocolate, a little smoked note, cocoa and coffee in the aroma. The flavor has chocolate, roasted malt, some smoke, and a nice, hoppy bitterness. Full body. Long, roasted finish with chocolate, nice fruityness and a pleasant bitterness. A nice smoked porter, could wish for more smoked though. 6-4-7-4-14-3.5. 071228Bottle, 22oz, at Cardinal. A clear, dark brown beer with a beige head. Roasted nose with chocolate and some smoke. Would have liked more smoke though. Theres only notes of smoke in the flavor too, chocolate and coffee, roasted malts that is, dominating, and a fine bitterness showing up in the back. The bitterness finishes off the beer in a nice way too. Full-bodied. A fine beer that probably would benefit from more smoke, but thats just me maybe. 090728
Poured black with a creamy brown head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavor was mostly the same. Wheres the smoke?

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Good porter, not remarkable.  The smoke hardly comes through in the aroma, It simply has a chocolate, roasty quality.  The appearance had the standard porter look, deep balck with a ring of crimson.  The flavor was chocolate, roasty, and a little smoke, not as much smoke as expected.  The palate has the usual pleasing finish of bittersweet chocolate for a porter, and the mouthfeel is medium/full, creamy.  Not bad.
Dark brown with nice head.  Mellow smoke and molasess/chocolate aroma/taste.  Not overly "American" in a hoppy sense.  Slightly bitter finish.  Well balanced.

Bomber.  Pours a deep brownish black with a fairly thin head. Light roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate but much less smoke on the nose and palate than I anticipated.   Medium bodied with an ok mouth feel.  This one is only my second smoke brew so I dont have much to compare and contrast yet, but the Alaskan Smoked Porter is far superior to this beer.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2008 Great beer.  Thick head and dark, almost black appearance.  Looks "thick" in a good way. Aroma of smoke, but the dark malt flavors come through. Flavors could have been ever so slightly stronger. Wonderful on the palate. Smooth finish.

The commercial description is right on for this wonderfully balanced beer. No one element is too pronounced but the smoked flavor is a bit understated IMO. Black malt is less evident than in most Porters as evidenced by the roasty flavor of other dark malts.
Bottle, at Yngwie´s xmas-tasting. Dark brown/reddish color. Beige head.Roasted malt, not very much «smoked» here. Coffee and chocolate in a nice, but not world class porter.

22oz. bottle.   Almost black with a tan head.   Nice chocolate aroma with a little smoke.   The flavor was typical porter, with some roast and acidity, but the smoke is almost undetectable, and this makes me sad.   I wish that there was a hundred times more... but this is life.   Pretty nice porter considering, but nothing amazing.

Very interesting beer.  A lot of malty character - coffee and chocolate.  The smokiness is so subtle that it almost tastes like a rich porter bring drunk by a campfire.  Finishes bittery-smooth...and very warm.
A bit chalky for my taste, and little to no smoke.  Could have been sweeter, too.  Otherwise, an okay porter from a really good brewing company

Bomber.  Pours very dark/opaque with a creamy tan head.  A bit of soap in the nose.  First taste is wonderful.  A bit of caramel, smoke, and a touch of fruit.  A little coffee taste as well.  Just a touch metallic.  Very good smoked porter.
Best smoked porter Ive had. Well balance, with nothing overplayed. Lots of hops. Great look and mouthfeel.

Porter fans rejoice. Stone is a great brewery with some great hits. This beer is not strong in aroma but the flavors are heavy. stone describes these flavors well. The smokey finish is a very enjoyable addition to this porter. Dark but not too heavy, make sure to enjoy a big glass of this delicious beer.

Going from memory here. I remember the body being a bit thin here. It poured a very dark brown, no where near black. Tons of roastiness, very hearty flavours of burnt wheat, coffee and smoke. The kind of smoke that comes off of sugared ham, if that makes sense. Great porter.
nice dark brown color.  creamy with a nice smoked aftertaste.  I enjoyed this beer
Bottle. Deep dark brown color, almost black. Beechwood, cream and a bit of soap in the aroma. Medium bodied. Creamy, soapy flavor with beechwood, cheese and lychee. Long smoky aftertaste.

served cold from tap. poured black, not oily, jet black like a stout, but definitely opaque. nice tan head. aroma is very sweet of malts and maybe some hints of coffee. definite smoky flavor, but not overbearing at all. its actually rather smooth, and easy to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2008 A dark, opaque beer with a healthy tan head that leaves drinking lines.  The aroma is rich and sweet - malt, hops, yeast.  The first gulp introduces the smoky flavor, and for a moment I wonder if I should put it in a glass or a pipe.  There is a good malt presence and those  peppy Stone hops are noticable as well.  This is a liquid malt-hop barbeque - very nice!  Just as the description says, they do not overdo the peat-smoked malt.  It is not as dramatic as some other Stone releases, but it is still another excellent beer from them.

Bomber. Black with a 1 finger tan head. Smells mildly meaty, but not as overpowering as some smoked beers. Same goes with the flavor...the smoke is definitely there, but doesnt overpower the palate. Theres still the body nutty flavors of the underlying porter here. Good stuff.
Not that great. Surprisingly light bodied and weak. Some sweetness and smoke to it. Roasted malt flavor as well. Watery, sweet finish.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 Tasty. Black in color with a dark tan head.Smells of coffee. Silky palate. Taste bitter sweet, coffee and maulty. A very tasty Porter. 
*Had this beer again but this time w/ a GRILLED PB&J and it was so so good! Highly recommended. Just get some sour dough bread and make a PB&J. then butter the outside and grill it like a grilled cheese. You wont be disappointed with this great combo.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2009 draft. pours black with one finger brown head.  nice espresso aroma. taste brings in roasted malts and a mild smokey flavor.  palate is fantastic - light body without being water and an extremely mild carbonation that just tingles the tongue and lets the flavors do all the work.  clean, dry, and bitter finish (without the green hoppy flavors that ive found with great lakes, sierra nevada, etc). a really great porter. recommended!

22 oz bottle.  Pours a nearly black ruby color with 1 cm off-white/tan head that is mostly diminishing.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and caramel, very slight aroma of smoke.  Initial flavor is a little sweet and smoky at the same time.  Aftertaste is lasting and dominated by smoke and bitter from coffee or chocolate.  Medium bodied, light carbonation, light lacing, and only a hint of alcohol detected.  Very drinkable, as both a good porter and smoky beer.
750 mL bottle. Pours black body with brown head. Smells extremely roasty and something else. Taste is great if you like porters - not a big fan personally.

Acquired in trade with Snojerk321, pint bottle, served in pint glass- poured black as midnight in the driving rain, 10 % transparency, tan head quietly dissolved.  Aroma of roasted malts, toffee, and a hint of chocolate.  Hits the mouth with a wide body, notes of smokeiness, finish is solid.  Very delightfull, would be a full time drinker of this if I could find it in my area!

Bottle - Pours clear but opaque dark brown with a slight tan head. Roasted aroma. Big body with full mouthfeel. Creamy. Underlying hop bitterness, big dark malt flavors and subtle smoky character with mild phenolic notes. Well done.

Pours black with a greyish tan head. Not a creamy head.  Aroma is not strong but I get coffee and caramel.
Mouthfeel is very carbonated but its got more body than most porters Ive had.  The flavor is a little cherry caramel and coffee.   The smoke is there but it just flavors the other flavors.  Its very well balanced and drinkable.  MIght be the best porter Ive ever had.  It tastes like...more.

Pours very dark brown/almost black. Aroma of chocolate and smoke. Flavor upfront of smoke, with a chocolate and hop background. Pretty good, but not up to par with east end smoke porter which i compare them all to.

Bottle from Sicilianos in Grand Rapids, MI.  Dark brown almost black color with small tan head.  Aroma is some aged cherry, roasted malt, only slight coffee, medium hops, and smoke as it warms.  Flavor is smoke, chocolate, very nutty, pine bitter, very nice.  Hotly carbonated with medium body.  Very nice flavor and aroma, I love how solid stone is yet being so inexpensive and accesible.

Stone just continues to put out the good ones!  Pours a dark chestnut brown with a beautiful head.  Lots of coffee and smoke flavor in this porter.  One of my fav. porters out there and decently priced.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: (bottle): Pours a black-brownish body. Tannish color heap, average & lasting, decent lasting. Very smoky aroma, mesquite. Woody. Porterish. Ashtrayish. Watery, smoky, coffee taste. Mesquity. Good & tasty.

Pours a deep, dark chestnut brown, almost black with a foamy beige head.  Smoky malt aroma with hints of dark chocolate, coffee and toffee.  Smooth, delicaate mouthful with a slighhtly bitter finish.  Creamy chocolate roasted maltiness with hints of roasted cofee
On tap at Bonaventure. Full dark tan head. Smoky, but not much else. It was good (because I love smoked beers - probably because I was a smoker) but if you dont love smoke you wont like this one.
i dont like stouts. never really cared for porters. i think its the chocolate. but this beer. this beer could be the gateway drug.

The Stone Smoked Porter pours almost black with a fluffy light brown head, but embodies a very red hue when you hold it up to a light.  The flavors of smoke and roasted malt are more subtle than I would have expected, especially from Stone co. but the beer is more drinkable than I expected too.  A pleasant porter.

Bomber split with Naka.  Pours black w/ smally beige head rimming the glass.  Deep roasted malt w/ a touch of smoke and raisin fruit nose.  Big, roasty flavor, coffe and bitter w/ a nice subtle smoke to accent the bitterness at the end.  Delicious porter.

A blackness from which no light escapes with a light tan one-finger head.  A hint of hickory smoke with some strong sweet vanilla and caramel malt.  Coffee and caramel in the taste with a good smokey backbone that isnt overpowering.  It is a very distinct smoke flavor, not roasted.  It has a decent body, but I expected a little more for how dense it looked.  Had a relatively dry finish.

Very dark brown to black in colro with ruby highlights and a lovely tan head.  Delicous smoke aromas dominate.  Strong dark and rick with nice maltiness.  Full bodied with a warming alcohol character.

This one is pretty special for me- 100th rating on a great beer. Damn this is delicious. Upon first whiff I was  bombarded with malt, hops, and a certain smoky quality that only comes after a day of sitting next to a campfire. The flavour was so very smooth...rich malt and a bit of hop bite- but not too much to be overwhelming. Just perfect hop integration with a bit of a subtle citrus undertone which gets along great with the smoky flavour. Apart from that, the flavour contains notes of licorice, bitter chocolate, and roasted coffee. Lacing is also incredible. Smooth, creamy, and delicious- just a plain great porter.
POW! ZING! KAP! Smooth and smoky like a musty old jazz club. Yeah, cats! On tap at BURP CASTLE!!!

bottle form secret santa thanks paul: pours black with some crimson coming thru when put to light. large tan head with lacing. aroma is slight smoke with roasted malt and chocolate. flavour is very nice roasted malt and a good smooth chocolate. just hints of the smoke a very well balanced tasty porter that is very enjoyable

Bomber.  Pours near black with reddish brown edges. Nice sized light tan head that lasts and leaves chunks of lacing all the way down the glass. Nose is of chocolate, coffee, hints of vanilla, and smoke in the background. Taste is similar with chocolate and coffee being the most prevalent, caramel malt backbone, with a smokiness that truly compliments it all. Light citrus hops on the finish with roasted malt coming through as well. Medium-light slick mouth feel with carbonation that tingles a bit.

Jet black beer with a fluffy tan head.  Aromas contain bittersweet chocolate and biscuit.  Nice dry balance and flavor of roast coffee and a green tree essence.  Medium body and nice dry finish.  I love this beer.

22oz Bottle: Pours dark brown w/ a large light brown head. Leaves some nice lacing behind as well. Aroma holds sweet malts, light smoke & a bit of nuttiness. Roasted malt flavor w/ a burnt coffee finish. Nice mouthfeel, kind of creamy. Very well balanced. After the true rating was done I ate some peanut butter cookies w/ the rest, yum.

Deep brown/black pour with a tan head that dissipates quickly.  Good chocolate aroma with a bit of smoke and bread.  Also, a slight Guinness sour smell.  Nice malty taste with obvious smoke and toffee notes.  Great porter!  Not overly smokey like some I have tasted.
Deep black pour with a light head. All the things you look for in a porter. The best porter i have had to this date hands down.

Pours almost black with a ruby hue. 3 fingers of light chocolate milk head with an aggressive pour that holds then dies to a ring. Smells of chocolate and a little caramel with a hint of smokiness. Tastes as it smells, subtle but delightful flavors and even an ever so slight hoppiness. Medium, creamy and smooth as silk in the mouth with a slight carbonation tickle. Drinks like a session beer and delightfully so.

Pitch black with a huge, creamy and lasting head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, sweet coffee and a light touch of smoke. The flavour has notes of sweet licorice, roasted malt, slightly bitter coffee, caramel and a light touch of smoke. The finish has a light touch of citrus, mostly grapefruit. 2566

Pours dark brown or black, cant see through it when held up to the light in a pint glass. Rich, creamy light brown head. Smells smokey. With hints of malt. 
Tastes less smokey than it smells but still smokey. The smoke is balanced well by the malt and the hops. Palate is creamy and smooth with no ill effects in the mouth. This isnt my favorite style of beer, in fact I think this is really the first time Ive had it since I started drinking beer.

Bomber.  Dark brown/black with a frothy beige head leaving striped lacing.  Aromas of coffee, cocoa, raisins, dark cake and some minerals.  Lightly smoky roast coffee flavor-robust but smooth- with some chocolate character.  Mild charred leaf essence left behind.  Very nice.  Another quality brew from Stone.

black pour..sudsy head....sweet malt aroma...coffee and charred goodness in the start ....crisp finish with a nice aftertaste....some licorice and chocolate but not overpowering...very nice, kicked back and complex

On tap at The Old Toad in Rochester, NY. Appearance: Black with small tan head. Aroma: Roasted malts, coffee and sweet hops. Palate: Full, coats mouth well. Flavor: Burnt chocolate malts, some coffee. Very well balanced by hops. Overall: Very tasty and well balanced beer. Loved it.

On tap poured a deep opaque black body with a great two-fingered tan head. Nose of mild smokiness and bold maltiness.  Coffee and chocolate notes and a bit bitter.  Smoke come out more in the finish than in the first sips.  Rivalled only by Alaskan Smoked Porter.  Yum!

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 Nice dark pour with an inviting look to it.  Not a lot of smoked aroma or taste, which is something i thought was a bit off because it was a Stone, i was looking for over the top in both.  Nice malty-ness but barely any alcohol to thicken it up in a way that it should have.

A coal black pour with tan lace. Light smoke aroma and coffee nose. A very coffee flavor with light smoke and very roasty malt flavor. Very nice bitter finish with a semi sweet after taste. A bit foamy but a very fulll solid palate. A very good all round beer light smoke but lots of flavor. A bottle that had been in the cellar for 2 years.

Pours a dark dark red brown with a latte colored head. Smells of roast, chocolate, sweet hops, a lot like your standard porter. If it didnt say smoked on the label, I might not believe it. Vaguely smoky flavor, lots of roast and chocolate, and it comes across as being incredibly rich and mealy. The smoke comes across much stronger in the finish than in the thick of the beer. Very balanced, with a decent hoppy edge that preserves its drinkability. Sticky, medium thick mouthfeel - somewhere between a standard porter (perhaps Anchors) and an impy stout. Wood, chocolate, ash, a bit of bitterness, hints of coffee here and there. All in all quite a nice, big beer.
Pours dark brown with a decent sixed head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, and coffee. Nice flavor, sweet to begin and finishes with a little bitterness. Good mouthfeel. Thanks OG.

1000th rating for this beer!

Courtesy of my Summer Secret Santa. Thank you. 22oz bomber. Dark brown, very nearly black pour. 2 finger thick, creamy looking dark khaki colored head. Pretty densely packed with only a smattering of bubbles on top of a mountain of foam. Mostly lasting, leaves a thick layer of foam once the head dies down a bit. Impressive coating sheet lacing. Nose of rich dark chocolate, coffee/espresso, peat malts, dark fruits and molasses. The little touch of smoke makes this one really stand out among other Porters Ive had. This smells really good. Peat, molasses, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits and charred roasted smoky malts make up the flavor profile. There is a bitterness present as well, just in the background, playing tricks on your mind. Medium bodied, fairly substantial, creamy mouthfeel. Coating on the tongue. Finish is lengthy, bitter and smoky, with a nice kick of roasted malts and chocolate to finish things out. A really, really good Porter.

Dark black with a short tan head that leaves moderate lacing on the sides of the glass.  The aroma is light, while roasted malts, cinnamon and chocolate come through.  The flavor has a light roasted bitterness, some chocolate, and plenty of smokiness that lasts through the exhale following a most enjoyable sip, and then gulp.  This is very nice and could be enjoyed on many occasions.

Bottle. About 9 months old. Black color, amber edging, smalI head. Blame sinus congestion, but aroma was nearly non-existent , it just was not there for me. Thankfully flavor was. A rich dark malt flavor with chocolate, raisin, anise, biscotti, vanilla, cherry, the list goes on. The roastiness comes out as it warms but is never overdone or overly smoky. There is a hint of cough syrup and a touch of tartness underpinning the black malt roastiness. Full bodied but not extremely filling. 5.9% deceived me. Very complex beer gains points in the overall category. Very good.

Had this beer on 10/8/2003.  Aroma is a light roasted scent with a slight dirt tone.  Color is a deep black purple with good carbonation and head.  Taste is rich, sweet and smoky.  Starting with a full medium body that goes down with a rich feel coming on.  Finish is a sweet rich roasted malt flavor backed by a light smokiness.  On the very end is a sharp feel.  Its not as good as Sugardaddy was but is still a nice porter.
UPDATED: DEC 6, 2007 Split a 22 oz. bottle with friends. Head lasted a while. Good coffee/caramel flavor with underwhelming smoke. Smooth. Overall, Im a big fan.
22 oz. bottle split two ways. Poured very dark, limited tan head. Flavor a dark nutty chocolate smoke. An enjoyable drink.
Poured very dark in color. Tasted of chocolate and coffee. Tons of malt flavor. Great beer!!

Murky black pour with a tannish caramel head.  Chocolately aroma with hints of malt and hops. Smooth mouthfeel with a perfect amount of carbonation artfully releases the chocolate, malt, coffee and caramel flavor.  A subtle smoky aftertaste lingers after this one goes down.  Not my favorite Stone but yet another solid brew.
Pours black with a fluffy tan head, the aroma is of coffee and chocolate, the flavor is smoke, coffee and chocolate, finishes bitter, good but i was slightly dissapointed
I really liked this porter from Stone.  Medium body, hints of chocolate and coffee.  Another good brew from Stone...well balanced.

the small bubble head seemed to last quite a while  - appearance got a 5 because of the small bubbles  
 liked the taste  - def smokey  - medium thinner body than i would have liked.  Smokey chocolatey flavor- liked it but not close to the other Stone beers ive had.
22oz bottle. Beautiful black pour with nice creamy head. Great "smokey" malt taste with a big chocolate and dry coffee  presence.

22oz bottle courtesy of Russells in Amherst, MA.
Following Stones advice I prepared a pb&j and cracked my bomber open. I ended up enjoying the sandwich more...

Im a big fan of Stone but this was just awful. SSP had a rusted metal, olive scent. Taste was of smoked rotten olives and beef. There wasnt an ounce of chocolate, vanilla or anything enjoyable in there. Mouth feel was okay but rather thin. When I started on the sandwich it  brought out the alcohol flavor and made things worse. 
Maybe this bottle was bad? Maybe I havent developed a taste for smoked brews? Either way, this is one of the few bombers Ive had to give away, and even then, it went unfinished.
On tap at Stone brewery.  Small bubble head that fades quickly.  A little bit of smoke in the aroma. Light ashy smokey smell and taste.  A little dry and astringent, but pretty mild.  Black color.
Light smoked aroma and dark body.  Roasted malt body with faint smoke undertone.  Light body.

22 oz bomber. Pours a very nice looking pitch black with an ample frothy light beige foamy head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of vanilla and chocolate. Medium bodied with nice carbonation and a velvety smooth feel.  flavor of roasted malts, light chocolate and a hint of smoke. This is probably my least favorite Stone brew and its still incredibally solid.
22oz...This is one silky smooth, dark colored brew...just how I like em.  I only wish they had 6pks available.

10-16-07 bottle.  Ink black with great head and lacing.  Smells of smoked ham and jerky - not as strong as some smoked beers - but is there nonetheless.  I have trouble with liquids that smell or taste like meat - call me crazy.  Overly smoked taste for my liking.  However, the mouthfeel is great.  Maybe someday I will be able to appreciate that smoked smell and taste - but today is just not that day.

22oz.  Poured black with maybe a tinge of red on the outside.  Lasting tan head.  Mostly sweet malt, not much smokiness in the head.  Once you get over the fact that this isnt a rauchbier, it is much more enjoyable.  Definitely opened up a bit once it warmed up a tad, I got a great combination of espresso and creamy mouthfeel that struck me as extremely tasty.  Touch of hops on a semi-dry finish.  Easily one of my favorite porters.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 I used to like this beer a lot more.  I think the production was kicked up to pay for the $13M Bistro & Gardens so they had to take a lot less time and care with their flagship beers.  This is one casualty.

Bottle, Solvang, CA. Nicely dark, not quite opaque. Coffee, smoked malts, chocolate on the nose. Flavor is extremely smooth smoked maltiness, with minimal acidity and bitterness, but some nicely rounding sweetness. Very smooth overall and highly enjoyable. Not very smoky as I wouldve hoped.
Had this one again down in Irvine.  Strong chocolate and coffee flavors to start.  As this one warms, it smooths out and becomes very drinkable.

Poured a nice dark blace with great dark tan head that stuck around.  Almost no light gets through this one.  Aroma of coffee and some chocolate.  Well balanced with malty undertones and the smoke is certainly apparent. Taste is very smooth and honestly a little boring for Stone.  Dont get me wrong, its a very good porter, but Stone has some very bold beers.  Their IPAs make the brewers of Sam Adams look like they forgot to add hops.  I just thought Id get a bit more originality when I picked this up.

Bottle: Poured a deep dark black brown with a creamy thick loight brown head. The aroma was smokey with sweet malt characteristics. The taste filled my mouth with that dark smokey malt, the suttle coffee hints along with chocolate made my mouth water for every sip. Stone has yet to let me down!
Grabbed a bottle at BEVMO while in San Jose.  Great tasting porter, smoky burnt coffee nose and a smokey coffee and dark chocolate taste.  Cheers to Stone!
Nice porter. Aroma is dark and smoky. The first sip is chocolate and coffee with slight hints of smoke. Delicious beer. This beer is excellent with bbq steaks and pastas.

I thought this was a decent tasting beer and a good porter, but pretty marginal in its smoked component compared to other smoked porters Ive had (Alaskan) or rachbiers.

This beer poured a slightly thick black, with a pretty abundant off-white head.  Aroma was pretty minimal, but offered up some nice chocolate malt (burned pizza crust) roastiness.  Flavor was decently roasty, but not very smokey to my palate (although other folks I split the bottle with disagreed).  Mouthfeel was unremarkable.

Not a bad beer, but I wasnt hugely impressed by it.  Definitely recommended though.

Bottle sampled. Pours black with a one finger tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and smokiness. Flavor is smooth and rich with dark roasted malts, cocoa, toffee, and some light smoke with a sweet and bitter finish. A excellent porter.
Black pour.  Aroma of roast malt and smoke.  Taste is dark and smoky.  Stone wins again.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2007 Good beer, tried it with a PB & J as suggested on the bottle, nice compliment. Smoke flavor was more pronounced to me than the bottle and some other ratings suggest. Quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries.

Draft: Looks almost completely black with a 1/2 finger off white dense creamy head. Aroma of roasted malts and lots of caramel as well. Flavor is roasty and malty, medium creamy body. Toasty with just a hint of smoke. I almost wouldnt even call this a smoked beer because its so subtle. I really dig the richness of this beer with a great balance between lots of maltyness with a balanced roast and just a hint of smoke for complexity.

Dark cola color. Redish tint black color. Coffee aroma and expresso taste. It tastes roasted but not smoked. Very nice porter tho, has many stout qualities. Does have a slight wood taste, maybe thats the smoked flavor. Very nice, i only wish it was a little stronger.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 Pours dark brown with a robust 2+ finger head which left nice medium lacing on the glass. Aroma has notes of coffee and a hint of smoke. Flavor has notes of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. The smoke is subordinate. Very dry slightly bitter finish. Mouth feel is medium and very smooth.

22 oz. bottle. Pours black with a big tan head. Has a chocolate malt smell with an essence of smoke. Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel. Taste is of chocolate malts with a very slight smoked quality. Finishes super smooth. 
Not much smoked flavor here, I was expecting more than was found. Still a pretty decent porter.
Oct 2004
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 Stone has never failed me before, and this smoked porter was no exception.  In fact, this is the best Stone beer Ive had.  The smoke taste is just perfect, not overpowering, but very evident.  Very dry beer.  The more porters I try, the more I realize the superiority of Stone Smoked Porter.
Im a sucker for a good porter. This is an awesome example of the quality that comes out of Stone. My personal favorite from Stone. A great beer.

Bottle poured into pint glass.  Opaque black pour with a tan coloured creamy head that lasted forever.  Normal porter aroma of chocolate and coffee.  I think the peat flavours were perfect.  Interesting slant from the porter.

Black pour with a big tan head.  Smell is  slightly sweet roasty malt and chocolate with a medium level of smokiness reminiscent of smoked meat.  Decent mouthfeel, but a bit thin.  Smokiness is more subtle than the Aecht schlenkerla beers, but still very much there.  Flavor overall aside from smokiness is a bit thin and watery.  A bit underwhelming, although not a bad beer.  Wouldnt buy again though.
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 A yummy and rich dark beer, with just the right amount of smokiness-- subtle yet affirms its presence in the finish.  Great with homemade beef jerky.
What more can I say, I have not had one beer from Stone that I have not liked and this being a porter with some smokiness to it.. makes it one great beer.

bomber from olde towne liq. louisville ky. jet black color is solid and thick. light brown head is tall and dense. soft aroma of of smoke and raisins, with dark fruits and lots of roasted malt. toasted bread crust, robust malts, and black coffee. nice hoppy bite slides into a slightly sweet chocolate kiss. pretty damn good!

Mmm, tasty porter. Got just enough roastiness but not to much that makes it a stout. Also, has a good body too whereas other porters sometimes seem a bit thin to me. Would like to drink again if it were available in texas.

22 oz. into pint. Pours a deep, dark brown with a light, tanish head. Smells of chocolate and malts. Taste is at first sweet with a hint of caramel, and finishes with a bit of smoked flavor. Very rich, smooth mouthfeel from start to finish. Will drink again!

Bomber bottle shared with mmmIPA and MattKool. Campfire and chocolate aroma. Chocolate dominates the palate, with undertones of smokiness, licorice, and earth. Medium sweetness. Its nice that the smoke takes a back seat on this one for a change. Given that I recently have tried the Alaskan Smoked Porter and Bieropholies Calumet Grand Chef, this would not likely have done as well if it tried to follow their footsteps. But it didnt, and I was pleasantly surprised at a pretty straightforward, well-made porter with smokey undertones, rather than a rich, decadent treat of a smoked beer.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: UPDATED: OCT 9, 2007 22oz. to glass at dinner in Williamsburg. Almost black brown with medium bodied head. Smell of chocolate, coffee, and malt. Same taste but a smoked finish. expecting more but not bad.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Smells of chocolate, roasted malt, nuts, lots of sweet sugary hints.  Tastes sweet and nutty with a hint of smokiness creeping in at the end.  All in all a very well rounded porter.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2007 This is an outstanding, ruich porter.  Frnm a bottle it is deep, dark reddish brown, almost black, with a thick dark tan head and very good lacing.  The flavour is smooth but rich, deep, and complex.  There is a caramelly sweetness which combines with the bitterness, coffee-chocolate element, and faint smokiness wonderfully.  The texture and palate are similarly smooth and rich.
Aroma of roasted coffee beans and dark chocolate.  Taste is similar.  Mouthfeel is a bit too fizzy for my liking.  Smoke note is very, very faint and almost not detectable.
Dark with a lot of flavor. Definite coffee, a bit of chocolate. Possible caramel. Surprisingly high carbonation. Excellent beer, overall.

good, poured into tulip.  pours a black with full head.  slight malty mocha smoky aroma.  slight smoked milky mouthfeel to smooth finish.  good, light finish, milky palate.  dry aftertaste.  was good.

22 oz bomber. Pours a deep brown with ruby edges. Small tan head. Mouthfeel is medium. Nose is of mild smoke. Kind of like the neighbor several doors down having a bonfire. Taste is of smoky sweetness. The smoke is not overwhelming like some smoked brews and the sweetness is just right. Hints of chocolate and nuts. Dry finish.

Pours a rich dark brown-black with a light brown head.  Wonderful color.  I didnt notice an overpowering smoked aroma, which was a bit of a disappointment.  I like to really inhale that smoky scent on these types of brews!  But the description says "subtle"  so at least it wasnt false advertising.  Roasted malt chocolate.  Medium mouth feel and a little bitter. It kind of lingers on the roof of my mouth.  I didnt like it as much as some of the previous raters.   I have tasted better ones.

Bottled. A nearly black beer with some reddish reflections with a very big and long lasting light brown head, leaving lace on the glass. Nice aroma of malt with hints of chocolate and a light smokiness. the flavour is powerful with chocolate, licorice and roasted malt. The smoke is detectable but doesnt prevail. Soft mouthfeel, quite sweet but there is some bitterness and some hops in the finish. The aftertaste is long. For me very well balanced and not as aggressive as other Stone products. a lovely beer.

Pours black with luxurious creamy, tan head. Robust porter flavor with subtle smokiness that complements, but doesnt interfere with the chocolaty and coffee components. Soft floral hops finish it out.

22 oz. bottle with enjoy by 04 24 07 date on it.  Pours dark brown with a small light tan head.  Aroma is that of a robust porter - roasty with coffee and chocolate notes, with some soft floral dry hops; the smoke element is muted.  Likewise the flavor is dominated by burnt malts which along with the subtle smoke gives it a nice charred wood/campfire character.  Mouthfeel was medium to medium-light and carbonation was moderately low.  I thought this was a pretty solid, well-balanced robust porter, though not terribly exciting.  It was less complex than Id anticipated from the smoked malts and a little thin.

Bottle Black pour with a decent head, no lacing. Rich smoky chocolaty aroma. Flavor following starts with a roasted malty flavor with a hint of chocolate followed by a roasted aftertaste.  I was kinda worried about a too smoky rouchbier flavor, but this was definitely an excellent amount of smoke.

Another great, great beer from my Vegas trip...  purchased at Lees, I couldnt decide which Stone to try...  but I picked a winner!

dark dark devil color, beautiful aromas of slight smoke and coffee and chocolate, taste was chocolate/slight smoke/caramelish....

Bottle.  Nice dark color, with a small tan head.  Nice lacing, though.  Aroma is smoke with a bit of malt.  Taste is a smooth smoke flavor.  Finishes smooth.  A very nice porter, smooth yet with a bit of smoke bite.

Was a little dissapointed with this one, Stone has become one of my favourite breweries, and so I guess I expected alot from this beer. Dont get me wrong, its good, I just thought itd be better. The aroma is weak for a porter, what is there is chocolate, and super light notes of smoke. Flavours are again, weak for a porter, roasty malts, with sweet chocolate, and a vanilla finish, like a few others, I was hard pressed to find any hint of smokey flavour. The palate was a touch watery, but not bad. The beer was smooth, so it went well with a meal, and the flavours were light but complex so it was good to eat dinner with. Just not what Ive come to expect from porters, especially from stone.

Mmmm. A nice and long lasting flow over the palate. The tones are even and it leaves a long taste in your mouth. I have saved trying a lot of the Stone productions in order to build up my palate, but I have to say that I am satisfied with this one beyond what I had expected. I have tried others with stronger flavors, so this wont be an all time favorite, but my opinion of it will always remain high.

Pours a dark brown almost black color with a fairly thick light brown head. Aroma is deep roasted flavors with dark chocolates and light smoke comming out in the various smells. Taste is very rich chocolate with roasted and toasted flavors comming out. Light smoke accents and rounds out the whole beer very nicely. Rich, velvetey, and smooth I found this beer to be a nice treat and very rewarding.

Bottle. Aroma consisted of just a hint of smoke and charred wood that opened up as the beer warmed. Some dark roasted malt. Pours a deed brown, almost black with rich amber highlights. Small khaki head with decent lacing. Rich roasted malt on the palate with dark chocolate and cocoa. Quite dry. Espresso. Finishes with a hint of liquorice. Fairly full bodied and creamy. Nice.

Bottle, Pours quite dark, with a large and fluffy tan head, very slight red coloration, chocolate and mocha elements, a bit of molasses in the nose. Slight sweetness, and ony slightly cloying nothing oily, nice roasty qualities. The medicinal smoke is more noticible in the nose than on the tongue its fairly subdued. A very nice brew.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2012 
Date: September 02, 2000
Mode: Bottle
Source: Norms, DC
