Appearance: dark with ruby highlights, thin tan head
Aroma: light smoked malt aroma
Flavor: rich malt flavor, just a hint of smoky peat, smooth body character, slight bitter finish

Date: April 06, 2005
Score: iii to ii
rich roasted flavor with lots of bitterness, great chocolate character, light bitter finish, just a hint of smoke on the exhale

Date: December 29, 2008
Mode: draft
Source: highlands grill
Score: 2.7 to 3.1
Appearance: black with ruby edges, fine beige head, streaks of lace
Aroma: chocolate aroma with a nice earthyness and just a hint of smokyness
Body: creamy body
Flavor: rich chocolate malt flavor, light roasted, touch of earthy peat belnded with earthy hops, bitter dark chocolate shows up as it warms

Date: October 07, 2010
Mode: draft
Words: duckworths
Appearance: clear dark brown, creamy beige head, solid lace
Aroma: sweet chocolate aroma, caramel sweetness, hint of smoke
Flavor: dry chocolate flavor, nice earthyness along with a light smokeyness

Date: February 26, 2012
Mode: draft
Source: Taco Mac, The Fred
drier and smokier, dry earthy chocolate, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4

Notable roast in that initial aroma.  Pour of blackened oak hue.  An initially dense head recedes into a thin layer of greyish skin.  Suggestions of oranges and pine sap on the nose.  Direct hoppiness.  Astringent French roast, slightly sour, eases its way in beside a thick mash of wild rice and maple syrup.  Silky smoke and milk chocolate taste.  Sweetness is prevalent for the most part as a calm vanilla tobacco, which has a bit of citrus sparkle to it.  Black coffee with a lot of sweetening.  Theres a breath of smoky evergreen bitterness before a thoroughly residual coke  sugar finish.  Reasonably heavy presence in the mouth, but lacks the velvet texture to contextualize it.  The malts are somehow insufficient, or just poorly paired.  Solid, though.

Poured from a bomber.  Pours a deep brown/black color with a nice tan head.  Aroma is mostly roasted malt with some smoke.  The taste is the same with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Smoke is not real evident, but it adds some character to this nice brew.
Bottle.  As far as looks go, this beer is not unlike most porters.  The aroma and flavor is a bit more burnt and smokey.  I definitely did enjoy it.

Bottle. [Courtesy of fiulijn] Average creamy beige head that lasted. Color was black. Fair display of lacework. Aroma was liquorish, hint of smoke, dried fruit, roasted malt. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Light sweet and bitter finish. Light bitter and hint of Smokey finish. 15-08-2007

Had this right after a davidoff ps #7 cigar, so dont take the numbers too serious. Like, I dont taste smoke at all. semi-sweet, mildly acidic. Not a bad porter, but I didnt really get into it, and needed some friends to help finish it. Maybe just too warm this time of year for a stone smoked porter.

very good well rounded beer, little or no smoke flavor, which I was a little disapointed in.  pours pitch black with lots of head, lacing, and carbination. remensient of a coke classic. thanks to hellbilly for te sample.
1 pt 6 fl oz. Pours deep black brown with light brown head. Slight chocolate and malty note aroma. Dry rye malty, smoked, dried raisin flavour. Finish is smoked. Great flavour and aroma.
Very good. Well-rounded. A little sweet, a little chewy, nice roasted flavors, and delicious. A favorite porter.

This is a decent porter but you really have to look for the smoke. This beer is classified as a "porter not a "smoked", so I think the name is just downright confusing. All in all though, like I said, its a nice porter.

Bottle @ Chris_o shindig 2007. Dark black color with a virtually none off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, chocolate, coffee, roasted, no smoke !!!  ;o(  Flavor is moderate sweet with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily to creamy, carbonation is soft.

THOUGHTS: Not the best porter Ive ever had, but even a so so porter is a great beer.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a deark brown that looked black in the glass with red highlights when helt to light. It had a lard tan head that mostly diminished but left good but patchy lacing. The aroma was light to moderate toasted, roasted, burtn, cocholate and mild coffee malt along with a little cherry and smokiness. It sort of smelled like a cherry cordial. The initial flavor was light to moderate sweetness and light acidity, while the finish was moderate sweetness and bitterness and light acidity with an average to long finish. The flavors were mostly chocolate and  coffee with some smoke. The medium to full body was both dry and syrupy with soft corbonation and a slightly chalky finish.

Very dark brown, almost black, with a huge brown head.  When I tasted this beer cold out of the fridge, all I could taste was the smoke flavor.  It was awful.  If I would rate it before it warmed up a little, Id give Stone Smoked Porter a 1.5 at best.  However, once it warms up just a little I taste coffee, dark fruit, and chocolate notes, and the roasted malt.  Great beer, just dont drink it cold.

(Bottle 65 cl) Courtesy of fiulijn. Pours a clear, chestnut brown with a warm, reddish glow and a dense, beige head leaving some laces. Lightly sweet, roasted malt with a wee whiff of dried fruit. Medium body, lightly burned malt accents with a bitter finish. Very little smoke to be detected. 150807

Bottle, Chris_o shindig. Brown, off-white head. Malted milk ball aroma, leather. Nothing particularly smokey there. Gentle coffee roast flavor, no smoke there either. Delicate palate, and for a Stone brew, a very well balanced un-abrassive beer. Smoke though? Not so much.
Draft at Stone.  A lot of smoked and roasted malt in the aroma.  Decent mouthfeel.  Good flavor but actually not as good as I remember it being a couple years ago.

Pours out an almost opaque dark brown, close to black color. Creates a thick, dense and creamy tan head with excellent retention and a bit of lacing. Smokey aromas were somewhat muted and tame. Notes of charred oak, chocolate, coffee, dark roasted malts and vanilla come through. Mouthfeel was moderately light and fluffy with a mild carbonation. Taste profile was a bit more assertive than the aromas revealing more of the charred wood and smoke characteristics expected. A nice balance noted between the smokey tones and the chocolate/coffee flavors from the dark roasted malts along with just a touch of hops. Finish seemed a touch astringent for a brief second or two, but if youre in the mood for a smoked dark ale this is a solid choice.

Dark brown color; big creamy head. Nice aroma of caramel, wood, light smokey and pepper. The body is weaker than expected, with a strong caramel flavor corrected by light roasted malt and light vanilla, a bit milky; very light smokey touch. The perfect marriage is not between roasted malt and smoked malt
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 Pours black with a fluffy light brown head.  Smokey aroma with roasted malt notes.  Very very complex taste of smokey roasted malt and coffee.  Hides alcohol well.  Great stuff!

Dark black center with mahogany at the edges.  Pretty, cream colored head that shrinks to a small collection of large bubbles.  Sudsy, soapy lacing drips its was down the glass.  The aroma is not what I expected.  I got light smoke, chocolate, coffee, and roasted caramel.  The smoke is rather subdued, and nicely integrated into the standard porter smells.  Coffee takes the top billing in the flavor, with chocolate malts and smoke falling in line.  Theres also a decent amount of bitter hops, adding further balance.  Medium body that goes down nicely.  Nice beer.

Pours an opaque black, with some mahogony highlights.  Aroma is more subued than I expected, with the smoke almost taking a bcak street to the roasted warming aromas coming through.  I might even have detected a touch of bittersweet chocolate.  Flavor is balanced and full, robust enough without becoming garish.  I really dig this beer.

Bottle. [thank you sk8viking].2006 vintage.
Pours blackish with a clear red-ness around the edges. A small creamy dark beige head settles nicely on top, before quickly becoming a thin film. Aroma is quite sweet, with a clear smoky edge. There are roasted caramel, a little coffee, some distant cherries as well. Quite high carbonation, making the beer relatively fresh. Flavour is great! There is some mild roasted tones, a good deal of chocolate, and only after a little while, the smokyness hits me - slow-burning. A nice well-rounded bitterness rounds it up nicely. A really great brew!
Another great beer from Stone. Does have some espresso overtones. Pretty much what you would expect from a porter, just better.

Bottle, chris_o shindig. Dark ruby with some hints of brown, large tan head. Espresso and dark chocolate nose, much the same in mouth. Some hints of burnt charcoal. Lasts sweet on the palate. Alright.

Pours a dark, opaque black with a medium-sized tan head. The aroma is full of chocolate with a touch of dark fruit. The flavor is very nice: a mix of chocolate, hints of dark, soft fruit, a touch of smoke, and rich coffee. The finish is somewhat dry, like bitter cocoa, with a touch of bitter hops and more chocolate & coffee. Overall, a very well-done porter.
Bottle at Chris_o Shindig.  Very deep ruby.  Lasting beige head.  Rather a good choccy porter, peppery hop finish, not huge smoke.  Some ashtray.  Sweetish toffee and choc.  Pretty good.

Strong moccha aroma with black currant. Dark brown color, beige head, good lace. Sweet, moccha, some whiskey malts, bit sandy finish. I missed the real smoke though.

A Mes rate: 
Bottle at Chris Os Shindig. Black body, tan head. Sweet chocolate aroma with some slight liquorice. A little too restrained in the mouth but its still pretty good. Plenty of chocolate and a delicate sourness. Smoke is just about there but not nearly enough to be called "Smoked Porter". Shame. Not bad over all.
Lots of flavor!  This is not for the faint hearted.  There is plenty of chocolate and coffee notes in the flavor and the head/aroma is a thing of beauty.

Nice brown head that didnt have a lot of retention.  The aroma is dominated (of course) by a nice brick smokehouse type smell. The chocolate and coffee are there but overpowered. The chocolate seems to come out a bit more in the flavor and thats good because I dont generally like my smoked porters to taste like beef jerky. The mouthfeel was rather thin for a porter and the finish was quick and uneventfull. I was happy with this beer as far as the style goes but wouldnt go out of my way for it. This is the best Smoked Porter Ive ever had. Unfortunately, that list isnt very distinguished.

Bottled - Chris O shindig 2007 - A black beer with an off-white head.  The aroma has hops and fruity malts but no smoke.  The taste is very American hop and malt big bang.  Good fruits and very drinkable but not sure I picked up smoked notes or porter notes.

Black pour with a slight amber halo tub-ring.  Small tan head.  A malt dominant aroma with just a hint of the smokiness.  Notes of bitter dark chocolate and anise as well.  Dry, smoky, bitter chocolate throughout the glass.  Good stuff and so far the best smoked beer Ive had.
Black with a red hue, lasting off-white head. Licorice dominates the aroma, also some caramel and alcohol. Dry and roast flavour, some wood notes, sweet and roast finish.
Stone Smoked Porter was a very solid beer.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  It is definitely worth a try and should have one ready in your refrigerator.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2011 Such a consistent, subtle beer. After many bombers of this, its time to rate. A big pour, but not as thick and oily as some of their other offerings. Moderate cafe au lait head with good retention and a fairly lively body (which I prefer in a porter, as some can be a bit leaden and dull). As always with smoked porters, this one succeeds by being a wonderful porter first and foremost. Nicely deep chocolate flavor, with prominent barley roasts and heavy peat. And a generous but well integrated smoke flavor is worked in well. A very slight acidity hovers throughout, but not at the expense of the long, smooth finish. Really wonderful.

Poured into an Affligem chalice. Midnight black pour with a good head. Smell is of chocolate and a wisp of smoke. Taste is bang on- roasty sweetness with just the right amount of smoke. The smoke is not overpowering at all. Appropriate carbonation for the style and very drinkable. Hop presence is quite muted, at least for by Stone standards. This must be their least hopped style. A great porter in my mind.

22 oz bottle. Poured a clear black color with red highlights. Head was thick and tan with good retention and lacing. Smelled of chocolate and light molasses. Slightly sweet up front with a thick, creamy mouth feel. The delicate sweetness gives way to dry, roasty malt with a touch of chocolate. There is only a subdued smoky note with a light roasty bitter finish.

"i was a little let down, more because expectations were high, not because the beer was bad. good aroma, faint smoke smell, with a nice dark roasted malty aroma. deep brown, almost black color, some head, some lacing. the body was a little lacking, not what i expected for in a porter. felt a little light, not full bodied as a "light stout" usually does. smoke flavor was absolutely perfect, just enough without smacking you. in fact, the smoke played second fiddle. hops run pretty high for a porter, a good level of bitterness. "chocolate, coffee" or roasted flavors inherent with porters are a little subdued. All-in-all, good tasting brew, enjoyable and very drinkable. great amount of smoke, but not the flavor profile id expect for a porter"
22oz bomber.  Opaque with brown head.  Aroma of chocolate.  Roasted malts and chocolate flavor.  Mild smoke flavor.  Excellent compliment to a slab of ribs.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown in color with a full foam brown head. Aroma sweet, hoppy and chocolate. Taste coffee, chocolate and smoke with lite bitter finish.
Great taste. Very pretty beer, very dark, with some pretty kaki head. Nice, smooth taste, coffee, chocolate notes, with a great finish. My favorite beer from Stone.

this was a good beer.. doesnt get boring 
hoppy chocolate and coffe flavor but not overpowering
very nice smoky taste

Brown with tan foamy head.  Hoppy, smoked chocolate with coffee creamed vanilla, floral alchohol notes on both nose and taste.  Smoky hops balance the sweet malts fairly well, and there is a good motuhfeel.  Nice porter

Bottle.  Robust porter smell, dark and milk chocolate and roast, and only a faint wisp of smoke way, waaaay in the back.  Pours a dark brown edging on opaque ruby-black, with a lusciously lacing and rocky tanned/light brown head.  Smoke is much more present in the taste, and especially the aftertaste, though, as advertised, only as one element among others.  Deep, dark and swirling, roast without screaming imperial stout or coffee beans, robust flavor with a whiff of alcohol, more from heft than taste.  Balanced and - good for Stone - not overhopped, a flawless melding of malt structure and hop flair, balanced and tasty.  Light bitterness measured against light sweetness.  Full body, dry and chocolaty, touch of salty licorice in the bg, smooth and classy!

Appearance: Deep, slightly reddish dark brown. Tan head with slight retention.

Smell: Estery malt nose with a hint of hops.

Taste: Roasted malt with chocolate notes, a wonderful smoky background, and medium-light hops.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied and rich with medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Very nice. The smoke is well integrated with the base style, and the base is no slouch either. My only issue is that the smoke is a bit too light; I would have liked to see a bit more of it in the nose.

Great looking beer with body and texture.  As described, only hints of smokiness.  If youre someone who wants a subtle smoked beer with tons of taste, this is as good as it gets.   Like any good wine, good beer needs to breathe as well.  Let it sit (if you can) for 15 minutes and it will be even better.

Tried at the brewery on tap.  I have to say I havent had very many porters and didnt think I would like it since I am not a big dark beer drinker, but it was very good.  Had a fair amount of head,  but both head and beer were very smooth.  Had flavors of chocolate and coffee.  Not overpowering the rest of the beer I didnt think.
Bottle courtesy of alexanderj courtesy of kleyland.  Pours dark black.  Small tan head.  Woody mouthfeel gives way to the smoky finish.

Draft at the Stone Brewery on 11Jul2007. Pours brown-black with small off-white head. Burnt, toasted malt, bit off coffee and cocoa. Slight smokiness, but very, very faint. Finishes with a slight bitterness across the palate for a mild bite at the end. Good porter.
Ill stay in my lane here and not comment on a style of beer I dont normally enjoy.  But gosh, this is tasty!  Very drinkable and SMOKY!  Good, Good, Good!

Not bad although not what I would have expected from a smoked porter.  The smokiness is very light if not a negligible aspect of this particular brew.  Coffee and chocolate tones are more prominent.  Head is thick, tan, and sustained: much like a Gunniess.  Not bad, not great.

Pours black with a small frothy/creamy tan head.  The initial taste is roasted coffee with caramel and chocolate undertones.  There is a grapefruity bitterness that followes.  The smoke is there but in the background.  The smoke finish really complaments everything very well.  There is a very distinct metallic taste to it.

Bottle. Aroma has a heavy toasted, molasses smell, with a light herb and earth note. Smokey wood is in the background. Small  fizzy off white head which is mostly diminishing and good lacing. Color is pitch black. Flavor is a little bland. It starts lighty sweet and acidic, and finishes moderately bitter and a bit acidic. Palate is light/medium, watery with lively carbonation. It finishes just a touch astringent.
UPDATED: JUL 5, 2008 Really nice blend of flavors - coffee, chocolate, smokiness, etc.  just the right amount of carbonation and smooth to drink.  Excellent beer.

Sampled this along side the AK Smoked...could have a big affect on the out come...
Appearance is good, nice dark tan head that holds up well. Smell is light, sweet and not very smoky. Taste is solid, smooth. Very little smokiness to it. Its there, but not extremely noticeable. Body is lacking any sort of part that stands out, very simple. Very good brew, just not a top notch smoked.

Thick and frothy without being rough or sickening, this beer presented itself out of the bottle as a deep, almost opaque blood red with a mocha head. The smokiness was immediately apparent. Comparable almost to a Guinness Draught, but without the bite (more bbq sauce, less motor oil). There is definitely a coffee taste in there, but this is overshadowed by the feeling that this beer was physically smoked over a beachtop grill. This would make a great beer to make a float with.

Pours dark dark brown from the bottle.  Lots of coffee and smoke in the nose.  Makes me crave gouda cheese.  Flavor didnt leave me dissapointed at all, mostly roasted coffee, and dark chocolate, but definate smokiness in the finish.  Mouthfeel was smooth and creamy a bit.  Quality brew.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2007 pours a black coffee color with nice lacing on the glass. smells of coffee, some alcohol, dark earthy smells, and some toffee. full mouth feel definitely some smoky wood nice carbonation, little chocolate, a little bitter in a nice way. not too overdone with any one flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2009 old rating:
8/4/7/4/17 - 4.0.

pours a thick dark black with a medium size dark khaki creamy head, and good lacing.

smells of smoke, espresso, baking chocolate, and a touch of licorice.

tastes pretty much as it smells, with some roasted nuts, and a touch of vanilla, end is a nice bitter.
xxx excellent beer, nice smoky taste, can stone ever make a bad beer? of course not.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2011 From 650ml bottle from Sprouts. Paid $3.49. Pours an opaque dark brown with a khaki head that diminishes after a few minutes. The Aroma was moderate with a subtle notes of alder-wood and roasted kielbasa. Flavor was overtly smokey  with bacon, bitter walnuts, dark chocolate and a shot of bitter espresso.   It has a mouthfeel that is silky smooth with lively carbonation. Finishes long with bittersweet dark chocolate. Overall: Good stuff.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY> one of the best porters Ive had. Dark, rich with coffee & chocolate. Little smokiness at the end lends a nice touch. Nice medium to full bodied porter. Great

Black. Tan head, leaving specks of lace. Morning campfire with dark chocolate and black, "cowboy coffee" aroma. Taste is sweeter than expected with crispy toffee and a smoky, runny molasess-like finish.
chocolate aroma with slight smoke, black beer, brown foam with some lacing, balance of sweet and bitter, chocolate and roasted malt flavor, medium body yet smooth,

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2009 Dark brown, just a few tan bubbles.  Very roasty aroma, lots of coffee, a bit of smoked salmon.  Chocolate and burnt coffee flavors, and of course serious smokyness.  Medium bodied (a bit thin maybe for a porter) with some light creamyness and significant carbonation.  Bitter-sweet chocolate finish.
Pours black and opaque with a small tan head.  There is a coffee and malt scent on the nose.  The taste is smokey with some coffee and chocolate tones.  Nice porter by Stone...they dont disappoint.

A sweet aroma of malt and smoke.  Appearance is black with a good tan head.  Taste is smoky, chocolate and sweet with a pleasant sweet aftertaste.  Palate is moderately thick and coating with noticeable carbination.  Overall an excellent porter.

Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a foamy head that fades away fairly quickly, leaving some coarse bubbles on the surface.  Aroma is of dark malts, coffee, cocoa, a very light woody smokiness, brown sugar, and a slight hint of dried dark fruits.  Flavors are very full and rich:  dark roasted malts, nice bitter hops, cocoa, coffee, a nice mellow smokiness that isnt too overpowering.  Mouthfeel is very full, but not too heavy.  This could be a great session beer for me.  Great stuff, Ill definitely be drinking more of these.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown, very little light gets through this brew. A short thick nutty brown head takes a long while to dissipate. This beer smells like deeply roasted malts, and lots of them. There is a hint of smoke but it is well mixed with the roasted smell. The taste is a bit coffee and chocolate with the smoke coming through a bit more as the beer warms. This is a very enjoyable brew.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2008 Bottle - really dark, aroma is smoky but not too stong, flavor is bitter w/some chock and coffee.  Well balanced and very, very good

bottle at the mondiale 07
very very dark, with a slight beige head.
aroma is soy sauce, smoke, and roasted malt. 
flavour is bitter, and again the soy sauce is prevalent. finish is bitter, and kinda malty. nice porter.
Bu au Mondial 07. Brune foncée, moyen collet. Arome de malte chocolaté, un peu fumé. Bon mélange de malte chocolaté et fumé dans le goût, légèrement cafiné.

nice and dark...faint malty chocolate nose. coffee, mild chocolate and brown sugar flavors.  it has a nice bitter coffee/hop finish with no smoke to speak of until the bottle is empty..maybe thats the coffee? nothing inparticular really stands out (strange for stone since their beers tend to be very aggressive). its really well balanced and under rated. they nailed this one.

Poured from a 22-oz bottle. Smelt of chocolate and toasted malts. Very faint smoke smell. The taste was of chocolate, coffee and had an aftertaste of caramel. A good beer, but not nearly as much of a smokey taste as I expected or wanted with this beer. Was almost more like a regular porter.
draft from brewery. Chocolate, roasty aroma, dark black in appearance with tan head..Super smoked flavor, with nice chocolate, coffee, patent malt undertones.

Rated 7/22/06:  This beer is a bit of a puzzler, had some really great qualities and some fairly average ones as well. I will immediately skip to the overall because overall this is a nice porter and I got a lot of enjoyment out of it. Aroma is medium to mild with scents of chocolate and roasted goodness, its just too mild to be given a higher score. Great pour one of the best Ive seen from a porter. Rich and dark this is a looker good swirling tan head and loads of tacky lacing. Mouthfeel is nice and smooth but lacks a thick creaminess I like to find in a good porter, it does get better as it warms but still doesnt hit the right level. Flavor is real nice. I can smell a bit of the smoked flavor as I drink, my taste buds first pick up on some chocolate and caramel followed with a bitter coffee taste. The smokiness is mild and it hits the back of the throat on the way down leading to a great exhale. A stronger aroma and thicker mouthfeel and we would have a superior porter.

Appearance: Dark brown body with a light tan-colored, creamy head.

Smell: Whats in that aroma... lets call it "excitement"! Lightly sweetened cocoa and coffee amidst the rich, smokey overtones.

Taste: More of that semi-sweet chocolate and coffee from the nose, and, of course, the smoke, but also just a hint of citrus on the finish. Though the flavors run a bit thin at times, its still pretty pleasant.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Mild carbonation. Slighty creamy.

Drinkability: Reasonably smoked, it gives you just enough of that smoke you want without ever becoming overpowering or life-threatening.
Mild caramel, smokey chocolate. Medium body, dark brown in color, light tan to white head. A good beer.

22 oz. shared with my Patty Cakes.  Enjoyed slightly colder than room temperature, which seemes perfect.  Slighlty carbonated with a light mouth feel, however it does not lack flavor.  Smokey coffee, chocolate and a hint of raisins make this a tasty choice.

22oz split with Brie while watching the 400th Simpsons episode.  This is one of my favorite porters and it is always readily available.  Flavs are coffee, peat, caramel and licorice.  The mouthfeel is creamy but not too heavy.  This is one of the great american porters.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2007 A good porter.  Alcohol on the nose, plus some sweetness and licorice.  Initial light roasted coffee flavor, slightly smokey, definet licorice, bitter dry finish.  Main problem is aftertaste is kind of like soda water.  Its very complex, dry, bitter, something quite bitey, smoke or licorice? Overall, roasty bitey smokey and dry.  Get again? Maybe.

22oz bottle. Drank at room temp in a regular pint glass. Poured a dark tan head. Slight Aroma of coffee/chocoalate/ Very very smooth! Pretty malty with molasses, coffee and chocoalate tastes Not as viscous as i thought it would be. Overall pretty enjoyable. Warmed me up on a cool night.

Bouteille de 22 oz achetée chez Oak Tree Discounts (South Plainfield, NJ). Arôme: Odeur de malt fumé et de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café et de chocolat avec une pointe de caramel fumé. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence de fumée légèrement astringente en arrière goût. (Rating #1042)
good porter, pours dark brown/light black with small tan head. rich coffee bean flavor with dry after taste. very enjoyable brew. 22oz bottle good......growler from stone excellent!

raisins, coffee, and light peat on the nose. a charred brown color with small head and moderate lace. medium body and light small crisp bubbles. tastes of  dark fruity malt with some coffee, mild pepper, and a beautiful balance of bitter and smoke. bold but not overpowing. leaves a rich and enjoyable aftertaste. another one of stones great beers!
22oz bottle. Very smokey aroma along wiht malt. Very dark pour with a long lasting through out. Very smokey and sweet taste. They just keep making great beers.

Draught:  Aroma of smoke, malts.  Poured dark brown with a big tan head that lasted throughout.  Great lacing.  Opaque.  Lightly sweet flavor.  Tasted of smoke, cream, caramel, and nuts.  Medium body.  Watery texture.  Soft carbonation.  Overall nice flavor but poor body.

Jet black with frothy light tan head.  Aroma of alcohol, smoke, and chocolate.  Taste of smokey roasted malt and chocolate transitioning to a bitter slightly licorice taste and finishing with a perfumy alcoholic bitterness.  Delicious.

A basic malt aroma with a small hint of earth. A black colored beer with a tannish white head. There are many flavor layers in this beer. First off were some mild citrus hops, followed by some chocolate malt, a little earth, a crisp resiny finish, and then an ever so slight smokey flavor. Somewhat resiny and dry on the palate. Lots of flavor and body. This was a damn fine beer, but not quite as good as Alaskan Smoked Porter.

a fan here for sure. although i like an even stronger smoke taste but this one was very drinkalbe and nice grayish smokey head good color a nice smoked porter all around if you enjoy this style grab one today!

Smoky, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, maybe some alcohol (or not). Quite an aroma. Opaque brown/black color with a tan head that was vigorous, but wasted away leaving delicate lace. Medium mouthfeel that thickens as the mild carbonation departs. Scotch smoke start, some dark roasted malt, a touch of sour, some floral hop? A smidgeon of baking chocolate. Its smooth, but the smoke adds a rough touch to the palate. The finish is not quite dry, but not like a sweet stout either. In the end the mouth puckers a bit, and it is still not absolutely dry. The flavors go on and on. I vote for some bitter in the end. Amazing stuff.

22oz bottle. date unknown. pours dark brown with off-white head. nose has nice smokey character with chocolate, caramel, black currants, and roasty notes. flavor has a nice element of smoke which adds a nice touch of complexity to this porter. other flavor notes of chocolate, toffee, caramel, dark fruits, coffee, and subtle charred wood. finish is long. body is a tad thin but true to style. extremely easy to drink and each sip is as rewarding as the last.

The color was dark chocolate with a very deep red hue.  The head was creamy, frothy, and light beige.  The aroma was roasty, dakr coffee grounds, and some spice.  The flavor was very roasty, coffee, a kind of burnt toast taste, smokey, and dry.  The palate was smooth.  The finish was roasty/smokey.

Via trade with dirty_martini. My first Stone exposure, how exciting. Poured a dark brew that allowed some light through and changed it to a dark reddish brown. Standard porter color. The head is thick, light, brown, and creamy. The aroma features a light roast, sweet chocolate, lightly sweet hops, and light alcohol. The flavor boasts bakers chocolate, roasty malt, a light light smoke, and some general sweetness. The palate is full and smooth, but not very viscous. The finish features an eventual alcohol warmth in the stomach and a roasty taste in the throat. Overall, I think I was slightly disappointed with this one. It was really solid, but not standoutish.

On tap.  Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of dark chocolate.  Dark red/black with an average sized, light brown, mostly diminishing head that left excellent lace.  Flavor is fairly sweet and bitter with roasted coffee and dark chocolate.  Finish really long and I thought detracted from the overall experience.  Palate is medium body and watery flat.  Very good brew but Id prefer an Imp stout.

Excellent brew! From the pour to the last drop, this brew dazzled me. Pours black, with a firm, brown/tan head. The body is beautifully complex and this beer will show you what porters SHOULD taste like! Great beer.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a tan head. Roasted malty hoppy arome with some smokey hints. Sweet malty slightly roasted smokey flavor with some hints of coffee and chocolate. Roasred malty finish with some hints of smoke in the aftertste.
Bottled. Coffe flavour. Very bitter. Bit dryish. Brown colour. Bit simplified and not very full. Nutty. Not at all amazed.

I dunno if my pallet is all messed up, but i could taste no smoke in this at all, couldnt even smell any, tasted like a regular porter to me, but that being said it was quite rich and malty. I typically like a bit more coffee taste, would have liked a little smoke flavor in there...

22 oz bottle that poured a decent tan head and dark black body. Smells of wood, chocholate and coffee, with tastes of coffee, chocolate, and caramel. I wished it was a little more potent. Good porter.
This beer has an awesome smoked woody taste to it. It pours almsot no head to it what so ever and has a very dark color. the taste is of a earthy flavors with some roasted chocolate malt.

Finally getting around to rating the more standard Stone brews. As with my buddy jarspag, Im not too fond of porters. This was alright though, drinkable and somewhat enjoyable. The midnight black appearance is great, with good head. Earthy and roasty. I prefer chewier palate and higher alcohol content of the Russian Imperial over this one.

22 oz bottle. Pours black.  This smells kind of like a Budweiser with a chocolate bar melted in it.  No wait... its a little better when it warms up.  Tastes like burnt chocolate, roasted malts.... has a smoky aftertaste.  This is my first smoked porter, so its a little strange but I think I like it.  (Temperature is important for the taste here too... gets much better with warming.)

Bomber.  Pours black with a small brown head.  Subtle aroma of rich chocolate and malts.  Taste is a nice, deep, rich, smooth, creamy chocolate.  Thats a lot of adjectives.  Smokiness is not too apparent but it is very roasty. As it warms there is a wee bit of pleasant smoke in the aroma And quite delicious.  This far exceeded my expectations.  One of the best porters Ive had.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2007 Cant really get myself to take a liking to porters too much I guess.  This receives high ratings, I disagree. . . . Ill save the supply for those who enjoy it.  But, nonetheless, I cant say its a bad beer just b/c Im not the biggest fan of the style.
This porter has a great smokey flavor and nice notes of coffee and choclate.  The porter has weight but is not too dense.  Not a bad effort!

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2011 On tap at the Bocktown. My very first stone. Pour is nice and dark brown black with a tinge of red in there. Initially has a large tan head that fades to a darkish tan froth. Aroma is less than expected for a smoked brew. It does have some mild roastyness about it but I dont think it can be called smoked. Hints of hickory smoking. Nice lacing on this stuff. It has some medium bitterness in the back of the throat after you get to know it. That bitterness builds as the drinks continue. Decent,  just slightly bellow medium carboatiion. That back of your throat bitterness continues to build with each taste. Not bad for a porter but the smokey bitterness makes this a little more interesting than a straight porter with gentleman manners.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 Im really big on this type of beer.  The smoke isnt a huge deal but its there and its great.  Tastes similar to Sierra Nevadas porter with more chocolate and a fuller, thicker mouthfeel.  This is a very good thing.  Hops are there but well balanced.  Good amount of complexity.  This is my favorite beer from stone and I can see myself being a big fan of these "robust" porter types.  No complaints whatsoever.

Black hue with lasting foam creamy tan foam, smells liked smoked wood and peat like you would find in some lowland scotch, at first tastes of chocolate and finishes smokey and meaty with a soapy hint, oily to creamy texture with a good medium to full body similar to other porters, there is a complexity here: the smokiness is the unique quality but there is a fine line between the smoke and the soapy taste, maybe my glass had some soap in itor it was a licorice taste.  Different.
very good beer. Light smokey flavor, a little coffee, im not tasting the chocolate.  Good mouthfeel
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 2, 2007 medium flavor and body. typical porter carbonation. ive had better porters and didnt try too hard. its a porter and its fairly good... so what?!
dark chocolate aroma.  big beer with hints of roasted coffee, chocolate and a lingering smoky finish. smoked beers are not my thing but still a pretty good beer

Pours dark brown and chestnut with tan head and more carbonated than I had expected . Aroma is malts, cocoa, coffee. Flavor was quite complex -- roasted malts, cocoa, burnt toast and a nice bitter finish. Chewy mouthfeel. Another full flavored and complex brew from Stone.

Bottle: Poured black with a tan, foamy head..nice lacing.  Aroma  rather sharp.   Wonderfully bitter.  Nice burnt finish.  Lingering smoky taste halfway through glass.  Great beer, but I think one would be enough.

Pours black with crisp northern brewer hop nose. slim er head by=ut rocky and yeasty nonetheless.  Some funkydoodle Willywonka-esque bubbles flowing out of the bomber.  Head settles to dusty film A nice touch of smokiness that is balanced and negated by the dark malts. Pleasantly pleasant. It stained the workbench lightly.

Pours black, big fluffy almond head. Chocolate, and slight smoked malt are the main flavors, some coffee and roastiness comes through in the aftertaste. The level of smokiness is perfect it blends just right with the chocolate malts not overpowering them but working together. Thin mouthfeel but really any bigger beer and I dont think this wouldve worked.

Pours a dark brown with light brown head that fades quickly.  Aroma is of light chocolate, slight smoke, and a bit of roasted malt.  Taste is not what I expect from a "smoked" beer.  The smoke is very light but mixes very well with the light chocolate and roasted malt, some floral hops make a nice appearance in the finish to give this beer some character.   Lightly carbonated and very easy drinking.  An excellent porter, however with the smoke being so subtle I think the "smoked" should be dropped from the name.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2010 Bottle... Poured a deep black with slight brown highlights, thick tan head with nice lacing.  Roasted/smoked malt and coffee aroma.  Flavors of malt, meat (like a smoked bacon) chocolate and coffee, and other sweet flavors. Mellow finish with a good aftertaste.

I appreciate the subtleness of the woody smoked taste. Smoked beers can really destroy the palate sometimes when the smoked character is to powerful. The chocolate, caramel and coffee are superb. I session this with my buddies all the time. Its one of my go to beers. An outstanding porter.

On tap Stone brewpub.  Pours black with a thick brown lacy head.  Smells of sweet caramel, dark malts, and light smoke.  Taste is pretty smoky as expected.  Still the sweetness remains in the foreground.  The finish is somewhat bitter as smoky beers somewhat are.  Kind of a nuttiness to it with a thick mouthfell.  Damn good porter.
Black. Good brown head. Malty aroma. Nice medium body. Smoky malted roasted taste.

On tap at Stone Brewery.Nice deep dark brown appearance with a small tan head.Smoky nose aroma. Smooth and easy on the palate. Rich smoky , sweet flavors of malt and chocolate. A very nice porter for sure!

Bottle. Pours a dark brownish black with a nice tan head on top. Aroma is not full of as much smoke as I thought it would. Smoke is there though, but not as strong. More chocolate and coffee coming through on the nose. Flavor is quite smooth with chocolate and coffee being mixed well with the smoke. The smoke is not overbearing at all. It blended perfectly together. Wow, I knew this beer has been rated real well but I didnt know I would like it just as much.

My first Stone Ale and well worth the wait its taken to try one.

Appearance: Black with a very full and very lingering head. If looks could kill, this beer would be on death row right about now.

smell: Chocolate first and foremost. There is also just the slightest hint of smoke to be found.

taste: Again Im getting chocolate above anything else, but the coffee undertones are still there in force and the smoky aspect.... not too strong not too faint, just about perfect.

Mouthfeel: Very creamy and the smoke seems to be more noticeable than in the taste alone or the smell. Still not overpowering by any means, but more assertive and ready to scare off all those "yellow fizzy" beer drinkers.

drinkability: Could see myself very easily having a couple bombers back to back of this majestic brew. Can only speak for myself, but it lives up to any hype its been given and then some.
Another one of Stones excellent beers. The smokiness is immediately noticeable, along with flavors like caramel, coffee and chocolate.

One of the tastiest and most well-crafted porters Ive ever tried, if not the best. The wood smoke is very soft, subtle and inviting at first, and then it subsumes itself into the complex and alluring flavours of coffee, licorice, herbal hops, chocolate, and a bit of alcohol. Slightly sticky body, soft carbonation and a gorgeous black gold character, this beer will haunt my dreams till I can find another. Beautiful...

Ive had a lot of Porters; I really love the brew style...and after the other Stone offerings Ive had I expected greatness out of this brew.  I was actually quite disappointed.  Mildly smokey, but thats what they intended to do from the label.  Its just not really that good, the balance felt a bit off, perhaps the local porters Im used to are just that good.

Black in colour. Think dark brow lacing head. Thick and smooth.  No dissernable scent.  Deep taste, slightly bitter, hint of coffee and barley/earthy hops.  Wheres the smoke?  Nice finish and aftertaste.  Very smooth.

Not as smoky as I anticipated, more of a subtle backdrop to the other porter flavors. Maybe thats a good thing. Overall it was tasty and rather unique, a good integration of the styles, but now that Ive had it I cant imagine going out of my way to try it again.

Amazing flavor. This smoked porter poured a deicious dark brown/black. The head a creamy tan color. It smelled of burt chocolate and espresso. The flavor was dry and velvety. A nice upfront hop flavor was followed by a sweet yet burnt toffee flavor. One of the best smoked porters in the market!

22oz Bottle Pours out a very dark red almost black topped with a nice tan head. A nice aroma off roast and a very little smoke on it. i was really looking to get a campfire out of this one but it was a very small smoke. Pretty good overall.

22oz. Bomber

Opened with a pfffttt...Poured in my pint glass a viscous black. Very dark. Some dark ruby tinting when held up to the light. A half inch tan head sits on top but fades fairly quickly to an even top coat. Lacing sticks as my glass is tilted but slowly slides back into the abyss that is the body of this beer.

The smell is filled with roasted malt goodness. Along with chocolate and a tiny bit of burnt grain. There is just a slight touch of smoke up front but to tell you the truth I dont think Id be able to pick it up if I didnt know it was there. As it warms I can pick up the smoke more and more.

The taste is very close to perfect. Starts with a small burnt grain taste quickly taken over by the roasted malts and chocolate. I cant really taste the hops but theyre in there. There is a nice bitterness from what tastes like a combonation of hops and darkly roasted malt. The smokiness is there faintly in the back throughout the drink. Very nicely done and balanced.

Mouthfeel is viscous but you could tell this from the pour. Its thick in my mouth but not coyingly so. Silky smooth but somehow a little chewy/gritty. I know that doesnt sound right but thats how it is. I really like the feel especially on a cold night like tonight.

For a smoked porter the drinkability is outstanding. The lower alcohol helps as to not be too big of a beer to drink a lot of. 

Sampled 10/28/06

On tap at the Pizza Plant.  My first trip to this highly regarded pub/eatery, thought Id try a couple nice dark brews.  This was served cool, not cold, as should be, light brown head that didnt last long but nice smoked flavor.  Very nice.
Smoked to perfection. Thick dark head shows the craftsmenship. Smell is rich and the beer sits nicely and deep in brown. Goes down very nicely and has a excellent after taste.

If youre looking for a sessionable porter--something on the lighter side, that goes down smoothly, that warms but doesnt inebriate, that pleases your tastebuds without overwhelming them--you simply cant do better than this....as long as you covet smoke--as in walking through wildfire-swept forests only hours after the fire subsided--is your thing. The smoky notes of this brew are utterly perfect--not gimmicky, not fake, not flavored, not bitter, not winey, not chalky...but real wood smoke. If youre looking for sweet, or full-bodied, or belly-warming, go bigger; if youre looking to enjoy a few pints on a fall day, go Stone Smoked!
Dark brown/black with thick tan head. Sweet aroma, creamy texture. Nice sweet malt but only a hint of smoke and a bit short on finish.
#100!  Very dark black with a small head.  Some roast and espresso in the nose.  Flavor is chocolate, with espresso, roasted malt, and just a hint of smoke.  Very nice, dry finish.

bottle- pours deep amber to black with a small tan head that has dispersed quite quickly.  smells much sweeter than expected, molasses maybe brown sugar? i cant quite put my finger on it. chocolate, coffee, apples and berries, and a subtle smoked wood scent. tastes smoked wood, mixed with chocolate, berries(and apples), mouthfeel is really highcarbonation and it is a bit watery on the palate.

Sampled on draught at "The Most Arrogant Bar (Pub) in America 2006-2007" event at Bostons Bistro & Pub (Dayton, Ohio) on 2/22/2007...  

Very dark brown color with a creamy tan head.  There is caramel and mocha characteristics in the aroma with some smoke in the background.  The flavor is cocoa, roasted malt, caramel, and weak coffee with subtle smoke undertones.  Some sweetness with the flavor with a balancing dry and roasty bitterness in the finish.  The mouthfeel is nearly full and quite smooth.  Stone Smoked Porter is a blend of a really good porter and a really good smoked beer.  I loved smoked beers, so I would have liked just a bit more smoke in this one, but thats just a personal preference.  Overall, this is a really well blended, balanced, and complex beer in which the smoke characteristic complement,s rather than dominates, the overall flavor and experience.  Another very nicely crafted beer by Stone!

22oz Bottle: Nice chocolatey aroma. Roasty sweet malts, somewhat mocha-like. The body is creamy, but its light to medium. Flavor is chocolatey, with more roastyness in the finish. Only a hint of smoke is evident. Its called a "Smoked Porter", but the style isnt labeled as a "Smoked" beer, so I wont complain too much about that. Light coffeeish bitterness is in the finish. A well made Porter all together.
Bottle. Medium head that hung around.  Roasted malt aroma, smoke is subtle.  Creamy and smooth, medium bodied.  Some chocalate.  Mildly sweet.  Would gladly drink more if readily available.
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 Very black color. Little head. Roasted malt flavor, with little sweetness. Medium body. Not much aroma.
Jet black in a medium light environment.  Nice   sized off white head.  Detectable chocolate and coffee flavors.  Excellent beer!

Growler purchased from the brewery ~ 2 months ago.  Beautiful pour- nice frothy head w/ good lacing and retention.  Smoke background w/ a nice, smooth chocolate finish.  Tried it w/ spicy tacos and it really brought out the spicy, smokey flavors. A very nice beer.

A fast "cascade" leaves a large, chunky, tan head above a cola-colored body with minor carbonation. Raw, worty notes with roasty black malt and an underscore of charcoal. Palate is mid-bodied and smooth without being oppressive (for a seemingly "heavy" beer), and the tongue finds a delicate lift of effervescence. Chocolate makes for a sweet base flavor while a bitter roastiness makes for a "serious" finish. A bit unrefined, but malts and hops conjoin here in a blissful union.
<font size=-4>Puchased over the summer at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/indiana/highlan Liquor Stop, Highland, IN 46322</font>
this and ofallons smoked porters are amazing. i have a newfound love of smoked porter thanks to the flavor of this. large bottle from international beverage, grand rapids.
good smoked porter.  excellent flavor with a great smokey taste.  chocolatey taste
Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and coffee. Taste of roasted malts,and a bit of smokey flavor.  Nice round palate. Good smokey porter.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 Poured from a bottle, lets just say still waiting for the smoked part of the smoked porter.  The  aroma was sweet, however I am still trying to acclomplish my sense of smell.  The appearence was really nice, the lace klinged to the glass like no other.  Sorry Stone, right now I have Sam Smith as a benchmark in the porters and you did not beat your benchmark.  You missed by a tad (dy porter)

Poured from large bottle. Dark brown, tan frothy head...Tasted like coffee beans, chocolate, and a bit of sugar, maybe molasses...Pretty well blended...Smoky falvor was not as overwhelming as I was anticipating...Not my favorite kind of beer, but tasty none the less...

Black body with a small tan head.  Less smoked that most smoked porter Ive had which is a good thing to me since Im not fan of smoke in porters.  The aroma has some coffee beans but the taste is more focussed of creamy dark malts and chocolate.  Overall cake/pancake flavour with some smoke and some dark fruits hint.  Very malty and syrupy body.  Nothing groundbreaking, simply very well done.  Nice beer.  Drinking a Stone Smoked Porter is almost as fun as being a stoned smoked stoner.

Thanks to IrishBoy & BuckeyeBoy for the Smokey Gargoyle. Pours basically black with a small off white head. Had pretty decent carbonation. Nice aroma of bitter coca, malts and coffee. Flavor is mild smokey malts, bitter chocolate, and a light hop finish. I found the body to be just a tad thin. I am glad that they did not overdue it with the smoke. It is just the right amount.
Bottle. Pours black brown red, thin off white head. Aroma grass, malt, molasses, caramel. Flavor is smoke, malt, molasses. Nice blend.

Pours a deep brown-black with about two inches of brown head. You have to hold it up to the light to see traces of ruby. The foam in the middle of the glass is a thick clumpy island. The head dies back after a minute or two. Excellent lacing - thick. Aroma is rich and malty with roasted grains and just a hint of smoke.

The taste slams you with darkly roasted malt, burnt coffee, a bit of chocolate, and a bit of smoke. Nothing sweet at all in the flavor. Full bodied, medium carbonation. Some hop bitterness at the end. Ah, there’s plenty of smoke in the lingering aftertaste.
Nice coffee nose and very slight smoke, rich peated malt flavor absent of the harsh bitterness associated with stouts...thats why I like Porters.

A nice beer, I enjoyed this beer with my brother over Christmas weekend. Im not a real fan of porters in general however this one had a great aroma and a nice finish. Very easy to drink. I recommend picking it up, my brother found it at BevMo.

Wow, bottle, creamy, soft and sweet yet has a rough burned corner to it.  Reminds me a bit of the burned part of a roasted marshmallow, plus light chocolate and cirtus hops.  
Excellent and delicious....will return to this one.

Tap.  Pours a deep, deep brown with a lovely foamy tan head floating on top which had a decent amount of longevity.  Nose is roasty with a smokey background.  Flavor is lightly smoked, licorice, and caramel.  It is a light brew, but thats not a negative, in fact, its a plus.  I am not a fan of porter, and the burnt coffee notes that are typical.  I do, on the other hand, enjoy smoked flavors.  This one is flavorful but not overpowering, thick in its lightness and full-bodied.

from tallboy bottle. pours dark, nice thick tan head. smells of roasted malts. light mouth feel but very very flavorful. as expected, same chocolate coffee tones. the smokeyness becomes apparent as it warms. nothing about this beer is execeptional, yet nothing is lacking. perhaps that is what makes it good.
Bottle at NB - Porter/stout ølsymposium. Black - big brown fluffy head. Light smoked, licorice, roasted, light metalliic, bread. Very mild. Would go nicely to a piece ofryebread with smoked-sausage.

At first glance, this beer is the solid black of the monolith.  When held to the light, it yields a very intense, low-frequency red of an LED.  The head is thick, lumpy, and tan.  The aroma is that of roasted coffee, a hint of smoke, and possibly spuce and licorice.  I cant help but notice the cementish smell of the yeast.  It is instantly recognizable as a California beer.  The flavor is very pulled-together.  The smoke flavor does not at all overwhelm.  The bitterness is appropriately prominent with a grapefruitish flavor.  Perhaps this is from Cascades?  Again, very California.  It seems to be around 35 IBU.  The citrus bitterness melds seamlessly with that of dark coffee and dark chocolate.  It avoids being astringent and the smoke flavor merely lurks in the background.  If anything, it serves to enhance the overall roasted flavor.  It is medium-bodied and very drinkable.  This could serve as a session beer.  The carbonation is lively and seems to bring out the flavor of the hops.  Neither the roasted flavor nor the grapefruit rind flavor muddle each other and work together brilliantly.  Again: a very pulled-together flavor.  The aftertaste is short and has the bitterness of french roast coffee and bitter chocolate.  I love it.

Dark pour - almost black, with medium tan head.  Rich aroma of peat-malt with bits of roasted coffee, and fresh-baked dark bread.  Taste has a pleasant malty flavor that is bready, with the peat very prominent.  Hops dont dominate, but they  balance this one nicely and give a nice tingle at the end.  Pleasant, full body for a porter.  This ones a winner.

Bottled. Poured into an English pint glass.  Black body with a decent lasting tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma was roasty malts with smoke evident, but not very prominant.  The flavor was more roasty and smoky, with significant bittering.  Straightforward and solid beer!
Bottle, Dark brown. Very perceptible chocolate flavor, slightly sweet, lower carbonation would be nice. Smoke becomes more evident in the finish.

Stone makes some awesome beers and the Smoked Porter is among my favorites.  Like the quote from Koch above the smokiness is understated relative to other "smoked" beers but it complements the finish nicely.  This porter is maltier and not so dry as other porters that Ive had.  The aroma is very malty as well.  The instant you inhale if youre thinking "malted milk balls" you wont be wrong.  As you inhale further you pick up fruity highlights.  The flavor is robust and full bodied and the finish is long.  Perhaps a bit fizzy out of the bottle.  I can see this being a really nice beer on nitro.

Pours a deep, dark brown that borders on black, with a creamy tan head.  Good retention but minimal lacing.  The aroma is malty with a light smokiness and very little hops.  Flavor is rich and chocolatey with little hop bitterness and a subtle, yet pleasurably perceptible smokiness that contributes to the balance of the sweet malts.  The smoke is not overpowering as it is in most beers with "Smoked" in the name.  The mouthfeel is silky smooth and refreshing for a porter.  Overall a great beer to drink with a meal that it wont overpower (like light fish or something like that).  Excellent.

I guess Im in the minority but this beer didnt do much for me.  I found it a bit thin, so lightly smoked as to be imperceptible other than perhaps imparting a slight dryness. Regardless of their approach, I think a bit more peat smoke would add to the character and not overwhelm it.  Maybe being a scotch drinker has dulled my peat-detectors. Anyway, nice looking, head, lacing, etc but just didnt excite me.  I once homebrewed some smoked porter using peated malt from Laphroigh, now that was kick-ass.

Bottle.   Pours jet black with a decent sized tan colored head.   Aroma is peat, chocolate, rosted malt.   Flavor is chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, peat.   Palate is medium-full, medium carbonation, bitter, slightly smokey finish.   I think the amount of smoke is just right, adds an extra dimension but doesnt distract from the overall product.   Nice.

A delicious porter with very little smoke flavor apparent.  Although the smoke flavor is not apparent the chocolate-like flavor, smooth body and creamy head are the reasons to drink this wonderful brew.
Not very smokey.  A nice porter with a more bready malt taste to it.  Something clean about the taste here. Its nice in colour and appearance.  A cola brown with a soapy off tan head.  Nice enough.

This dark brown ale poured with a very thin tan head, eliciting a strong malty aroma. The flavor is slightly chocolate, but rather more smoky. This is not a very complex brew, but is a nice version of porter and is quite pleasant to drink.
Not as smoked as I was anticipating but still full of lovely chocolate/espresso esque flavor.  Another stone and another great beer.

The colour of this is a dark brown, maybe a hint of red on the edges with a lage soda like head that deflated to a thick fine bubbled coating on top leaving some lace without even having taken a drink. There is certianly some chocolate and burnt aromas when I stuff my nose into the glass and its all followed by a hint of smoked meatyness. I agree with Greg Koch, the smoke is an element, not the beer. The first sip isnt really of porter. Rather its sweet with some coffee flavours and a bit of chocolate, hints of burnt malts and that meaty smoke flavour again comes in and doesnt take over per se, but it commands attention from your palate.
Pours a deep brown color with off white head.  Aroma is of sweet dark malts with a hint of smoke and chocolate.  Flavor is malty with bitter smoke and chocolate.  Good Porter.

A beautiful dark brown pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma is roasted coffee, chocolate and smoke.  Flavor is somewhat lacking.  I was hoping for a more complexity but found it to be overwhelmed by the smoke flavor.  Then I reminded myself "hey jackass, youre drinking a SMOKED porter".  The mouthfeel is pleasant and creamy with a finish that isnt overly bitter.  A decent brew but not one that blew my doors off.
Pours a dark black with a tan ring. As the name suggests, the taste is of smokey malts with coffee and chocolate undertones. A great offering by Stone, but Ive had tastier porters.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very dark pour, near total black.  Thin tan head.  The bottle actually suggests some foods to server this with including PB&J (sourdough or squaw bread, chunky style all natural & blackberry preserves).  Stong smoky dark chocolat coffee scent.  Waterier then expected but still a very nice tast.  Lots of coffee some choclate and just a hint of the smoked taste.  Slighter bitter with no tart aftertaste.

Not the best porter and not the best offering from Stone, but still a very solid, high quality beer.  Big, bubbly, dark tan head dissipates quickly but leaves creamy lacing all the way down.  Not much aroma.  Complex taste, though just a bit hollow in the middle.  Mouthfeel is not a full as I like.  Good but not great.
Bottle: Pours dark brown with a fliffy tan head.  The flavor is of chocolate and caremal malts.  There is some hops present.  A medium bodied well balanced beer.

22oz bottle. Bottle was ~2 years old. Reddish black color. Mild, smokey, malty aroma. Taste is malty, roasty, slightly smokey. Silky mouthfeel. Finish is mildly smokey, mildly sweet, and malty. Smoke flavor is mild, maybe due to the age. Enjoyable. This was a brew day beer.

From a 22 oz. bomber bottle with blurb on the back label, no freshness date.

Poured a dark coffee brown with a tall, pale tan foamy, fluffy head that settled into a thin creamy lacing.

Aromas of smoky charcoal, roasted dark coffee and a very light chocolate.

Good steady carbonation and a malty crisp, chewy, creamy smooth medium-full bodied mouthfeel.

A pleasant smoky porter taste, roasted expresso with a dash of dark chocolate syrup, caramelized sugar, charcoal, a very subtle citrus hoppiness, a light toasted graininess and a smoky, coffee and chocolate finish with a lingering citrus flavor.

An excellent porter, smooth and easy drinkability, very enjoyable.

Slightly smokey aroma, as you would expect.  Deep brown appearance, with a lacy tan head.  Flavor of chocolates and hints of smoke.  Smoke seems less prevelant than when I had this in the past.  Very good flavor.  Malty and smooth with just a slightly smokey aftertaste.  One of my favorite porters.

Bomber.  Pour is dark brown with some ruby red.  Off white head, and great layering.  Aroma is smoke, hop and roast.  Initial taste is pure Porter with a backdrop of smoky / roasty.  Stone nailed this one, truly a smoked Porter.  Anyone who has had a smoked porter that is all smoke and no porter knows what I mean.

Bottled. Thanks to Stegosaurus for this gem. Pour was a dark black color with a 3 finger tan head. Aroma smoke and chocolate malt. Flavor was a perfectly blended smokey chocolate/coffee taste. Small hoppy smokey finish. This is what its all about. GOOD BREW.

22oz - The commercial description is pretty much spot on.  The smoke is there, but its a part of the flavor.  Under the dark tan head the brown/black liquid holds a roasted coffee front and a smoky finish.  Works well with grilled pork chops.

22 oz bottle.  Pours black with a tan long-lasting head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, fruit, coffee, and slight smoke.  Taste of malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel, cream, and a hint of smoke.  Creamy body with a slight kick.  Aftertaste of coffee and chocolate.  A very nice porter.
Very solid. The smoke is an accent to the flavor of a well brewed porter, not the ONLY flavor. Nice acidity at the end.

22 oz. bottle  dark brown / black in color  nice off-white head- nose of cappuccino , anis , dark chocolate , dark fruit ( cherries , and raspberries ) , malt , smoke , slight peat and iodine  taste of malts , caramel , milk , chocolate , coffee , anis , and a slight sourness  wonderful body creamy with a hint of acidity  aftertaste is milk chocolate and coffee

22 oz bottle: My thanksgiving beer!  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, malts, smoke, caramel, and a bit of roasty goodness.  Appearance is a black pour with a fluffy tan head that lingers around for a while.  Taste is espresso like with chocolate and roasted coffee coming to the forefront and the smoke lingering on to the back end of the brew.  Palate is bitter, lively, and nice and long.  Overall, Its a good porter rather subdued but drinkable all the same.

Quick thankyou to Kook for lobbing this one back from the U.S., amongst others.  Served up at backyard patio temperature at a small tasting here in Perth. It was getting late as we cracked this one.Poured a deepest ruby brown, quite bright, sparkling in the lights but with no visible carbonation. Head rose, fell, did not last long, given the film on my glass at this stage I was not surprised. Sweetish, leathery, tar and marmite nose with a feint whiff of next day bonfire. First mouthful establishes some very dusty chocolate malts. From the next a sharp, resinous and acridly grassy twang spreads across the palate tainting what could be a decent beer. A good edge of rough pasty dark malts counteract bringing it back in the aftertaste. Smoke begins to linger also somehow balancing it out and making it pleasant despite the raspy sharp edge. Excellent length and a lovely smoothness adds points. The body itself not big, but it atleast holds ground. This wasnt too bad a drop, just nothing special to merit a high score. Sessionable, I suppose. (1 pint, 6 Fl.Oz, age unknown)

22 oz bottle, shared with StompBrockmore - black.  Aromas of toffee, some dark chocolate, a bit of coffee, but well-integrated, not like SOME coffee-bombs that I know.  Some smoky malt, but THANKFULLY not the crazily overpowering rauchbier smokiness, which I was expecting and not looking forward to.  Instead what we have here is a supremely quaffable really well-balanced full-bodied and flavourful porter that is just so fun to be with, especially when you walk away from a card game that youre winning because youre "tired"......PANSY!

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2006 22oz bottle, shared with VeloVampire - pours a dark, almost black shade. Some reds in the highlights. Roasted, smoky malts in the aroma, along with some subdued chocolate. The flavour is similar to this, and the smoke is something that provides backbone rather than being dominant in any way. Not really what I was expecting. Its subtle and blends nicely with the chocolate and coffee flavours, but you really have to look for it. I was expecting the smokiness to be much more pronounced - maybe not right in the front, like a rauchbier, but this was quite deep in the background. Theres a clean, lightly bitter finish to this and all-in-all, its a very fine porter, very smooth and easy drinking, even if I was expecting something much heartier, smokier, and robust...especially as this was coming from Stone, typically a brewer of such big, "look at me" beers. Not complaining though. This is a very good beer, once you put assumptions to the side.

This was my first try at a "smoked" beer. Poured a nice dark black with a thin tan head. There was definitely a slight smokiness to the aroma, along with coffee and chocolate hints. The taste was very similar. Though there was smokiness, it wasnt really a dominant flavor, which I think was a good thing. Finished somewhat bitter and smoky. This is something Id definitely try again and probably keep a few in the fridge for when Im in the mood for something dark.

22 ounce bottle in an English pint glass.  Pours a perfect fudgey brown with a lasting light brown head.  Aromas of chocolate, mild coffee, tobacco, Same in the flavor.  I would almost question if this beer is smoked at all.  Damn fine drinking porter though.

[tap @ The Other Side Cafe] Pours very nicely, with a dark ruby/brown color and a fully, coffee-colored head. Aroma is malty, slightly sweet with a very slight touch of smoke. Flavors are well-rounded, with molasses, dark roasted malts, a touch of bitterness and finally, a bit of campfirey smoke. Smoke presense is subtle, but provides a nice flavor in the finish. Overall, a tasty unique porter.
22 oz bottle.  Very dark brown, aroma of molasses, velvety smooth with notes of toffee and bitter sweet chocolate, clean finish with slight bitterness.  all in all, a very fine porter

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2006 22 oz bottle.  Very light aroma, almost non-existent.  Dark, dark brown.  Virtually no head.  Silky feel in mouth with really nice dark malt flavor.  Only a slight hint of smoke.  A very easy to drink brew.  Not the best, but really good.

The aroma on this one is of smoke and hints of chocolate.Pours dark with big tan head.Has a smokey caramel taste with someroasted malt flavors.Mouthfeel is medium with a nice smokey finish.Very smooth very easy to drink.
Dark brown to black, nice head. Can see light through it. Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  I couldnt make out the smoke over and above the dark malts in there. But a pretty good porter.

Great looking porter poured from a 22oz bomber.  Large frothy head of light brown and lasts most the pint. Dark black/brown appearance with a slight red hue when held to the light.  The aroma of this beer is what struck me. Heavy malt and molasses/roasted chocolate and virtually no hop aroma but did detect a bit of bread/dough.  Smokey smell was light, I expected it heavier and it would have been invited.Unfortunately, this smoked porter did not live up to the aroma for me.  Albeit a great beer, it had a lightly sweet initial flavor but I was struck immediately with fair bitter taste with a hint of smoke.  Exceptional medium to full body with a pleasant carbonation and dry yet creamy texture.  As I drank I felt it finished even more bitter and it lasted quite some time on my palate.  Would surly drink again but not something I will stock in my beer fridge. A little acidic/bitter for my taste, would go great with a hearty meal.

Pours a dark brown/black with some brown lacing on an overly carbonated head. Nose is semi-sweet chocolate and medium roast coffee. Body is fairly thin with more chocolate, cocoa dust, and very little smoke. In fact, unless I knew this was a smoked beer, I would not have guessed it. Its a solid porter, but unexceptional. Good to cook with, however, as my roast beef turned out excellent with this as the basting liquid.

22 oz Bomber, pours a deep dark brown with a large, light brown frothy head, the head is mostly lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is dark chocolate, roasted malt, with a hint of smoke.  Medium to full body with a dry,  bitter-sweet finish.  I loved this beer its a perfect balance not overpowered by smoke.

Amazing. Deep and dark reddish-brown body topped with an abundant frothy tan head, elegant lacing. The aroma is deep and rich- smoked peat, heavy malt, and baked bread nuances abound. The flavor delivers in full- initially sweet then malty with a smooth smokiness. Finishes with a dry yet sweet lifting sensation. Possibly the best beer I have ever had. I am in awe of this beer.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 Bomber, poured black with brown & red highlights, off-white head, nice lacing left behind, smelled of charred wood smoke, I had another smoked beer that smelled like pork fat, this was different, faint stout smell, roasted malts, tasted of the charred smoke, little hint of chocolate and coffee, some cola taste in there to, dry on the palate and bubbly mouthfeel, as it warms some the coffee came out, it was different but not impressive enough to want me to buy on a regular basis- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 
Thought I would give this another try, I found this much nicer this time around, nose wasnt to much different but the flavors are, 
roasted malt, some nut and sweet fragrances, chocolate, smoke aromas was there but it was faint, flavors of roasted malt, 
chocolate and charred wood smoke, I could really taste the charred wood smoke flavor, 
I do not remember the smoke flavor being this obvious, some coffee bitterness to, flavors burst onto the palate, more flavor then what my nose let onto,
some toasted malt and burnt flavors that have a coffee bitterness and the coffee bitterness is pronounced in the finish,
a nice mouth feel, I enjoyed this drink more then last Fall, glad I gave it another try.

22oz bomber. Very dark amber color with tan head. Light aroma. Just a hint of roasted malts. Great flavor! I taste roasted and chocolate malts and maybe a hint of black patent. There is also a subtle smoke flavor that hits about midway and builds towards the finish.
Bottle. Beautiful black pour with a tan head.  Sweet aroma. good taste with a hint of smoke. Finish is nice and long and tasted like roasted malt. A very good porter.

nothing too special here, and i might add that i was feeling a bit kind while rating this brew...deep brown body with beige head..aroma is exactly what you would expect from a smoked porter, and nothing else...i was glad to notice that the smoke did not dominate the chocolate roastiness of the porter...flavor was nice, but a bit toned down...seemed like this could have been a bit more robust...smoke, chocolate, and light toasted malts...

Bottled. Dark brown color with small creamy head. Sweetish and malty aroma with coffee and hints of peat. Sweetish flavor with mild coffee-like roastedness. Finishes  bittersweet with coffee, heather and peat. Very pleasant, excellent finish.

black with a dark brown edges and a tan head. aroma chocolate with a bit of smoke anise and coffee. rich dark bitter chocolate flavor with light smoke and anise. bitter slightly acidic with only a hint of sweetness. medium bodied creamy mouthfeel. bitter mocha finish with a hint of smoke. slightly acidic. a very tasty porter. its nice that the smoke isnt overbearing but it could use just a bit more. a very solid porter.

Stone Smoked Porter
22oz bomber
Recent brewing, ashed out 10/06
Medium pour in a pint glass.

Poured dark mahogony with a huge light brown fully lasting frothy head with excellent lacing.

Smelt of moderate mild chocolate, caramel, cola and molasses.

Taste was upfront moderate roasted bitterness and coffee with some sweet chocolate and burnt sugar tones and light piney hoppiness followed by a blend of strong smokiness, moderate sweet chocolate and cola, light piney hops bitterness on a long finish that reminds me of rootbeer or cola.  Mouthfeel was medium bodied, creamy and silky, lively carbonated, and moderately astringent.

Overall, the beer looks great, smells good, and the taste is balanced to perfection and intensely complex on all its duration.  Makes my neurons pop.  Minor points off for slight lack of sweetness and weakness of aroma.

pours black and muddy good light brown head.  Aroma is lightly toasted malts, moderate pine and grapefruit esters.  Flavor is moderatly bitter which seems out of character for this style, ends with a long bitter finish.  Light to medium bodied mouth feel was dissapointing, watery and lively carbonates.  Too  hoppy and fizzy for style, Grapefruit hoppiness a bit much.

Bottle.
Herbal hop bitterness on a vineous note.
Dark opaque brown, low creamy brown head.
Milk chocolate, fudge, a hint smoked coffee.
Medium body, creamy mouthfeel.

22oz bottle.  Dark black center, brown along the edges; off-white head showing large bubble formation and good retention.  Light aroma, showing smoke and a hint of citrus.  Medium-to-full bodied; emphasis is definitely on the porter end; smokiness is well-integrated with chocolate / roasted malts, hints of vanilla; slightly creamy and beautifully well-balanced.  So tasty.  Medium finish, slightly dry; vanilla and charred malts.

One of my favorite by stone.  Just powerful enough to be intense, but not over the line to where it becomes less refreshing.  If it didnt say that this was smoked, I wouldnt have known it.  Smoke is VERY light.

I really liked this. The smoke is subtle, not overdone. In most rauchbiers, all you taste is smokineness--not here. Strong milk chocolate aroma with modest smokiness. Flavor of milk chocolate wrapped around a caramel core. Good counterbalancing bitter hops--not very aromatic, but strong on the tongue. Thick in the mouth, lovely in the glass. I think this is one of Stones better beers.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2007 Delicious!!...So dark just about black in color....on the pour a mild foam that lingers sweetly.....on the swirl, the aroma  is caramel and espresso melded together and dipped in bitter sweet chocolate....and the taste follows the aroma...with an added smokiness that ties it all together...the smoke is a delight, so light...just right.....:)

Bottle from Liquid Solutions.  Poured a very dark brown, nearly opaque, with a small quickly diminishing brown head.   Taste is slightly sweet, caramel, roasted malt and chocolate. A little bit of smokiness.  Less than I expected from Stone.  A solid beer.
Bottle.  Thick brown lasting head, leaving Queen Anne lace. Black as night.  Aroma of malt and smoke. Smoky flavour, with notes of espresso and chocolate.  Full mouth with smoky finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: 22oz bottle via trade from Jason @ Knightly Spirits, no date.  Pours a black with a tiny brown head.  Aroma of caramel and chocolate malts up front, then some coffee roastiness and a little smoky peat.  I was wondering why this beer was in the porter category and not in the smoked (even though I read the description), but it really isnt that strong.  As soon as I said that, the taste had a fair amount more smoke--not too much, mind you.  Not as sweet as you would imagine from the aroma, either.  Biggest flavor was roasty coffee and dark chocolate.  Lightly chalky, roasty bitter dry finish.  Moderate carbonation bordering high, pretty smooth mouthfeel.    Good porter.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: (Bottle) Pours dark brown, no head. Burned wood aroma with hints of allmond and some hops and malt. Gluish. Clean, light smokey flavour with some wet stone. Milk chocolate ice cream. Porter-ish sweet. Small to medium body.

this beer was disappointing to me.  stone usually goes over the top with flavors so i was expecting liquid campfire, not so much.  a pretty average porter with a hint of smokiness.  pours opague wit a nice head.  aroma of chocolate and coffee.  nice hop taste and finish but i needed more smoke!
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Excellent pour, dark brown to black, with a great head that lasted a while.  Eventually came down to a covering film.  Good lacing as well.  Aroma of chocolate and surprisingly, a decent amount of hops.  This porter could be a good choice for a dessert beer.  The flavor is semi-sweet, very light on the smoke, with licorice, chocolate and dark fruitiness up front, followed by a mild alcohol finish.  Probably some coffee in there too.  Above average, but not outstanding in my opinion.
Large brown head deep black body.  Chocolate, wood smoke fire, hazelnuts,  sweet malt aromas.  Smoked, definitely mesquite or hickory
Almost black color. Beautiful aroma of smoked wood and malt.  Caramel and wood flavor with a smoke tinge in it. Overall, an excellent beer to sip.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2008 Bottled. Almost opaque black colour, small off-white head. Aroma is roasted malts, smoked wood and slight "babyrauchbierish". Flavour is American hops, caramel and a bit wood. Aroma has the smoke/roast in it, but the flavour seems to totally lack that part... 8 4 6 3 14
[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Deep ambery brown colour, small brown head. Aroma is oak, smoked wood, licorice, vanilla and some mild hoppyness. Flavour is wood, mild notes of brandy, alcohol and licorice along with some mild vanilla and smoked notes. Kickass! 9 4 8 5 18

Bottled.
