Almost opaque black, not much head. Smoked malty nose. Malty, roasted flavor, American hops. Long roasted aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2015 Draught at Steampunk Bar, Göteborg. Black beer with a rich and lasting beige/brownish head. Roasted smoked aroma, tar, licorice, caramel, dark chocolate, some hops. Smoked hop and soot aroma, licorice, caramel, tar, leather notes. Fresh and decently heavy beer with balanced smoke.
[Bottle] Dark brown with a weak head. Malty aroma. Really malty flavour with notes of liquorice. Wheres the smoke??
Opaque black colour, tan head.  Very smoky aroma.  Even smokier flavour with a kick of alcohol.  Very minor malts.

Bottle Sept 2006.  Aroma was not strong, a light coffee smell.  Head was a a nice rich light brown.  Taste was smooth.  Finish was the best part of the beer.  I did not detect much, if any, smoky flavor.  Taste mostly of chocolate and coffee.  Solid porter.
aroma coffee and only a touch of smoke.  flavor much the same.  not a whole lot smoke jus a hint with touch of ash and is a little acrid.  not to bad.  stone definitely came make interesting beer

Havent had this in a long time, so given my recent refound appreciation for Porters, I picked one up this evening.  No real discernable smell, but a killer head with nice lacing.   You would think that Smoke would be a dominant fixture in this beer, but its barely there.  A malty beverage with lots of chocolate and Coffee going on.  I would like this to be a little sweeter.  As is, its a tad dry.  Rather hoppy too.  Pretty good beer.
A smooth porter with a rich flavor.  Nice finish to a good beer.  Only hints of a smoky flavor.  Recommended!

definitely got the chocolate and coffee flavor.  did not pick up a whole lot of the smoke flavor in it.  i did have ruination the night before though, the affects of that may not have completely worn yet.  thats not a bad thing, some smokes taste like a campfire in your mouth.  not a bad porter.

Excellent Porter américain. Sans être trop porter ni trop américain nous pouvons goûter les multiples saveurs. Le caramel, le fûmé, lagrume-houblon et le malt chocolat. Bu tiède, les saveurs ressortent davantage et la soirée nest que plus agréable.

Poured a deep black with a thick lasting tan head.  Good lacing.  Aroma is rough and seems to be confused by itself though it is no indication of the rest of the beers qualities.  Once the beer enters the mouth a harmonious blend of chocolate, coffee, sweet toffee, figs, and smoke.  I was expecting a smokier beer such as alaskan but was very impressed by the balance achieved in this beer.  Mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy with a subtle bitterness that cuts through the sweetness.

A fine porter indeed.  I find this a good welcome to winter and the colder months.  I has plenty to fill the palate and warm you on a nice cold winter night.  It is a porter packed with chocolate and coffee flavors with a hint of smoke.  I dont typically like smoked beer, but this one is an exception.

22 oz bomber from trade with realale420. Thanks Brian! Pours a rich dark brown color with a thin tan head that slowly dissapates. It has a thin to meduim body with an aroma of smoke and cocoa. Taste was very different from other Porters in the fact that it is very balanced and smooth. Nothing really prevelent in the taste.  This means that no one specific flavor dominated the beer. A complex but yet straight forward brew. Nice!

Pours a dark brown, with a reddish glow in the light, and a medium brown head, that is thin, yet long lasting.  Aroma was oddly faint to me, but Im not sure if my nose was working correctly...Hmmm.  What I smelled was good though; mocha/coffee and a slight bit of that smokiness.  Flavor was similar, with a more interesting smoke character that appears both in the taste and the finish.  The smoke dries out the finish which is very well balanced, compared to Ruination (which I had before I started actually writing reviews).  A nice medium bodied beer that is nicely balanced and well aware of its more mellow intentions.  Very enjoiyable.

22oz bomber.  Pours black with a foamy chocolate colored head.  This is not the first time ive had this but im getting so many more smoky aromas.  Nice light smoky aroma with chocolate and malt.  Chocolate coffee woody flavors come through, its sweet but still bitter enough to balance that and be a very enjoyable beer.

Robe noire claire aux reflets rouges surmontée dune mousse beige épaisse en dentelle qui persiste. Arômes de caramel, de levure, de pain et de sucre. Saveurs légers de fumé, de caramel et de malt torréfié.

Bomber.

Translucent black (is that an oxymoron?) with a tan head. The aroma is vinous with some chocolate and a slight hint of smoke. This one provides a well-balanced flavor, dark malts blending with raisins and a subtle peach sweetness while the smoke whispers around the edges adding wood-and-tobacco accents. 
This is not an attempt to be bigger-than-thou, but rather its a terribly quaffable beer, and its a treat to see something so well balanced coming from Stone. This is just plain extremely well made.

This is only the second smoked porter, or beer for that matter that I have tried. This smoked porter *PALES* in comparison to the Alaskan Brewing Co. smoked porter. The "smokiness" is hardly present at all. The color, head, aroma and taste are "decent". Im certainly glad it was half the price of the Alaska Brewing Co.s smoked porter...It certainly tastes like half the beer the AK brewing does.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2009 Pours a oily opaque black with a creamy tan head thats on the warmer side of the spectrum. The aroma is pretty nice and balanced: chocolate, sweet smoke, peat and coffee..they all seem to blend together very well with the chocolate and coffee remaining dominant. The flavor has bitter coffee in the front, some chocolate and smoke in the middle, and a bittersweet finish when they all seem to come together in a way.  Pleasant mouthfeel, rich but not thick with a smooth carbonation. The use of smoke is a nice accent, even though personally I wouldve cared for a bit more...but thats being really picky. A pretty great porter overall, Im still waiting for Stone to disappoint me.

Poured deep and dark with a tan head.  Aroma was a nice smokey hop smell.  First drink I was blown away on the great smokey malt taste with a great chocolate backing.  The smokey adds a great touch that moves the porter from a good beer to a great beer!

Bottle.  Pours the color of espresso with a fine khaki colored head.  Smell is smoky (as to be expected), a bit hoppy, and marked by a smooth maltyness.  Nice earthyness to the smell also.  Flavor profile echoes the the nose nicely.  The best part about the beer is that the smoky notes dont overwhelm all the others (like cocoa and nuts).  Nice smooth texture but tastes a little flat, but it is a porter.  A very nice porter.

1 pint 6 oz bottle.  Poured a dark, rich brown color with a medium tan head.  Aroma was very rich with hops and smokiness.  The taste was incredible, a lot more than I expected, with the smokiness of the malt mixed with chocolate and rich coffee flavors.  It was very complex yet it balanced out so well and finished lingering on the tongue.  Great sipping beer, loved it.

Black with no head. This beer is rich and sweet with smokey notes. Chocolate, maple, and coffee flavors are also noticed.  A complex dance between the mentioned flavors and hops make this beer a winner.

22 oz bottle. Black beer with a large beige head that dissappears rapidly leaving a lot of lace. Smokey licorice aroma.
Smoked licorice taste with some plum notes. Full bodied creamy moutfeel. Dry hoppy finish with some burnt espresso at the end....also this doesnt come alive until it hits about 60 degrees. Let is warm a bit and is much better!

Just as one would expect, another great beer from Stone. Cocoa, coffee, and faint hops in the aroma, as well as a hint of toffee. Taste follows the aroma almost perfectly. A little more cocoa on the palate, nice coffee notes, some faint hoppy bitterness on the finish, and smoky goodness all the way through. Coffee and hops linger on the palate. This is probably the best porter Ive had to date.

Hopnessmonster gave me a bottle to try.  I was afraid I woulnt like it due to an overpowering smoke Rauch flavor.  Not overpowering at all.  Dark in color.  Very smooth texture that blends the malt and the little bit of smoke that there is.  Very excellent take on a Porter.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2006 Pours almost black with a nice tall tan/brown head.  Faint aroma of coffee, smoky malt and hops.  Taste is much lighter then expected  but same as aroma.  A bit too much carbonation for me, but a nice change of pace for a "dark" beer.  Paired this with Cahill Porter cheese and its pretty good!

Pours exactly like one would expect, dark. Head is brown in color and very full with good lacing. Smells like a lot of chocolate and coffee. Tastes identical to the smell with a lot of hop flavor as well. This is a great beer, but not quite as good as Stone can do, IMO.
Dark black color.  Smell of hops, chocolate, coffee, smoke, malt and milk.  Taste of hops, roasted coffee, chocolate, some alcohol and a nice bitter finish.  Very good beer.

On draught.... pours almost black, but the darkest ruby available.  It has a creamy tan head with mild retention and webbed lacing.  The bouquet is malty, with roasts and sweet grain.  The flavors are of sweet malt, some subtle smoked roasts and slight cherries.  A sweet, smoked hop finish rounds out the creamy mouthfeel.  This is a GREAT brew!

I was expecting more. The head was long lasting and cream colored, quite thick. The color dark and opaque. The initial flavor was that of the hops, very notable, much like in everything Stone produces, however the malts I felt were completly overshadowed by the hops. I dont really see a reason to go back to this one.
Appearance like coca-cola. Not an overly smokey porter which was harder to detect in aroma than in flavor. Taste was smooth. Hints of dark cherries and sweet, smokey malts. Pretty damn good.
This had an average head.Color was black.Aroma was a biting malt and smoky.Tasted like a nice stout with a dry smokey flavor.nice.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 I am rather finicky about smoked beers. Sampled on draft at the State College beer festival this beer poured a black color with a large tan head. The aroma is mild roasty malts. The body is rather light. The flavor is wood smoke with light roasty malts. The smoke dominates and lingers. Not remotely subtle. Not my style at all.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2006 Poured into liter mug- looks awesome. Pillowy head... just looks creamy. Aroma is very slight roasted malts. Flavor is subtle chocolate sweetness and roasted malt; Im not getting coffee at all really. A touch of acidity that I dont love. The smoked malts are far in the background, but that I think that is good. Finish is well balanced and the palate is appropriately medium bodied. Only negative is that I get a slight medicinal twinge in the finish that turns bitter... I think it is a remnant of the smoke mixing with the hops... sort of like charcoal. This dies down substantially as it warms.

Pours black, opaque with reddish tinge, barely noticeable aroma of chocolate and campfires.  Nice thick feeling in the mouth, flavor is pleasant and chocolatey with some coffee notes.  Not much smokiness, but I dont like that very much anyway!  A great porter!

There is a pleasent smoked and chocolate aroma with a pour that is a moderate black and a nice tan head.  The sweetness of the malt comes through initially followed by a smokines with a light coffee background.

Nice mahogany edge with total black in the middle...just like the bottle says. Great coffee and smoked chocolate smell. Nice carmalized sugars mixed with smoked mocha and coffee flavors. Full bodied feel. Great finish.
bottle. pours allmost black. liqerice aroma. nice and smokey. roasted  malt. lots of liqerice. soft and a bit thin.

22 oz. Bottle Jet black, only Superman can see through this one.  It has a fluffy light brown head.  Wonderful aromas of coffee with sugar, chocolate and a "subtle smokiness."  If all you were able to do was sniff the aroma, it would still be a delightful experience.  But alas, in my case, I went to the next and crucial step of tasting.  And what I discovered was smoky charcoal flavor compunded with other flavors as coffee and burnt sugars.  The feel has the porter slick feel that I dont prefer, but fits the style.  It leaves a nice aftertaste on the back of your tongue.  Yum!

bomber.  dark black/maple pour with thick creamy tan head.  nice lacing.  coffee, chocolate, slight smokey, malt aroma.  nice chocolate and coffee.  smoked coffee aftertaste.  a little watery but all in all a nice porter.
Bottle. Almost black in colour with a medium sized brown head. Not very smokey. More mild than I expected. But malty and sweet with notes of chocolate and a weak hint of smoke.

Bottle thanks to a friend of mine. Poured a jet dark black with a thin, bubbly, off white head. I liked the aroma of this one, almost charred. Like burnt mixed with sweet chocolate malts, carmel and coffee. Taste is even better, with heavy smoke. I havent had to many smoked beers, but Im lovin this. Its going great with my BBQ chicken, for the 4th of July I dont think Id want any other beer.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2007 Not as good as expected, Ive had better porters.  Pours a dark brown, almost black.  Nice smokey aroma.  Flavor of roasted malt (which is the main flavor) with hints of chocolate, coffee, and caramel.  The smokey flavor is very good, but other than that its not too good.  Medium mouthfeel.  Good, but not the best.
Great beer which goes great with any BBQ.  great after taste which hits the taste buds.  Really a great all around beer.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 Re-Rate from a bottle:  Completely different, as they say, this time it was an ELEMENT, not THE character.  Quite good actually.  Nice coffee aroma, with a tad bit of smoke.  Flavor is roasty, slight sweetness, some underlying smokiness, and a hint of some crisp hops.  Full bodied, I like.

This first time I tasted this I liked it more.  Also had the chipotle version at the real ale fest, interesting and innovative, but not necessarily my cup of tea.  Aroma was nice and smoky.  Looks nice, dark brown, nice off white head.  Flavor is a little too one-dimensional, just smoky.  Props to Stone for a unique beer, but smoke was a little overpowering.  My least favorite stone beer so far, but all the others have been exceptional.

Had from keg at the Pizza Port Real Ale fest.  This particular version was brewed with chipotle.  Soke came through nicely but was not overwhelming, chilies also came through as a nice accent, though not entirely necessary.  Body was a bit thinner than the typical stone smoked porter.  Nose has hints of a rich spicy molé.  Overall good, but I think I prefer last years richer version a bit better.

Appears a dark mahogany brown with auburn edges when held up to the light. Nice, fluffy tan head that slowly fades out into a cap that floats upon the brew. Scattered streaks of lacing are left around the glass.
Smell is of some sweet, smokey peat, and beef jerky notes, along with caramel, cocoa powder, vanilla, and raisins. Perhaps a touch of anise buried in the background. Pretty complex.
Taste is of the same aromas with a lip smacking sweet malt that confuses the tastebuds at first but makes for a plausable and complex brew.
Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with mild carbonation that makes the smokiness more tolerable and enjoyable like a delicate digestif.

Dark, & a lot of depth. Mug.I liked it a lot. I grab one or two every time I see it now. All the flavors are blended perfectly to my taste. Chocolate, coffee, and a slight hint of smoked flavor. Great beer.

(Bottle (best by 1/16/06) via trade with IrishBoy, thanks Richard!) Pours a dark cola-tinged brown with about 3" of tan head. Coffee-chocolate aroma. Mouthfeel smooth, slightly watery. Sloppy lacing. Fairly heavy coffee taste upfront with some chocolate developing on back end. Bitterness overlays and is more prominent in finish. At first I was beginning to wonder if this was actually a smoked beer but smoke flavor really began to develop as beer warmed. Pleasant smoked flavor then appparent from beginning through finish and aftertaste.
Pours like motor oil with a heavy tan head.  Aroma consists of chocolate, coffee, and smoked nuts.  The smoke is subtle enough to make this one of the best porters around.

Bomber. Pours a semi-opaque blackish brown with garnet highlights and a fading tan head with a bit of lace. Aroma of roasty malt, chocolate, coffee, and smoke. Medium-full body with light carbonation and a creamy, slightly oily mouthfeel. Taste is smoke, coffee, molasses with a lingering, lightly bitter finish. Nicely balanced.

On tap 6/7 @ the Brewery: Pours jet black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate with hints of smokiness in the malt. Flavor was smoky with hints of roasted nuts and caramel leaving a creamy mouthfeel and a mild chipotle pepper finish. Well balanced and delicious!

very good smoked porter.A bit on the mild side.Very good with smoked cheder
cheese.It doesnt compare to the alaskan at all.The alaskan is better in every way.

Bottle. Outstanding. Pours almost black with a nice brown head.
Aromas of  roasted malts and roasted coffee.
The flavor is spectacular: malty, with a hint of caramel. The smokiness is very subtle but definitely adds to it. Overall this beer is very well balanced.

Delicious, on tap at the real ale fest. The note said it was brewed with chipotle peppers. I thought it was going to be a bit corny. This is more of a stout with lots of coffe and dried fruits at the start, the middle was more smokey and roasted nuts but not overly done. And the finish was spicy and hot. Very faint, barely noticible chipotles. Nice rich and strong body. Very well made brew. Some of the best ive had.
Bold look, sophisticated taste-- this beer understands the dance of malt and bitter in a profound way. The smoke blows a kiss dry chocolate and clean coffee character of this beer. First rate.
dark brown color with tanish head. Chocolatey coffee aroma, taste was smokey coffee and sweet chocolate. Very smooth.

Bottle - Pours deep dark brown with light tan medium head.  Aroma is chocolatey with some coffee.  Palate is somewhat thick, but silky smooth.  Taste is bitter chocolate and coffee with a touch of smokiness.  I was expecting more smokey flavor, but it is fairly subtle coming out more in the aftertaste with a touch of hoppy bitterness.  Overall an excellent porter.  Another Stone classic!

Poured a nice dark brown color with a tan head that was pretty solid and sustained itself quite well. The aroma was burnt coffee with some hops and the flavor was a bitter coffee-chocolate with a burnt aftertaste. The hops were a tad strong for what I like in my stouts/porters, but not bad. The mouthfeel was slightly on the thin side and carbonated. A nice beer, but one I wouldnt overpay for in the future.

(04.23.06) One pint 6 oz brown bottle purchased from Beeronthewall.com.   5.9% ABV.  Poured clear ruby brown with small white head. No discernable carbonation. Roasted malt in the nose. Full  bodied porter that started with light malt sweetness with smoky/roasted malt/fruity (raisin) flavors. Finished with light smoky fade and some bitterness.  Smooth and rich tasting. Smoke aroma and flavor did not overwhelm the beer.  Rich tasting, this is one awesome porter.

Near opaque black-brown.  Generous foamy head, recedes slow with attractive lace.  Smells of smoke, malt, molasses, dark fruit, and floral hops.  Tastes full-bodied and balanced.  Sweet malt, smoke, charcoal, chocolate, toffee, and dark fruits dominate, with the hops contributing to a slightly herbal quality rather than bitterness.  Mouthfeel is solid and slightly chewy.

Pours a rich dark brown with nice tan head.  Aroma has roated chocolate and coffee notes.  There is some smoke on the aroma, but it is not very heavy.  Medium to full bodied beer - slick and velvety mouthfeel with soft carbonation.  Starts out with a creamy roastedness, then some charred malts and coffee.  The finish has roastedness and some smoke, but mainly bingling bitter hops.  Further down the beer some chocolate starts coming out.  A good beer for what it is.

Rating# 500 WoooWhooo!Wow the pour is great.Black as night with a thin, lacing tan head.Aromas of burntness and coffee.Full on flavors of coffee, roasted malts and a slight chocolate.Finish was clean leaving me smacking my lips for more.Most excellent.

22oz Bomber.  Surprisingly light cream head, not dark [ish] at all. On the other hand the porter is as dark as it gets, at least with side, back lighting in this room, i cant see through this at all, just some red tinting on the edges of the glassware.  Little traces of lace on the way down.  This is the "lightest" tasting Stone i can remember [dont remember their Levitation when i tried that before] [and on another note, their Ruination has truly "ruined" me, i need MORE HOPS]
Slight coffee smell.  Taste is a nice light porter, with a mild smokey flavor.  The aftertaste is like coffee almost, the bitterness present is very light.

22oz bomber. Mistakenly grabbed this instead of the Imperial Stout at the store, as the shelf-stockers, in their infinite wisdom, put two beers from the same co. with remarkable similar labels as far as color scheme and overall design goes...well the idjits put them side by side and I departed with this instead of the RIS goodness. So be it.

Turns out, for something I would never ever try, if not only on a dare, this one isnt too bad at all. As a homebrewer myself, I am fascinated by the process involved in making this one. The smoke is prevalent, yet subtle. There is even some dried fruit on the downtake, and a sweetness at the end. Well more than any balance I expected to find in a beer like this. All the same, finishing a mere 22oz bomber is a chore, unless you pour liquid smoke on your morning toast or something. Ack! on the smoke, Aces on the execution of this style.
Very dark pour with a generous head. Just a hint of chocolate brown  in colouring. Smokey taste is mixed nicely so as not to be overpowering. Its a nice dessert beer on the lighter side.

Draft at the Barking Dog. Great stuff; pours jet black with a nice dense tan head. The nose is surprisingly vacant, but only by the standards of the style. Sweet malt, roast, and smoke come up a bit. This is a good clean drinkable porter with great roast, chocolate, coffee, and resin-y flavors. Its like hearing Stevie Ray Vaughan play Voodoo Chile, though. Alaskan so totally owns this style (for me), that this is just a happy reminder of how much I like Alaskan Smoked Porter/Hendrix. But I never get tired of Stones beers, anymore than I ever get tired of SRV.

This might be my favorite porter. Pours a beautiful dark brown color, almost black. Initially starts off with a nice head, but it does diminish a bit leaving a faint froth on the top, just enough to keep the lace going. Smells of dark roast coffee, smoke (duh!) and dark bakers chocolate. Goes down nice and smooth, very easy to drink. Makes for a perfect rainy day type beer, when its cold outside and you wish you were grillin

Perhaps out of curiosity and perhaps a certain masochism, I continually return to Stone for new challenges despite my apathy towards the brewery. Dont get me wrong, Stone produces quality beers, and with remarkably consistent standing - I simply cannot help questioning the excitement it generates within the craft brewing community. It may be for that reason that I persevere testing their range in hopes of an epiphany. Pouring the Porter produced a deep brown body that shines a woody rim in the light. A custard-colored mousse sits comfortably on top as the familiar aroma of chocolate rises from my goblet. The nose is straightforward but enjoyable: coffee, cream and berries mingle with the slight bitterness of chocolate as an unobtrusive smokiness lingers in the background. It may have been a rough day for my tastebuds as my sole notes regarding flavor read as follows: "choco-HAM!". I do recall the initial chocolate sweetness being brutally interrupted at the mid-palate by a dense smoky flavor, reminding of cured ham. I may need more experience with smoked beers in order to recognize the nuances from one to the next, but my sense was of a definite asymmetry. Not an unsatisfactory flavor, but a true lack of complexity and "core". Still not the Stone I am looking for...

poured a wonderful very dark, mostly black, dark dark reddish brown but still very clear.  also poured very smooth and fluid.  the head was of average size and was a nice brown/tan color.  i didnt notice any lacing, but the head did stay around for a decent amount of time with a little remaining around the edges towards the end.


as for aroma i mostly got a dark roasted scent with a very mild hint of dark chocolate and coffee.  best way to describe it was a nice clean dark roast.


i was suprised by just how mild of a smoke flavor this did have and was impressed by how smooth and balanced of a flavor it had as well.  again like the aroma there was a strong dark roasted flavor, but not overly powerful or bitter.  there was also a note of sweetness in both the start and finish, but mostly the initial flavor.


the most amazing thing, actualy left me in total awe, was just how light boddied the beer was.  with as dark as the beer looks you expect something much thicker, but it was actualy light and refreshing.  i would actualy say the body was in the medium light to medium area with a smooth but almost creamy texture.  there wasnt much for carbonation, but it was very soft through out the beer and fit the beer very well.


since this one is a very easy beer for me to find in my area and quite affordable, i would deffinently buy this one again as well as strongly recomend it to others.

Bomber.  Poured a beautiful deep black garnet with an average sized off-white head that lingered for a while, but mostly diminished before I was through.  In an apparent contradiction, this beer smells both earthy and clean.  Maybe like a well-swept cabin with a dirt floor.  Can you clean dirt?  I dunno.  But it smells like clean dirt.  Moderate malty smell, big chocolate notes, faint campfire.  They definitely didnt overdo the smoke in the nose.  Nice to have a smoked that isnt asphyxiating.  Raisin and cola notes coming out stronger as the glass warms.  The aroma is surprising.  Kind of like a sophisticated lumberjack, and not what I was expecting at all.  Superbly balanced.  First gulp and the peat smoke comes out soft, then crescendos nicely.  Again, not overwhelming, but like the dying embers of last nights fire.  Some sweetness helped along by the chocolates presence.  Some musty basement too.  A beautiful, long, lightly bitter finish that carries wifts of smoke all the way to end.  Moderate carbonation, soft anf fluffy mouthfeel.  An outstanding porter by any standard.  Not to be missed.

A truly excellent porter, one that will at least cause me to pause before automatically reaching for Anchors. The aroma immediately said "Stone", with a sweet spicy (mango chutney?) melody harmoniously laid on top of a classic roasted-coffee porter background, and a strong hint of smoke. It pours beautifully dark and clear, with a nice creamy head which subsides quickly into a drinkable thin film. Even though served quite warm, the flavor and mouthfeel didnt quite live up to what my eyes and nose had promised--I prefer porters that pack just a little bit more sweet, roasted maltiness--but it was still quite good, with the smoke flavor again perfectly balanced. And it all finished very clean, making this one very drinkable porter.
lots of somke on the way down, with hints of chocolate, and coffee. Not bad at all.

Black body, small light brown head, no laces; quite small nose, it has great depth and and complexity, but it is well hidden behind nothing: very fresh with very little smokiness to it, spicy honey (only the spicy part of honey, not the sweet), little bitter chocolate, milk chocolate, some cinnamon. it is fantastic, but could be a little more powerful; balanced, creamy body to bitter side with the perfect amount of great and full carbonation; it finishes of very, very long (actually well into the next beer I drank). first very flowery, turning into a long bitterness: first the very sweet smell of the inside of a Danish garden flower, that I dont know the name of, this sweetness disappears slowly turning into a long complex, constantly changing never ending finish. Super, super beer only loosing a bit on its nose. Thanks a lot to Numenor for sending this one!
Pours a black with tan head.  Smokey, roasty.  Sweet aroma.  Notes of coffee, caramel.    Chewey, malty.  A little acidic.   Dry, bitter finish.    Somewhat thin.

bomber: poured black with a ruby tinge at the bottom of the glass.  The head was full but goes down to a coating on the top.  Lucious nose full of dark roasted malt, carmel, some of the smokieness.  Taste of coffe, carmel, smoke is present.  Notes of licorice.  Its delicious, and it really does go with PB&J like the bottle says.  (I had to try it).  Nice body.  A very good porter.
The smokeyness is beautifully integrated into the porter flavor.  Frankly, I prefer this modification instead of the oak aging in some beers I have sampled.  Seamless and delicious.

Smelled of chocolate, toffee and smoke.  The taste is similar but less sweet and more roasted.  A nice black pour with a chocolate colored head.  This porter was more like fire smoke then meat smoke like a smoked beer.  It was nice and smooth going down.

a rauchbier this isnt,aroma was coffee ,malt, and a touch of smoke,the texture was smooth as silk,taste was chocolately sweetish, and just a tinge of smoke,actually not even enough to warrant the word in the name

Nose is mostly roast with some actual smoke character. Palate is disappointingly thin and watery. Flavor, however, is excellent with more of the roast that deepens revealing dimensions of bittersweet chocolate and coffee before a touch of peaty funk. This is much better than I was expecting and was only held back by the thin mouthfeel. Stone timid for once about ingredients or just showing uncharacteristic restraint?
good dark beer flavor a little smokey but this was first smoked beer i had so i will not judge this one like it.it was good and very tastey .

Thanks to paskal...
Aroma:Chocolate,rosted malt,caramel...
Appearance:Dark brown-light tan head...
Flavor:rosted nutty,light smoked,.....

Light smoke, sweet. Hints of coffee and bitter choco. Decadent and smooth. Desserty but drinkable. I would of liked it to be more smoked. Thats about my only complaint. This beer is heaven in the mouth.

Bottled.  This porter pours black with a large fizzy light-brown head.  The aroma is malty with only a slight hint of roast and chocolate.  Its heavy and the taste is dominated by a dry roasty coffee flavor.

22 oz. bottle.  Dark brown body with some reddish tinge, with a small white-ish head.  Aroma was smoky but subtle with chocolate and coffee.  Flavor has notes of barbequed meats, but also chocolate, coffee, and dried fruits.  Theres alot in there.  Palate could be a bit thicker.  A very nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2007 22 oz bottle.  I love Stone beers. This one is no exception, very good. Dark malty, some chocalate and coffee lingering flavors.  I learned something great from visiting Stone brewery.  Take a Stone IPA and mix with Stone Porter (75/25) they called it Smokin Indian! Its fanfreakintastic!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2007 Draft
Dark coffee looking beer. No strong aroma but great appereance. Great smooth flavor that makes it very drinkable. Gets better as it warms creating a different character. Cheers!

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2009 Pours an opaque dark brownish-black with a thin tan head. Nutty, chocolate and coffee aroma with just a hint of smoke. Sweet roasted malt flavor with a subtle, pleasant smokiness. Touch of hop bitterness at the end. Very smooth, satiny mouthfeel ... just shy of thick and syrupy. overall, an excellent, well balanced beer and a great porter.

Pretty dark near-black pour with a lasting and thick tan head.  Sweet chocolate aroma with some peat, molassas and coffee.  Definite smoked taste that accentuates the robust malts.  Sweetness is kept muted, but Im getting more chocolate and light expresso.  Smokiness lingers into the finish, with a bit of citric hop smacking.  Pretty darn balanced and enjoyable.
Pours a deep brown color with a light brown head.  Aroma of smoked malts,  roasted malts,  and a bit of chocolate.  Smooth....silky mouth feel.

22 oz bottle, via Sprinkle.  Pours a clear dark mahogany with a tight two finger light brown head that left nice lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, smoked malt, and a touch of chocolate and caramel.  Flavor is balanced up front with roasted malt and smoke, while the smoke comes on strong in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with moderate carbonation yielding a slightly oily texture.  This is a pretty nice Porter, made better with the addition of the smoked malt.  This is a nice into beer for those who dont care for smoked beers in general.  Worth seeking out.
at first i was a bit intimidated... but it was really good... very dark with white head, and smells of chocolate and coffee.

Bomber. Pours black, not opaque, but black. Minimal brown head. Aroma is intensely coffee, smoke, wheat?, apple. Taste is upfront with cocoa and caramel. Lots of coffee and smoke. Roasted malts do not overwhelm as description atests. Excellent bitter quality bites at back and lingers forever. Bitterness reminds of ashes and mocha coffee. Most porters are too watery for me. Stone Smoked Porter does not have this problem, although the palate is light. My favorite porter to date.

On tap at the Banshee @ Scranton, PA. Strong currents of syrup, black licoriche and fruits accompany a malty kick which practically burns the tongue in a good way. The smokiness is here but its not dominant. I wish the aroma had more of a kick but it was enjoyable nonetheless.
Bottle. Pours dark with a one finger thick tan head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, smoke, and hops. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, smoke, smooth, and hop in the presence. Good body, good brew.

Poured a black color with ruby highlights when held to a light.  Almost no head at all and it quicly disappeared.  This is a very smooth beer and I would say it is more along the lines of a Schwarzbier in flavor than a porter.  Had a slight coffee hint in the finish.  I do not get any smokeyness at all.
22oz bottle.  Had this a while ago.  Rich dark color, with a tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, and malt.  Slightly bitter finish.

pours a very dark amber, almost black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of coffee and roasty.  Taste is coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt up front with a slightly smokey and bittersweet finish.  nice.
Oh yeah, this is bad medicine that works so good.  Very nice finish, sort of a smokey-sweet flavor.  Definitely try this if you see it.  CLONES.

Roasty smell, and some coffee.  Small tannish head, dissipated pretty fast, which was dissapointing.  Dark, completely opaque body.  Thinner mouthfeel, but very roasty and delicious.  This is a good porter.  I prefer the Stone Imperial Russian, but the Smoked Porter is fantastic.  For a bomber, this was a quick and tasty drink.  Light lacing as well.

Black. Large, frothy, tan head leaves a nice coat of lacing. Aroma of roasty, smokey, ashy malt and subtle resinous hops. Rich, smokey porter with a pleasant, hop heavy finish. Full, smooth body is very drinkable. Excellent.

Quite dark.  Very weak head, dissipated quickly.  Pretty complex for a porter.  Neither chocolate nor coffee are particularly strong.  Smells a little like coins actually.  Not very bitter, despite my sisters objections.  As the label suggests, its quite malty - and delicious.  gets better as the bomber/palate wears on.  Palate solid for a porter, though nothing extraordinary.  A nice conversational beer.
Quality porter.  The smoke and mild hops create a very smooth finish.  Probably the tamest Stone brew Ive had yet.  My only gripe is that the body is noticibly thin as it warms.
A awesome porter... Not as sweet as most porters, but not very dry either.  It has a nice smooth hickory cedar taste.  Dark black with a nice mahogony head.   One of my favorite porters
great porter. the smokiness is a welcome addition to the coffe roasted world of porters.

Pours a beautiful dark black color with a perfect amount of froathy, bubbly light brown head.  Aroma is roasted dark chocolate, sweet lactic cream, carmalized brown sugar, and slight licorice.  Flavor is sweet and lactic, then slighty bitter with a very slight smoke undertone that is almost fruity in flavor.  Finish is long and drawn out with chcolate covered peach flavors.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy.  Overall, great porter!

bottle.. dark brown pour ,small beige head that disapates quickly . good lacing . aroma of chocolate and smoke but not overpowering . definate smoke taste as well as coffee and licorice . light body with a good finish . good porter
Solid porter that really is worth it.  Not a throwaway beer from them.  Decent amount of smoke and everything else that you expect from a good porter and Stone.

This offering from Stone poured out of the bottle a dark brown,almost looking like cola, with a small tan head that quickly dissappears.You definely get hints of chocolate,coffee and licorice as well as smoke flavoring.This was a very unique and pleasant tasting brew.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2007 Stone has maintained an unusual track record of consistency.  Other breweries seem to deviate from any standards theyve set for themselves, sometimes letting down their beer devotees, and sometimes excelling beyond the expectation of any beer snob potentates.  But Stone has built a small beer empire by being expectedly strong and curiously good.  As far as my experience goes, the Imperial Stout brought me from childhood into manhood; the Ruination robbed me of 60% of my senses for a month; the Double Bastard leveled me on what was supposed to be a peaceful Friday evening.  But all that stopped, at once, when I had the Smoked Porter.  I suppose I was expecting something raw and barbaric.  The very word smoke connotes burning Nordic villages and masculine chop houses.  I think of the passion Prometheus had when he braved the Gods of olde and took their flame; I think of a thousand sieged castles, raging with a whisping cloud of opal black trailing towards the sky.  None of these, however, are present in Stones lighter, tamed Porter.  I suppose theres something in there that resembles the porter I dream of: the unctuously dark color, the dark fruits in the smell and taste, and the cackling cloud of hickory smoke.  But this is a mere simulacrum of what it should be.  I think its too weak, or that the beer is too far away from its tradition and roots.  A Stone fan desires strength and Hellish flames on their beer, not a paltry substitute!  No, this beer isnt up to Stones standards, I think.  Rather, it stultifies them.  How can any one brew master who puts berating comments on their bottles on the subject of Stones intensity settle for this?  The smoked porter is simply too far from what Stone settles for, and also far from what I expect and continue to expect from them.
On tap at Andys for Stone Promo Night.  Hippoportermous.  Makes you want to swing a tankard and get besotted.  I want to see this in my local likkkka store
Beautiful dark brown color.  Nice thick head.  Chocolate...malt....smoke and coffee.  Very good porter.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2008 bottle. Good black pour with ruby hues in the light. The once dense head fades away pretty fast. Interesting nose of toffee, coffee, faint cola, and a campfire. This wasnt as well rounded as I was hoping, given Stones reputation and my recent experience with the Alaskan smoked porter, but this is solid none-the-less. All the porter characterisitcs are there: solid caramel foundation and roasted coffee. The smoke comes into play heavily in the finish which accents the bitterer notes quite well. Its quite ashy, almost puckering, but doesnt quite go beyond what the sweet malty foundation can balance. Easy drinking beer without being trite, but isnt an intense experience like Im accustomed to Stone delivering.


[April 28, 2008]

2008 bottle at Taco Mac. There is a distinct smoked quality on this brew, but it comes across more like an ash tray or pure smoke than meat or smoked food. The palate was surprisingly thin. By thin, I mean for a porter and more so a porter from Stone. Nice chocolate and nutty flavors come through while dark roasted coffee and cigarettes make up a sharper edge on the brew. For me, the tasteful, but gritty, smokiness really saves this brew.


[May 8, 2008]

bomber. Pours a deep, dark red. Kind of near black, but it is visibly red even in medium light. The aroma has some caramel and dough with a hint of gumminess. A decent chocolate and smoked tobacco scent is also present. The mouth is decent, kind of thin for Stone, but certainly not problematic. I definitely enjoy the flavor more than the aroma. Almost none of that gummy thing is on my palate. Its just creamy coffee with hints of smoked meat. The finish is rough with ashtray qualities, but I actually like that.  Not bad. . .

22 oz bottle. Very dark brown with some red notes. Beige and lacing head. Aroma is a bit fruity, with chocolate and some weak smoked notes. Some espresso coffee bitterness, but mostly sweet with emphasis on chocolate. Semi-dry finish. Surprising light body. Easily drinkable and definitely enjoyable.

this is a good one!  and one i thought for sure i had rated.  how, do these little gems slip through the keyboard without being trascribed?  look to the left, thats pretty much how my bee looked except i was drinkn it out of a st bernardus glass.  rich nose of vanilla, smokiness, and earth.  a charred sensation whips around your mouth with a velvet liquid that cries burnt malt, choc, coffee, and wood laden charms.  good and nice.

Bottle.  Perfect deep brown and tan head pint looks.  Roast premium mocha coffee aroma.  Big sticky pinecone and roast flavor.  Nice, nice... nutty.  good citrus hop profile.  Just slightly beneath similar three floyds stuff.  Well rounded, Id be glad to drink this anytime.

Looks like a fine porter, dark dark red black, a bit more head wouldve been nice.  The aroma is subtle (and not just for a Stone beer!).  Mostly malt, but theres some lightly roasted coffee, cream, chocolate, honey, and maybe some raspberry.  The mouth feel is really very nice.  Rich for a porter, or even a stout,  the bubbles are small, but theres good creaminess (smoothest of the Stone beers Ive had!).  Theres definitely some smoke in the flavor (not too much like I was afraid), I wouldnt say its peaty, more like hardwood smoke flavor, but how much peat have I cooked over anyways?  Big sweet malt, coffee, chocolate.  Simple and robust, but extremely well done.  The roasty bitterness really lingers, in a very nice way.

Sweet malty aroma (almost smell honey roasted peanuts in there, or maybe just general nutty aroma).  The smokiness in the flavour is great, I also get chocolate, caramel and nutty flavours.  The sweetness in the aroma is absent from the taste- or very subtle.  Smooth and creamy.  I really enjoyed this beer.

Deep, dark, clear garnet, almost black if theres no light behind the glass.  Medium-thick, tan head that lasts nicely.  Chocolate and doughy aromas (almost like cookie-dough or chocolate cake).  Dark and roasted grain bitterness and astringency.  Just a hint of smoke, barely noticable.  Rich, chocolate and dark malt tastes predominate.  Medium-bodied (my only complaint is that it doesnt have a bigger body ... but that might make it a stout, eh?).

Delicious tasting beer nice dark color with tan head. Smell of chocolate and coffee with a bit of smokiness. Tastes great a smoky chocolat and coffee flavor. I love this beer, I love this brewery they make some really great tastimg beers.

Im 42 beers in and feeling it big time.  I know that Ive got to lay off sooner than later.  But a smoked porter from Stone is too much to resist.  It displays the flavor profiles from a great porter: cocoa and coffee, along with the enhancement of some smoke that lies in the underbelly of this brew.  Im a fan of Rauchbier, so I think this is awesome stuff.

650ml bottle
Pours pitch black with a small tan head.  Your nose is immediately blasted with chocolate, roasted coffee, and smoked malt.  The flavor is just excellent.  All the same elements dancing in harmony on your tongue.  One of the best porters Ive had.
Deep dark color with a tan head.  Light roast aroma.  Roast flavor comes through with a hint of smoked flavor.  Hop bitterness balanced nicely.  Easy beer to drink.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2010 Another excellent beer from Stone.  Looks like other porters, but that is where the similarities stop.  Chocolate flavor dominates the nose followed by roasted coffee, some floral hops, faint toffee, and a smoked meat hint.  Then the flavor is similar with the same components but richer without the meat tinge.  Roasted flavor really shows itself and the hop bitterness and smoke flavor takeover into the finish.  A perfectly balanced porter with the smoke adding the a nice compliment.  For someone who is a not a smoked beer fan, this was pretty good.

Bottle: Poured a medium-black color porter with a medium size foamy head with average retention. Aroma of slightly bitter hops with some very subtle smoke in there. Taste is also slightly bitter with a very subtle touch of smoke. I was honestly expecting a more smoky character because of the name of the beer. Also, I was expecting a hoppier porter based on previous tasting of Stone beers. A bit of letdown really.

Dark pour with a ruby red tinge and a medium roasted tan head.  Big, dark chocolatey aroma with a hint of pepperminty coffee.  Light, almost creamy texture with a lot of roasted malts and just a hint of smokiness.  Surprisingly thin and easy drinking. The smoky elements are most noticable on the final smack, which brings back horrible memories of Marlboro Lights.   Flavors are initially tasty, but not complex enough to warrant outstanding scores from me, and the finish is kind of killer.  There isnt much more than the commercial description reveals.

Feb. 25, 2006; 22 oz. "bomber."

The "commercial description" is dead on. Love the hops/bitterness in this one.  Full-bodied and well-balanced, as are all Stones brews.  Roasted flavor, with long-lasting notes of dark chocolate (prominent in the aroma as well) and strong coffee.  Probably the best porter Ive tried, and yet another top-flight offering from this amazing brewery.
A very nice porter from the boys at Stone. smokey malts dominate with hints of chocolate and coffee bean. very dark, like voldermort.
looks like a coca-cola, maybe a little darker, n head. strong roast/toffee aroma.  Nice smokeness in aftertaste, brew is also very smooth and enjoyable to drink.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 Almost black in color with just a little bit of light leaking through at the ends of the glass. Wonderful smokey aroma compliments a strong chocolatey smell. This is a phenomenal porter in its own right that is topped off with the addition of smoke. Absolutely fantastic compliment to the chocolate and coffee notes that dominate most porters. Highly recommended. I have to get more of this stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2006 This was a damn fine brew.  Shag and I had it the night before I went to visit my future grad school.  Cool beans!  Very dark pretty damn close to black, with a medium colored tan head.  This seemed more like a smoked stout if there is such a thing.  It had a nice coffee flavor, with some toffee, some sweetness, almost chocolatey flavor, with just enough smoke to make it interesting, but not enough to make it charcoaly or meaty.  Very very well done.

This beer is a great example of the style, my first porter in a while.  This is a style that I think gets neglected a lot because of its (strangely) more hyped cousin, stout.  With this guy, you get all the dark malts without as much of the bitter punch or dryness that comes with so many stouts.  The niche that porters fill is an important one, and a yummy one.

Just found my notes for tasting this from last years trip to dba in NY.  Pours dark and opaque with nice lacing, fruity full flavor, coffee and just a slight hint of smoke, very subtle, I wouldnt have minded a bit more (but then I love a good rauchbier).
a good, flavorful beer with a great sense of subtleness to its taste that blends well and is pretty smooth for even the moderate beer drinker. enjoy.
UPDATED: MAY 14, 2007 A nice and dark ale with a distinct, yet friendly smokiness.  Well balanced in coffee and chocolate flavor.  Overall, a very tasty brew.

Very dark amber brown ale with a long lasting medium high tan head that laces your glass sides as it recedes. Light smokey-caramel aroma. Medium body with a bitter chocolate and coffee flavor. Now that I have rated it, I will finish the rest of the bottle with some smoked yellow-tail tuna, my friend caught off of San Diego, should be appropriate with a Stone ale.

This is a good porter but there was no smoke at all; and that is with me expecting the smoke somewhere in the aroma or flavor.  As is, this is a good, but not great porter.  It is full bodied with a medium palate.  Mostly coffee flavored with some bitter dark chocolate.

Thanks to Secret Santa Dhlesq for this fine Cali brew.

Not at all what I expected, with the smoke being very light. Nice pour, well balanced, with a lot of bitter coffee and chocolate with the smoke on the finish. Great with as smoked gouda.

Pours a dark brown color with thin tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate and coffee with a little smokiness.  The flavor was very smokey with malts coffee, chocolate, and a hint of fruit.  Finished off with a slightly hoppy flavor.

Bomber. Pours a deep brown you can just barely see through when you hold your glass up to the light. Thick, medium brown head. Nose is a nutty coffee and chocolate, with very little smokiness. The taste - ahh, theres the smokiness! Not overwhelming, but it is pronounced, mingling in between the bitter chocolatey coffee flavors. A bit of charcoalish flavor, like when a steak is on the grill a bit too long. The body is lovely - satiny smooth and rich, but again, not overly so. What balance! Finish is just slightly bitter.  Yet another big winner from Stone!

Ive been sitting on this awhile, so I figured its hi-time to open it up and give er a try. I poured this out into my Spaten glass .5 liter glass and immediately was greeted with a HUGE head that looked like it belonged on a hot cup of cocoa. Aroma had definite chocolate notes, it had some coffee notes but not as smoky as I had assumed it would be. The smokiness was very toned down in the aroma. I could also detect hints of wet dirt or an earthiness to it. Mouthfeel was definitely full-bodied but it wasnt chewy at all. Flavor was very subtle as well, not the over-the-top smoky flavor I was expecting. This porter was very smooth and silky, having chocolate, coffee, smoke, peat and earthy tastes all throughout. Very well done indeed and a definite repeat buyer. I dont think Stone makes a product that isnt quaffable. Enjoy this with others.

Very dark but seems to have a reddish tint when held at certain angles of light. Choclatey and coffee tastes. Tastes great to start, but leaves an odd bitter taste on my tongue. Overall it was very good.

Dark and slightly translucent with a large root-beer type head.  Aroma is of malt and earthy/woody undertones.  Flavor is remarkably complex and interesting, but doesnt put too many eggs in any one basket.  At the starting gun, it is earth/peaty/malty which give way to just a touch of chocolate and then to a woody flavor.  All of this is very mild, but not underwhelming.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Black in color with aromas of wet charcoal and malt. Palate density is super full and flabby, akin to 60k mile motor oil. This extremely rich, bacon fat, specimen exhibits a steaky flavor along with the obvious sweet, malty smoke. "Wow" is all I can say. Take a well marbled porterhouse steak and throw it in a blender with a pound of brownsuger, and a few charcoal briquettes. Blend to puree and serve cold. You might need to buy a throat expander to get this one down. Stone does it again. Over the top. Not a ballanced brew but I really dont think they were going for that.

Pours dark with small tan head that leaves us quickly. Aroma is malts, smoke and coffee, along with a touch of sweetness. Flavor is smokey and with malt and roasted coffee. Mouth is medium bodied with a smooth creaminess to it. Definitly a good porter.

22 pz bottle.  Pours a very dark red, almost opaque.  Medium tan head.   Chocolate and coffee flavors with a smoky background just as advertised. It make this very unique.  Very smooth and slightly dry for a porter.   You can detect some hops.  Feels good on the tongue to the last drop.  A simply excellent Porter.

Nice dark pour with a smoke and malt aroma. Flavor was balanced with coffee, licorice, cherry,and a touch of chocolate. the porter finished long and dry with slight hints of bitter. Very good porter and is worth repeat visits.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2006 Looks black, but when held to the light, a deep ruby is revealed underneath a thick light tan head. Theres certainly a smoky quality in the aroma, but nothing like Schlenkerla which just knocks you over with smoke. Theres also some brown sugar and coffee that wafts up. The flavor is roasted and faintly smokey, and I detected some licorice and tobacco flavors as well. The body is medium/full and very smooth. The finish is dry, but I wouldnt call it bitter, at least not a hop bitter. Very easy to drink, nicely balanced with no one characteristic being dominant.

Pours a deep dark reddish brown, will show some color if held to the light. Thick tan head fades out to swirls of thin foam. Nose is smokey and malty. Flavor is rich and smokey with smooth malty sweetness, some subtle chocolate like bitterness in the finish. Damn good!

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2006 Draft/updated with 22 oz bottle - Pours black with a nice, long lasting head.  Enjoyable aroma of roast malt and hops.  Very mild smokiness in the roasted malt flavor.  The hops are noticeable, but frankly not as much as Id expect from a Stone brew.  My experience with some porters is that they taste a bit short on hops.  Stone gets it right in that sense.

Smoke seems to be just one of the several flavors that emerge from this porter rather than being the dominant characteristic. The aroma is almost all roasted malt with just a hint of smoke and sweet malt. Smokiness is apparent in the flavor, but it is wrapped with chocolate, cherry, coffee, licorice and bitter hops. The medium body is pleasant on the palate and the finish is long, dry and bitter. A very nice porter.

Bomber poured a clear dark brown with a small, diminishing amber head. Aromas of dark chocolate, molasses, and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied, smooth and dry. Flavor was smokey, bitter chocolate,and roasty with a smooth, lingeringsmokey finish.
Large head quickly dissipates. Burnt malt aroma.  Very deep burgundy that barely lets light through.  Very nice malty porter taste.  Not as smoky as a rauchbier. Long hop finish.

Very smooth for a smoked porter, drinks real easy. Initial big head that dissipitates. Understated smoke in aroma. Deep rich chocolate malt, roast flavour taste. Well malted and not overhopped. Satisfying medium to full mouthfeel. Good porter. On tap at Pizza Plant Transit.

"Poured a nice dark brown with a tan/smoky head. Burt coffe smell. Taste was mucht the same with a bitter burnt coffee. medium to thin mouthfeel. Overall not a bad beer, but wouldnt hunt down in the future."

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2006 Smoke comes through.  Heard they use the same smoked malt that they use in scotch.  Not much chocolate or coffee really come through for me.  Would have liked it to pour a bit more heavy as well.

Thick head but falls quickly. Malty, roasty nose with a hint of burnt coffee. Smokiness readily apparent but not overpowering at all. Moderate bitterness. Slightly sweet but somewhat balanced. Long, smoky/roasty finish with plenty of body. Very Stout-like due to prominent roast and bitterness.
Wheres the smoked?  Try alaskas smoked if you want smoked.  This one tastes more like it was aged and brewed with smoke.  Finishes of chocolate and coffee, smells of roasting barley.

Bottle, courtesy of Quintana. Black color with tan head. Aromas of dark malt, dark fruit, and faint stale cigar smoke. Flavor is mostly a nice dark porter, somewhat dry, but the smoke ends up tasting like, quoth Quintana, "the butt end of a cigar." Agreed. I just couldnt get into this one-- the smoke really seemed out of place and an unpleasant side-note to an otherwise fine porter. Ill have my smoke from the cigar and my porter from the beer, thank you. Oh well, it gets a 3 because I _believe_ in Stone....
Had this after christmas dinner, so I didnt get the full effect this time around. Nice smokey chocolaty aroma and flavor. A crisp kind of finish. Good porter.
Deep rich color with a large head.  Suprisingly sweet aftertaste for a porter with a smoky aroma, not so great for me personally.  Seems to taste better when not immediately pulled from the fridge.

Pours an inviting dark brown with a significant head. Surprisingly mellow smokiness with strong hints of dark chocolate. Finishes with a malty sweetness that becomes more pronounced as the beer warms.
mm mm mm mmm..  one tasty brew.  cant believe i hadnt had this till now.  the smokey quality really sets off the dark carbonation.
very good beer.  nice deep rich flavor finishes nicely.  complex and still very drinkable.  good beer by stone
22oz bottle. pours black with a very thin tan head. aroma is chocolate an oak/vanilla/smokey taste. has a very smooth chocolaty creamy mouthfeel. i love this beer.
Pours a nice dark brown with a tan head. Heavy aromas of chocolate . Flavor was of a smokey chocolate and  coffee.
very smoky chocolatey flavor.  smoke flavor lingers in your mouth a little while.
Bottled. Pours a dark brown, with a tan head. Aroma is dark roasted, smoked, chocolate. Taste is smoked, roasted, chocolate. Long roasted aftertaste.
Black body with reddish tint. Medium size, tan head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel and a good dose of smoke. The flavor is rich, smokey chocolates. Medium-bodied, medium length, dark chocolate finish.
Not a big fan of smoked porters but this one was pretty good.  Huge malt with gently smoky aftertaste.  Hardly any hops but plenty dark and malty.
Pours a nice dark brown with a tan head.  Heavy aromas of chocolate and tobacco.  Flavor of smokey chocolate and some coffee.  Big flavor on this beer.

I love smoked porters...and this is a good one. Great head out of the bottle...not a strong smell. Dark amber, almost black, color. You can definitely taste the roasted malt...but its not overpowering. 
Decent head still present after half way through the glass...I love it.

Amber color. Medium thickness. Nice coffee-colored head. Thin lace. Alcohol smell. Fruity tasting. Raising. Alcohol on the back end. Overall disappointing compared to other porters (Fullers London and Samuel Smiths Taddy, for example) that rate as highly on RateBeer.

Beautiful beer in many ways - appearance, smell, taste, feel (doesnt really have much of a sound).  Flavor is quite as strong as I expected (based on other Stone brews), but very rich and smooth nonetheless.
Strong smoky aroma with a thick head. Pours a dark brown copper color.  Can taste the chocolate and coffee. Smoke is a little overpowering for my taste.

Nice dark brown colour. Round and mild start with notes of roasted coffee. Mild flavour with hints of chocolate. Quite sweet finish. Aftertaste lacks the smoked notes one would expect to find in a smoked porter. Rather disappointing.
Bottle. Black colour with a small baige head. Roasted malty, chocolate aroma and a sweet roasted malty, chocolate taste. Medium body and a sweet finish. Not very smoked.

Brown beer with a light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with notes of chocolate and liqourice. Sweet malty, light roasted flavor with a balanced smokyness. Notes of dark chocolate and a light hoppy finish.

Bottled.
Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of chocolate, liquorice and dried fruits.
Flavour of chocolate and liquorice with notes of smoke.
Hoppy finish.

From Bottle

Aroma was smokey. Flavor was slightly hinted chocolate, and smokey burnt flavor. It had a good mouth feel, but for some reason I just didnt care for it. i ended up giving mine to a friend, who in turn gave it to another friend. I think the smokeyness was too overpowering.

nice dark porter

good mouth feel and flavor

not memorable, but satisfying
Thick tan head that lasts, dark black color beer. The smoked taste is very noticable. A very good porter overall.
A very nice Porter from Stone.   Tastes of a brown ale and porter are combined with caramel to make for a truely unique brew.  Highly enjoyable with food or as a stand-alone drink.

Bomber.  Rather clear mahogany pour with a tall, rocky, creamy caramel head.  Nice lacing followed the brew down.  Heavy roasted malt aroma with rich chocolate, caramel, coffee, and some subtle smoked peat.  Full and creamy mouthfeel with a dry coffee bitterness on the finish.  Flavors of caramel, chocolate, fresh coffee, and again a little smoke.  Very good balance, and just smooth all around.  Very much enjoyed this one!
Dark chocolate color creamy head. Coffee chocolate smokey roasted. I love porters and this is a good one.

Pours a black color with a creamy white-beige head.  Aroma is smokey with hints of coffee and malts.  Taste is predominantly smoke flavor with touches of light roasted coffee and lots of malt.  Good Porter.

Great flavor, a medium amount of smoke needed a tad more for my liking.  This could have been an early batch.  This had a great carmel flavor with no hops and an overall flavor great for a good pasta.  I likd the beer and liked the balance between malts, the yeast gave off a very dry flavor.

Bottle. Medium tan head that was mostly lasting, fine-small sized bubbles, sparse lacing, transparent, no visible carbonation, and a reddish brown hue. Aroma was malty, chocolate, roasty, amd sweet.  Malty, coffee, roasty, smokey, and chocolate flavor. Very tasty. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body. Worthy of a try.

"Smoke Beer Out"  Meaning a marathon of smoked beers in one evening.  October 14, Taster #4 of 6.  22z bottle.  Brownish-opaque.  Tan head with large bubbles.  Light roasted coffee notes.  Caramel, sugar, little if any smoke flavor.  Dark roasted coffee flavor, and very hop driven.  Tasty flavor, but the name is misleading...Then I read the commercial description!  Whoops!  I guess if I had this beer earlier, I might have liked it better.

Bottle.  Pours a deep ruby color that appears to swallow all light, a thin light tan head floats lightly on this beer.  Aromas of chocolate malt, roasted coffee beans, and a bit of BBQ smoke.  Flavors of chocolate and coffee with a bit of a light hop after taste.  Some smoke flavor but its not really pronounced.
Bottle @ Stockholm Beer Festival 2005Dark dark red with a big head. Milk chocolate, hoppy, and maybe a touch of smoke, but not much. Very dry chocolate tinted aftertaste. Smooth.

In the bomber bottle. Pours a very dark brown-almost black with a dark brown head. Aroma is mostly roasted, but there is a mild smoke aroma. As this warms, it mostly smells roasted. Body is rich and strong. Great maltiness absorbs most of the smoke. Good bitterness to the finish. This is almost a big beer, but not quite. Surprising smoothness from something that could have been rather harsh. How odd that Stones most mainstream beer might be a smoked-porter. And remember thats a relative statement.

Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, some smoked meat.  Appears red-brown in color with a small brown head that dissipates immediately.  Flavor is sweet malt giving way to assertive peat smoke, and finishing with a nice roasty tang.  Palate is medium-light, with moderate to light effervescence.  Overall, this beer is somewhat greater than the sum of its parts.
A great porter but not amazing like I hoped.  Not overwhelmingly smoky.  Very well blended components, coffee, smoke, etc.

Tasted during trip to california. 65 cl bottle. Black colour with a nice rocky head. Very delecious aroma of coffe. Great taste of roasted malt and coffee hints of smokeness and dark chocolate, very tasteful. Ends up very much bitter and dry. Overall a great beer.

Bottled. Almost black with red edges. Rich light brown head. Loads of roasted coffee and chocolate in flavour with subtle tones of smoke and pepper. Black chocolate, cocoa and mocha in flavour with a bitter finish of black coffee. Mocha with a very subtle tone of smoke in long aftertaste.

Bottle. Dark black with tan head. Lovely nose of sweet malt, but where is the smoke? Flavor is very well balanced and dominated by chocolate with some caramel evolving to a bitter, lightly roasted, finish - but where is the smoke?. Light mouth feel, and high carbonation. This is a very good and balanced beer, Im not sure why this qualifies as being smoke... The smokiness is too subtle for me - which explains the low overall score - when something is labeled as smoked, I expect to be able to detect it.

not sure if i would taste the smoke flavor in this beer if it wasnt called stone smoked porter.....but since it is i can taste it a little throught the power of suggestion.....smoke aside this is a good porter not quite as roasty(whatever i mean by that) as i like......i didnt get any of coffee, but this beer has a great chocolate flavor........shibby
i love this beer. another great beer from stone. a couple 22s and you will be saying hello to your pillow.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2005 22 oz bomber.  This pours a great dark brown, with a thin white head  just the way a great beer should.  Nice smoky aroma.  The taste is all porter with just enough smoke that does not over power the beer, but fits in nicely.  Medium bodied and not over carbonated, just simply an excellent beer.

Aroma is so smokey, rich... barbeque, soft cheese... man you can just keep going. Totally awesome. If this flavor was as good as the aroma this beer would be a perfect 5... unfortunately, it doesnt shine quite as much. Still get some of that coffee, smokyness, cheese in the flavor, though the palate is definitely too watery... nice hops in the flavor, too... well balanced, but doesnt quite reach the heights it should.

Bottle from my Secret Santa.  I had planned on sharing this one, but nearly everyone I know has already had this one.  So, I popped the cap on this bomber and poured it into my glass.  The aroma has lots of chocolate and a light peat.  Unfortunately, by lots, its still pretty weak and is disappointing.  The appearance is an extremely dark red (you can catch a glimpse of light through it).  A thin beige head sits atop it.  The flavor starts with a lots of coffee flavors, mellows into some darker chocolate flavors, and finishes with a peat smoked malt.  The palate is medium bodied and mediocre.  I had high hopes for this beer but feel let down.  Its not as smoky as I had hoped.  Definitely a standard porter, not a good smoked porter.  I like my smoked beers to be strongly smoked and taste like strong smoked malts and meats.  This is the first Stone brew that fell very short.
Typical Stone beer and that is by no means a derogatory statement.  Anotther impressive beer by the great Stone Brewery!
Had a bomber of this for the first time last night. Good stuff. Pours out dark with a good tan head. Tastes of dark coffee and bakers chocolate. I liked the smokyness of this beer a great deal.

This is the first beer that my dog wouldn’t even drink... SERIOUSLY.  Some people may give this beer a free pass since it comes from the well-renowned Stone name, but this frankly was undrinkable.  The flavor encroached on burnt Folgers’ crystals steeped in tap water.  Very bitter, but not in any remotely pleasing way.  The aftertaste is what truly got me, however. This is where the "smoked" comes in -- only it is like stale cigarettes.  Seriously, it’s like a tea of burnt coffee and cigarettes.  And with each sip, I felt as if the beer was separating into two layers: something trying to pass as a beer and some ultra watery, smoky mess that was poured into it - like some poorly mixed oil and vinegar salad dressing.  A total drain pour after attempting to stomach half of the bottle.

I was served this in a 22 ounce bottle at the Beer Sellar in Covington,KY. Pours out a dark black color but with an amber-red tint, held into the light. smokey, roasty aroma, with a very small hint of coffee. It has a smokey, but not overpowering taste. Full-bodied and an average texture. Flat carbonation, with an lively finish.  I loved this porter. The best porter Ive had yet. Two thumbs up.
Beautiful dark reddish coffee color.  Tan small head.  Smokey chocolate burnt bitter with some coffee mixed in.  It is a lighter than I expected for a porter.

Bottle.  Pours a wonderful onyx with a nice tan head.  Aroma is smoke with a dash of coffee.  Flavor is  a wonderfully light blend of  smoke and roasted malt-- until the aftertaste kicks in.  Who put melted pennies in the brew kettle???  Its been 10 minutes since I poured it, and the copper taste seems to have subsided.  Not a bad beer-- just let it warm to about 55 degrees before drinking.  Id drink it again.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Sampled from bottle. An inviting, clear pour that is blackened-ruby in color with a frothy tan head and sheets of lacing. Some mild smoke in the aroma (think peat/whiskey barrel not rauch/smoked bacon) as well as citrus hops. Bitter flavor has the same mild smoke profile as the flavor (peat) as well as stong roasted malts (mocha coffee), caramel, spicey/citrus hops and fresh, dark fruits. Full-bodied, but not heavy, moderately carbonated and very drinkable. TOO subtle in the smokiness category.

I dont know why it took me so long to drink this Stone offering.  Now I do.  Kind of lackluster for Stone.  Not much of an aroma; typical chocolate, coffee, and smoke, but not strong.  Color is very dark brown with minimal tan head.  Flavor is good; coffee and smoked malt, but not as big as I wanted.  There is also a noticeable lack of hops.  I agree with Cornfield, this is a stout more than anything else.

Doth a gift beer not taste finer than any other? Perhaps not, but this qualifies. Deep and dark and full and flavorful. Smoke seemed subdued (or maybe my tongue was half asleep) but it was JUST RIGHT for me. Excellent balance. When you check five times to see if the last drip is drained from the bomber, you know it was an appreciated beer.

bomber brought back from the Liquor Stop bty my son.  deep, dark brown on the pour with a reddish edge.  creamy tan head fades to a ring of lace.  aroma of coffee, bittersweet chocolate and peat.  flavors are of some bitter coffee & chocolate.  throughout the entire spectrum of aromas & flavors there is an underlying note of smoke.  not overdone but just lingering in the background.  Well done.

Bottle from Premier Gourmet - thanks to rudolf. Dark brown colour with ruby tints and a moderate tan head. Wonderfully balanced aroma of roasted malt, coffee and subtle peaty smoke. The flavour is similarly well-balanced, with the smokiness working nicely alongside the roast and chocolate without becoming overpowering. Finish is moderately bitter, with a hint of the smoke lingering along with some well-integrated hops. An extremely well-crafted and enjoyable beer.

Dark brown pour with a tan head.  Bitter aroma with a hint of chocolate.  Smooth taste with hint of malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Pleasant aftertaste that tastes a bit like coffee.  Overall excellent.

Great dark brown color with a thick tan head and outstanding lace.

Aroma of dark malt and chocolate with a very pleasant taste of malt, chocolate and coffee that leaves the palate with a slight hop bitterness.

Overall a very pleasant Porter.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with very little brown head. Almost an oily pour, though not as thick as some beers. Smells of chocolate and smoke with hints of dark sweet fruits. Tastes of chocolate, roasted coffee, smoke.  Sweet start with a mildly bitter finish. This is definately one of my favorites.

Pours a very dark amber with an average sized tan head that laced the glass nicely.  Aroma of smoke and some darker chocolate.  Flavor is smoke up front with some bitterness at the end.  Want to try this one with some smoked ribs.

The description has a rather pretentious statement by Greg Koch: Unlike a rauchbier, the "smoke" in Stone Smoked Porter is an ELEMENT of the character rather than being THE character.  The smoke is always just an element, even in the hardiest rauchbier.  Why not just call this a stout and cut the BS?It is indeed quite a good brew, dark brown with a weak tan head.  The nose is roasted barley, dark, sweet chocolate, and a light hint of smoke.  The bodys kind of rough, nice in a dry stout.  The flavor is roasted barley and barley malt, just a dollop of chocolate, coffee grounds, and a whisking of smoke.  The finish is a dry coffee taste.  Very nice.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Stop, Highland, IN<font size=-1>

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2005 Pitch black with a dark brown head. Smokey, earthy, chocolate, some slight coffee, and some roasted nuttiness. The smoked flavor wasnt as prominant as I anticipated which was very nice. Malty body, good chocolate taste, coffee, light smoke. A little dry in the finish. Finish is a little watery. Flavors are too subtle

Nearly black appearance with a foamy tan head.  The nose has a little bit of smoke and roast with a touch of chocolate.  The body was not as smoky as anticipated with a huge hop bite giving to mintiness.  Very West Coast in its hoppiness, typically big and bitter.
This one is a little too bitter for me and otherwise low on flavor.  The body is also a little thin and fleeting.  This beer just generally doesnt stand out or impress me.

Tasted in Keystone, CO, USofA.  This is my third beer on my 2005 Colorado adventure.  Tomorrow we head to Brekenridge for a big time beer day hahahahahahahahaahahahaha!!!!& love altitude.  Anyhow, let us begin with the rating.  As I write this, I am watching rain fall on my chalet balcony, whilst the fog and dew rolls in off the A-Basin.  Lovely.  Pours a deep dark stout like colour, fairly aggressive head very white colour.   Quite nice.  Aroma has elements of fruitiness and is very light for a stout.  Little or no hints of coffee or chocolate in the aroma but some very faint hints of nuts.  Flavour is subtle, fairly roasty, a little smoky and still persistent fruitiness.  De-lovely.
Very dark. One of my favorite beers. Always a cold one in the fridge. The smoke aroma and taste is what does it. Very easy to drink.

Pours a dark brown with amber edges with a thin, tan head. A little bit thinner than I would like. I can taste the smoke, and there is roast and some bitter hops. A good, solid porter, but less aggressive than I expect from Stone. Ben, with whom I shared the bottle, says: "This is something I could drink a lot of."

Bottle.  Beautiful dark dark color.  Head that lasted forever and left great lacing throughout the glass.  Aromas of chocolate and more malt.  Flavors were definitley smokey, with a slight hoppy and slight dusty finish.

22-oz bottle.  Pours black with brown hints and a medium frothy tan head; lined lacing.  Smoked dark roasted malt aroma, some chocolate notes, but not much going on here.  Heavy bitter start with smoked dark roasted malt and chocolate with an acidic light finish.  Full bodied and dark fizzy palate.

Black with ruby hues in color. Pours a tan wispy head, most receding, but leaves a thin layer of protection.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste has a sweet front which melts into malt, with roasty finish. Finish is moderately sweet and highly bitter.  Mouthfeel is creamy and rich.  The taste really gets more smokey as the beer warms, it was  much more subdued at cellar temp.
This beer is above and beyond one of the all time best dark beers that you can have whenever and whatever still you prefer

Pours dark brown with small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and faint amount of smoke.  Flavors of the same, and the smoke doesnt become apparent until the finish.  Hop bitterness slightly above average and palate a little to thin for style.  But, definitely a good beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours an extremely blackish brown with a tan-white head.  Aroma is coffee and roasted barkey with a little smoke.  The mouthfeel is near the best for a porter Ive ever had.  The roastiness starts and lingers with a smooth, subtle smoke finish.  This certainly among the best smoked beers Ive had, probably because the smoke flavor is used judiciously and with a great beer to begin with.

Had aromas of burnt wood, roasted barley and a hint of chocolate. Dark body with tan head. Flavor was well balanced with malt covering up the alcohol for a roasty flavor. Left an aftertaste like if you had an unlit cigar in your mouth for awhile. Real good beer.

On tap at The Moan and Dove. Pours a dark brown color with a small light brown head. Very appealing aroma of smoked and roasted malt with chocolate. Very good flavor of roasted and smoked malt, chocolate and black liquorice. The palate is medium and dry with moderate carbonation.

Bottle: Motor oil brown with scant beige head. Semi-sweet chocolate, roasty, earthy, port, very mild smoke, need to focus to pick it up. Again the semi-sweet chocolate up front with a tangy bite in the middle (could be the peat/smoke) sweet follow with a tart-bitter aftertaste.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, tupalev & jerc. Pours ruby-black with a long lasting light brown head. Fantastic aroma and flavour of smoke, coffee, chocolate, cereal, roasted malts and a nice amount of hops. The smoke is nicely balanced and subtle which is how I like it. Palate is bitter, full-bodied and long lasting. A great porter, Stone delivers the goods once again.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2009 2009-12-05.  Black body, creamy tan head and lace. 3+ Aroma is mild, light smoky roast malt. Flavour is similar, light smoky roast is even less than the bottle, which I like. Pleasant base malt. Smooth average palate is pleasant. Enjoyable. 7/3+/7+/3/15 - 3.5 Cask at Coles, Buffalo
2005. Ruby black body, good sized khaki head. Mild roasty malt aroma. Smoke is pleasantly restrained over the malt in both the aroma and flavour.
